title: Imran Khan’s hypocrisy betrays Pakistan’s voters
text:
Imran Khan, the former cricketer and professional playboy turned prime minister of Pakistan, is a staggering hypocrite. Khan, who spent his youth in Britain partying in the company of glamorous and often scantily clad women, now blames the way women dress for a rise in rape cases across Pakistan. Khan’s ridiculous advice to women is to cover up to prevent men being tempted, along the lines of the Islamic concept of purdah or modesty, which often involves segregation of the sexes.

Khan’s views, seemingly devoid of any self-awareness, range far and wide in their ignorance. Sexual violence is apparently the fault of societies “where vulgarity is on the rise”, by which he means places like Britain; Hollywood and Indian cinema’s obsession with “increasing obscenity”
summary:
Imran Khan, the former cricketer and professional playboy turned prime minister of Pakistan, is a staggering hypocrite.
Khan, who spent his youth in Britain partying in the company of glamorous and often scantily clad women, now blames the way women dress for a rise in rape cases across Pakistan.
Khan’s ridiculous advice to women is to cover up to prevent men being tempted, along the lines of the Islamic concept of purdah or modesty, which often involves segregation of the sexes.
Khan’s views, seemingly devoid of any self-awareness, range far and wide in their ignorance.
Sexual violence is apparently the fault of societies “where vulgarity is on the rise”, by which he means places like Britain; Hollywood and Indian cinema’s obsession with “increasing obscenity”

title: Rajinder Kalia: Baba Balak Nath Temple cut off over rape allegations
text:
The organisation representing British Hindus suspended links with a temple at the centre of High Court claims that a guru raped four women and that an undetected cult was operating.

The Hindu Council said that following an emergency meeting yesterday it had suspended the Baba Balak Nath temple in Coventry as an affiliate with “immediate effect” over allegations that Rajinder Kalia, 65, groomed followers into believing that he was God on Earth.

Sponsored

summary:

title: Brenda Power: Blaming male cruelty on women makes me snap
text:
Eight years ago, Cork farmer Martin McCarthy brutally murdered his little daughter in order to spite her mother and then, rather than face the consequences, drowned himself too. And yet there were some people in Ballydehob who took McCarthy’s side, according to his widow, and blamed her for his wicked deed.

The only reason we can name the drowned child, Clarissa, is because McCarthy was too much of a coward to stand trial for her murder and so, as no charges were brought, no crime was recorded and the prohibition on naming child crime victims doesn’t apply. This technical absurdity is matched by the obtuse absurdity of those locals’ sympathy for the killer, and disdain for his bullied and ultimately devastated wife. They don’t believe

title: Condemn Roth’s biographer Blake Bailey, but let us buy his book
text:
When Claire Bloom published her memoir, Leaving the Doll’s House, I was shocked because her life with Philip Roth had appeared so glamorous. He was the world’s greatest “living” novelist, although inwardly seething at his lack of a Nobel prize. She was the brilliant actress who had starred at 20 with Charlie Chaplin in Limelight and was known to my generation as Lady Marchmain in Brideshead Revisited.

Roth emerged as a vengeful, controlling, unfaithful husband who had thrown Bloom’s 18-year-old daughter out of the house because she “bored” him and demanded $62 billion, a billion for every year of Bloom’s life, for her refusal to honour a prenuptial agreement that would have left her with nothing. He was so furious at the torching
summary:
When Claire Bloom published her memoir, Leaving the Doll’s House, I was shocked because her life with Philip Roth had appeared so glamorous.
He was the world’s greatest “living” novelist, although inwardly seething at his lack of a Nobel prize.
She was the brilliant actress who had starred at 20 with Charlie Chaplin in Limelight and was known to my generation as Lady Marchmain in Brideshead Revisited.
Roth emerged as a vengeful, controlling, unfaithful husband who had thrown Bloom’s 18-year-old daughter out of the house because she “bored” him and demanded $62 billion, a billion for every year of Bloom’s life, for her refusal to honour a prenuptial agreement that would have left her with nothing.
He was so furious at the torching

title: Coronavirus in Scotland: Reported rapes fell by a fifth during lockdown, police reveal
text:
Police Scotland warned that a reduction in reporting does not mean less offending as all forms of sexual crime continue to be under-reported

Reports of rape when the country was in lockdown dropped just over a fifth on the same period as last year, according to Police Scotland.

Between the start of lockdown on March 24 and July 5, just before Scotland entered phase three of the route map, 529 rapes were recorded — representing a 20.2 per cent reduction compared with 2019, Police Scotland said.

Sponsored

The force said that reports increased again as lockdown eased but the figures remained lower than in 2019. Between March 24 and November 15, the number of both recent and non-recent offences reported was down 6.5 per cent — 1,427 compared with 1,526 for the same period in 2019.

A recent offence is one within a year of the crime occurring —
summary:
Police Scotland warned that a reduction in reporting does not mean less offending as all forms of sexual crime continue to be under-reportedReports of rape when the country was in lockdown dropped just over a fifth on the same period as last year, according to Police Scotland.
Between the start of lockdown on March 24 and July 5, just before Scotland entered phase three of the route map, 529 rapes were recorded — representing a 20.2 per cent reduction compared with 2019, Police Scotland said.

title: Man found guilty of sexual assault on asylum seeker
text:
The jury at the Central Criminal Court in Dublin convicted the man of sexual assault but was deadlocked on further charges of rape

A 54-year-old man has been convicted of sexually assaulting a woman who had come to Ireland seeking asylum.

The man, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had pleaded not guilty to three counts of rape, one of sexual assault and one of attempted rape of the woman at his Dublin home over the weekend of December 1-3, 2017.

Sponsored

The jury told Mr Justice Alex Owens, after eight and half hours of deliberation at the Central Criminal Court in Dublin, that they could reach a majority verdict on one count but they were deadlocked in relation to the other four.

Mr Justice Owens remanded the man in custody and revoked his bail before he adjourned sentencing to July 12.

title: Lay off private schools, Gavin. There’s bad behaviour in comprehensives too
text:
A not hugely bright schoolmate of mine, aged 15, carved his girlfriend’s name — Julie — onto his arm with a razor blade and some Quink ink but was so distressed by her subsequent behaviour — she had been “slaggin’ around”, as he put it — that he decided to hang himself rather than have the tattoo removed. This act he attempted to achieve by fixing his school tie in a noose around his neck, holding it aloft with one hand and then jumping off a lavatory seat. He was deeply surprised and disappointed to find himself still possessed of the breath of life when he landed, tie still in hand. I don’t know what he’s doing now. Probably an aide to Gavin Williamson, the

title: Anger after rape prosecutions fall by 30%
text:
Campaigners claimed that the 1,439 convictions obtained last year were the lowest number ever for a 12-month period

Rape prosecutions have dropped by more than 30 per cent over the past 12 months, resulting in the lowest number of convictions for at least five years.

The revelation caused anger among women’s rights campaigners, who accused Max Hill, QC, the director of public prosecutions, of overseeing the effective “decriminalisation of rape”.

Sponsored

Mr Hill will face further pressure after the Court of Appeal gave campaigners the go-ahead to challenge what they say is a change of Crown Prosecution Service policy that raised the evidence bar required to bring cases to court. Yesterday officials at the CPS revealed that 2,102 rape allegations were prosecuted over the past 12 months compared with 3,034 in 2018-19 — a fall of nearly 31 per cent.

title: Rape and murder among 2.2 million unsolved cases closed by police
text:
Screening out crimes — where police mark a case as requiring ‘no further action’ — has increased rapidly

Nearly 2.2 million crime cases, including murders and rapes, were closed by police last year without being solved.

Police in England and Wales abandoned investigations into more than 300,000 burglaries in 2019, with a third of forces closing at least 80% of cases before they were solved, according to official figures from the Home Office.

Sponsored

West Midlands police had the worst record on burglaries, with 22,166 cases closed without a suspect being identified, 89% of the total number recorded. Only 1,166 resulted in a suspect being charged. In Surrey and Cambridgeshire no suspect was identified in 85% of burglaries last year.

Two forces — South Yorkshire and Lincolnshire police — abandoned murder investigations before a suspect could be identified.

The Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran
summary:
Screening out crimes — where police mark a case as requiring ‘no further action’ — has increased rapidlyNearly 2.2 million crime cases, including murders and rapes, were closed by police last year without being solved.
Police in England and Wales abandoned investigations into more than 300,000 burglaries in 2019, with a third of forces closing at least 80% of cases before they were solved, according to official figures from the Home Office.
SponsoredWest Midlands police had the worst record on burglaries, with 22,166 cases closed without a suspect being identified, 89% of the total number recorded.
In Surrey and Cambridgeshire no suspect was identified in 85% of burglaries last year.
Two forces — South Yorkshire and Lincolnshire police — abandoned murder investigations before a suspect could be identified.

title: Guardian apologises to rape victim for Roy Greenslade piece
text:
Roy Greenslade did not disclose his links to republicanism

The editor of The Guardian has personally apologised to a woman whose account of being raped by an IRA member was questioned by the journalist Roy Greenslade.

Greenslade, 74, the paper’s former media columnist, raised doubts about Máiría Cahill’s testimony on the grounds of her “anti-Sinn Fein agenda” in a 2014 article, without disclosing his own ties to Irish republicanism.

Sponsored

The former Fleet Street editor’s sympathies have been widely known for more than a decade, but he caused outrage this week by confessing his support for violent IRA terrorism.

The left-leaning newspaper has now ruled that Greenslade broke its editorial standards by failing to be transparent with readers about his political views.

A lengthy note has been added to the bottom of the online version
summary:
Roy Greenslade did not disclose his links to republicanismThe editor of The Guardian has personally apologised to a woman whose account of being raped by an IRA member was questioned by the journalist Roy Greenslade.
Greenslade, 74, the paper’s former media columnist, raised doubts about Máiría Cahill’s testimony on the grounds of her “anti-Sinn Fein agenda” in a 2014 article, without disclosing his own ties to Irish republicanism.
SponsoredThe former Fleet Street editor’s sympathies have been widely known for more than a decade, but he caused outrage this week by confessing his support for violent IRA terrorism.

title: Harassment on campus: female graduates speak out
text:
Sexual harassment at university shaped my student life. No wonder Everyone’s Invited, the movement that has been exposing rape culture in schools, is now shining a spotlight on universities. From the first year of my undergraduate degree, I was forced to consider how I chose to spend my evenings and when I could go out safely.

One evening during my second year I was groped at a fraternity party in a local club. The group that organised the evening did not evict the man who groped me, and I was forced to leave. On a separate occasion on a university sports night, boys in our social group took turns slapping girls’ bottoms. When we protested, we were told it was just a “joke”. Some of
summary:
Sexual harassment at university shaped my student life.
No wonder Everyone’s Invited, the movement that has been exposing rape culture in schools, is now shining a spotlight on universities.
One evening during my second year I was groped at a fraternity party in a local club.
The group that organised the evening did not evict the man who groped me, and I was forced to leave.
On a separate occasion on a university sports night, boys in our social group took turns slapping girls’ bottoms.

title: We fell for Isis propaganda, say foreign wives stranded in Syria
text:
Huda Muthana, a Yemeni who grew up in the US, was an outspoken advocate of the jihadist cause but now says she regrets her choices

The six women sit, nodding along to a Spanish pop video showing dancers in skintight clothing. Their earrings, hairstyles and fashionable shoes contrast with the sea of abayas all around. This is not the usual image of Islamic State’s “foreign wives”.

Among them is Shamima Begum, now 21, who travelled from Bethnal Green, London, at the age of 15 to join the Isis cause in Syria, and who has since been stripped of her British nationality and refused permission to return.

Sponsored

Her plight, first reported by The Times two years ago, has come to symbolise the refusal of most western governments to allow the wives of Isis fighters, now mostly dead or missing, to return home.

Huda Muthana in more traditional attire last year

Begum abandoned her face veil a year
summary:

title: Norbert Feher: Spain jails ‘Man with a Thousand Faces’ for triple murder
text:
A notorious multiple murderer nicknamed “Igor the Russian” was sentenced to life in prison today for killing two policemen and a farmer in a case that has gripped Spain.

Norbert Feher, 40, a Serbian criminal who also earned himself the nickname of “The Man with a Thousand Faces” due to his ability to elude justice by disguising himself, had fled to Spain after escaping from custody in Italy, where he was convicted of killing two people.

Sponsored

The court in Teruel, in Aragon , northeast Spain, heard that on December 14, 2017 he shot dead the cattle farmer on whose property he had taken refuge. He then shot the two police officers, firing with a gun in each hand, when they surprised him at the scene.
summary:
A notorious multiple murderer nicknamed “Igor the Russian” was sentenced to life in prison today for killing two policemen and a farmer in a case that has gripped Spain.
Norbert Feher, 40, a Serbian criminal who also earned himself the nickname of “The Man with a Thousand Faces” due to his ability to elude justice by disguising himself, had fled to Spain after escaping from custody in Italy, where he was convicted of killing two people.
SponsoredThe court in Teruel, in Aragon , northeast Spain, heard that on December 14, 2017 he shot dead the cattle farmer on whose property he had taken refuge.
He then shot the two police officers, firing with a gun in each hand, when they surprised him at the scene.

title: The books that made us cry, from A Little Life to Never Let Me Go
text:
TikTok, the video sharing app that is quickly becoming the social media of choice for those under 25, is most often credited with popularising dance moves and music styles such as K-pop or, bizarrely, sea shanties. But books, too, can go viral on TikTok, it turns out. “BookTok” is apparently a thing (although we’re far too old and uncool to know much about it) and the key to BookTok fame is to film yourself crying over a book. So, in a probably ill-fated attempt to be down with the kids, here are some of our favourite tear-jerking books.

This Booker-shortlisted tale of four college friends is a literary soap opera. Car crashes, spousal abuse, sickness, child abuse... you name it, the characters endure it as

title: Coronavirus in Ireland: Calls to rape crisis centres soared in lockdown
text:
The length of time spent on calls to crisis centres has also increased

The number of people who sought help from rape crisis centres after an assault jumped by 98 per cent during the first four months of the Covid-19 outbreak.

Data from the Rape Crisis Network Ireland (RCNI) showed a huge increase in the numbers contacting centres compared with the period between March and June last year.

Sponsored

There was also an 83 per cent increase in the length of time spent on calls to Rape Crisis Centre (RCC) helplines.

The number of calls rose by about 23 per cent during the three months of coronavirus lockdown measures, with the largest increase being in March — 63 per cent.

The RCNI said the data, taken from six Rape Crisis Centres, showed that they had to rapidly adapt. A

Data from the Rape Crisis Network Ireland (RCNI) showed a huge increase in the numbers contacting centres compared with the period between March and June last year.

The number of calls rose by about 23 per cent during the three months of coronavirus lockdown measures, with the largest increase being in March — 63 per cent.
The RCNI said the data, taken from six Rape Crisis Centres, showed that they had to rapidly adapt.

title: DNA breakthrough snares rapist Graham McGill who killed stranger in 1984
text:
Graham McGill, 59, had got away with killing Mary McLaughlin for decades

A sexual predator who killed a mother of 11 while on release from prison has been convicted of murder 36 years later after a DNA breakthrough.

Graham McGill, a 22-year-old convicted rapist, was on release from HMP Edinburgh in September 1984 when he met Mary McLaughlin in a pub and strangled her at her home in Partick, Glasgow.

Sponsored

McLaughlin, 58, had enjoyed a night out drinking and playing dominoes at different bars and was last seen leaving for a chip shop six days before her body was found. She had been throttled with a dressing gown cord, the High Court in Glasgow was told, but the case went unsolved despite dozens of lines of inquiry.

title: Victorious Angels ‘raped’ by model agency boss Gérald Marie take on archaic French legal system
text:
The model Carré Otis has criticised the “archaic” French legal system that “protects perpetrators”, after she accused a former boss of one of the world’s top modelling agencies of raping her as a teenager.

Otis, 52, and 11 others filed testimonies last year to the Paris prosecutor claiming that they were sexually assaulted by Gérald Marie, the former European head of Elite. She has co-founded a group, Victorious Angels, to support those who have been sexually abused in modelling, which has led to more women coming forward.

Sponsored

Four British women are among those to make accusations against Marie, 71, ex-husband of the model Linda Evangelista, 55. He categorically denies the claims, and there is no suggestion that Evangelista knew about the allegations.

title: Fraternity at centre of St Andrews rape claims told to fight back
text:
A number of members of the St Andrews branch of Alpha Epsilon Pi have been suspended while investigations continue

Members of a controversial fraternity at the centre of campus rape allegations should fight back to stop it being removed from universities, its international leader has claimed.

Last month dozens of first-hand accounts of alleged sexual assault and harassment were posted online by a group called St Andrews Survivors.

Sponsored

Many of the claims revolve around a chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi at the alma mater of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. AEPi is an all-male Jewish society founded in New York in 1913.

The fraternity is investigating the St Andrews branch, suspending a number of members and insisting that anyone found guilty of wrongdoing will be expelled.

title: Roth biography pulped after author Blake Bailey is accused of sex assaults
text:
The publishers of a new biography of the novelist Philip Roth are to take it out of print over allegations against its author less than a month after release.

WW Norton said it would halt shipments of the book by Blake Bailey, 57, after the biographer was accused of sexually assaulting a number of women and behaving inappropriately towards 13 and 14-year-olds when he was an English teacher. A 2014 book will also be pulped by the publisher.

Sponsored

The decision by WW Norton comes amid a bitter row in the US over so-called “cancel culture”, where those with views that do not sit comfortably with the mainstream say they are being prevented from speaking at events or having articles and books published.

WW NORTON/AP

Roth, widely regarded
summary:
The publishers of a new biography of the novelist Philip Roth are to take it out of print over allegations against its author less than a month after release.
WW Norton said it would halt shipments of the book by Blake Bailey, 57, after the biographer was accused of sexually assaulting a number of women and behaving inappropriately towards 13 and 14-year-olds when he was an English teacher.
A 2014 book will also be pulped by the publisher.

title: Polly Vernon on why being sexually assaulted won’t define her life
text:
When I was 18 years old, nearly three decades ago, while at home in Devon on Easter break from my first year of a French degree at Sussex University, I went to meet an old mate from sixth-form college for an afternoon drink in a pub. This pub was – presumably, still is – located halfway up a canal on the outskirts of Exeter. My mood was off. Visiting home from your first year of college is a discombobulating business, pushed and pulled as you are between the faintly terrifying adult identity you’re forming at college and the comforting younger version of yourself you’ve left behind. Also my first university boyfriend had cruelly dumped me a week earlier; I was, in that moment, straightforwardly heartbroken.

Sponsored
summary:
When I was 18 years old, nearly three decades ago, while at home in Devon on Easter break from my first year of a French degree at Sussex University, I went to meet an old mate from sixth-form college for an afternoon drink in a pub.
This pub was – presumably, still is – located halfway up a canal on the outskirts of Exeter.
My mood was off.
Visiting home from your first year of college is a discombobulating business, pushed and pulled as you are between the faintly terrifying adult identity you’re forming at college and the comforting younger version of yourself you’ve left behind.
Also my first university boyfriend had cruelly dumped me a week earlier; I was, in that moment, straightforwardly heartbroken.

title: Felicia Sonmez: Washington Post reporter wins right to cover sex assault stories
text:
The Washington Post has revoked its controversial policy banning a sexual assault survivor from covering news stories involving sexual misconduct.

Felicia Sonmez, a politics reporter, went public last week to criticise of her employer’s approach. It was introduced in 2018 and related to the paper’s coverage of the nomination hearings for the Supreme Court justice Brett Kavanaugh, who was accused of sexual assault.

Sponsored

Earlier claims by Sonmez that a reporter from another newspaper had sexually assaulted her persuaded her editors that a potential conflict of interest existed that should prevent her from reporting on such matters. On Friday Sonmez tweeted that tensions stemming from the disagreement with her editors over her remit had left her unable to work and “led to a recurrence of the
summary:
The Washington Post has revoked its controversial policy banning a sexual assault survivor from covering news stories involving sexual misconduct.

title: What I went through as a pupil at Westminster School
text:
As I entered my final interview for Westminster School I was buzzing with hope. It was 2008, my interviews had gone well and I had only the head master to meet. While sitting with him and talking about my plans, it occurred to me that this wood-panelled room pre-dated my right as a woman to an education — for centuries it had exclusively schooled boys, and even now girls were admitted only to the sixth form.

That September, walking into the ancient cobblestone courtyard as a 16-year-old, I was caught between terror and elation. I’d been told that you had to be tough to succeed as a girl at Westminster. I had no idea how tough I would need to be.

Sponsored

summary:
As I entered my final interview for Westminster School I was buzzing with hope.
It was 2008, my interviews had gone well and I had only the head master to meet.
That September, walking into the ancient cobblestone courtyard as a 16-year-old, I was caught between terror and elation.
I’d been told that you had to be tough to succeed as a girl at Westminster.
I had no idea how tough I would need to be.

text:
A military court cleared Lieutenant Rhys Christie of rape but questioned his fitness to continue his military career

A Royal Navy commander has been cleared of raping a teenage cadet but was told that he had “fundamentally failed” in his duty of care and may not be fit to continue his military career.

A court martial found Lieutenant Rhys Christie, who at the time was commanding officer of Edinburgh-based HMS Archer, not guilty of five charges of rape. He had been accused of “pouncing on the vulnerability” of a young woman after two navy nights out.

title: Rape charge for high society internet tycoon Lawrence Jones
text:
A British tech tycoon who counts the rich and famous as friends has been charged with rape and sexual assault.

Lawrence Jones, 52, who is said to be worth £700 million, founded the internet hosting service UK Fast and was its chief executive until he stepped down in 2019 after allegations by female colleagues made during an investigation by the Financial Times.

Sponsored

They had included inappropriate physical contact, verbal abuse and bullying, which he denied at the time. The company, based in Manchester, had been ranked as one of the top ten places to work in Britain.

Greater Manchester police said yesterday that Mr Jones, who lives in Hale Barns, a village near Altrincham, had been charged with one rape and four sexual assaults.
summary:
A British tech tycoon who counts the rich and famous as friends has been charged with rape and sexual assault.
Lawrence Jones, 52, who is said to be worth £700 million, founded the internet hosting service UK Fast and was its chief executive until he stepped down in 2019 after allegations by female colleagues made during an investigation by the Financial Times.
SponsoredThey had included inappropriate physical contact, verbal abuse and bullying, which he denied at the time.
The company, based in Manchester, had been ranked as one of the top ten places to work in Britain.
Greater Manchester police said yesterday that Mr Jones, who lives in Hale Barns, a village near Altrincham, had been charged with one rape and four sexual assaults.

title: Jeremy Clarkson: Brexit red tape is sowing the seeds of disaster
text:
As we know, the nation’s Brexiteers are now running around with a smug look on their faces, and Union Jacks on their mobility scooters, telling anyone who’ll listen that if they hadn’t won the referendum, we’d all be painting red crosses on our front doors and throwing granny on the cart because she’d just coughed.

“Look,” they scream, priapic with delight, “even the Germans have not been able to organise themselves thanks to the bureaucratic monster that is the EU, whereas here, where we are free and agile, every man, woman and child has now been vaccinated with a proper British jab.”

title: British UN official accused of raping girl escapes prosecution
text:
A woman and child wait to receive the ebola vaccination in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where peacekeepers and other officials face claims of sexual abuse

A British United Nations official escaped prosecution for alleged sexual exploitation of a teenage girl in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) despite an investigation finding credible evidence against him.

The man was working for the UN’s peacekeeping mission in the DRC in 2017 when he is alleged to have given a 16-year-old girl money and goods in exchange for sex.

Sponsored

The allegation was reported to the Congolese authorities and investigated by the UN’s internal affairs unit, which concluded that the allegations were substantiated. UN records showed the man paid $5,000 to the girl’s family.

The employee was dismissed and Britain’s delegation to the UN in New York was alerted to the case. His identity, whereabouts and present employment status are not known.

Dame Barbara
summary:
A woman and child wait to receive the ebola vaccination in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where peacekeepers and other officials face claims of sexual abuseA British United Nations official escaped prosecution for alleged sexual exploitation of a teenage girl in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) despite an investigation finding credible evidence against him.

SponsoredThe allegation was reported to the Congolese authorities and investigated by the UN’s internal affairs unit, which concluded that the allegations were substantiated.
UN records showed the man paid $5,000 to the girl’s family.
The employee was dismissed and Britain’s delegation to the UN in New York was alerted to the case.

text:

Ciara Charteris, one of the stars of Poldark, has revealed that she was raped by a close friend five years ago.

title: Alex Massie: Specialist rape courts have right to a fair trial in Scotland
text:
Imagine you are summoned for jury duty. Being a civic-minded soul, you recognise the importance of the task allotted you. It is a weighty responsibility, but one you embrace. You arrive at the High Court on the required date, filled with curiosity and, perhaps, a little nervousness, too. What kind of case might you get? Something interesting, you hope, but also one that will not require you to attend court for weeks on end. You are ready, however, and you know you will discharge your duties honestly and without prejudice. You are a fair-minded soul, after all. Everyone says so.

You are certainly the kind of person who will not bring their own views or prejudices with them to court. No, of course not. Just
summary:
Being a civic-minded soul, you recognise the importance of the task allotted you.
It is a weighty responsibility, but one you embrace.
You arrive at the High Court on the required date, filled with curiosity and, perhaps, a little nervousness, too.
Something interesting, you hope, but also one that will not require you to attend court for weeks on end.
You are certainly the kind of person who will not bring their own views or prejudices with them to court.

title: Richard Browning’s jet suit set to target ship hijackers
text:
Seizing control of a ship that has been hijacked by terrorists presents a nightmare scenario for special forces: rapelling down a “fast rope” from a hovering helicopter or climbing aboard by ladder sacrifices the vital element of suprise.

Now, however, there appears to be a third way — the jet pack. Designed and built by Richard Browning, a former Royal Marine reservist, a fast and manoeuvrable jet suit is set to revolutionise special forces’ counter-terrorist operations both at sea and on land.

Sponsored

Powered by one micro-gas turbine jet engine on each arm and a bigger version on the back it provides 150 kilograms of thrust, sufficient to launch a man or woman into the air and hurl them forward.

Browning has carried out similar tests with the Royal Navy and Royal Marines

Browning, who runs Gravity Industries
summary:
Seizing control of a ship that has been hijacked by terrorists presents a nightmare scenario for special forces: rapelling down a “fast rope” from a hovering helicopter or climbing aboard by ladder sacrifices the vital element of suprise.

title: Eighteen cases of sexual abuse a week at universities
text:
A third of students say they have “learnt more about sex from pornography than from formal education”, according to a report for the Higher Education Policy Institute

Eighteen cases of sexual violence are reported at universities every week, but overall just one in twenty leads to the accused being expelled, according to data released under information laws.

At least 2,800 reports of sexual assault, rape and harassment have been made in the past three years, including more than 1,026 claims last year despite attendance being reduced by Covid restrictions.

Universities have expelled or suspended at least 156 students for sexual violence since 2018, including ten each from Nottingham and Warwick universities.

Italian police have arrested four men and are investigating four other suspects in connection with the alleged drugging and gang rape of two 15-year-old British girls on holiday in the south of the country.

text:

The studies were ordered by the Scottish Funding Council in February after the case of Kevin O’Gorman, the former Strathclyde professor who was convicted in 2019 of the sexual assault of seven male students between 2006 and 2014.

title: Scandal of widespread sexual abuse in schools reveals urgent need for guidance
text:
The widespread abuse described on the website Everyone’s Invited undoubtedly signifies a failure or inability of schools and government to educate pupils and students in the definition and potential effects of such incidents.

The collective experiences posted on the website include the commission of criminal offences — many of them of a sexual nature.

Sponsored

Given that by the age of ten children are deemed capable of committing criminal offences, the curriculum needs to include guidance about what constitutes an offence, especially a sexual one, and what sort of sentences and orders the courts can impose.

Teachers and parents also need to be educated in this area. Children of primary school age need to be taught about what makes relationships healthy, respectful and safe. Children
summary:
The widespread abuse described on the website Everyone’s Invited undoubtedly signifies a failure or inability of schools and government to educate pupils and students in the definition and potential effects of such incidents.
The collective experiences posted on the website include the commission of criminal offences — many of them of a sexual nature.
SponsoredGiven that by the age of ten children are deemed capable of committing criminal offences, the curriculum needs to include guidance about what constitutes an offence, especially a sexual one, and what sort of sentences and orders the courts can impose.
Teachers and parents also need to be educated in this area.
Children of primary school age need to be taught about what makes relationships healthy, respectful and safe.

title: Times letters: Racism, inequality and the Sewell report
text:
Sir, The Sewell review is the first government-commissioned study on race seriously to engage with the family, finding that educational failure and crime required an upstream response “to family breakdown as one of the main reasons for poor outcomes” (News, Mar 31 & Apr 1). It is important to challenge the metropolitan elite’s enduring reluctance to acknowledge the considerable contribution that dysfunctional relationships, fractured families and father absence make to most if not all social problems. The report highlights family hubs, which play a vital role in preventing family challenges from escalating. The government needs to be far more ambitious in fulfilling its manifesto commitment to champion them. The report concludes that “family is also the foundation stone of success for many ethnic minorities”. Getting

Sponsored
summary:
Sir, The Sewell review is the first government-commissioned study on race seriously to engage with the family, finding that educational failure and crime required an upstream response “to family breakdown as one of the main reasons for poor outcomes” (News, Mar 31 & Apr 1).
It is important to challenge the metropolitan elite’s enduring reluctance to acknowledge the considerable contribution that dysfunctional relationships, fractured families and father absence make to most if not all social problems.
The report highlights family hubs, which play a vital role in preventing family challenges from escalating.
The government needs to be far more ambitious in fulfilling its manifesto commitment to champion them.
The report concludes that “family is also the foundation stone of success for many ethnic minorities”.

title: Veteran news reader Patrick Poivre d’Arvor is accused of rape
text:
One of France's best-known television presenters has been accused by a writer of rape, adding to a string of celebrities recently accused of sexual assault.

Patrick Poivre d’Arvor, 73, a journalist and novelist who presented the evening news on the TF1 network for 21 years and also hosted arts programmes, denied the allegations made by Florence Porcel. She said that he raped her in 2004 and forced her to have oral sex in 2009.

Sponsored

Prosecutors began an investigation when Porcel, 37, made a complaint a month after she published a novel that described her alleged ordeal without naming Poivre d’Arvor, who is known by his initials PPDA.

The claim comes after a series of scandals in which women have accused famous men of sexual abuse

text:
Peter Nygard, one of Canada’s richest men, cultivated a playboy lifestyle over the course of decades

For two decades Jane has lived with boards over her windows and security cameras inside and outside her home.

She lived like this, she said, because she was so scared of Peter Nygard, the Canadian fashion mogul, who she claims trafficked her from Canada to the Bahamas and raped her when she was in her twenties.

title: QC Gordon Jackson’s fears about rape trial proposals
text:
Gordon Jackson QC says he is hesitant about the rape trial ideas put forward by Lady Dorrian

The QC who successfully defended Alex Salmond against sexual assault allegations has raised concerns about the prospect of rape trials without juries.

Gordon Jackson, the former Dean of the Faculty of Advocates, said he was “worried” about proposals made by Lady Dorrian, the lord justice clerk, in her review into the prosecution of sexual offences.

Jackson was among senior legal figures to object to Dorrian’s suggestion of a pilot scheme to assess the impact of dispensing with jury trials in rape cases.

“Any proposal that does away with juries worries me, in case it will affect the right to a fair trial in our system,” he said. “I’m hesitant about it, it worries me, but to make a decision, I’d need to sit down

title: Rape and sexual assault has an effect on all of society
text:
In the wake of 14,000 testimonies of sexual abuse and harassment published on the website Everyone’s Invited, Ofsted has been ordered to undertake an “immediate review” into safeguarding policies and practices in state and independent schools and colleges. The focus on the education system is well intentioned, but it ignores the much wider problem of sexual violence against young people.

Data from the 2020 Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) shows that nearly one in fourwomen and girls were sexually assaulted since the age of 16, ranging from indecent exposure to rape. title: No boss has ever thrown a potato at me — but there have been some odd ones
text:
Some wrong ’uns, even allowing for the benefit of hindsight, pretty much look like what they are. I give you, as a for-instance, Jimmy Savile, who couldn’t have provided a bigger clue as to his true nature short of getting “paedo” tattooed on his forehead. Scott Rudin, the film and theatre producer revealed as a shocking bully, offered no such evidence. Could be he was lovably benign. Could be he was the unpleasant person he in fact turns out to be.

What we could surmise purely from Rudin’s appearance, however, is that he really likes baked potatoes, lots of them. Preferably stuffed with all manner of highly calorific fillings. This has been proved by the news that he once threw a baked potato at

title: The low-tech way chefs make pesto, sauces and marinades — a pestle and mortar
text:
My mother has proudly eschewed a dishwasher all her life. I think the reasoning is that with five children there was always someone to press gang into washing-up duty. I’m made of softer stuff, so what was the first piece of kitchen equipment I invested in? Too right. A dishwasher. What is the point of labour-saving devices if you don’t, as the name suggests, allow them to save you time and effort. Washing machines, mixing machines, food processors, coffee grinders . . . I’ve welcomed them all into my kitchen.

There is one manual process I like to keep strictly low-tech, though, and that is the grinding and pounding of herbs and spices with a pestle and mortar. Not for me the whirring blades of
summary:
I think the reasoning is that with five children there was always someone to press gang into washing-up duty.
I’m made of softer stuff, so what was the first piece of kitchen equipment I invested in?
What is the point of labour-saving devices if you don’t, as the name suggests, allow them to save you time and effort.
Washing machines, mixing machines, food processors, coffee grinders .
There is one manual process I like to keep strictly low-tech, though, and that is the grinding and pounding of herbs and spices with a pestle and mortar.

title: French rape law lets firemen off over sex with girl, 14
text:
Emergency service workers who repeatedly had sex with a fragile 14-year-old girl were not guilty of rape, the Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

Feminists have cited the case as evidence of France’s reluctance to protect children from sexual predators. The judgment comes during a heated national debate over attempts by parliament to set an age of consent beneath which victims would automatically be considered victims of rape.

Sponsored

The legislation was prompted in part by the case of the woman, now 26, who alleged she was raped by officers at the fire station in Bourg-la-Reine, a southern suburb of Paris.

The woman, identified in court documents as Julie, which is not her real name, was bullied at school and suffered from poor mental health. She called

Emergency service workers who repeatedly had sex with a fragile 14-year-old girl were not guilty of rape, the Supreme Court ruled yesterday.
Feminists have cited the case as evidence of France’s reluctance to protect children from sexual predators.
The judgment comes during a heated national debate over attempts by parliament to set an age of consent beneath which victims would automatically be considered victims of rape.

title: Harvey Weinstein claims ‘media firestorm’ prevented fair trial
text:
Harvey Weinstein has launched an appeal against his conviction for rape and sexual assault, arguing that his case was heard amid a “media firestorm” before a judge who failed to protect his right to a fair trial and imposed an overly harsh sentence.

The former film mogul, whose downfall caused a reckoning that toppled powerful men in Hollywood, the media and politics, has been accused by more than 90 women of sexual misconduct.

Sponsored

His conviction by a jury in New York last year, concerning allegations by two women, was hailed by leaders of the #MeToo movement as a landmark for victims’ rights advocates, who had long bemoaned the difficulties of bringing alleged sexual predators to trial. Judge James Burke sentenced him to serve 23 years

title: Measures needed to cut persistent sexual violence
text:
Tougher measures to tackle gender-based violence are needed in Scotland, campaigners and politicians have said after figures highlighted blackspots for sexual offences.

A breakdown of crimes, including rape and assault, last year shows that the highest number, 203, were recorded in the Anderston/City/Yorkhill area of Glasgow, followed by Edinburgh’s Liberton/Gilmerton ward, with 102. Govan, in Nicola Sturgeon’s Glasgow Southside constituency, had 100, as did Buckhaven, Methil and Wemyss villages in Fife.

Sponsored

A total of 13,240 incidents were reported last year, an average of more than 1,000 a month. When the number of sexual offences is adjusted to account for population, the highest rate was recorded in the police division of Fife, with 32.3 crimes for every 10,000 people. The rate for Tayside was 31.1, for
summary:
Tougher measures to tackle gender-based violence are needed in Scotland, campaigners and politicians have said after figures highlighted blackspots for sexual offences.

title: Cressida Dick: Kate’s Sarah Everard visit was legal but vigil was not
text:
The Duchess of Cambridge laid flowers for Sarah Everard on March 13, in what Kensington Palace described at the time as a private affair

Dame Cressida Dick has suggested that the Duchess of Cambridge carried out a legal working visit to the Sarah Everard vigil even though her force classed the event as illegal.

The Metropolitan Police commissioner, who had earlier said that she would have attended the vigil herself had it been legal, said the duchess was in the “course of her duties” when she placed flowers on the Clapham Common bandstand, in south London.

Sponsored

Her comments, the day after an independent report exonerated the Met over its policing of the event on March 13, created further confusion about the legality of protest in the pandemic.

Dick also told Today on Radio 4 that her officers faced “extreme provocation” at the vigil in memory of Everard, 33,

text:
More than 50 claims of sexual assault were made by students at St Andrews

A “rape culture” has become established at Scotland’s oldest university, fuelled by toxic male-dominated societies, a campus organisation has claimed.

The existence of a number of powerful and elitist men-only groups has turned St Andrews into an unsafe environment for female students, the university’s Jewish Society has alleged.

The claims were made after more than 50 first-hand accounts of sexual assault were published on a social media account for students at the alma mater of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.

A chapter of the Alpha Epsilon Pi (AEPi) fraternity, an all-male Jewish society founded at New York University in 1913, is at the centre of the allegations, with a number of members under investigation.

The university says that it will not tolerate any form

title: Dublin Rape Crisis Centre warning after drop in sex assault crimes
text:
Noeline Blackwell, of the Dublin Rape Crisis Centre, said the figures were not consistent with the number of offences “actually happening”

There has been a drop in the number of reported sexual offences for the first time in almost six years, according to new crime statistics.

The Dublin Rape Crisis Centre cast doubt over the figures, saying that sexual offences are often under-reported.

Sponsored

There were 3,114 sexual offences reported in the 12 months to March this year, 149 fewer than the same period last year. This is a decrease of 4.6 per cent and is the first year-on-year decrease since the third quarter of 2014 when 1,849 incidents were reported.

The figures, from the Central Statistics Office (CSO), also show that the number of reported sexual offences reached a record high of 3,307 last year.

title: How to use wild garlic
text:
Walking throughout the countryside in the first throes of spring can be a real treat for our senses. Wild garlic carpets the woodland floor with its vibrant green leaves and white flowers, and its sweet-tangy smell is unmistakable.

The scientific name is Allium ursinum but being a favourite of wild boars and brown bears in Asia and other European countries, it is often known as bear’s garlic.

Sponsored

This is the perfect beginners’ plant to forage because it grows in abundance and can be cooked following foolproof, versatile recipes.

Wild garlic grows from March to June, generally before deciduous trees start to leaf. It is identifiable by its bright green leaves, which grow up to 25cm long and 7cm wide. The white, star-like flowers are about
summary:

The website that exposed the scale of sexual harassment and abuse in schools is turning the spotlight on universities.

Everyone’s Invited is today releasing the names of more than 100 universities where students have submitted anonymous testimonies of abuse.

After receiving more than 1,000 accounts in a single week — a fifth of all testimonies posted to the site — the website took the step of naming universities. text:

Police and prosecutors are behind a decline in the number of suspects being charged with rape because they are ignoring crucial evidence and stereotyping victims, a report has warned.

text:

While Sir Keir Starmer, QC, was director of public prosecutions from 2008-13, the number of pre-charge decisions for such offences rose from 79,787 to 109,419 and the rate of convictions increased by 74.4 per cent. Those decisions were made on a “merits-based approach”, which was part of a commitment given by Starmer.

text:
Access to a female doctor is the biggest issue brought up by victims, campaigners have said

Scotland’s health secretary has said she is confident rape and sexual assault victims will be able to choose the gender of their forensic medical examiner under new legislation.

Jeane Freeman told Holyrood’s health committee people will be able to self-refer and should not have to wait more than three hours for examination.

title: MP’s arrest over rape claim drives up helpline calls
text:
The parliamentary complaints procedure changed in 2018 to make the process more transparent

The arrest of a Tory former minister for alleged rape and sexual assault has led to a surge in calls to a helpline for parliamentary staff.

Downing Street insisted last night that Boris Johnson had full confidence in his chief whip, Mark Spencer, despite growing criticism of his decision not to suspend the MP.

Sponsored

Further details of the case emerged yesterday, including the alleged failure of Mr Spencer to update the complainant, a former parliamentary staffer in her twenties, about the progress of a promised investigation.

The woman contacted Mr Spencer in April to detail the allegations against the Conservative MP, who is in his fifties. The chief whip is said to have promised to get back to her in a “week or so”

title: Rape suspects in Scotland could face trial without jury
text:
A combination of High Court judges and sheriffs would preside over cases, and proceedings would be designed to deal sensitively with the most traumatised people

Serious sexual crimes would be prosecuted at a new Scottish national court using recorded evidence under proposals to create one of the most sensitive judicial environments in the world.

One proposal of a review led by Lady Dorrian suggests the consideration of a time-limited pilot scheme to assess the feasibility of dispensing with jury trials in rape cases in favour of judge-led hearings.

Sponsored

The principal recommendation is the creation of the new specialist court. Another proposal suggests that “rape myths and stereotypes” are debunked as a matter of routine where juries are asked to adjudicate on serious sexual cases.

The specialist court would wield sentencing powers of up to ten years’ imprisonment with the option to apply to the High Court for a higher tariff
summary:

title: ‘Ten rapes’ at tea farm supplying PG Tips
text:
The British owners of tea estates in Malawi that supply most of the UK’s biggest brands, including PG Tips, Yorkshire Tea and Tetley, are being sued over the alleged sexual abuse of workers.

Women working at Lujeri Tea Estates in southern Malawi report a culture of abuse at the farms. Supervisors and managers are accused in 31 different claims of sexually assaulting, harassing and, in ten cases, raping women working there.

Sponsored

The claims, which date from 2014 to 2019, include a woman who said she was raped by a supervisor in a tea field and contracted HIV, fell pregnant, lost her job and had a stillborn baby.

Most big supermarkets have, until very recently, used Lujeri as a supplier for their own-brand tea, including Waitrose,
summary:
The British owners of tea estates in Malawi that supply most of the UK’s biggest brands, including PG Tips, Yorkshire Tea and Tetley, are being sued over the alleged sexual abuse of workers.
Women working at Lujeri Tea Estates in southern Malawi report a culture of abuse at the farms.
Supervisors and managers are accused in 31 different claims of sexually assaulting, harassing and, in ten cases, raping women working there.
SponsoredThe claims, which date from 2014 to 2019, include a woman who said she was raped by a supervisor in a tea field and contracted HIV, fell pregnant, lost her job and had a stillborn baby.
Most big supermarkets have, until very recently, used Lujeri as a supplier for their own-brand tea, including Waitrose,

title: Former boss of Elite agency Gérald Marie ‘raped two models’
text:
Gérald Marie, president of the Elite model agency for 25 years, with his former wife Linda Evangelista

A former top boss at one of the world’s biggest modelling agencies may face investigation in France after being accused of rape and sexual assault.

In legal documents, which will now be reviewed by a prosecutor in Paris, two former models who were then aged 17 and 20 allege that they were raped by Gérald Marie, who was president of the European arm of Elite for 25 years. He denies the allegations.

Sponsored

Marie is now the chairman of a Paris modelling agency called Oui Management.

A third woman alleges that Marie, now 70, sexually assaulted her during a meeting in his office at Elite in Paris. The allegations date back to the 1980s and 1990s. The allegations come as Paris fashion week opens on Monday.
summary:
Gérald Marie, president of the Elite model agency for 25 years, with his former wife Linda EvangelistaA former top boss at one of the world’s biggest modelling agencies may face investigation in France after being accused of rape and sexual assault.
In legal documents, which will now be reviewed by a prosecutor in Paris, two former models who were then aged 17 and 20 allege that they were raped by Gérald Marie, who was president of the European arm of Elite for 25 years.
SponsoredMarie is now the chairman of a Paris modelling agency called Oui Management.
A third woman alleges that Marie, now 70, sexually assaulted her during a meeting in his office at Elite in Paris.
The allegations come as Paris fashion week opens on Monday.

title: The Times view on allegations of sexual abuse at leading independent schools: Educating Equality
text:
The allegations of sexual abuse in schools have been likened to a “MeToo” moment in education GETTY IMAGES

Recalling his experience of Charterhouse, the poet Robert Graves wrote: “The opposite sex is despised and hated, treated as something obscene.” There is disturbing evidence that this still describes attitudes within independent schools in the 21st century. It is vital that schools are transparent and allow a full external investigation into allegations of sexual harassment of girls.

Sponsored

We have reported over the past week on an outpouring of testimonies from students and alumnae concerning abuse and rape within leading schools. Thousands of anonymous contributions to a website called Everyone’s Invited tell a consistent story of predatory behaviour by boys and an insouciant response, if any, by the schools concerned. Though these institutions are not limited to the private sector, it is notable how many prominent

title: Rape and murder suspects failing to show up in court
text:
The coronavirus pandemic has resulted in an unprecedented backlog of court cases

More than 20,000 suspects are wanted by police after they failed to appear in court, the highest number in nine years, according to statistics.

Magistrates issued 21,248 warrants for suspects who failed to appear between June and September, a 15 per cent increase on the same period last year. They included 416 warrants that related to offences such as murder, rape, robbery and serious assault.

Sponsored

The number of warrants issued for suspects who failed to appear had fallen from 92,000 in 2010 to a total of 70,000 last year.

However, the recent steep increase has brought the highest number of warrants issued in a single quarter since the same period in 2011.

The authorities attributed the rise in part to the pandemic, saying that increased
summary:

Magistrates issued 21,248 warrants for suspects who failed to appear between June and September, a 15 per cent increase on the same period last year.
They included 416 warrants that related to offences such as murder, rape, robbery and serious assault.

title: Sex abuse claims at St Andrews: Power, privilege and the fraternity in rape turmoil
text:
A still from a promotional video for Alpha Epsilon Pi, whose biggest British chapter is at St Andrews

It was founded on the principles of social awareness and charitable giving and its alumni include global stars, titans of industry and Nobel laureates.

But in the past two weeks the Alpha Epsilon Pi fraternity (AEPi) has faced sex-abuse claims that have rocked St Andrews University, one of Britain’s most prestigious institutions and alma mater of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.

title: Cost of rising crime is nearly £100bn a year, ministers told
text:
There has been a sharp rise in murders, serious assaults, rape and robbery

The “cost of crime” to individuals and businesses has soared to almost £100 billion a year, according to analysis of government figures.

A sharp rise in murders, serious assaults, rape and robbery has driven the estimated total financial costs incurred by individuals each year in England and Wales to £72.5 billion. This is up from £50.1 billion in 2015-16.

Sponsored

Costs incurred from crimes against businesses have more than doubled from £8.7 billion in 2015-16 to £22.8 billion in the year last to September.

The figures are from research by the Labour Party, which has updated the Home Office’s latest cost of crime assessment carried out in 2018 with the last year’s crime figures. The Home Office bases its calculations on how much individuals and

title: Restaurant worker raped teenager in Glasgow street
text:
Prosecutors told the High Court in Glasgow that the girl had been so intoxicated she was incapable of consenting to sex

A kitchen assistant has been convicted of raping a 17-year-old girl within six minutes of finding her “unsteady on her feet” after a work night out.

The teenager, who is understood to have committed suicide in March last year, was attacked by Ji Ren Lin after he carried her into a lane in Glasgow city centre on November 21, 2018.

Sponsored

Lin, 32, had been dumping boxes during his shift at a nearby Chinese restaurant. He denied the charge and said the girl had been able to consent to sex.

He was convicted of rape after a trial at the High Court in Glasgow. Lin, who was born in Hong Kong, will be sentenced next month.

The victim had been to several bars. A colleague concerned
summary:
The teenager, who is understood to have committed suicide in March last year, was attacked by Ji Ren Lin after he carried her into a lane in Glasgow city centre on November 21, 2018.
SponsoredLin, 32, had been dumping boxes during his shift at a nearby Chinese restaurant.
He denied the charge and said the girl had been able to consent to sex.
He was convicted of rape after a trial at the High Court in Glasgow.
Lin, who was born in Hong Kong, will be sentenced next month.

title: We must bring back British families trafficked by Isis
text:
In the statutory guidance that accompanies the Modern Slavery Act, the duty of public employees faced with a trafficking case is made clear: “The safety, protection and support of the potential victim must always be the first priority.”

Unless, it seems, the victim was trafficked by so-called Islamic State. Because unfortunately, there seems to be a blind spot when it comes to the handful of British families who were trafficked to Syria by Isis, and are now held in unstable and dangerous detention camps that are bursting at the seams.

Sponsored

In its new report, the legal NGO Reprieve describes the grim reality of the sophisticated trafficking operation employed by Isis. It tells the stories of several British women and children who were groomed and trafficked
summary:
In the statutory guidance that accompanies the Modern Slavery Act, the duty of public employees faced with a trafficking case is made clear: “The safety, protection and support of the potential victim must always be the first priority.”Unless, it seems, the victim was trafficked by so-called Islamic State.
Because unfortunately, there seems to be a blind spot when it comes to the handful of British families who were trafficked to Syria by Isis, and are now held in unstable and dangerous detention camps that are bursting at the seams.

title: EU is becoming policeman of the internet
text:
The Americans innovate and the Europeans regulate. That was a simple way of explaining the interaction between government and the technology business. It is still broadly true. The European Union is not quite an innovation desert but nothing rivals Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook or Microsoft. The US has flubbed questions such as internet privacy, whereas the EU is a rule-making superpower. The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) of 2018 has become, in effect, a global standard.

Now the EU is flexing its muscles again, issuing proposed regulations on the hottest topic in digital governance: artificial intelligence, or AI. That is well overdue. Computer decision-making can determine whether you get a job, a loan, a home or a date, as well as what news or ads
summary:
That was a simple way of explaining the interaction between government and the technology business.
The European Union is not quite an innovation desert but nothing rivals Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook or Microsoft.
The US has flubbed questions such as internet privacy, whereas the EU is a rule-making superpower.
Now the EU is flexing its muscles again, issuing proposed regulations on the hottest topic in digital governance: artificial intelligence, or AI.
Computer decision-making can determine whether you get a job, a loan, a home or a date, as well as what news or ads

title: Justice department to defend Trump in E Jean Carroll lawsuit over rape claim
text:
President Trump, at a rally in North Carolina, had said his accuser was “totally lying” about the attack

The US Justice Department has moved to take over the president’s defence against a lawsuit by a prominent columnist who says Donald Trump raped her.

E Jean Carroll, 76, alleges that Mr Trump sexually assaulted her in the changing room at the luxury Bergdorf Goodman department store on Fifth Avenue in New York in the mid-1990s.

Sponsored

Mr Trump had previously denied the allegation, saying in an interview in June last year that she was “not my type” and that he had never met Ms Carroll.

Ms Carroll sued the president in November in New York state, accusing him of defamation after he claimed she was “totally lying” about the assault.

title: Court quashes man’s conviction for joining in gang rape
text:
The Director of Public Prosecutions did not oppose the application to overturn the conviction

The Court of Appeal has quashed the conviction of a man for taking part in a gang rape after the defence received undisclosed information that the complainant had made other sexual allegations in the past.

The Director of Public Prosecutions did not oppose the man’s application to have his conviction overturned. The man, now 25, who was jailed for four years in June 2017, is reserving his position in relation to compensation for a miscarriage of justice.

text:
Missed it in hardback? Don’t want to break the bank? Or maybe you just want a book that’s not going to weigh your bag down. Whatever you’re looking for, we’ve got you covered.

Here’s our list of the best paperbacks of 2021 so far, which we’ll be adding to each week. You can also check out our comprehensive guide to the best paperbacks of 2020.

title: St Andrews told to ban Alpha Epsilon Pi fraternity group at the centre of rape allegations
text:
A number of members of the St Andrews chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi are being investigated

The University of St Andrews is facing calls to ban a fraternity at the centre of rape allegations after it emerged that campuses across the United States had removed the society following complaints of sexual misconduct.

More than 50 first-hand accounts of sexual assault were posted on a social media account for students at St Andrews, leading to a police investigation. A chapter of the Alpha Epsilon Pi (AEPi) fraternity, an all-male Jewish society, is at the heart of the claims, with a number of members being investigated. The group has faced previous allegations of sexual and physical violence.

Sponsored

In February, Ari Goldstein, 23, the former president of a chapter of AEPi at Temple University, Philadelphia, was convicted for an indecent assault on a female

title: Scottish football delaying child abuse report, rape victim claims
text:
A rape survivor who was abused by an assistant referee after being invited to the Scottish Cup final has demanded that Scottish football’s governing body release its delayed report into child sexual abuse within the sport.

Pete Haynes, 54, alleges that he was abused by Hugh Stevenson, a top-flight linesman and coach, after attending the match at Hampden in 1979.

Sponsored

Mr Haynes reported the allegations to the police in 1993 and 1996 and informed the Scottish Football Association (SFA) but Stevenson died in 2004 without facing any charges.

The report of the Independent Review of Sexual Abuse in Scottish Football was due to be released in 2018 but has been held back on several occasions.

Martin Henry, chairman of the review, handed over the finalised
summary:

title: UK firm pays £4.6m to settle claims of ‘rape and murder’ at Kakuzi avocado farm
text:
The British owners of a Kenyan avocado farm that supplied British supermarkets have paid substantial compensation to 85 alleged victims of human rights abuses.

Kakuzi, a vast farm north of Nairobi, sold the fruit to supermarkets until last October, when a Sunday Times investigation revealed claims of abuses by its security guards. The allegations included that farm guards beat to death a 28-year-old man accused of stealing avocados, raped 10 women and committed dozens of brutal attacks on villagers.

Sponsored

Kakuzi’s parent company, Camellia, will spend up to £4.6 million on the settlement, including compensation, legal costs and funding schemes for the community. Camellia, whose headquarters are a Kent mansion, owns a majority share in the Kenyan farm and is valued at £180 million.

The original
summary:
The British owners of a Kenyan avocado farm that supplied British supermarkets have paid substantial compensation to 85 alleged victims of human rights abuses.
Kakuzi, a vast farm north of Nairobi, sold the fruit to supermarkets until last October, when a Sunday Times investigation revealed claims of abuses by its security guards.
The allegations included that farm guards beat to death a 28-year-old man accused of stealing avocados, raped 10 women and committed dozens of brutal attacks on villagers.
SponsoredKakuzi’s parent company, Camellia, will spend up to £4.6 million on the settlement, including compensation, legal costs and funding schemes for the community.
Camellia, whose headquarters are a Kent mansion, owns a majority share in the Kenyan farm and is valued at £180 million.

title: Scottish students add rape claims to website
text:
Current and former pupils at Scottish universities have reportedly been encouraged to come forward following the death of Sarah Everard in south London

Claims of rape on Scottish university campuses are among thousands being posted on a website for survivors of sexual abuse.

Everyone’s Invited, a website and social media account for students and former students to share experiences of sexual assault and harassment anonymously has been inundated in recent weeks. People have apparently been inspired to come forward after the death of Sarah Everard, who went missing in south London.

Sponsored

Almost 5,200 accounts have been posted. They include alleged sex attacks at Edinburgh and Glasgow universities. One testimony describes a rape by “a boy in my block” during a first term at Edinburgh’s Pollock halls of residence: “I still see him around sometimes and it triggers huge anxiety in me, I’m sure he has no idea of
summary:

People have apparently been inspired to come forward after the death of Sarah Everard, who went missing in south London.

title: Rape victims given the right to ask for female forensic team
text:
Some people questioned the motives of MSP Johann Lamont, who delivered two speeches during the debate

Rape victims have the legal right to be treated by female forensic teams before going to the police after a new law was passed at Holyrood last night.

A change to the legislation ensured that the definition of a woman is by their sex rather than their gender. This means that self-identifying transgender women are not permitted to provide such treatment.

Sponsored

Johann Lamont, the former Scottish Labour leader who pushed for the law, pointed out that several government ministers had said “sex” — which is a protected characteristic under law — and “gender” were not interchangeable.

She cited groups including Engender, Rape Crisis Scotland and Zero Tolerance which have at points “sought definitions of gender that are explicitly not interchangeable with the word ‘sex’.” This,
summary:

title: Brenda Power: Naming in fake rape cases is the real shame
text:
In 2017 a “peaceful, law-abiding, diligent young man” — the judge’s words — from a decent hardworking family, with no previous convictions, was jailed for four years for taking part in a gang rape. Last month, having served three years in jail, the now 25-year-old was freed by the Court of Appeal after it emerged that the complainant had made previous allegations of a sexual nature, which were not disclosed to the defence.

title: Natasha Golding: Woman ‘raped on island’ must pay thousands to attend trial
text:
Natasha Golding has been told she will not be giving evidence at the Cape Verde hearing

A British woman who claims she was raped on a Cape Verde island more than two years ago will not be called as a witness at the trial of her alleged attacker.

Natasha Golding, 44, from Leeds, has fought to make sure that her alleged attacker faces justice. She is concerned about the outcome in a country that she claims has never prosecuted a rape.

Sponsored

Ms Golding was told last month that under Cape Verde’s criminal justice system it was not necessary for the alleged victim to play a role in any trial. The court would rely instead on her statements.

She was also told that she would have to pay her own way to any trial and that she would have to hire translators.
summary:
Natasha Golding has been told she will not be giving evidence at the Cape Verde hearingA British woman who claims she was raped on a Cape Verde island more than two years ago will not be called as a witness at the trial of her alleged attacker.
Natasha Golding, 44, from Leeds, has fought to make sure that her alleged attacker faces justice.
She is concerned about the outcome in a country that she claims has never prosecuted a rape.
SponsoredMs Golding was told last month that under Cape Verde’s criminal justice system it was not necessary for the alleged victim to play a role in any trial.
She was also told that she would have to pay her own way to any trial and that she would have to hire translators.

title: 365 Days: Netflix film glamorises rape, says singer Duffy
text:
Duffy said 365 Days “should not be anyone’s idea of entertainment”

Duffy has accused Netflix of distorting sexual violence and using kidnap for titillation in its dramas.

The Welsh singer wrote an open letter to Reed Hastings, the streaming company’s chief executive, about the film 365 Days because “of a violent experience that I endured of the kind that you have chosen to present as ‘adult erotica’”.

Sponsored

After a ten-year absence from the public eye, Duffy recently posted an account of how she had endured kidnap and rape.

She said Netflix was “irresponsible”, adding: “365 Days glamorises the brutal reality of sex trafficking, kidnapping and rape. This should not be anyone’s idea of entertainment, nor should it be described as such, or be commercialised in this manner.”

title: CPS wins case over ‘policy that legalised rape’
text:
Campaigners argued at the Court of Appeal that the CPS had become more hesitant in prosecuting serious sexual assaults

The Court of Appeal has backed the Crown Prosecution Service over its policy on sexual assault cases, rejecting claims that a shift in approach had effectively “legalised rape”.

A coalition of campaign groups argued that the CPS had moved away from a “merits-based approach” to deciding which cases of alleged rape and other more serious sexual assault should be prosecuted.

Sponsored

The campaigners maintained that the policy shift gave rise to “systemic illegality”. They claimed that between 2016 and 2018 prosecutors became more risk-averse and shifted towards an “unlawful predictive approach when deciding whether to charge” people over alleged sexual offences.

Lawyers for the group argued that this allegedly unlawful approach led to a “shocking and unprecedented decline in both the rate and volume of rape
summary:
Campaigners argued at the Court of Appeal that the CPS had become more hesitant in prosecuting serious sexual assaultsThe Court of Appeal has backed the Crown Prosecution Service over its policy on sexual assault cases, rejecting claims that a shift in approach had effectively “legalised rape”.

title: Justine McCarthy: Society looked away as children were raped
text:
During the 23 years when James O’Reilly was starving, beating and raping his daughters and his younger sister, Ireland’s dirty little secret of child sexual abuse refused to stay silent any longer. When the horror stories began exploding, they shook the country out of its see-no-evil slumber — or so we thought. There were landmark court trials, state investigations and reams of reports recommending reforms. A new government department for children was established and a referendum was passed to enshrine their constitutional rights. As far back as 1994, Albert Reynolds’s government collapsed over the case of Brendan Smyth, a rampaging paedophile priest.

Throughout it all, O’Reilly kept brutalising his own flesh and blood. He abused his eldest daughter when she was just four years old,
summary:
During the 23 years when James O’Reilly was starving, beating and raping his daughters and his younger sister, Ireland’s dirty little secret of child sexual abuse refused to stay silent any longer.
When the horror stories began exploding, they shook the country out of its see-no-evil slumber — or so we thought.
There were landmark court trials, state investigations and reams of reports recommending reforms.
A new government department for children was established and a referendum was passed to enshrine their constitutional rights.
As far back as 1994, Albert Reynolds’s government collapsed over the case of Brendan Smyth, a rampaging paedophile priest.

title: Violence against women is still not taken seriously
text:
Dame Cressida Dick, commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, has announced Project Vigilant under which undercover police officers will be placed in nightclubs across England and Wales. This project comes as a direct response to both the tragic case of Sarah Everard, and a UN survey which reported that 86 per cent of women in the UK between the ages of 18-24 had been sexually harassed. It is hoped that this initiative will reduce male violence towards women.

Project Vigilant has been criticised on several levels, not least because sexual harassment is not limited to nightclubs, and 90 per cent of assaults are committed by people who women already know. A handful of police officers in a nightclub just won’t do it. Education of men from
summary:
Dame Cressida Dick, commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, has announced Project Vigilant under which undercover police officers will be placed in nightclubs across England and Wales.
This project comes as a direct response to both the tragic case of Sarah Everard, and a UN survey which reported that 86 per cent of women in the UK between the ages of 18-24 had been sexually harassed.
It is hoped that this initiative will reduce male violence towards women.
Project Vigilant has been criticised on several levels, not least because sexual harassment is not limited to nightclubs, and 90 per cent of assaults are committed by people who women already know.
A handful of police officers in a nightclub just won’t do it.

title: Everyone’s Invited: Universities ordered to get tough on sexual harassment
text:
Nicola Dandridge said she was still hearing of “worrying cases that have not been properly addressed”

Universities must take action urgently to tackle sexual misconduct, the Office for Students has said, after finding examples of “worrying” cases that have not been addressed.

The regulator has published a statement of expectations for universities to follow to make the process easier and fairer for students reporting sexual misconduct or harassment.

Sponsored

It includes providing training to staff and students to raise awareness of harassment and abuse, including consent courses and bystander training to encourage students and staff to intervene.

Nicola Dandridge, chief executive of the Office for Students, said that “students continue to report worrying cases that have not been properly addressed by their university or college”.

Last week the website Everyone’s Invited named more than 100 universities where students had submitted testimonies of
