title: MeToo comes to Cairo as sons of business elite arrested for rape
text:
The alleged gang rape is said to have taken place at the Fairmont Nile City Hotel in Cairo

Egypt’s public prosecutor has issued arrest warrants for a group of young men alleged to have filmed themselves gang-raping a young woman in a five-star Cairo hotel.

Reports of the incident have surfaced on social media this year, six years after it allegedly took place. The pictures have prompted outrage at the behaviour of Egypt’s elite, and at the impunity they appeared to expect. The men were said to have inscribed their initials on the woman’s back, and to have threatened her with public shaming if she reported them.

Sponsored

The case has re-energised a MeToo campaign that had already led to the arrest of a former student at the American University of Cairo, Egypt’s most renowned college. He was accused of rape and serial harassment
summary:
The alleged gang rape is said to have taken place at the Fairmont Nile City Hotel in CairoEgypt’s public prosecutor has issued arrest warrants for a group of young men alleged to have filmed themselves gang-raping a young woman in a five-star Cairo hotel.
Reports of the incident have surfaced on social media this year, six years after it allegedly took place.
The pictures have prompted outrage at the behaviour of Egypt’s elite, and at the impunity they appeared to expect.
The men were said to have inscribed their initials on the woman’s back, and to have threatened her with public shaming if she reported them.

title: Marina O’Loughlin reviews The Bridge Arms pub in Kent
text:
A fat, vibrating bee follows me into the Bridge Arms when I go for a sneak peek at this old pub’s interior refurb. It’s that sort of place — bees and flowers and nooks and beams, every fantasy country pub cliché made flesh. And I’m wallowing in it.

Prior to this I’ve done some other wallowing. In a puffy potato flatbread, a whisper of char from the wood grill, dotted with tiny acidulated petals of pearl onion, blobs of caramelised onion puree, tiny fresh herb leaves, suave rapeseed — so pretty, so delicate, it looks as if Tinker Bell branched out into pizza delivery. It’s under the menu’s “snacks” section but comes across as intricate and as labour-intensive as the main dishes. And — less
summary:
A fat, vibrating bee follows me into the Bridge Arms when I go for a sneak peek at this old pub’s interior refurb.
It’s that sort of place — bees and flowers and nooks and beams, every fantasy country pub cliché made flesh.
And I’m wallowing in it.
Prior to this I’ve done some other wallowing.
It’s under the menu’s “snacks” section but comes across as intricate and as labour-intensive as the main dishes.

title: Alex Renton on exposing transatlantic slave traders – in his own family
text:
Anyone attempting to discuss Britain’s historic involvement in the transatlantic slave trade, in which we sent some three million Africans in shackles across the ocean, faces a wall of whataboutery and deflection. I’ve recently attempted to spark conversation with my book Empireland and have met furious resistance, with people objecting even to discussing the history on the grounds that Spain/Portugal did it first, that France/Belgium did it more brutally, that slavery had a long history predating the British Empire with the Greeks/Romans/Ottomans/Mughals /Americans/Brazilians/Cubans all taking slaves, that the awfulness was counterbalanced by the good that Empire did, that Africans are ultimately to blame as they did the enslaving, that the Irish/British working classes actually had it worse, that it’s more important to focus on the

Sponsored

title: Effect of a historic conviction for rape in a foreign country
text:
Queen’s Bench Division

Published June 17, 2020

Regina (Halabi) v Crown Court at Southwark

Before Lord Justice Haddon-Cave and Mr Justice Holgate

[2020] EWHC 1053 (Admin)

Judgment May 1, 2020

The automatic imposition of notification requirements on a person who had been convicted of sexual offences in a foreign country, many years earlier, without a proportionality assessment or consideration of his individual circumstances, did not constitute a disproportionate interference with his right to respect for private and family life.

text:
Wesley Streete attacked Keeley Bunker, who had trusted him to get her home

A man has been convicted of raping and murdering his childhood friend who had trusted him to walk her home.

Wesley Streete, 20, attacked and killed Keeley Bunker after she told a worried friend: “I’ve got Wes. Wes will walk me back, it’ll be fine.” She had been out celebrating her 20th birthday at a gig in Birmingham on September 19 last year before returning by taxi to Tamworth, Staffordshire.

title: Row grows over failure to suspend Tory MP accused of rape
text:
The former minister was questioned at an east London police station after allegations made by a former parliamentary aide

The Conservative Party is under mounting pressure to suspend a senior MP who has been arrested on suspicion of raping a former parliamentary aide, after the alleged victim said she was devastated that the action had not been taken.

Some Tory MPs have privately expressed dismay at the decision made by Mark Spencer, the chief whip, not to take action against the MP until the police investigation has concluded.

Sponsored

One former Conservative minister said their colleague should “of course” be suspended from the whip pending the outcome of the police investigation. “Whether an MP has the whip or not is totally irrelevant during recess,” they said. “That, and consistency, are both arguments for suspension.”

A female Conservative MP said she was “shocked” by the allegations

text:
The MP agreed not to return to Westminster until police reached a decision

A Conservative MP who was accused of rape, sexual assault and coercive control is free to return to parliament after police confirmed they had dropped their investigation into him.

title: Chinese police ‘routinely spy on British visitors’
text:
British visitors to China are being routinely spied on by the country’s police, according to a leaked database that has been handed to MI5.

A Chinese police security watchlist contains the names of 150 British citizens who have travelled to Shanghai for business or leisure.

Sponsored

The security database stored data on their dates of birth, passport numbers and their points of entry and exit.

Among them were British government officials, businessmen and even tourists, according to a leak of the watchlist obtained by a cyber-security consultancy, which passed its findings to The Daily Telegraph. They appear alongside other international visitors.

The database also has files on 7,600 Uighur Muslims in Shanghai who are blacklisted on the watchlist as “terrorists” and criminals for alleged offences
summary:
British visitors to China are being routinely spied on by the country’s police, according to a leaked database that has been handed to MI5.
A Chinese police security watchlist contains the names of 150 British citizens who have travelled to Shanghai for business or leisure.
SponsoredThe security database stored data on their dates of birth, passport numbers and their points of entry and exit.
Among them were British government officials, businessmen and even tourists, according to a leak of the watchlist obtained by a cyber-security consultancy, which passed its findings to The Daily Telegraph.
The database also has files on 7,600 Uighur Muslims in Shanghai who are blacklisted on the watchlist as “terrorists” and criminals for alleged offences

title: Promising Young Woman review — a masterly tale of vengeance
text:
★★★★☆

From the opening electronic tinkle of the pop-dance tune Boys by Charli XCX, over neon-lit businessmen dancing badly in a subterranean nightclub, the intent of Promising Young Woman is precisely revealed. “I need that bad boy to do me right on a Friday/ And I need that good one to wake me up on a Sunday,” squeaks the song as these would-be masters of the universe writhe clumsily among themselves while one irate alpha at the bar launches the narrative with the movie’s first aggressive, and telling, line of dialogue: “F*** her.”

This is a film about misogyny. It’s the story of a rape and a suicide and a life upturned. But it’s also a movie that crackles and fizzes with style and wit
summary:

“I need that bad boy to do me right on a Friday/ And I need that good one to wake me up on a Sunday,” squeaks the song as these would-be masters of the universe writhe clumsily among themselves while one irate alpha at the bar launches the narrative with the movie’s first aggressive, and telling, line of dialogue: “F*** her.”This is a film about misogyny.

title: Staff fears as bail is lifted for Tory MP rape suspect
text:
Trade unions representing staff in parliament have raised objections to the MP’s presence in Westminster

Parliamentary staff, trade unions and the Labour Party have called for guarantees that an MP arrested in the summer will not be allowed into Westminster after his bail conditions were lifted.

The unnamed Conservative MP, a former minister in his 50s, was arrested in August on suspicion of rape, sexual assault and assault. He remains under investigation and entered a voluntary agreement with the Commons Speaker and the chief whip not to attend parliament for the period of his police bail.

title: Rape victims may be denied justice by courts backlog
text:
Lawyers said delays in bringing cases to court will have a serious impact on the reliability of evidence

Rape and other crimes involving sexual violence are being made more difficult to prosecute by the huge delays in jury trials caused by the pandemic.

Victims’ groups fear that some women who have waited years for justice will drop proceedings after being told that their cases have been postponed either indefinitely or for many months.

Sponsored

Witness testimony, meanwhile, will become less reliable as the time between alleged offence and court date lengthens, according to lawyers.

Some defendants have received a lighter sentence after deciding to plead guilty and avoid going to trial.

Osman Basri, 47, a convicted sex offender, was sentenced to only 10 months in prison at Wood Green crown court, north London, in July, after admitting stalking with intent to cause distress. The
summary:
Lawyers said delays in bringing cases to court will have a serious impact on the reliability of evidenceRape and other crimes involving sexual violence are being made more difficult to prosecute by the huge delays in jury trials caused by the pandemic.
Victims’ groups fear that some women who have waited years for justice will drop proceedings after being told that their cases have been postponed either indefinitely or for many months.
SponsoredWitness testimony, meanwhile, will become less reliable as the time between alleged offence and court date lengthens, according to lawyers.
Some defendants have received a lighter sentence after deciding to plead guilty and avoid going to trial.
Osman Basri, 47, a convicted sex offender, was sentenced to only 10 months in prison at Wood Green crown court, north London, in July, after admitting stalking with intent to cause distress.

text:
Mary McLaughlin was found dead at her home in Glasgow in 1984

The “friendly and trusting” nature of a woman strangled in her own flat ultimately brought about her death, a court has been told.

Mary McLaughlin, 58, a mother of 11, was found dead at her home in Partick in Glasgow’s west end in October 1984 after enjoying a night out at bars playing dominoes, the High Court in Glasgow has heard.

Graham McGill, 59, denies murdering her and fastening a belt from her dressing gown around her throat with intent to rape on September 26 or 27 of that year.

title: You think British men are bad — try Aussies
text:
While young women in Britain have been mounting protests against misogyny and sexual assault, thousands of Australian women have joined rallies demanding a more robust response to harassment and assault — especially in parliament. I’m not surprised.

As an Aussie, I totally understand the reason for Antipodean female outrage. The catalogue of sexist behaviour is piling up, particularly in politics. Last month Brittany Higgins, a former ministerial press officer, claimed that she had been raped by a colleague in the office of the woman who is now Australia’s defence minister. Separately, a senior cabinet minister, the attorney-general Christian Porter, 50, has taken mental health leave after being accused of raping a teenager more than 30 years ago. title: Gardaí appeal for information on mother and baby home criminal acts
text:
Catherine Corless, the woman who uncovered the Tuam mother and baby home scandal, said it would be fantastic if survivors contacted gardaí and people were held to account for their actions

Gardaí yesterday issued an appeal urging anyone who knows of criminal acts which took place in the state’s mother and baby homes to contact them.

The decision to begin an inquiry was made after a review of the 2,800-page report by the commission of investigation, published in January, which concluded that 9,000 children died in the homes where unmarried women were sent to deliver their babies in secret.

Sponsored

About 56,000 people, including girls as young as 12, were sent to the institutions where some 57,000 children were born. The homes were run by religious organisations but overseen by the state.

Drew Harris, the garda commissioner, yesterday told a meeting of the Policing Authority that he believed an investigation was warranted having read the stories published

title: Rape victims criticise not proven verdict
text:
Plans to scrap the “not proven” verdict from Scottish courts are being supported by rape victims who believe attackers are more likely to be acquitted under the present system.

The 17th-century verdict has been found to cause confusion among modern jurors who fail to understand how it is distinct from “not guilty”.

Sponsored

It was coined “the bastard verdict” by Sir Walter Scott. Scotland is the only country in Europe to have a third verdict in criminal trials.

Nicola Sturgeon has said it will be reviewed as the conviction rate for rape and sexual assault is “shamefully low”.

A Scottish government study found in 2019 the verdict caused “inconsistency and confusion” among jurors, and Rape Crisis Scotland believes that 30 per cent of acquittals in rape
summary:

title: Rape prosecutions are at a record low
text:
Dame Vera Baird said that little was being done to reverse a “catastrophic” decline in rape prosecutions

Rape is in effect being decriminalised as prosecutions reach a record low, the victims’ commissioner says in a report publihsed today.

Predatory rapists are reoffending because they know they are unlikely to be prosecuted, Dame Vera Baird says.

Sponsored

The commissioner, who represents the interests of victims and witnesses to crime, says that little was being done to reverse a “catastrophic” decline in rape prosecutions in recent years. “In effect, what we are witnessing is the decriminalisation of rape. title: ‘Bullying’ physio is jailed for 9 years for rape and assaults
text:
Derek Adams was also found guilty of physically assaulting four women and two children at the High Court in Edinburgh

A physiotherapist who committed a series of sex attacks on four women during a catalogue of violence has been jailed for nine years.

Derek Adams carried out the assaults against adult women and children over more than 20 years.

title: Rape victims must relive trauma after police lose interviews
text:
At least 17 interviews by south Wales police at Cardiff Royal Infirmary have been lost

Victims of rape and serious sexual assault in south Wales will have to relive their trauma in video interviews with the police because a digital recording system was incorrectly installed by a private company.

At least 17 interviews by South Wales police have been lost after an IT system was installed to record video and sound at Cardiff Royal Infirmary.

Sponsored

The force said it “understands this has affected six victims”. The installation was carried out by Capita, the outsourcing company, at the end of last month, but the fault, which meant that no sound was recorded and the video froze after several minutes, was not noticed by police until 17 interviews had taken place.

Last week officers were told not to use the new equipment
summary:

title: Jack was a force for good, says mother of Fishmongers’ Hall terror victim
text:
Usman Khan sat next to Saskia Jones at the opening speeches of the conference. During a break Khan went into a lavatory cubicle and taped knives to his hands. He emerged and stabbed Merritt, above, before killing Jones

A Cambridge graduate sat at a table with a convicted terrorist shortly before he stabbed her to death at a prisoner rehabilitation conference, an inquest heard today.

Saskia Jones was photographed one seat away from Usman Khan at the conference held at Fishmongers’ Hall in the City of London in November 2019.

Sponsored

Khan killed Jones and Jack Merritt, who had also worked at Cambridge University’s Learning Together prisoner rehabilitation programme.

Well-wishers laid tributes to the victims at London Bridge after the attack PETER SUMMERS/GETTY IMAGES

Detective Chief Inspector Dan Brown, of the Metropolitan Police’s counterterrorism command said Khan had been released from prison 12 months earlier, having served eight years for planning jihadist terror camps.

Khan taped two knives to his gloves in a cubicle of the lavatories at Fishmongers’ Hall during a lunch break. He stabbed Merritt 12 times
summary:
Usman Khan sat next to Saskia Jones at the opening speeches of the conference.
Saskia Jones was photographed one seat away from Usman Khan at the conference held at Fishmongers’ Hall in the City of London in November 2019.

title: Regulations prevent tour operator from avoiding liability for rape of holidaymaker by hotel employee
text:
Court of Justice of the European Union

Published April 6, 2021

X v Kuoni Travel Ltd

Before A Prechal (Rapporteur), president of the chamber, and Judges N Wahl, F Biltgen, L S Rossi and J Passer

Advocate General M Szpunar

(Case C‑578/19)

Judgment March 18, 2021

An employee of a supplier of services performing duties under a package holiday contract, concluded between the holiday organiser and a consumer and governed by Council Directive 90/314/EEC on package travel, package holidays and package tours, could not be regarded as the “supplier of services” for the purposes of article 5(2) of the directive, in the event of improper or non-performance of the contractual obligations, which was the result of the actions of the employee.

However, since those actions

title: We’re girls, not guys: pupils urged to protest against ‘sexist’ language
text:
Children at a state primary school have been taught to hold up posters rejecting the use of “sexist” language by teachers.

Words and phrases banned at Anderton Park primary in Birmingham include “let’s go, guys”, “man up”, “grow a pair” and even “boys and girls”. The training starts in the nursery with children as young as three.

Sponsored

Pupils who challenge sexist language, such as calling an assertive girl “bossy” or saying “boys don’t cry”, are rewarded with a certificate. Children also monitor their reading books and worksheets for sexist stereotypes. Two certificates are handed out in each class weekly to pupils who come up with the most telling examples.

title: Nudes, porn, abuse – the toxic culture in UK classrooms
text:
One of the many unexpected benefits of home schooling, Sophie found, was being able to go up the stairs in peace. There was no upskirting. No one was competing for photos of her knickers – the more intimate the shot, the better the trophy to share around Whatsapp groups and the more lad points to win among their friends.

There were plenty of other things she didn’t miss about Highgate, the private school in north London where, as a 13-year-old, teachers measured her skirt with a ruler, and boys dominated the common room with loud boasts of “smashing” girls and “banging” girls and “thrusting” into their drunken mouths, while the quiet ones laughed along.

text:
An Australian state MP has resigned after he sent “disgusting” phone messages to a sex worker during parliamentary question time.

Michael Johnsen, 55, a member of the centre-right National Party, stood down after it emerged that he sent a woman a string of texts and a video while he was sitting in the New South Wales parliament in Sydney. In one he offered her AS$1,000 (£550) to have sex in his office in Parliament House.

title: Rape normal at private school, says dossier of 170 testimonies
text:
Highgate School in north London asked a victim of sexual assault to sign a non-disclosure agreement, according to one student

One of the country’s leading private schools has been accused of upholding a “rape culture” after governors were sent a dossier containing 170 testimonies of sexual abuse and harassment.

Former pupils at Highgate School, whose alumni include Sir John Betjeman and Michael Mansfield QC, alleged that pastoral staff repeatedly failed to act on accusations and one pupil attempted suicide after being raped by a fellow classmate.

Sponsored

The school, which charges fees of £21,600 a year, asked a victim of sexual assault to sign a non-disclosure agreement, according to one pupil, and was allegedly told by a staff member to consider “how legal ramifications for his actions might hurt his feelings”.

A pupil said she had been raped by one boy, sexually assaulted by two more

title: Nawal El Saadawi obituary
text:
Nawal El Saadawi was six years old when she was circumcised. She cried for her mother until she saw her standing with her aunts, watching and smiling. “Since I was a child that deep wound left in my body never healed,” she wrote long after the traumatic event.

Other episodes in her childhood outraged her too. She was furious when her grandmother declared that “a boy is worth 15 girls at least . . . girls are a blight” and angry at her parents’ favouritism towards her older brother. When told at school that she had to use her father’s family name, not her mother’s, she became upset again. Aged seven, she wrote a letter to God in which she stated: “If you are not

★★★

Amazon et al

Neil Marshall, 15, 100min

Quentin Tarantino has a great riff on what he calls “uptight” action movies — revenge movies that don’t quite have the stomach for revenge, like the fight on the boat at the end of Patriot Games, in which Sean Bean helpfully falls on an anchor to save Harrison Ford the job of killing him. “The minute you kill your bad guy by having him fall on something, you should go to movie jail,” Tarantino said. “You’ve broken the law of good cinema.”

title: Mugabe’s violent youth militia could be ready to march again
text:
A national youth service programme that spawned a violent militia that carried out some of the worst excesses of Robert Mugabe’s rule in Zimbabwe is to be revived.

Kirsty Coventry, 37, the minister of youth and the only white person in the government, proposed its resurrection to instil patriotism and loyalty among people aged 18 to 35, according to a cabinet briefing note. It has provoked fears that the unit is being readied before a bloody general election in 2023 and has led to fresh criticism of Coventry, a retired Olympic swimmer. Last year she was criticised for taking a lease on a prized farm that was seized during Mugabe’s catastrophic land grab.

Lawyers representing the director of public prosecutions (DPP) are unhappy that a woman who was a victim of rape as a child is unable to identify herself due to a recent decision by the Court of Appeal.

Due to a challenge taken by the DPP itself, the court ruled in October that the Children Act 2001 prevents the identification of child victims of crime even after they have died or become adults.

title: Man who raped sister and daughters jailed for 20 years
text:
A man has been jailed for 20 years for the repeated rape and sexual abuse of his younger sister and seven daughters over 23 years.

From 1977 to 2000 James O’Reilly, 75, subjected the young girls to sexual abuse as well as physical beatings, starvation and degradation, the Central Criminal Court was told yesterday.

Sponsored

O’Reilly, of Thurles, Co Tipperary, denied 81 charges of rape and sexual abuse. Last December, after a five-week trial, a jury convicted him of 58 counts of rape and nine charges of sexual assault.

O’Reilly’s rape of one daughter caused her to become pregnant in late 1988. He continued to rape her during the pregnancy.

At the time he told his daughter to allege she had been raped by another man.
summary:
A man has been jailed for 20 years for the repeated rape and sexual abuse of his younger sister and seven daughters over 23 years.

title: Thousands of women march for equality after Australia rape claim
text:
Tens of thousands of women rallied in cities and towns across Australia demanding greater protection from sexual abuse and harassment after rape allegations that have forced two cabinet ministers to stand aside.

The protests were spurred by recent claims of sexual assault involving a senior cabinet minister and an unrelated allegation of rape inside a minister’s office at the Australian parliament.

Sponsored

Outside the national parliament in the capital, Canberra, thousands were addressed by Brittany Higgins, a former parliamentary assistant, who alleged she was raped in a minister’s office by a co-worker. Higgins had been described as a “lying cow” by Linda Reynolds, the defence minister. Reynolds, who has since taken leave of absence from her job, apologised and last week agreed to pay damages for
summary:
Tens of thousands of women rallied in cities and towns across Australia demanding greater protection from sexual abuse and harassment after rape allegations that have forced two cabinet ministers to stand aside.
The protests were spurred by recent claims of sexual assault involving a senior cabinet minister and an unrelated allegation of rape inside a minister’s office at the Australian parliament.

title: Student’s rape complaint ‘dismissed by Oxford’
text:
Oxford University is at the centre of a rape scandal after a female member of its rowing club claimed she was sexually assaulted by one of the university’s top athletes.

The woman reported the allegation to Sir John Bell, the esteemed scientist who advises the government on Covid-19 and sits on the women’s boat club’s executive committee, but claimed that he diminished her allegation.

Sponsored

A disciplinary officer informed her that it could not take action because she had not reported the matter to police, even though her alleged attacker had written her a letter apologising for having “crossed that boundary”.

title: Turkish-backed militias rape and torture Kurds
text:
Militiamen loyal to Ankara have been in the vanguard of all its Syrian offensives<cpi:div>

Turkish-backed militias fighting the Assad regime in Syria are committing war crimes against Kurdish civilians, including rape and torture, the UN has said.

The Commission of Inquiry on Syria said it has “reasonable grounds to believe” that forces funded and trained by Ankara have committed pillage, hostage-taking, rape and torture, possibly with the knowledge of Turkish forces present in the area.

Sponsored

Russia, along with Iran, supports President Assad’s forces while Turkey backs some of the rebel groups which have been trying to oust him in a complex civil war that has dragged on for more than nine years. Turkish forces seized control of the border town of Ras al-Ain last year in an effort to push back Syrian Kurdish YPG fighters, which Ankara views

title: Man who lied about vasectomy has rape conviction quashed
text:
Jason Lawrence, 55, was convicted of rape after he assured a woman he met online in 2014 that he had undergone a vasectomy but she became pregnant

The rape conviction of a man who lied about his vasectomy has been quashed in a ruling that said dishonesty about fertility did not negate a woman’s earlier consent to sex.

The judgment, which cited the Swedish case over rape allegations levelled against Julian Assange, the Wikileaks founder, could have widespread implications and raise concern among women’s rights campaigners.

Sponsored

Jason Lawrance, 55, was convicted of rape after meeting a woman online in 2014. Before having sex he had told her he had had a vasectomy but the next day texted her: “I have a confession. I’m still fertile. Sorry.”

The woman became pregnant, had an abortion and accused him of rape.

Before his trial, his lawyers applied to have the case dismissed on the basis
summary:
Jason Lawrence, 55, was convicted of rape after he assured a woman he met online in 2014 that he had undergone a vasectomy but she became pregnantThe rape conviction of a man who lied about his vasectomy has been quashed in a ruling that said dishonesty about fertility did not negate a woman’s earlier consent to sex.
The judgment, which cited the Swedish case over rape allegations levelled against Julian Assange, the Wikileaks founder, could have widespread implications and raise concern among women’s rights campaigners.
SponsoredJason Lawrance, 55, was convicted of rape after meeting a woman online in 2014.
Before having sex he had told her he had had a vasectomy but the next day texted her: “I have a confession.
Sorry.”The woman became pregnant, had an abortion and accused him of rape.

title: Jean-Luc Brunel, the catwalk king who ‘raped and pimped out models to Jeffrey Epstein’
text:
Thysia Huisman first read the rumour on social media. When her lawyer called to tell her it was true, she burst into tears.

It was Wednesday. Jean-Luc Brunel, once a key player in the modelling world, had been arrested as he was about to board a flight from Paris to Senegal.

Sponsored

Huisman, a former model, alleges that he raped her when she was a teenage ingenue. She is not alone. Brunel, 74, a former close associate of Jeffrey Epstein, faces allegations that he used his position in the fashion industry to rape and sexually assault women, including minors, as well as trafficking girls across the world for the US paedophile. Brunel denies the allegations.

The Paris prosecutor’s office said yesterday that Brunel had been remanded
summary:
Thysia Huisman first read the rumour on social media.
When her lawyer called to tell her it was true, she burst into tears.
Jean-Luc Brunel, once a key player in the modelling world, had been arrested as he was about to board a flight from Paris to Senegal.

title: Fiction reviews — Lean Fall Stand; Great Circle; The Performance
text:
4th Estate £14.99 pp288

A life-changing accident in the Antarctic kicks off the Reservoir 13 author’s latest novel

Sponsored

Jon McGregor’s novels usually revolve around community. His Booker-shortlisted debut, If Nobody Speaks of Remarkable Things (2002), was a panorama of an inner-city street; So Many Ways to Begin (2006) told the story of a museum curator and local history buff in Coventry; and Reservoir 13, which won the Costa novel award in 2017, depicted everyday life in a rural village in the Peak District. His fifth novel, Lean Fall Stand, is ostensibly very different — a tale of personal adversity rather than a communal tableau — but it still has a social dimension.

Its protagonist, Robert “Doc” Wright, an Antarctic expedition guide, gets caught

title: Abingdon School pupil expelled for online rape threats
text:
The 15-year-old’s parents have argued that Abingdon School had no right to invade a child’s life on social media

A teenager who was expelled from a top private school for sending antisemitic images and rape threats online had his privacy invaded, his parents have claimed as they vowed to fight his expulsion.

The 15-year-old at Abingdon School in Oxfordshire sent a series of “highly offensive” jokes including a picture of three people dressed as Nazi soldiers with the caption “Happy Birthday”, a disciplinary hearing was told.

Sponsored

He was said to have sent the image to another Abingdon student, who comes from a Jewish family, over Snapchat.

In another incident the schoolboy allegedly made a rape threat in a video on TikTok. A female user on the app posted a clip of herself removing a balaclava with the caption “what would you do if I

title: Student rape victim wrote essay to understand attack
text:
William Muir was found guilty of three rapes involving the student and a 28-year-old woman at the High Court in Edinburgh

A student wrote a personal thesis on the definition of consent to work out whether she had been raped by a boyfriend, a court has been told.

When she completed her PhD research the 30-year-old woman concluded that the verbal and physical abuse to which William Muir subjected her meant that she had not willingly consented to sex with him.

Sponsored

She told a court that she had been “playing a character” in an attempt to defuse an angry row with Muir and that character would have been OK in having sex with him. However, she said that looking back on the experience she realised that she had not freely consented to intercourse.

The jury took five and a half hours to find Muir, 32, guilty
summary:
William Muir was found guilty of three rapes involving the student and a 28-year-old woman at the High Court in EdinburghA student wrote a personal thesis on the definition of consent to work out whether she had been raped by a boyfriend, a court has been told.
When she completed her PhD research the 30-year-old woman concluded that the verbal and physical abuse to which William Muir subjected her meant that she had not willingly consented to sex with him.

title: Education’s MeToo moment must be met with policy change
text:
I was 17 when the MeToo movement really got moving. Now I’m 21, and I can’t say it’s done much to change my life as a young woman in Britain: I’ve still been harassed at work and groped in nightclubs, as have almost all of my friends. So when Chief Constable Simon Bailey told The Times yesterday that the ongoing spate of private school sex abuse revelations is a “MeToo” moment for the education sector, I had to wonder what he meant.

In some ways, the comparison is apt. MeToo gained momentum through personal testimonies shared on Twitter, much in the same way that Everyone’s Invited has provided a virtual space for girls harassed at school to tell their stories. “Instagram justice” has changed who
summary:
I was 17 when the MeToo movement really got moving.
Now I’m 21, and I can’t say it’s done much to change my life as a young woman in Britain: I’ve still been harassed at work and groped in nightclubs, as have almost all of my friends.
So when Chief Constable Simon Bailey told The Times yesterday that the ongoing spate of private school sex abuse revelations is a “MeToo” moment for the education sector, I had to wonder what he meant.
In some ways, the comparison is apt.
MeToo gained momentum through personal testimonies shared on Twitter, much in the same way that Everyone’s Invited has provided a virtual space for girls harassed at school to tell their stories.

title: Ex-No 10 aide Mark Adams who raped teenager at Edinburgh Festival loses OBE
text:
Mark Adams was jailed for seven years for attacking the woman in a camper van. He raped another woman at his house in 2015

A former aide to Tony Blair and John Major has been stripped of his OBE after he was jailed for raping a teenager during the Edinburgh Festival.

Mark Adams, 57, spent six years in Downing Street as a private secretary to both prime ministers and received the honour in 1997 for services to public life. Adams, who described himself as an “independent political consultant, media commentator and general business adviser”, was later exposed as a sexual predator.

Sponsored

In March last year the High Court in Glasgow was told that a 19-year-old woman woke to find Adams raping her in the back of his camper van in Edinburgh in August 2017. He was jailed for seven years. He was already serving seven years for raping
summary:

He raped another woman at his house in 2015A former aide to Tony Blair and John Major has been stripped of his OBE after he was jailed for raping a teenager during the Edinburgh Festival.
Mark Adams, 57, spent six years in Downing Street as a private secretary to both prime ministers and received the honour in 1997 for services to public life.
Adams, who described himself as an “independent political consultant, media commentator and general business adviser”, was later exposed as a sexual predator.

title: Former Ros na Rún actor Garrett Phillips loses appeal against rape conviction
text:
The Court of Appeal has rejected an appeal by a former Ros na Rún actor against his conviction for the rape of a young woman in Galway over five years ago.

The three-judge court dismissed a plea by lawyers for Garrett Phillips that his legal team during his trial in April 2018 should have been allowed to cross-examine the victim about sexual activity with her boyfriend about a week before the offence.

Sponsored

Phillips, 48, a father of two of St Mary’s Terrace, Taylor’s Hill, Galway, was convicted by a 11-1 majority verdict of a single charge of raping a 20-year-old woman on the outskirts of Galway city on November 5, 2015 following a four-day trial at the central criminal court in Dublin. He was sentenced
summary:
The Court of Appeal has rejected an appeal by a former Ros na Rún actor against his conviction for the rape of a young woman in Galway over five years ago.
The three-judge court dismissed a plea by lawyers for Garrett Phillips that his legal team during his trial in April 2018 should have been allowed to cross-examine the victim about sexual activity with her boyfriend about a week before the offence.

title: Australian MPs study dossier of rape allegations against minister
text:
There is speculation that Scott Morrison, Australia’s prime minister, will be forced into an imminent cabinet reshuffle

A sexual abuse scandal embroiling Australia’s government has intensified after MPs received a 31-page dossier outlining rape allegations against an unidentified serving minister.

The woman, who accused the minister of raping her as a teenager before he won a seat in parliament, reportedly left behind a cache of correspondence, including emails and letters, before she took her own life in Adelaide last year.

Sponsored

The allegation comes as Scott Morrison, Australia’s prime minister, struggles to manage public anger over his government’s handling of a young staffer’s allegation that she was raped by a colleague in the office of another minister and how women are treated within the parliamentary culture.

title: Coventry cult leader Rajinder Kalia accused of raping devotees
text:
Worshippers are allegedly indoctrinated to believe Rajinder Kalia is “an incarnation of God and or the divine”

A guru who claimed he was God on Earth has been accused of raping four devotees, according to court documents that appear to reveal an undetected cult in Coventry.

Rajinder Kalia is accused of exerting “undue influence” over young girls for three decades and allegedly using Baba Balak Nath, an obscure branch of Hinduism, for his own nefarious purposes.

Sponsored

Kalia, 65, is alleged to have groomed worshippers as young as four at the temple in Bell Green, Coventry, where devotees see him as “all-powerful, all-seeing and all-knowing” and are allegedly indoctrinated to believe he is “an incarnation of God and or the divine”.

Kalia was photographed wearing a crown and depicted as a deity in paintings

title: Eat! Perfect Thai curry recipes
text:
Curry fanatic Dan Toombs, 55, has spent two decades learning curry-house secrets and perfecting the recipes that have helped him to sell more than 250,000 books. Now he has decided to jump borders and reproduce the classic Thai takeaway and restaurant dishes he enjoys at his home in Yorkshire.

“Thai food is well known for its heat but there is much more to it than that. The recipes are a beautiful melody of sweet, sour and savoury,” he says.

He was introduced to Thai food at a young age, growing up in California, where there was a large Thai expat community.

Dan Toombs KRIS KIRKHAM

title: Yes! British men are the worst at everything
text:
It’s time to add barbecuing to the list of things that men shouldn’t do. That was the big news in The Times on Tuesday, with a page three headline that ran “TV chefs haul men over the barbecue coals”. While the same story in The Guardian was given a strong dash of the national self-loathing so flavoursome to readers of that august internationalist organ, with the headline “Are British barbecues the worst in the world?”

It was John Torode and Gregg Wallace who started it, those two tireless, young, black, non-hetero-normative campaigners against gammonism, who were in no way just doing a bit of harmless press ahead of the MasterChef final and trying to say something lively about a subject (home cooking) that has

title: Whitney Wolfe Herd: how Bumble made her the world’s youngest female self-made billionaire
text:
The first time I met Whitney Wolfe Herd, four years ago, Bumble HQ was a humble two-bedroom apartment in downtown Austin, Texas. A fresh-faced team of just 10 (with a further 20 in London, New York and Los Angeles), plus Wolfe Herd’s elderly golden labrador, Jack, were crammed into the tiny space, whose entire second bedroom was a storecupboard of bright yellow Bumble-branded merch. Wolfe Herd, then 27 and undeniably impressive – polished, passionate, articulate, driven – had founded the dating app that forces women to make the first move just two and a half years earlier. She had recently made the prestigious Forbes 30 Under 30 list, alongside actress Margot Robbie, bestselling author Emma Cline and Olympic gymnast Simone Biles.

title: Rape and a drugs death as 6,000 go to illegal parties
text:
A 20-year-old man died of a suspected drug overdose, a woman was raped and three people were stabbed during two illegal raves that attracted more than 6,000 people in Greater Manchester.

The 20-year-old man, who is thought to have died of a drug overdose, had attended a gathering of about 4,000 people at Daisy Nook Country Park in Droylsden, Greater Manchester police said. There were no further reported criminal incidents.

Sponsored

At the other rave, in Carrington, an 18-year-old woman was raped and men aged 18, 25 and 26 were hurt in separate stabbings. A 25-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

title: Meet Steve Huffman, co-founder of Reddit, the world’s most influential website
text:
The frenzy began slowly when a day trader using the alias DeepF***ingValue uploaded a screenshot depicting a single $53,000 investment in the ailing video games retailer GameStop.

He posted the evidence of his stock options purchase to the social media platform Reddit in September 2019 along with the message “YOLO” (you only live once). Specifically, he shared it on a Reddit forum called WallStreetBets, a raucous community of mostly amateur investors who swapped expletive-filled insults, cheered on each other’s triumphs and failures and proudly called themselves “degenerates”.

Sponsored

GameStop’s widely scorned shares were then worth about $4 each.

For the next 15 months the day trader built excitement around GameStop on Reddit, on Twitter and through his Roaring Kitty YouTube account, where he live streamed himself

title: Cleared of rape: man who was unaware he had sex while asleep
text:
A man has been acquitted of rape after a jury accepted his claim that he was unaware sex was taking place because he was asleep.

Darrell Swanson, 39, told jurors that he suffered from a rare psychological condition called sexsomnia which meant that he was having intercourse during the night without knowing it. Mr Swanson, from Dunfermline, Fife, had denied three historical rapes, two of a woman now aged 36 and one involving her younger sister, now 30.

During the trial at the High Court at Livingston, Ian Morrison, a consultant neurologist with NHS Tayside and a specialist in sleep medicine, supported Mr Swanson’s defence. He said: “It’s almost exclusively the case that there’s a lack of recall. Generally speaking patients do not recall. Some

A man has been acquitted of rape after a jury accepted his claim that he was unaware sex was taking place because he was asleep.
Darrell Swanson, 39, told jurors that he suffered from a rare psychological condition called sexsomnia which meant that he was having intercourse during the night without knowing it.

title: Torture U-turn is a boost to Britain’s standing
text:
I have lived in the UK for more than a decade, after fleeing torture and violence in my native country. I feel proud to have found safe haven and a new citizenship in the UK. I was honoured that the UK government appointed me as one of two Survivor Champions for the global Preventing Sexual Violence Initiative.

In recent months, however, to my dismay and the dismay of other torture survivors, the government seemed happy to go ahead with proposals which – astonishing though it feels to even write these words – paved the way for torture impunity.

Sponsored

Last week, the House of Lords voted by an overwhelming majority to amend the new Overseas Operations Bill to block the impunity proposals. Until yesterday afternoon, the
summary:
I have lived in the UK for more than a decade, after fleeing torture and violence in my native country.
I feel proud to have found safe haven and a new citizenship in the UK.
I was honoured that the UK government appointed me as one of two Survivor Champions for the global Preventing Sexual Violence Initiative.
In recent months, however, to my dismay and the dismay of other torture survivors, the government seemed happy to go ahead with proposals which – astonishing though it feels to even write these words – paved the way for torture impunity.
SponsoredLast week, the House of Lords voted by an overwhelming majority to amend the new Overseas Operations Bill to block the impunity proposals.

title: Exiled Bolivian former president Evo Morales accused of rape
text:
Evo Morales is accused of having a sexual relationship with a minor

The ousted Bolivian president Evo Morales has been accused of statutory rape and human trafficking by the country’s justice ministry.

Guido Melgar, the deputy justice minister, told a press conference in La Paz yesterday that his department had filed a criminal complaint against Mr Morales, 60, over his alleged sexual relationship with a minor.

title: Ulster’s Challenge is to show progress they’ve made
text:
Tonight is a big occasion for Ulster — a semi-final in Europe, a third straight cup tie against Premiership opposition on English soil. Fifteen years after they last won a trophy, this feels like a significant point in their journey.

Okay, so it’s the Challenge Cup and it is easy to sneer at European rugby’s secondary competition. Once known as the Parker Pen Challenge Cup, then the Amlin Cup, it hasn’t been able to attract a sponsor in recent years, which says something in itself. Too often, many English and French clubs use it as an opportunity to rest players before heading back into the more serious business of the Gallagher Premiership or Top 14.

title: Unmarried women no longer have to flee UAE if pregnant
text:
Unmarried women who become pregnant in the United Arab Emirates will no longer have to flee the country for an abortion or marry in the latest move by the Gulf state towards secularism.

Previously, unmarried women who became pregnant faced deportation or jail, with expatriates commonly flying abroad for a shotgun wedding, or opting for a termination in their home country.

Sponsored

Many low-paid workers who could not afford to leave, including maids who have been raped by their bosses, have been forced to give birth secretly and bring up their children hidden from authorities.

Children born to unmarried parents cannot obtain a birth certificate, and are not eligible for healthcare or education.

When the UAE announced social reforms in November, decriminalising alcohol and suicide,

Unmarried women who become pregnant in the United Arab Emirates will no longer have to flee the country for an abortion or marry in the latest move by the Gulf state towards secularism.

title: Conservative MP accused of rape ‘should volunteer’ to give up whip
text:
The alleged victim told The Times she was devastated that no action had been taken against the MP, who has been accused of coercing the woman into having sex with him

A former deputy chief whip has called on the senior MP arrested on suspicion of rape to give up the whip voluntarily while the claims against him are investigated.

Anne Milton, who supported the victims of the former MP Charlie Elphicke in securing his conviction last week for sexual assault, said: “Giving up the whip is a serious step. It would provide an appropriate way forward and should not be considered an admission of guilt.”

title: Escape to the Suffolk countryside
text:
It’s good to be free again, isn’t it? Even partially. I was giddy leaving the capital for Suffolk last weekend. Fresh air! The sea! Fish and chips! Better still — a pub garden that we didn’t have to book ahead. These days that’s enough to make you feel as if you’ve won the lottery.

We caught the last of the sunshine at the King’s Head in Laxfield, which is better known as the Low House, a 16th-century thatched pub run as a co-operative behind the village church. To my husband Rob’s delight, our (admittedly modest) round cost £3.50.

Sponsored

Yes it got chilly but, luckily, we had a fire pit to get back to — another frequent scorer in pandemic bingo — at Blyth Rise Stays,

title: Northern Ireland’s mother and baby homes traumatised rape and incest victims, says Arlene Foster
text:
Arlene Foster, the first minister, has received a report on the “victimisation” of women in the homes

Victims of rape and incest were put in homes for unmarried mothers and their children in Northern Ireland and victimised again, the first minister has said.

More than 10,500 women entered mother and baby homes over 68 years from 1922. The youngest was aged 12.

Sponsored

Arlene Foster said that the voices of survivors would be heard “loudly and clearly” in a “victim-centred” independent investigation ordered by Stormont ministers.

She added: “Children were raped or victims of incest then they were victimised again by being put into these homes. It was not their fault that they were raped or the victims of incest yet they were the ones who suffered and it appears to me that those who perpetrated the crime went scot-free.”

More than 10,500 women entered mother and baby homes over 68 years from 1922.

text:
Ghislaine Maxwell, who is accused of helping Jeffrey Epstein traffic young girls for sex, was arrested last July

Ghislaine Maxwell helped Jeffrey Epstein to repeatedly rape a Florida estate agent in front of her eight-year-old son, a lawsuit alleges.

The mother was also forced to have surgery to make her appear a virgin and was threatened to be fed to alligators if she did not keep quiet, it is claimed.

The allegations, among the most gruesome to date against the late financier and Maxwell, his associate and former girlfriend, are separate from two new criminal charges this week.

They come amid renewed pressure on the Duke of York to co-operate with US officials. The claims are alleged to have occurred between 2001 and 2008, when Prince Andrew was in contact with Epstein, a convicted sex offender.

title: US seeks allies for boycott of Beijing Winter Olympics in 2022
text:
Players from Tsinghua University and Renmin University of China play in a test event for the 2022 Winter Olympics

The United States is considering boycotting the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, a state department spokesman said yesterday amid mounting international criticism of China’s human rights abuses.

Ned Price said that the US was consulting with like-minded countries to determine how to proceed. It is understood that the British government has not been approached with any boycott proposal, although ministers have not ruled out the option.

Sponsored

Asked whether the Biden administration was considering a boycott with allies, Price said: “Part of our review of those Olympics and our thinking will involve close consultations with partners and allies around the world.

“We have consistently said when it comes to our concerns with the government in Beijing, including Beijing’s egregious human rights violations, its conduct of genocide
summary:

title: Coventry cult: I was told sex acts were worship, follower claims
text:
Rajinder Kalia is alleged to have used “undue influence” as the temple’s guru to sexually abuse worshippers and financially exploit devotees

For three decades the grand gates of the Baba Balak Nath temple in Coventry have appeared to protect little more than a place of Hindu worship.

Now the temple in the unassuming suburb of Bell Green is at the centre of a High Court claim that Rajinder Kalia, 65, used an obscure branch of Hinduism to hide what amounted to a personal cult hidden in plain sight.

Sponsored

The former draper and clerk from India is alleged to have used “undue influence” as the temple’s guru to sexually abuse worshippers and financially exploit devotees.

Kalia is showered with confetti and worshippers reach out to touch him and kiss his feet on the temple’s special occasions SWNS

The allegations were dismissed by the authorities in 2017. Six years earlier, two police community support officers from the West Midlands force were filmed accepting a cheque from Kalia’s business for £2,500.
summary:
Rajinder Kalia is alleged to have used “undue influence” as the temple’s guru to sexually abuse worshippers and financially exploit devoteesFor three decades the grand gates of the Baba Balak Nath temple in Coventry have appeared to protect little more than a place of Hindu worship.
Now the temple in the unassuming suburb of Bell Green is at the centre of a High Court claim that Rajinder Kalia, 65, used an obscure branch of Hinduism to hide what amounted to a personal cult hidden in plain sight.

title: IRA rape accuser criticises Guardian over Roy Greenslade
text:
The Guardian is reviewing articles by Roy Greenslade after his admission

The Guardian has launched a review of Roy Greenslade’s articles after it was accused of allowing him to question the credibility of a woman who accused an IRA member of raping her.

Greenslade, 74, resigned as a lecturer in journalism ethics at City University of London on Monday after confessing to supporting IRA violence.

Sponsored

The newspaper’s investigation follows a complaint from Máiría Cahill, a politician and member of a prominent republican family who waived anonymity to allege that she was raped by a senior IRA figure as a teenager.

Greenslade, a former Daily Mirror editor, wrote several articles on the Cahill case for The Guardian while employed as its media commentator.

In one piece in 2014 he criticised a BBC documentary that exposed her ordeal
summary:
The Guardian is reviewing articles by Roy Greenslade after his admissionThe Guardian has launched a review of Roy Greenslade’s articles after it was accused of allowing him to question the credibility of a woman who accused an IRA member of raping her.

title: Scott Morrison changes view on rape after talking to wife
text:
Scott Morrison said his wife told him: “You have to think about this as a father first”

The Australian prime minister has been moved by a discussion with his wife to apologise for the way that a staff member’s rape allegation was dealt with.

Scott Morrison ordered reviews into the complaints process and the treatment of women in parliament after Brittany Higgins, 26, gave a TV interview on Monday about having been attacked.

Sponsored

Morrison said speaking with his wife, Jenny, overnight had changed his perspective. The couple have two young daughters. “Jenny has a way of clarifying things,” he said. “She always has.”

Brittany Higgins’s claims prompted the comments

title: Tough Irish rape law to raise threshold for consent
text:
Victims of sexual and domestic violence are the focus of dozens of new justice reforms

Men accused of rape must prove they had “reasonable belief” that their alleged victim had consented to sex under reforms announced yesterday.

The tighter law is one of many designed to help victims of sexual and gender-based violence. The Justice Plan for 2021-23 includes two public awareness campaigns on the meaning of consent; one will target third-level students.

Sponsored

At present defendants can be acquitted if a jury accepts that they honestly or genuinely believed they had consent. The threshold of reasonable belief is seen as more objective.

title: Brenda Power: Time to scrap court testimonials for rapists
text:
What were they really saying, those men of Dingle — and they were all men — who stood up to laud a rapist’s previous good character at his sentencing last month? What message did they intend their testimonials to convey to the judge who was about to sentence him, or to the wider community to whom their words may also have been directed?

Conor Quaid was convicted last September of sneaking into a young woman’s bedroom and raping her while she slept. A trusted friend of her family, he admitted the crime in text messages to the outraged woman next day. “I am really f***ing sorry,” he wrote. “I am a retard, like. I’m giving up drink.” She replied: “Drink is no f***ing excuse .
summary:
What were they really saying, those men of Dingle — and they were all men — who stood up to laud a rapist’s previous good character at his sentencing last month?
Conor Quaid was convicted last September of sneaking into a young woman’s bedroom and raping her while she slept.
A trusted friend of her family, he admitted the crime in text messages to the outraged woman next day.
“I am really f***ing sorry,” he wrote.
I’m giving up drink.” She replied: “Drink is no f***ing excuse .

title: Protest over Gérald Darmanin, Macron’s new minister under investigation for rape
text:
Feminist activists demonstrate in Paris yesterday. The Élysée Palace said it had examined the case and stood behind Gérald Darmanin

President Macron is facing criticism over his promotion of a politician who is under investigation for rape.

The appointment of Gérald Darmanin, 37, as interior minister comes after an appeal court ordered the police last month to reopen an investigation into allegations against him by Sophie Patterson-Spatz. In 2017 she told police that Mr Darmanin had forced her to have sex with him eight years earlier in return for helping her to expunge from her criminal record a conviction for blackmailing a former boyfriend. Prosecutors dropped the case in 2018.

A group of demonstrators chanted “rapist” outside the ministry as Mr Darmanin took over his new duties. He was previously budget minister.

title: Sturgeon accuses Salmond of misleading voters
text:
Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister, at the launch of the SNP virtual electoral campaign in Glasgow

Nicola Sturgeon has accused Alex Salmond of misleading Scottish voters over the impact his new party would have on the case for independence.

In return, Salmond suggested that Sturgeon had to be able to take criticism, as the gulf between the former close allies was further revealed.

Sponsored

The Scottish National Party leader reiterated her criticism of her predecessor as a “gambler”, adding that “he backs the horses on an almost daily basis”. She said that he had changed his stance over the best way to make the case for separation.

Salmond has set up a new party, Alba, which will only stand on the regional lists at Holyrood’s election next month. He said that this would help achieve a “super majority” in favour of independence

Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister, at the launch of the SNP virtual electoral campaign in GlasgowNicola Sturgeon has accused Alex Salmond of misleading Scottish voters over the impact his new party would have on the case for independence.

title: Porn sites used by children show ‘criminal’ sex acts
text:
Sites such as Pornhub are more popular than eBay, PayPal and LinkedIn

The most popular porn sites are bombarding users with sexually violent material depicting rape, upskirting and other abuse, according to a landmark study.

An analysis of 131,738 titles on the homepages of Pornhub, XHamster and XVideos found that one in eight showed non-consensual or incestuous acts, including where the subjects were described as drugged, unconscious or “very young”.

Sponsored

More than 8,000 titles referred to physical aggression or forced sexual activity, even when the researchers excluded representations of consensual bondage, discipline and sadomasochism (BDSM) practices.

The study, published today in the British Journal of Criminology, is one of the most in-depth analyses of online porn to date and draws on the largest sample of mainstream material yet collected. Swathes of material depicting degrading and extreme violence

title: Metropolitan Police cleared over handling of Sarah Everard vigil
text:
The Met faced a sustained public outcry after women who attended the vigil, including Patsy Stevenson, were bundled to the ground and arrested

Scotland Yard has been exonerated over its policing of the Sarah Everard vigil by an independent report that rounded on public figures who criticised the force.

Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Constabulary and Fire and Rescue Services found that police “did their best” to peacefully disperse the crowd at Clapham Common in south London, remained professional when subjected to abuse and were not heavy-handed.

Sponsored

The Met faced a sustained public outcry after women who attended the March 13 event in memory of Everard, who was allegedly kidnapped and murdered by a police officer, were bundled to the ground and arrested.

The inspectorate was asked to carry out an independent inquiry by Priti Patel, the home secretary, who had described the images as “upsetting”, and Sadiq Khan,

title: Youth raped girl he met on social media
text:
A plea to spare the youth a custodial sentence was rejected by the judge at the High Court in Edinburgh

A teenager who raped a 12-year-old girl whom he met on social media has been detained for 32 months.

The youth, who was aged 16 at the time, had contact with his victim through Snapchat and Instagram in the lead-up to the offence. He then asked the girl if she would like to meet him to have “some fun” before raping her at his home in Fife on March 10 last year.

text:
Sarah Everard‘s death led to women sharing their experiences of abuse and harassment by men

A student who was raped as she walked home has spoken publicly about her ordeal in the wake of the Sarah Everard case, saying she fears for women’s safety on the streets.

Laura Prada, 21, was attacked by serial sex offender Callum Jamieson, 24, as she returned to her student accommodation following a birthday party in Liverpool city centre.

Jamieson — who had several convictions for violent and sexual offences against women — stalked her for a mile before dragging her by the hair into bushes.

He fled the scene but was later jailed for eight years at Liverpool crown court after DNA evidence linked him to the attack in December 2019.

title: I’m determined to see my father jailed for rape, says Peter Nygard’s son
text:
When the fashion mogul Peter Nygard was arrested last month in Canada amid allegations of rape and human trafficking, his son Kai, 38, said that he felt huge relief. “Not letting him escape to a jurisdiction where he could avoid charges had become a full-time obsession for me,” he told The Times.

Mr Nygard, 79, who faces extradition to the United States on nine charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, spent Christmas in prison in Manitoba, a huge fall from grace for a man who built a global fashion empire and an estimated fortune of $900 million. He spent much of his time at a sprawling Mayan-themed Bahamas estate, where he was once visited by the Duke of York.

Sponsored

The charges against Mr Nygard

text:
Gérald Darmanin was told to crack down on Islamist extremism

President Macron’s hardline interior minister, hailed as a rising star after his promotion this summer, has been questioned by judges over a rape allegation.

Lawyers for Gérald Darmanin, 38, said that he was questioned by two investigating magistrates, who granted him assisted witness status, one step short of bringing charges against him.

Sponsored

Mr Darmanin denies wrongdoing, claiming to be the victim of a “manhunt” in a case that dates back more than a decade.

The allegations, however, have undermined the political clout of the minister who was tipped as a future president after being given the interior portfolio in July.

He was handed the mission to crack down on crime and Islamist extremism. The claims have proved a thorn in the side of Mr Macron,

title: ‘Animal’ who raped nursing home resident jailed
text:
The central criminal court was told that Emmanual Adeniji had “single-handedly destroyed” the woman’s life

A healthcare assistant who raped an elderly woman in her nursing home bed during the Covid-19 lockdown has been jailed for 11 years.

The woman’s family described how they have been unable to comfort their mother by hugging her since the rape in April. The woman, in her seventies, remains terrified that the man will return to her room.

title: Amber Heard ‘stole rape ordeal’ of assistant to use in Johnny Depp libel case
text:
Amber Heard “stole” the horrific rape experience of an employee to use in the libel case about alleged domestic violence she suffered during her marriage to Johnny Depp, the High Court was told yesterday.

Heard was also accused of perjury over the smuggling of her dogs into Australia and of lying to US immigration authorities about the employment of a British stylist.

title: Priti Patel plans police league tables as serious crime crackdown starts
text:
The Home Office’s “relentless focus on cutting crime” will involve measuring police performance on six crime types

Priti Patel is drawing up league tables ranking police forces on their success in cutting serious crime in a move that chief constables warned was a return to targets.

Police chiefs have been told they will be measured on six crime types including homicide, serious violence and cybercrime. The Home Office will compare their performance against national benchmarks in what it said was a “relentless focus on cutting crime”.

Sponsored

The scheme will add to concerns that the home secretary is encroaching on operational independence. Some chiefs have complained she went too far when she demanded forces increase enforcement of protests and coronavirus restrictions.

The new system of “national crime and policing measures” was described by senior officers as a return to the culture of targets
summary:

title: Change of policy in rape cases ‘was to counter bad publicity’
text:
End Violence Against Women blames the low rate of cases taken to court on a Crown Prosecution Service reform

The country’s former top prosecutor approved a controversial policy for rape cases in an effort to counter bad publicity around four prominent acquittals, campaigners have told judges.

A coalition of women’s groups has claimed that “unlawful” changes to rape prosecution policy led to a “shocking and unprecedented” decline in the rates of cases taken to court.

Sponsored

In a highly unusual move, the Court of Appeal has agreed to hear a judicial review of the Crown Prosecution Service’s policy despite the High Court rejecting an application last year.

The End Violence Against Women coalition says that between 2016 and 2018, senior CPS officials changed the way that cases of alleged rape and serious sexual assaults were considered by prosecutors, leading them to become more risk-averse. The
summary:
End Violence Against Women blames the low rate of cases taken to court on a Crown Prosecution Service reformThe country’s former top prosecutor approved a controversial policy for rape cases in an effort to counter bad publicity around four prominent acquittals, campaigners have told judges.
A coalition of women’s groups has claimed that “unlawful” changes to rape prosecution policy led to a “shocking and unprecedented” decline in the rates of cases taken to court.
SponsoredIn a highly unusual move, the Court of Appeal has agreed to hear a judicial review of the Crown Prosecution Service’s policy despite the High Court rejecting an application last year.
The End Violence Against Women coalition says that between 2016 and 2018, senior CPS officials changed the way that cases of alleged rape and serious sexual assaults were considered by prosecutors, leading them to become more risk-averse.

title: Latymer Upper School reports ‘rape culture’ claims to police
text:
Latymer Upper School in Hammersmith, west London, has been named on a website created for students to report claims of harassment

A leading private school has reported allegations of sex abuse to the police.

Latymer Upper School in Hammersmith, west London, has been named more times than any other school on Everyone’s Invited, a website created for students and former pupils to report claims of sexual harassment.

Sponsored

The £20,000-a-year co-educational school has reported the allegations to the Metropolitan Police and Hammersmith and Fulham council.

Accusations against pupils include rape, sexual assault and encouraging underage girls to share naked photographs. One pupil claimed she was given a detention after a boy coerced her into sending naked photographs when she was 12. Others claimed that the school ignored emails when worried family members reported alleged abuse.

However, the school said that it took “any report or allegation
summary:

title: Modelling agent Jean-Luc Brunel linked with Jeffrey Epstein arrested on rape charges
text:
Jean-Luc Brunel, who disappeared from public view after the death of Jeffrey Epstein, is accused of rape, sexual assault on minors, and human trafficking

A powerful French modelling agent accused of rape and of procuring hundreds of women and girls for Jeffrey Epstein was arrested in Paris yesterday.

Jean-Luc Brunel was detained on suspicion of rape, sexual assault on minors, human trafficking and involvement in a criminal conspiracy, the Paris prosecution office said in a statement. He was arrested at Charles-de-Gaulle airport while preparing to take a flight to Dakar in Senegal, according to a police source.

Sponsored

Along with Ghislaine Maxwell, the British socialite in prison in New York awaiting trial, Mr Brunel is alleged to have had a pivotal role in the Epstein scandal, supplying the US financier with the women and girls who became his victims. Epstein hanged himself in a cell in New York in 2019
summary:

text:

Michael Bowman SC, for the 18-year-old, had told the Court of Appeal that a delay in bringing his client’s case to court means that he will serve a significant portion of his 18-month sentence in an adult prison, having committed the offence when he was a child.

title: Durham University ‘let down Peru rape victim’
text:
The student was told by Durham University that if she committed a crime while studying abroad, its insurance would cover her legal costs, but as a victim she did not qualify

A student who was raped while studying abroad was told that her university would not cover the legal costs to help her case because she was a victim of a sex crime rather than the perpetrator.

She described Durham University’s policy as absurd because it meant that in cases of sexual violence a male student accused of rape would have his defence costs covered, but a female student who was raped would have to pay her own legal costs.

Sponsored

The woman, who was in her early 20s, was left with bruises all over her body after she was allegedly raped by a teacher at a school in Peru where she was volunteering. The placement had been arranged through the university and an NGO.

She reported

title: The King’s School calls in police after pupils share rape jokes online
text:
The King’s School in Grantham has contacted police after the comments by pupils in a live Instagram broadcast

A grammar school that boasts Sir Isaac Newton among its former pupils has contacted police after students took part in an Instagram chat where pupils swapped jokes about rape.

The King’s School in Grantham, Lincolnshire, confirmed that some of its pupils were involved in a live Instagram broadcast last Monday.

Sponsored

Simon Pickett, the school’s head teacher, said it would be taking “appropriate action” and had contacted police after complaints over the broadcast.

Sreenshots of the comments on the chat included one that said: “I’d take rape as a compliment” and another that read: “What do 9 out of 10 people enjoy? Gang rape.” Others described women as “objects”, while another said that women should “wake up and realise your [sic] never going to have equality”.
summary:

title: Rape protest is sedition, says Modi ally Yogi Adityanath
text:
Police in a state run by one of the prime minister’s key allies have brought charges of sedition, inciting violence and conspiracy against 19 campaigners, politicians and journalists who visited the family of a lower caste woman who alleged she was gang-raped then died of her injuries.

The charges follow growing outrage over the attack in Uttar Pradesh that left the 19-year-old with a broken spine and a slashed tongue. She died on September 29 having accused four higher caste men. Public anger intensified with the cremation of her remains in the dead of night by the authorities in a field near her home in Hathras, which took place without rituals. title: Promising Young Woman — the film taking on ‘nice guy’ predators
text:

Not all of his advice, it must be said, was quite so progressive. He told me, for example, that if I wanted to kiss a girl but was struggling to transition our relationship to the physical then I should bite her lightly on the back of the neck, in the manner of a kitten being carried by a mother cat. title: Prosecutors accused of ignoring rape confession
text:
Bonny Turner says that her alleged rapist had sent her an apology

Prosecutors ignored an alleged written confession of rape, a woman has claimed as part of a landmark hearing this week into the handling of the crime.

Three senior judges will hear a claim that the Crown Prosecution Service changed its policy in rape cases, which campaigners have claimed “led to a catastrophic collapse in the number of trials going to court”.

Sponsored

Last year, Dame Vera Baird, QC, the victims commissioner, said that the alleged change to policy in 2016-17 had led to the “effective decriminalisation of rape”. Figures published last June showed that rape prosecutions dropped by more than 30 per cent over the previous year, resulting in the lowest number of convictions for at least five years.

title: Pakistan PM Imran Khan prompts outrage with rape comments
text:
Imran Khan has grown increasingly conservative since returning to his home country from Britain and entering politics

In his playboy days as a handsome cricket star in 1980s London, Imran Khan was renowned for chasing models and actresses around the nightclub circuit. Decades on, the 65-year-old prime minister of Pakistan has provoked outrage with comments blaming women’s dress for a surge in rape cases in his home country.

During a televised interview, the Oxford-educated Khan fielded a question from a caller asking what his government was doing to combat a rise in sexual violence in Pakistan. Lashing out at declining standards of modesty among women, the prime minister replied that an increase in rape indicated the “consequences in any society where vulgarity is on the rise”.

title: Tory ex-minister arrested over rape
text:
Police said the offences are alleged to have occurred at addresses in Westminster, Lambeth and Hackney

A former minister has been arrested after a woman in her twenties accused him of rape, sexual assault and coercive control.

The Conservative MP was taken into custody early on Saturday. He has been released on bail to a date later this month.

Sponsored

The complainant, a former parliamentary employee, accuses him of abuse during a relationship last year. She alleges that the MP assaulted her, forced her to have sex and left her so traumatised that she had to go to hospital.

The Metropolitan police said they had launched an investigation, and No 10 is now likely to face pressure to suspend the MP.

Robert Jenrick, the housing secretary, told Times Radio this morning: “These are very serious allegations and they should be investigated.”

title: ‘A very sizeable minority have no voice in Scottish politics’
text:
A politician’s ambition should be to create a sense of balance and harmony in society, according to Philipp Tanzer, one of the hundreds of candidates standing in the Scottish elections.

“All my life, I’ve been through extremes,” he said. “I’ve seen the damage too much liberalism can have on society and on individuals. It’s why I advocate for a little bit more wholesomeness.”

Sponsored

Tanzer’s views have evolved over time. Little more than a decade ago he was the “rugged and aggressive” gay idol of Raging Stallion porn movies. Now he is contesting Highlands & Islands for the Scottish Family Party, seeking to inject a little rectitude back into national life.

“As a centrist, which I usually am, I feel forced to take very strong positions
