title: Morrison strips Australia’s judges of protection from sexual harassment claims
text:
Australia will bring judges and politicians under sexual harassment laws as its centre right government battles a series of sex scandals which has seen it lose support among women.

Scott Morrison, the prime minister, announced wide changes aimed at empowering complainants in gender-related disputes at work, removing historic exemptions from complaints about gender discrimination provided to public servants, judges and politicians.

Sponsored

The reforms will include classifying sexual harassment as “serious misconduct” and clarify that it is a valid reason for sacking employees on public and private payrolls. While MPs and judges cannot be dismissed, the changes will open them to censure or harsher penalties for proven sexual harassment.

“Sexual harassment is unacceptable,” Morrison said. “It’s not only immoral and despicable and even criminal . .
summary:
Australia will bring judges and politicians under sexual harassment laws as its centre right government battles a series of sex scandals which has seen it lose support among women.
Scott Morrison, the prime minister, announced wide changes aimed at empowering complainants in gender-related disputes at work, removing historic exemptions from complaints about gender discrimination provided to public servants, judges and politicians.
SponsoredThe reforms will include classifying sexual harassment as “serious misconduct” and clarify that it is a valid reason for sacking employees on public and private payrolls.
While MPs and judges cannot be dismissed, the changes will open them to censure or harsher penalties for proven sexual harassment.
“Sexual harassment is unacceptable,” Morrison said.

A Jehovah’s Witness congregation was responsible for the rape of a young woman because of the power male “elders” wielded over “sheep-like” members, the Court of Appeal ruled.

The victim had complained about Mark Sewell’s kissing and innuendo but was urged to show “compassion” by his father, who, like Sewell, was an elder at the church in south Wales.

title: Teenager held woman at knifepoint and raped her
text:
A judge at the High Court in Glasgow told the boy he would receive help in detention

A teenage boy who abducted a woman at knifepoint and raped her has been detained for seven years.

He admitted attacking the 20-year-old woman on wasteland in Methil, Fife, on January 29 last year. He was 14.

Sponsored

At the High Court in Glasgow, Judge Lady Stacey told the boy, now 15: “What you did was very serious and it must have been very frightening for the young woman. It has had a serious effect on her life.”

The judge accepted his remorse, adding: “You will receive help in detention and you may not be such a danger as you were that night. It is up to you to take advantage of the help.”

Derick Nelson, for the prosecution, said the woman was walking in Methil

title: Minister sorry for calling alleged rape victim ‘lying cow’
text:
Linda Reynolds has been under sustained pressure over her handling of the rape allegation

Australia’s defence minister will pay damages to a former staffer whom she called a “lying cow” after the younger woman claimed that a co-worker raped her in the minister’s office.

Linda Reynolds, 55, has publicly retracted comments she made in her parliamentary office minutes after former staffer Brittany Higgins, 26, disclosed the allegation in a television interview last month.

Sponsored

The defence minister, who has taken medical leave from her duties, has also agreed to pay undisclosed damages to Higgins, under the terms of the settlement brokered by lawyers.

Higgins said she plans to donate the money to a charity that assists victims of sexual assault and abuse.

Ten days ago The Australian newspaper reported that Reynolds called Higgins a “lying cow” in an open-plan area

title: Medusa statue at Weinstein court angers rape survivors
text:
Medusa with the Head of Perseus inverts the Greek myth but critics say that installing it outside the New York court where Harvey Weinstein was convicted sends the wrong message

A statue of Medusa holding the severed head of Perseus has been erected outside the New York court where Harvey Weinstein was convicted of rape, in a monument hailed by its fans as a new “icon of justice” for the modern age.

But days after it was placed in the park across the street from the Manhattan criminal court, Medusa with the Head of Perseus has come under fire from rape survivors, who say that it offers a “revenge fantasy” that wrongly casts victims of sexual violence as aggressors.

Sponsored

There were also those who felt that the artist, a man, had made Medusa look like a swimsuit model. “Why did they make her really hot and nude and hairless?” asked one commentator on Twitter.

Luciano
summary:

title: The Adventures of Miss Barbara Pym by Paula Byrne review — imagine if Jane Austen had dated an SS officer
text:
Mislaid on Banbury Road in Oxford some time in 1934: a small swastika brooch belonging to Miss Barbara Pym, a gift from her Nazi boyfriend. It may still be lying there.

A swastika brooch is not quite the item most of us would associate with Barbara Pym, the supreme novelist of unmarried sisters, curates and Sunday lunch at the vicarage. Her previous biographer, her colleague and friend Hazel Holt, did mention that Pym travelled to Germany in the mid-1930s, “quite uninterested in politics of any kind”, and enjoyed a love affair with a handsome SS officer called Friedbert Glück.

Sponsored

title: Sturgeon is forced to fault her own judgment
text:
Nicola Sturgeon does not wish to spend this election talking about Alex Salmond but she cannot escape his overbearing presence either. Speaking to the SNP’s “virtual conference” she made but a single, fleeting, reference to her predecessor. Having done so, she moved on, presumably on the basis that if no one mentions the bear outside the window the bear may disappear.

This is no time for putting self-interest before the national interest, Sturgeon said, though that is a self-serving, even self-interested, appraisal of this election’s new circumstances. Whether one approves of him or not, Salmond’s analysis of the election arithmetic is sound: except in the south, many SNP list votes do little to elect SNP MSPs.

Sponsored

If that poses a problem for the first minister,
summary:
Nicola Sturgeon does not wish to spend this election talking about Alex Salmond but she cannot escape his overbearing presence either.
Speaking to the SNP’s “virtual conference” she made but a single, fleeting, reference to her predecessor.
Having done so, she moved on, presumably on the basis that if no one mentions the bear outside the window the bear may disappear.
This is no time for putting self-interest before the national interest, Sturgeon said, though that is a self-serving, even self-interested, appraisal of this election’s new circumstances.
Whether one approves of him or not, Salmond’s analysis of the election arithmetic is sound: except in the south, many SNP list votes do little to elect SNP MSPs.

title: Thule Ventus: Firm’s award for cod with Shetland twist
text:
David Polson has been running the business producing salt cod delicacies for seven years

A Shetland producer has won an industry award for its salt cod pâté.

Salt cod is popular in countries such as Portugal and Italy where it keeps well thanks to its high sodium content despite high temperatures and humid weather.

Sponsored

While the delicacy is more readily available on the continent than on home soil, David Polson, who founded Thule Ventus in 2014, hopes to change that after the pâté took a small producer platinum award at the 2021 Scottish Retail Food and Drink Awards.

Polson, who is based in Cunningsburgh, said he had “Shetland-ified” a Provence-style recipe, adding Aberdeenshire rapeseed oil, live cultured Shetland buttermilk, garlic, lemon and lime juice.

The pâté is sold online and in two Glasgow fishmongers, Wilson’s Catch of the Day
summary:

title: Men forced to rape family members in Tigray, UN says
text:
A woman in hospital in Mekele, Ethiopia, said she has been raped by soldiers on three occasions

Appalling stories of rape being used as a weapon of war have emerged from Ethiopia’s five-month civil conflict as the prime minister Abiy Ahmed belatedly admitted that atrocities had been committed.

Among hundreds of cases reported to clinics in the Tigray region are gang rapes by troops at gunpoint and men forced to rape members of their own family.

“Given the fact that most health facilities are not functioning and also the stigma associated with rape, it is projected that actual numbers are much higher,” Wafaa Said, the deputy UN aid co-ordinator in Ethiopia, told a briefing of United Nations member states in New York.

title: Murder and rape suspects charged by post
text:
Dame Vera Baird said that the trend was concerning for victims and society

People suspected of crimes including murder and rape are increasingly being charged by post, figures suggest.

Last year Britain’s biggest police force sent 12 suspects letters telling them they would be tried for murder, an increase of seven compared with the previous year. In 2017 two were sent. The Metropolitan Police also issued postal charges to 91 people suspected of rape in 2019 — more than double the previous year’s figure of 43. Letters were also sent to 414 people charging them with sex offences.

Sponsored

Dame Vera Baird, QC, the victims’ commissioner for England and Wales, said the figures were “deeply concerning for victims and for society”. A senior solicitor said charging a suspect with murder by post simply gave them time to go on

text:
The head of a leading private school has warned against “gender wars” in the light of thousands of stories of sexual abuse from current and former pupils of dozens of schools.

title: Sturgeon proposes end to ‘not proven’ verdict
text:
In a typical year, over 2,000 rape or attempted rape offences are recorded in Scotland, of which about 150 lead to a conviction

Sir Walter Scott called it “that bastard verdict” and it is has been a feature of Scottish crime writing and TV drama, from Val McDermid to Taggart.

Now Scots juries are to lose the power to issue the not proven verdict in an effort to improve conviction rates for sexual offences.

Sponsored

In a typical year, over 2,000 rape or attempted rape offences are recorded in Scotland, of which about 150 lead to a conviction. Less than half of the cases brought to trial result in convictions.

title: Cadet did not report ‘rape’ by officer for three months
text:
The cadet told Bulford military court in Wiltshire that she was embarrassed by the alleged incident

A teenage officer cadet allegedly raped by a Royal Navy officer failed to report it for three months because she was said to be scared and embarrassed, a court martial has been told.

The woman said that she was sexually abused by Lieutenant Rhys Christie after nights out in the Borders and in Kent. A military court has been told Lieutenant Christie, 28, exploited the cadet, then 18, in his hotel room after she got so drunk she lost all memory.

Sponsored

Lieutenant Christie, the commanding officer of the Edinburgh-based HMS Archer, is accused of “abusing his authority”. William Peters, for the prosecution, said that the woman failed to report the offences immediately because she did not feel “comfortable”.

The cadet told Bulford military court

title: Former Court of Appeal judge to investigate Highgate School rape culture claims
text:
One of Britain’s most esteemed schools has brought in a former senior judge to lead an independent review into allegations of a rape culture there.

Highgate School, which was the subject of a dossier featuring 220 testimonies of peer-on-peer sexual harassment and rape, has appointed Dame Anne Rafferty, a former Court of Appeal judge, to investigate.

text:
Suzanne Russell, Graham McGill’s former wife, told the High Court in Glasgow that when they were together he had told her that he had killed a woman but she did not believe him

The former wife of a man accused of murdering a mother in 1984 has alleged that he confessed to killing a woman because he “just wanted to know what it felt like”.

Mary McLaughlin, 58, was found dead at her home in Partick in Glasgow’s west end in October 1984 after spending a night out at bars playing dominoes, the High Court in Glasgow has been told.

Graham McGill, 59, denies murdering her and tightly fastening a belt from her dressing gown around her throat with intent to rape on September 26 or 27. title: People smugglers know Joe Biden is the weak point, not the Mexican border
text:
Asylum? The word meant nothing to Joel. I had just seen him descend from an inflatable boat on the banks of the Rio Grande with his wife, Iris, seven-year-old daughter and baby son. By rights, he must claim asylum in the US or be deported, but Joel didn’t hide the fact that he was an economic migrant. He had landed in America and that was all that mattered.

title: Met police officer accused of rape by two colleagues was not suspended
text:
Both women were awarded substantial sums last year after the compensation authority concluded that police evidence indicated that they had suffered serious sexual and physical abuse

A serving officer with the Metropolitan Police accused of rape by two female colleagues has continued working since the allegations surfaced four years ago.

The officer, who has not been charged, was restricted in his interactions with the public but the force has not prevented him from working with female colleagues.

Sponsored

The two co-workers accused him of sexual and physical abuse but the case was not taken up by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), according to the Bureau of Investigative Journalism.

However, the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA), which compensates the victims of violent crimes, awarded both women substantial sums last year after concluding that police evidence indicated that each had been the victim of serious sexual and physical abuse.

The government-run CICA assesses cases
summary:

title: Political scientist Olivier Duhamel admits he sexually abused stepson Antoine Kouchner
text:
Olivier Duhamel, 70, acknowledged the truth of allegations in a book by his stepdaughter

A senior academic and powerbroker at the centre of a paedophile scandal that rocked the French establishment has admitted that he abused his stepson.

Olivier Duhamel, 70, acknowledged “with difficulty” the truth of allegations in a book by Camille Kouchner, his stepdaughter, that he had sexually abused her twin brother, Antoine, when he was a teenager, police said.

Sponsored

In January Kouchner’s book La familia grande caused a storm over the sexual mores of the powerful political and media class that emerged after the 1968 Paris student revolt. Thousands of people posted accounts on social media of their experiences of abuse.

Duhamel, a political scientist, did not address the claims but complained of “personal attacks” against him and resigned all his posts, including chairmanship

title: Sara Khan: ‘There is no right not to be offended... and no one should live in fear for doing their job’
text:
Sara Khan said it was “just horrifying” that the religious studies teacher was “hounded” after children were shown a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad

Sara Khan knows how it feels to face death threats and messages of hate. The Muslim from Bradford who was appointed this week as Boris Johnson’s independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience has had many since she began campaigning against extremism. On police advice she installed a fireproof letterbox at her home, having been attacked by the hard left and far right as well as Islamist groups.

The protests outside a school in Batley, West Yorkshire, after children were shown a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad have, however, made her more determined to challenge intolerance. “There is no right not to be offended,” she says. “The teacher was hounded and I found that just horrifying. text:
Gérald Darmanin, the interior minister, said that the woman had slept with him willingly

The new French interior minister claimed yesterday to be the victim of a “vicious manhunt” over a rape allegation as feminists across the world joined the outcry over President Macron’s decision to appoint him.

Gérald Darmanin, 37, became the target of street demonstrations by #MeToo activists after Mr Macron promoted him. The president made the judgment that there was no substance in the claim by Olga Patterson, 36, that Mr Darmanin had raped her in 2009.

Former Haberdashers’ Girls pupils Sophie Max, left, and Philippa Lawford, say their time there was marred by sexual harassment and misogyny from boys at the next-door school

Children’s “unfettered access” to pornography on their phones and the film Fifty Shades of Grey are partly to blame for the crisis of sexual abuse at private schools, head teachers warn today.

title: Steuart Bedford obituary
text:
No opera house could create an atmosphere like the Suffolk coast under a dark sky, the biting breeze whistling down from Sizewell. As the audience sank deeper into their thermals and the waves crashed over the shingle, Steuart Bedford, secluded in a half-buried dugout, brought down his baton. The temperature of the drama began to rise as, according to Richard Morrison’s Times review, the conductor did “a superb job of synchronising his shivering cast with his taped band”.

This was Aldeburgh Festival’s remarkable al fresco production of Peter Grimes, Benjamin Britten’s tale of a wayward fisherman, staged on the beach for the composer’s centenary in 2013. It was also Bedford’s professional farewell to a region that he had known all his life. He had
summary:

title: Database of abusive men promised within a year
text:
Hundreds gathered earlier this month in central London to call for more action to protect women from harassment

Ministers are to pledge steps towards introducing a national register of men who harass women, saying they can create a database modelled on the sex offenders’ register within a year. A list of abusive men is part of a “perpetrators strategy” to be promised this week by Robert Buckland, the justice secretary, to persuade MPs to pass the government’s Domestic Abuse Bill.

Ministers are trying to win over backbenchers after the government rejected an amendment to create the register, which was passed by a landslide in the House of Lords last month after the outcry over the death of Sarah Everard.

title: Rape suspects can choose to self-identify as female
text:
Humza Yousaf, the justice secretary, has been accused by Johann Lamont MSP of taking a different view on the policy from Police Scotland

Rape suspects are able to self-identify as female, it was revealed after a freedom of information request by a feminist policy think-tank.

Police Scotland said that if a rape or attempted rape was perpetrated by a “male who self-identifies as a woman . . . the male who self-identifies as a woman would be expected to be recorded as a female on relevant police systems.”

Campaigners claim that the position could lead to a “distortion” in society’s understanding of crime and the measures needed to tackle it. They also say the policy is at odds with what Humza Yousaf, the justice secretary, has said should be legal proof that a suspect is female.

title: Harriet Wistrich: Prosecutors should focus on most vulnerable rape victims, not virgin nuns
text:
Harriet Wistrich with Sally Challen’s son, David. Wistrich helped to overturn Challen’s conviction for murdering her abusive husband

Harriet Wistrich is never far from the news. The campaigning solicitor and founder of the Centre for Women’s Justice (CWJ) has been involved in a string of ground-breaking cases — notably a human rights challenge to the police’s failure to investigate complaints made by two victims of the black cab rapist, John Worboys.

That case led to a Supreme Court ruling that established a duty on the police to conduct effective investigations into serious crimes.

Sponsored

In the High Court Wistrich also successfully challenged the Parole Board’s decision to release Worboys after serving only nine years in jail and she won a Court of Appeal victory, overturning Sally Challen’s conviction for murdering her abusive husband.

text:
John Leslie, 55, a former Blue Peter presenter, said it was ludicrous to claim he assaulted a stranger

A former Blue Peter presenter’s voice cracked as he described claims that he grabbed a woman’s breasts at a Christmas party as “crazy” and “ludicrous”.

title: Jury clears man accused of rape after GAA clubhouse ball
text:
After a ten-day trial at the central criminal court in Dublin the jury returned a unanimous verdict of not guilty

A man has been cleared of raping a woman after they met at a New Year’s Eve ball at a GAA clubhouse.

The 33-year-old man had denied rape at his home in Westmeath on January 1, 2017.

Sponsored

The complainant was visiting a friend and had planned to spend the night in that woman’s home after going to a ball in the local GAA clubhouse. She met the accused, who was of a similar age, and they were kissing in the clubhouse.

She told the jury that towards the end of the night she could not find her friend and her mobile phone had gone dead. She said she decided she had no other option but to accept an invitation to the man’s house.

title: What the critics are watching and listening to, from Promising Young Woman to Iggy Pop
text:
Promising Young Woman

This is a film, in no uncertain terms, about misogyny. It’s the story of a rape, and a suicide, and a life upturned. But it’s also a movie that crackles and fizzes with style and wit and blackly humorous subtext. It’s written and directed by Emerald Fennell, aka Camilla Parker Bowles in The Crown, making her feature debut with a gobsmacking display of authorial nous. Fennell fills each scene with characters and situations that seem dramatically real, then symbolic, then real again. Carey Mulligan is perfectly cast as Cassandra, a brittle coffee shop barista dealing with the death of her best friend, the victim of a university rape and subsequent downward spiral. But Cassandra is also an avenger and a symbolic

Sponsored

It’s the story of a rape, and a suicide, and a life upturned.

It’s written and directed by Emerald Fennell, aka Camilla Parker Bowles in The Crown, making her feature debut with a gobsmacking display of authorial nous.

title: Justin Baldoni is on a crusade against toxic masculinity – starting with his own
text:
Most of my life I have been told men are in crisis. Perhaps we finally are. The hashtags that have of late been in our pursuit – #MeToo, #TimesUp, #EverydaySexism – send us in the dead of night word-searching the transcripts of our lives for transgressions. We may beerily protest that woke has gone too far, but how carefully we now phrase our opinions of women. We know the truth. Out in the world, women’s physical violation by our gender is running wild. Yet, and just as doggedly, the 21st century targets the male with advertisements for a robust masculine ideal that would have us preen our bodies, chase material success, strive for the qualities of “leadership” (aka dominance) and unwind to bespoke pornography.

Should
summary:
Most of my life I have been told men are in crisis.
The hashtags that have of late been in our pursuit – #MeToo, #TimesUp, #EverydaySexism – send us in the dead of night word-searching the transcripts of our lives for transgressions.
We may beerily protest that woke has gone too far, but how carefully we now phrase our opinions of women.
We know the truth.
Out in the world, women’s physical violation by our gender is running wild.

title: Major in rape case claims that he was the victim
text:
A Scottish major accused of raping a female officer after a Burns supper told investigators he was too drunk to recall having sex and claimed he may have been the victim of sexual assault, a court martial was told today.

Major Gregor Beaton, 33, was arrested on suspicion of rape by the Royal Military Police. He said DNA evidence suggested he had been forced into sex and should make a complaint himself.

Sponsored

Mr Beaton, an Afghanistan veteran, told officers that he was so drunk he could not recall what had happened, adding: “I did not want sexual contact. I did not initiate it.”

The court was told that he added: “She has assaulted me. That’s my understanding. I did not have sex with her.”

title: MeToo hits hip-hop – Russell Simmons, rape accusations and On the Record
text:
From left: Sil Lai Abrams, Drew Dixon and Sheri Sher, photographed by Shayan Asgharnia. Right: Russell Simmons in the Nineties, photographed by Anthony Barboza

When Drew Dixon invokes the words of Biggie Smalls, aka the Notorious B.I.G. – killed in a 1997 drive-by shooting at just 24 years old – it is not with the distant reverie of simply a hip-hop fan, but with the familiarity of a friend and colleague.

In the early Nineties, both lived in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a gritty corner of Brooklyn, New York, a city still in the throes of a crack cocaine epidemic. text:
The MP has voluntarily agreed not to return to parliament when the summer recess ends on September 1

A former Conservative minister arrested on suspicion of rape has agreed not to return to Westminster next month after his bail was extended to November.

The MP has voluntarily agreed not to return to parliament when the summer recess ends on September 1. Opposition MPs had called for him to be suspended but the Conservatives are resisting calls to remove the whip.

The MP was taken into custody in east London on August 1 and then released pending investigations.

title: Tez Ilyas is making comedy work
text:
If you were born on 9/11 you will be 20 this year. If you were born into a Muslim family in the West you will have had 20 years of not quite being accepted by the white mainstream, but being uncertain of how to fit into your parents’ world. How will this generation of outsiders create a culture for themselves? The answer might fruitfully involve comedy.

Over the past couple of years a generation of twenty and thirtysomething Muslim creatives have been finding that jokes are the art form most fit for purpose when telling their story, from New Jersey stand-up Ramy Yousseff’s eponymous sitcom, through Guz Khan’s Man Like Mobeen to Tez Ilyas’s subtly confounding autobiography The Secret Diary of a British Muslim Aged
summary:
If you were born on 9/11 you will be 20 this year.
If you were born into a Muslim family in the West you will have had 20 years of not quite being accepted by the white mainstream, but being uncertain of how to fit into your parents’ world.

title: Sex-crime victims can choose gender of interviewer
text:
Dame Vera Baird QC said: “Under the victims’ code, everyone has a right to support following a crime”

Victims of rape and sexual violence will be able to choose the gender of the police officer interviewing them under plans to bolster the rights of victims.

It is among 12 rights being introduced as part of a “victims’ code”, which comes into force today and will set out the minimum level of service victims can expect from criminal justice agencies such as the police and courts.

Sponsored

Victims of serious crimes will be offered the option of receiving automatic alerts when their perpetrator is released from jail. They will also be offered support to challenge Parole Board decisions to release criminals.

Victims of foreign criminals will get the right to know when they are deported under the new code, which ministers say is a stepping

title: I served 17 years in jail but DNA proves real rapist is still at large
text:
Andrew Malkinson was convicted of rape despite no forensic evidence against him

A man who spent 17 years in prison for rape and maintained his innocence is a step closer to clearing his name after a fresh DNA breakthrough in his case.

Andrew Malkinson was convicted of raping a 33-year-old mother left for dead on a Manchester roadside in the middle of the night in July 2003.

Sponsored

There was never any forensic evidence against him and his conviction depended on an identity parade and testimony from witnesses whose criminal pasts were hidden from the court.

Andrew Malkinson’s ex-girlfriend, Karin Schuitemaker, never doubted his innocence

Malkinson, 55, who was 37 when he went to jail, was released from prison last December for good behaviour. He was locked up for ten years beyond his tariff because he refused to admit to the crime.

title: Armie Hammer and the trouble with Hollywood men: how he joined the long list of cancelled stars
text:
This week Armie Hammer withdrew from his starring role in the Broadway play The Minutes and completed one of the most spectacular implosions in Hollywood history. The 34-year-old American actor, the epitome of rangy, thoroughbred glamour in Call Me By Your Name and The Social Network and heir to a multimillion-dollar industrial fortune, has been accused of violently raping a former girlfriend who said she feared he was going to kill her as well as abusing several other women and harbouring cannibalistic fantasies. Another former girlfriend has claimed he told her, seriously, “I want to eat your ribs.”

Hammer, who denies the allegations, had already split from his wife, the television personality Elizabeth Chambers, with whom he has two children, been jettisoned by his agent

title: ‘Rape, beatings and death’ at Kakuzi, the Kenyan farm that helps feed the UK’s avocado habit
text:
The British owners of an avocado farm in Kenya that supplies supermarkets including Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Lidl — and until recently Marks & Spencer — are being sued over a string of alleged human rights abuses.

Guards working for Kakuzi, a farming estate the size of Manchester, are accused of extreme violence against the local community in 79 claims.

Sponsored

The allegations, dating from 2009 to January this year, include battering a 28-year-old man to death for allegedly stealing avocados, the rapes of 10 women, and attacks on villagers walking on paths through Kakuzi land. Former employees of Kakuzi are among the claimants.

The case has stirred uncomfortable echoes of colonial-era exploitation and raised difficult questions for British supermarkets, including Tesco, Sainsbury’s, Lidl and Marks &

title: Ofsted will visit schools named on sex abuse claims website
text:
Ofsted will send inspectors into schools named on the Everyone’s Invited website as it emerged that the regulator failed to mention sexual abuse in any reports on secondary schools in the year before lockdown.

The watchdog said yesterday that it would visit a sample of schools and colleges at which cases had been highlighted. It declined to say how many or how they would be chosen. Inspectors will talk to head teachers and pupils and look at how systems of support and response are working. They will also “discuss the wider issues raised by the evidence” they find.

Sponsored

Gavin Williamson, the education secretary, said last week that an immediate review of sexual abuse in schools would be led by Ofsted and a helpline for victims
summary:
Ofsted will send inspectors into schools named on the Everyone’s Invited website as it emerged that the regulator failed to mention sexual abuse in any reports on secondary schools in the year before lockdown.

title: Mitcham rape suspect traced after vigilante alert
text:
Residents in Mitcham who were furious at the perceived failure of police to investigate the man began their own hunt for him

Scotland Yard thanked the public yesterday for tracking down a man suspected of raping a schoolgirl, hours after police used gang-violence laws to try to control a vigilante search party.

Residents furious at the perceived failure of police to investigate the man, who was suspected of abducting a young girl in south London on Tuesday morning, had begun their own hunt for him, organising it through social media.

Sponsored

The man was finally arrested after he was tracked down by members of the public in Tooting, south London, on Tuesday night.

title: Navy officer’s trial for rape scrapped after serious breach in proceedings
text:
Lieutenant Rhys Christie claimed that he and a cadet had consensual sex

The trial of a Royal Navy captain accused of raping an officer cadet in Scotland has been scrapped after a serious breach in proceedings.

The panel of five military officers retired to consider their verdict in Lieutenant Rhys Christie’s trial after three days of hearing evidence at Bulford military court, Wiltshire.

However, after just an hour of deliberation, Judge Advocate-General Alan Large was forced to discharge the panel, bringing the trial to a halt. It was heard that there had been a serious breach by one of the panel members.

The prosecutor, William Peters, indicated he would seek a retrial although it was not clear when this might be.

title: Harvey Weinstein almost blind and losing teeth in prison, claims lawyer in LA extradition challenge
text:
Harvey Weinstein faces extradition to Los Angeles to answer charges of rape and sexual assault

Harvey Weinstein’s eyesight is failing and he has lost four of his teeth, his lawyer said yesterday as he sought to delay the former film-maker’s extradition to Los Angeles for a new trial.

The disgraced Hollywood mogul is facing charges that he raped or sexually assaulted five women in hotels in Beverly Hills between 2004 and 2013.

Sponsored

Weinstein, 69, who was convicted of rape and sexual assault by a New York court last year and is serving a 23-year sentence, has now been indicted in California. He faces a request from prosecutors there to transport him to Los Angeles, to stand trial in the city where he once held sway.

Weinstein appeared from prison via video link during his online extradition hearing in Buffalo, New York state AP

title: Tory MP can return to parliament after rape case is dropped
text:
The alleged victim is believed to be lodging an appeal with the Victims’ Right to Review Scheme

Whips and parliamentary authorities are discussing how to help a Conservative MP accused of rape return to work after police dropped their investigation into the alleged offences.

The former minister, a man in his fifties, was arrested in August after a woman in her twenties alleged that he sexually assaulted her and subjected her to coercive control between July last year and January this year.

Sponsored

The MP has always denied the claims. He entered an informal agreement with the whips and the Speaker’s Office to stay away from parliament in the summer while he was under arrest. He could return now that he is no longer under investigation.

A spokeswoman for the whips’ office said: “We will review any changes to police conditions.”

A Metropolitan

title: Penne for your thoughts
text:
The chances of an Italian holiday this summer look slimmer than the thinnest slice of prosciutto, but we can all learn to conjure up a taste of Italy at home. The country has some of the most envy-inducing food in the world, but even the experts insist that cooking like an Italian is not that complicated — though a good delicatessen helps. “Eating like an Italian is more a state of mind than only using Italian ingredients,” says Manuela Spinelli, the secretary-general of Euro-Toques Ireland, the Irish branch of the European community of chefs and cooks.

In non-foodie circles, Spinelli is probably better known in her other role as a translator, most famously for Giovanni Trapattoni while he was managing the Republic of Ireland football
summary:

title: I won’t be decolonising, I’ve no shame about empire
text:
Rather suddenly, something people call “colonialism” has become the root of all evil. Monuments, statues, the National Trust, stately homes, Cambridge colleges, the school curriculum, even the BBC, are suddenly diagnosed as suffering from this distressing condition. If the gents at Derby station isn’t as clean as one might like, colonialism is probably to blame. We are instructed to decolonise as a matter of urgency.

Well, this child of empire has no intention of decolonising and nor will I betray my forebears or the ideals of my youth. I am proud of empire. I recognise that for Britain its time has passed; that its motives were mixed; that its attitudes are now outdated; that colonialism did terrible as well as many good things, and there
summary:
Rather suddenly, something people call “colonialism” has become the root of all evil.
Monuments, statues, the National Trust, stately homes, Cambridge colleges, the school curriculum, even the BBC, are suddenly diagnosed as suffering from this distressing condition.
If the gents at Derby station isn’t as clean as one might like, colonialism is probably to blame.
Well, this child of empire has no intention of decolonising and nor will I betray my forebears or the ideals of my youth.
I am proud of empire.

title: Shaming boys just for being male is a sorry situation
text:
As a father of two boys and one girl, my heart breaks when I think about any of them navigating today’s world of relationships. Never have I felt more strongly the desire, common to all parents at some time or another, to bind them in bubble wrap and keep them away from a world impossible to understand.

An assembly was held recently at Brauer College, a school in rural Warrnambool, in southwest Victoria, Australia, during which its boy pupils, some as young as 12, were made to stand up and apologise to the girls for crimes of rape, sexual abuse and harassment committed by men against women. text:
The boy was 12 when he attacked his first victim, who was 11, the High Court in Glasgow was told

A 17-year-old schoolboy has been sentenced to five years for raping three girls.

The teenager, who cannot be named for legal reasons, attacked his first victim who was 11, when he was only 12. He went on to rape another two victims — one while he was on bail.

At the High Court in Glasgow Judge Lord Arthurson ordered the teenager to be on licence for seven years after his release from custody.

He told the teenager, who pleaded guilty via video link: “I am deeply concerned by the risk you present to the public and in particular to young female children and women.

“You appear to be an extremely dangerous young man.”

The court was told that the teenager began watching pornography aged 11

title: Times letters: Parents, schools and responsibility for abuse
text:
Sir, I went to a similar prep school in the 1960s as described by Louis de Bernières (News & letter, Mar 31). At that time most schools believed in corporal punishment. There was a strong belief that one needed to be toughened up at prep school to survive public school. Homesickness is an intense sadness at any age, but it did teach me how life can be unpleasant and how one has to deal with it. It is wrong to assume every child at boarding school in this period was unhappy, or every master sadistic or perverted because he believed in the merits of corporal punishment.

Parents have different concerns for their children today, and only time will reveal their mistakes made for the best
summary:
Sir, I went to a similar prep school in the 1960s as described by Louis de Bernières (News & letter, Mar 31).
At that time most schools believed in corporal punishment.
There was a strong belief that one needed to be toughened up at prep school to survive public school.
Homesickness is an intense sadness at any age, but it did teach me how life can be unpleasant and how one has to deal with it.
Parents have different concerns for their children today, and only time will reveal their mistakes made for the best

text:
Some of the sexual assault claims on social media revolve around the St Andrews University chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi

A fraternity at the centre of campus rape allegations has claimed that it risks becoming a victim of “cancel culture”, saying its members have been subjected to trial by social media.

An investigation was opened after almost 100 accounts alleging sexual assault and harassment were posted on a social media account. Some of the claims revolve around a chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi (AEPi), an all-male Jewish society founded in New York in 1913.

title: Woman raped by priest set to sue over Catholic Church’s response
text:
A woman sexually abused by a priest has threatened legal action against the Catholic church after officials branded her “needy” and “manipulative”.

The abuse, and later rape, began when she was 15 and continued for years. She reported her allegations to the church in 2016 and received a settlement in 2018.

Sponsored

It is understood that the woman has sent a letter threatening legal action on the grounds of personal injury after alleging she was “re-traumatised” at the hands of safeguarding staff when she disclosed the abuse.

The case is against the Archdiocese of Westminster, of which Cardinal Vincent Nichols, leader of the Catholic church in England and Wales, is head. It is understood that Nichols is named repeatedly in the letter. No personal legal liability

title: London Oratory School is accused of fostering ‘rape culture’
text:
The headteacher wrote to parents reminding them of the virtues of “chastity” and the “sacrament of marriage”

The London Oratory has become the latest leading school to face accusations of fostering a rape culture among its pupils.

An Instagram account has been set up to share the testimonies of girls who join the Roman Catholic school in the sixth form, which include claims of rape and sexual assault.

Sponsored

The headteacher of the school in Fulham, west London, has been accused of failing to address the matter properly after responding to pupils and parents reminding them of the virtues of “chastity” and the “sacrament of marriage”.

Despite being a state school the London Oratory has a low uptake of children from deprived homes. It counts the actor Simon Callow and the children of Tony Blair and Nick Clegg among its alumni.

title: Oscars 2021: Nomadland takes best picture as Anthony Hopkins becomes oldest best actor
text:
The hot favourite, Nomadland, won best picture at the 93rd Academy Awards last night, while Sir Anthony Hopkins led a troupe of British winners by becoming the oldest recipient of an acting Oscar at 83.

The best actor award was long thought to be heading to the late Chadwick Boseman, who died of colon cancer shortly after completing his work in Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom. Instead, it went to Hopkins for his role as a man battling dementia in The Father in a surprise victory.

Sky Atlantic

title: Alleged rape victims will no longer face ‘digital strip searches’ by police
text:
The forms obliged victims of sexual offences to hand over their data to investigators

Controversial consent forms known as “digital strip searches” because they allowed police to examine everything in the mobile phones of rape and sexual offence victims are being scrapped.

The National Police Chiefs Council (NPCC) has written to chief constables across the country to announce the forms will be withdrawn and replaced by August 13.

Sponsored

The decision comes after Elizabeth Denham, the information commissioner, last month recommended they be removed and rewritten as they did not properly explain the legal basis for the digital intrusion into alleged victims.

The Centre for Women’s Justice (CWJ) brought a legal challenge last year which argued that the use of these forms was unlawful, discriminatory and led to excessive and intrusive disclosure requests.

Rape and sexual violence groups have warned
summary:

text:

In the great Covid-19 largesse-meets-election-freebie munificence, in which everything from laptops for school kids to free bikes have been promised, students have been largely left to fend for themselves. The more prestigious the establishment, the worse it seems to be.

title: Demonising boys won’t change toxic culture
text:
Three weeks ago, my teenage daughter mentioned that her Instagram feed was suddenly full of testimonies from girls talking about appalling sexual abuse they had suffered at school and university. “Read them and weep,” she said, “it’s even worse than I thought.” I was horrified. One of my teenage sons had also seen postings on Everyone’s Invited. “It’s barbaric,” he said.

I eventually tracked down the website’s founder, Soma Sara, who lives with her grandmother in Paris; the 22-year-old was polite, charming and quietly spoken but determined. She’d been trying for nine months to get people to listen to her and her friends’ stories of rape culture. It was only when she started to mention schools by name that Everyone’s Invited went viral on

title: I witnessed torture and rape in Syrian jail, says German aid worker
text:
Martin Lautwein, who worked for an aid organisation, was also tortured in detention in Damascus

A German aid worker has given a harrowing account of the torture and rape he witnessed in a Syrian detention centre where he was held for six weeks with a friend after being arrested on suspicion of spying.

Martin Lautwein, 29, said he saw prisoners hanging by their wrists like “sheep waiting to be slaughtered” and others being electrocuted while tied to metal chairs.

Sponsored

On the second night in detention, he heard crying in a neighbouring cell next to his where children were being separated from their mother, who was then assaulted. “I cannot forget her screams,” he said. “It was clear she was being raped.”

Lautwein, a former nightclub bouncer, says he too was tortured but declined to give details for fear of upsetting

title: A cold shoulder for the hot spell’s ‘bathing beauties’
text:
High Peak in Derbyshire is a fair distance from the sea in any direction, which may explain a wistful email that arrived from there a couple of days ago. “I think it was last Wednesday,” Jeremy White wrote, “when your front page carried a delightful picture of two young women sunbathing on the beach at Bournemouth. Just in case some killjoy writes in to complain can I just say that I thought the picture had an old-fashioned air of seaside innocence about it — the phrase ‘bathing beauties’ comes to mind. We need more bathing beauties, not fewer on your pages.”

We also need warmer weather, but full marks for the sentiment — one not shared, I’m afraid, by others who got in touch.

Sponsored

title: Sylvana Simons: the pop princess who became a hate figure, then went into politics
text:
It seems appropriate that the broadcaster Sylvana Simons’s historic ascent to the Dutch parliament should have happened after an election campaign that, because of lockdown, played out mostly on screens.

Talking on Zoom from her Amsterdam living room wearing a floral sundress and no make-up, the 50-year-old former TV presenter — and the first black woman to start a political party in the Netherlands — exudes the same charisma and humour with which she brought music television to the Dutch masses in the 1990s.

title: My escape from a Chinese internment camp
text:
After two or three days at the internment camp, Sayragul Sauytbay heard the screams for the first time. She had been sent to work as a teacher in one of the centres where China “re-educates” Uighurs and other ethnic groups in the northwest province of Xinjiang. Already she had seen that the “living dead” inmates, shaven-headed with black eyes and mutilated fingers, were chained together in packed, stinking cells.

The sounds of distress resonated through the halls of the “concrete coffin” in which they were housed. “I’d never heard anything like it in all my life. Screams like that aren’t something you forget. The second you hear them, you know what kind of agony that person is experiencing,” she wrote later. “They sounded like the
summary:
After two or three days at the internment camp, Sayragul Sauytbay heard the screams for the first time.
She had been sent to work as a teacher in one of the centres where China “re-educates” Uighurs and other ethnic groups in the northwest province of Xinjiang.
Already she had seen that the “living dead” inmates, shaven-headed with black eyes and mutilated fingers, were chained together in packed, stinking cells.
The sounds of distress resonated through the halls of the “concrete coffin” in which they were housed.
The second you hear them, you know what kind of agony that person is experiencing,” she wrote later.

title: US border overwhelmed by record migrant surge
text:
Migrants cross the Rio Grande river at the end of a dangerous journey. Last month 170,000 were apprehended at the US border, with many more slipping into the country undetected

The migrant refuge in the Texan border town of McAllen is searingly hot, overcrowded and noisy, and it smells strongly of sweat.

But the 300 or so people crammed into a room the size of a basketball court, behind blacked-out windows, are arguably among the lucky ones: footsore from weeks of gruelling travel from central America, they have made it through Mexico and across the US border. The traffickers earning large profits from the misery of their human cargo are far behind them.

Sponsored

Here, at the Humanitarian Respite Centre run by a Catholic nun, there is food, basic medicine and clean clothes, and mattresses to rest on, even if the constant sound of crying toddlers makes sleeping hard.

The journey undertaken by these people and

title: Jim Steinman obituary
text:
Jim Steinman, left, and Meat Loaf worked together for a number of years, writing the rock opera Bat Out of Hell together in 1977

“If you don’t go over the top you can’t see what’s on the other side,” Jim Steinman said. “So I start at ‘extreme’ and go from there.” It was a rule he applied to considerable effect in writing some of the most memorably operatic and bombastic songs in popular music.

Unable to “see the point in writing songs about ordinary, real-life stuff”, Steinman instead cast himself as rock music’s heir to Richard Wagner, creating an alternative universe in gothic songs populated by vampires, fast cars, motorbikes, obsessive lovers, beautiful but doomed heroes and bats out of hell. It was, as Steinman put it, a Grand Guignol world in which everything was “heightened, oversized, gigantic, thrilling and silly”.

Sponsored

For Bonnie Tyler he wrote not just any

title: British girl stuck in Syrian camp was trafficked at 12 then raped
text:
Syria’s Roj camp, pictured, and Al Hol camp are thought to house nine British men, 16 women and 34 children

A British girl who was trafficked to Syria at the age of 12 and then raped and impregnated by an Islamic State fighter is among 50 women and children stranded in refugee camps.

A report from the campaign group Reprieve reveals that two thirds of British women detained in northeast Syria were coerced and trafficked to the region before being sexually exploited.

Sponsored

The group says that many were under 18 when they travelled to Isis territory and have suffered years of exploitation, including forced marriage, rape and domestic servitude.

Some have since had their own children, who are denied basics such as education and consular assistance. Reprieve argues that the government is “systematically failing trafficking victims” by not bringing them home.

The Conservative MP Andrew

title: Court quashes man’s conviction for joining in gang rape
text:
The Director of Public Prosecutions did not oppose the application to overturn the conviction

The Court of Appeal has quashed the conviction of a man for taking part in a gang rape after the defence received undisclosed information that the complainant had made other sexual allegations in the past.

The Director of Public Prosecutions did not oppose the man’s application to have his conviction overturned. The man, now 25, who was jailed for four years in June 2017, is reserving his position in relation to compensation for a miscarriage of justice.

text:
Protests against President Lukashenko were held outside the Belarusian embassy in Kiev, Ukraine

Thousands of striking workers and protesters converged on the centre of Minsk last night, ratcheting up the pressure on President Lukashenko of Belarus after a disputed election.

Industrial action broke out at numerous enterprises and factories in the capital and other cities as Mr Lukashenko’s main opponent called for nationwide rallies against his rule this weekend.

Speaking in a video address from abroad, Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, 37, condemned police violence and said she was convinced she won Sunday’s election, despite receiving only 10 per cent of the vote in the official count.

title: Brenda Power: Naming in fake rape cases is the real shame
text:
In 2017 a “peaceful, law-abiding, diligent young man” — the judge’s words — from a decent hardworking family, with no previous convictions, was jailed for four years for taking part in a gang rape. Last month, having served three years in jail, the now 25-year-old was freed by the Court of Appeal after it emerged that the complainant had made previous allegations of a sexual nature, which were not disclosed to the defence.

title: Burmese soldiers told to ‘shoot all that you see’ in atrocities against Rohingya
text:
Two former Burmese army soldiers have confessed to killing as many as 180 people during the ethnic cleansing of Muslim Rohingya in 2017, in unique and detailed testimony that is being studied by prosecutors in the International Criminal Court in the Hague.

The two soldiers, who deserted this year, named individual fellow soldiers and commanders who ordered the murders of Rohingya in several villages in Rakhine State in western Burma, also known as Myanmar. They described the widespread gang rape of women, and one of them admitted to raping a woman himself. After the killings they took part in dumping the bodies into mass graves.

The two men, who were members of separate infantry units, recalled being told by commanders to “exterminate all”, “kill all”,

title: Hundreds of Rohingya land after ‘six months at sea’
text:
Hundreds of stateless Rohingya Muslims who have landed in Indonesia, mostly women and children fleeing persecution in their native Burma, say they have spent six months at sea.

According to the authorities in the Indonesian province of Aceh, almost 300 of the refugees, the biggest group to land in the country since 2015, came ashore early yesterday morning at Ujung Blang beach near the city of Lhokseumawe.

The group had been at sea for six months, said Chris Lewa of the Arakan Project, a human rights organisation that monitors the movement of Rohingya refugees. According to reports from Aceh, it consisted of 181 women, 102 men and 14 children.

title: MeToo comes to Cairo as sons of business elite arrested for rape
text:
The alleged gang rape is said to have taken place at the Fairmont Nile City Hotel in Cairo

Egypt’s public prosecutor has issued arrest warrants for a group of young men alleged to have filmed themselves gang-raping a young woman in a five-star Cairo hotel.

Reports of the incident have surfaced on social media this year, six years after it allegedly took place. The pictures have prompted outrage at the behaviour of Egypt’s elite, and at the impunity they appeared to expect. The men were said to have inscribed their initials on the woman’s back, and to have threatened her with public shaming if she reported them.

Sponsored

The case has re-energised a MeToo campaign that had already led to the arrest of a former student at the American University of Cairo, Egypt’s most renowned college. He was accused of rape and serial harassment
summary:

title: St Andrews fraternity fears assault trial by social media
text:
An investigation has been launched after almost 100 accounts of sexual assault and harassment were posted on a social media account at St Andrews

The St Andrews University fraternity at the centre of rape allegations claimed that it is in danger of becoming a victim of “cancel culture” and that members are being tried by social media.

An investigation began after almost 100 accounts of sexual assault and harassment were posted on a social media account at St Andrews, alma mater of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.

Sponsored

The claims revolve around a chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi (AEPi), an all-male Jewish society founded in New York in 1913. The fraternity has confirmed it has suspended a number of members over the allegations and insisted any wrongdoers would be expelled.

However, it has now issued a detailed statement, claiming social media was being used as a weapon against it.

title: Uighur women in Chinese camps victims of ‘systematic abuse’
text:
Gulzira Auelkhan, a Kazakh woman, said that she had been forced to strip Uighur women naked in the camps

Uighur women forcibly detained in Chinese internment camps in Xinjiang have been subjected to a systematic campaign of rape, sexual abuse and torture, according to an investigation.

Victims, witnesses and guards have given first-hand accounts to the BBC of systemic sexual abuse in the so-called re-education camps, where a million Uighur Muslims and other minorities are detained. The accounts come after revelations about a system of mass surveillance, detention, indoctrination and forced sterilisation that the United States has said amounts to genocide.

title: The Assistant review — Weinstein’s office culture is exposed
text:
★★★★☆

Despite the best intentions in the world, depicting rape and abuse of women on screen is never neutral, always compromised. Male film-makers have been at it for years and have argued about the need for these scenes as narrative motivation (the slow reveal of the rape in The Accused), or as part of an exploration of male violence (the horrific abuse of Jessica Alba’s character in The Killer Inside Me), or as the defining moment in a female protagonist’s psyche (the rape of Lisbeth Salander in The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, both versions).

But, try as they might, it’s almost impossible to eradicate entirely the whiff of prurience that mixes freely with shock and outrage. The scenes become a deliberate

title: Why World Rugby must suspend Fiji
text:
The picture was striking. Fijian rugby now has a high-performance academy for women, funded by World Rugby and under the managership of one of Fiji’s greatest, Simon Raiwalui. On their first day in the academy, some weeks ago, the players were immaculate in their tracksuits. It was Fijian rugby as we love to regard it: talented and joyous.

How many of those smiles have already gone from the faces of rugby’s women and their sex in general? While we should admire World Rugby’s initiative, there are clear grounds today for expelling Fiji from the sport at all levels and we unequivocally call upon World Rugby to do so.

Sponsored

Fiji should not be allowed back until they remove a divisive figure at the top of their
summary:
Fijian rugby now has a high-performance academy for women, funded by World Rugby and under the managership of one of Fiji’s greatest, Simon Raiwalui.
On their first day in the academy, some weeks ago, the players were immaculate in their tracksuits.
It was Fijian rugby as we love to regard it: talented and joyous.
How many of those smiles have already gone from the faces of rugby’s women and their sex in general?
While we should admire World Rugby’s initiative, there are clear grounds today for expelling Fiji from the sport at all levels and we unequivocally call upon World Rugby to do so.

title: Rohingya must not be let down by the international community again
text:
Three years ago, hundreds of thousands of Rohingya fled to Bangladesh to escape, what the UN fact-finding mission concluded was a campaign of genocide and war crimes carried out by the Myanmar military.

The atrocities the Rohingya faced almost defy comprehension. They include killings, torture, executions, mass deportations and the razing of villages. Women and girls endured gang rape and other forms of horrific sexual violence. Children were thrown into fires and burned alive. No one has yet been held accountable for these crimes.

Sponsored

Today, there are nearly one million Rohingya refugees living in overcrowded camps in Cox’s Bazar in Bangladesh, the largest refugee camp in the world. Seventy per cent of them are women and children. Now, Covid-19 is further endangering the lives of
summary:
Three years ago, hundreds of thousands of Rohingya fled to Bangladesh to escape, what the UN fact-finding mission concluded was a campaign of genocide and war crimes carried out by the Myanmar military.
The atrocities the Rohingya faced almost defy comprehension.
Children were thrown into fires and burned alive.

Italian police have arrested four men and are investigating four other suspects in connection with the alleged drugging and gang rape of two 15-year-old British girls on holiday in the south of the country.

title: The King’s School calls in police after pupils share rape jokes online
text:
The King’s School in Grantham has contacted police after the comments by pupils in a live Instagram broadcast

A grammar school that boasts Sir Isaac Newton among its former pupils has contacted police after students took part in an Instagram chat where pupils swapped jokes about rape.

The King’s School in Grantham, Lincolnshire, confirmed that some of its pupils were involved in a live Instagram broadcast last Monday.

Sponsored

Simon Pickett, the school’s head teacher, said it would be taking “appropriate action” and had contacted police after complaints over the broadcast.

Sreenshots of the comments on the chat included one that said: “I’d take rape as a compliment” and another that read: “What do 9 out of 10 people enjoy? Gang rape.” Others described women as “objects”, while another said that women should “wake up and realise your [sic] never going to have equality”.

BBC Two

text:
A Catholic girl who says that she was kidnapped at gunpoint, gang-raped and forced to marry a man 30 years her senior has begged Boris Johnson to grant her asylum in Britain after a Pakistani court ruled that she should be returned to her abductor.

Maira Shahbaz, a 14-year-old altar server, and her family are in hiding after defying a Lahore High Court ruling that she should return to Mohamad Nakash Tariq, a 45-year-old barber, who claims he is her husband. title: The Good Girls by Sonia Faleiro, review — two girls’ deaths and India’s shame
text:
Sonia Faleiro was scrolling through Twitter in 2014 when she saw two girls floating in the wind. The cousins, aged 14 and 16, were hanging lifeless from a mango tree, their bodies draped in colourful salwar kameezes.

The teenagers had been the subject of a frantic search after disappearing from their village in the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. A few days before they vanished, they were seen speaking on a mobile phone, a rebellious act for girls from Katra Sadatganj. Suspicions were aroused and rumours had spread. Then on May 27 at around 9pm, they left their house — like they did before bed every night — and walked to the nearby field to go to the toilet.

title: MPs must back the genocide amendment to oppose the oppression of the Uighurs
text:
In the 1948 Genocide Convention, genocide is defined as five prohibited acts committed with the intention of destroying a group of people “in whole or in part”. As well as the more obvious acts of killing and causing serious harm, the list includes preventing births, forcibly removing children and “deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part”.

These acts must be carried out with the intention to destroy. This is what distinguishes genocide from other international crimes. But few genocidal regimes leave a paper trail detailing their genocidal intentions, and so intent can be inferred from actions.

Sponsored

Is what is happening to the Uighur people in China a genocide? Let us look at
summary:
In the 1948 Genocide Convention, genocide is defined as five prohibited acts committed with the intention of destroying a group of people “in whole or in part”.
These acts must be carried out with the intention to destroy.
This is what distinguishes genocide from other international crimes.
But few genocidal regimes leave a paper trail detailing their genocidal intentions, and so intent can be inferred from actions.

text:
Avocados are grown for British shoppers at Kakuzi farm in central Kenya

All British supermarkets that sold avocados from a farm in Kenya at the centre of a human rights abuse scandal have dropped it as a supplier pending further investigation.

The decision comes after The Sunday Times revealed last week that security guards working for Kakuzi, a farm in central Kenya, had been accused in 79 court claims of extreme violence against local residents.

title: Lowest caste Dalits seek salvation in Buddha
text:
At a simple ceremony in northern India last week, more than 230 men and women gathered to renounce their Hindu faith. Chanting vows, the group pledged to live by the teachings of the Buddha. In moments, their passage to Buddhism was complete. With it, they hope, comes an escape to freedom.

The converts were Dalits, the lowest rung of India’s caste hierarchy, formerly known as “untouchables”. The ceremony was an act of protest against the Hindu society that has shunned them, a defiant gesture of self-determination.

title: US border overwhelmed by record migrant surge
text:
Migrants cross the Rio Grande river at the end of a dangerous journey. Last month 170,000 were apprehended at the US border, with many more slipping into the country undetected

The migrant refuge in the Texan border town of McAllen is searingly hot, overcrowded and noisy, and it smells strongly of sweat.

But the 300 or so people crammed into a room the size of a basketball court, behind blacked-out windows, are arguably among the lucky ones: footsore from weeks of gruelling travel from central America, they have made it through Mexico and across the US border. The traffickers earning large profits from the misery of their human cargo are far behind them.

Pupils at Oxford High, whose alumnae include Dame Cressida Dick, the Metropolitan Police commissioner, and Dame Margaret Hodge, a former Labour minister, hosted an online conference for female politicians yesterday.

title: As nations squabble over the virus, Britain should lead the way on foreign aid
text:
For two decades, economic and political power has been shifting around the world, challenging the dominance of the West in the post-Second World War order. Covid-19 is now giving us a taste of crisis management in a world of competing power centres, and it is not a pretty picture.

Without urgent action, the prospects for the world’s most vulnerable are frightening: a chilling double emergency of Covid-19 contagion, often undetected and unrecorded, and economic shocks piling on the pain, while the most powerful and richest countries in the world squabble.

title: Tough Irish rape law to raise threshold for consent
text:
Victims of sexual and domestic violence are the focus of dozens of new justice reforms

Men accused of rape must prove they had “reasonable belief” that their alleged victim had consented to sex under reforms announced yesterday.

The tighter law is one of many designed to help victims of sexual and gender-based violence. The Justice Plan for 2021-23 includes two public awareness campaigns on the meaning of consent; one will target third-level students.

Sponsored

At present defendants can be acquitted if a jury accepts that they honestly or genuinely believed they had consent. The threshold of reasonable belief is seen as more objective.

title: Large rise in domestic abuse over three years
text:
The number of incidents reported to gardaí this year has risen sharply, but the number of individual victims has stayed about the same

The number of people who reported that they suffered domestic violence shot up by 57 per cent between 2016 and 2019.

Department of Justice figures showed that 7,489 individuals contacted gardaí last year, up from 4,755 in 2016. The latest figures showed that the number of reported victims of domestic violence this year had stayed at a similar level to 2019, with 7,258 people contacting gardaí up to November 23.

Sponsored

Separately, however, the force has reported that the number of individual incidents of domestic violence reported has increased by 18 per cent so far in 2020. This has widely been attributed to the lockdowns and other pandemic restrictions.

title: Gardaí investigate thousands of naked images shared on Discord website
text:
Discord said it had deleted the server involved and identified users associated with the content

The social media site where thousands of naked images of Irish women were posted without their consent has said that it will co-operate with the garda force to identify those responsible.

It emerged on Wednesday that the images were being shared online on Discord.

Sponsored

The leak is believed to include a range of images harvested from social media channels, including OnlyFans, where “fans” follow “creators” for a fee in order to access otherwise illicit content.

The leak also includes photos allegedly taken without a woman’s consent. It is alleged that some of the images are also of minors, meaning they would be considered child pornography under Irish law.

title: Why World Rugby must suspend Fiji
text:
The picture was striking. Fijian rugby now has a high-performance academy for women, funded by World Rugby and under the managership of one of Fiji’s greatest, Simon Raiwalui. On their first day in the academy, some weeks ago, the players were immaculate in their tracksuits. It was Fijian rugby as we love to regard it: talented and joyous.

How many of those smiles have already gone from the faces of rugby’s women and their sex in general? While we should admire World Rugby’s initiative, there are clear grounds today for expelling Fiji from the sport at all levels and we unequivocally call upon World Rugby to do so.

Sponsored

Fiji should not be allowed back until they remove a divisive figure at the top of their
summary:
Fijian rugby now has a high-performance academy for women, funded by World Rugby and under the managership of one of Fiji’s greatest, Simon Raiwalui.
On their first day in the academy, some weeks ago, the players were immaculate in their tracksuits.
It was Fijian rugby as we love to regard it: talented and joyous.
How many of those smiles have already gone from the faces of rugby’s women and their sex in general?
While we should admire World Rugby’s initiative, there are clear grounds today for expelling Fiji from the sport at all levels and we unequivocally call upon World Rugby to do so.

title: Erdogan puts his faith in Turkey’s stuttering economy
text:
President’s Erdogan’s strategy is to keep the economy turbocharged with cheap credit while making headline-grabbing moves that indulge his supporters

Each time Ayse Ozturk goes to the supermarket she thinks about what else she can cut from her basket. She works six days a week as a cleaner in Istanbul, and raises her daily rate each year, this January from 200 lira (£18) to 250 lira. As soon as she does so, however, the price of food and basic essentials overtakes her again.

“I go to the market and buy three things, and then I look at the price I am paying and it is huge,” said Ozturk, 49, a mother of two. “When I get to the next shop I don’t have money enough left to buy everything I had planned to.”

title: Teachers given help to spot signs of domestic abuse
text:
Professionals who work with children were asked to look out for anger and stress-related illnesses

Local authorities are sending domestic violence resource packs to schools to help teachers to recognise signs of abuse at home, due to an increase in incidents of abuse during the pandemic.

There was a sharp rise in the number of people seeking support from domestic violence during the first six months of the Covid-19 pandemic.

Sponsored

Between March and August of 2020, 3,450 women and 589 children contacted a domestic violence service for the first time. It is a crime that often goes under-reported, so the true prevalence is likely to be higher.

The information packs have been distributed to schools and other professionals such as GPs and community volunteers in Roscommon, Dublin City North and Fingal. They contain information on different types of domestic abuse

title: We mustn’t surrender the UK’s reputation for fighting violence against women
text:
Today, on the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, we must demand that the government step up and commit to creating a safer world where women and girls, no matter where they reside, are able to live a life free of violence.

Though it may feel that a vaccine is in sight, Covid-19 continues to spread around the world infecting more than 50 million people causing 1.3 million deaths.

Sponsored

In the UK and around the world, Covid-19 lockdown measures have unleashed a surge in gender-based violence (GBV) at exactly the same time that the services on which survivors rely on have been cut or forced to close. This has left women and girls trapped in, or forced to return to dangerous households
summary:

title: More claims of sex abuse on university campuses
text:
Two more Scottish universities are investigating claims of sexual abuse on campus after students posted accounts of rape and harassment online.

Details of ten incidents have been written on a “Stirling Survivors” forum on Instagram, while students at Aberdeen University have also shared allegations of sexual misconduct.

Sponsored

It comes after St Andrews students used an Instagram page to detail 50 first-hand allegations of rape, sexual assault and harassment this month.

The incident was reported to the police but “because it was an issue of consent, no charges were pressed,” the student said.

title: EU offers Erdogan more money to halt migrant surge from Turkey
text:
President Erdogan has won more money from the EU in return for preventing a new refugee crisis in Europe.

Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, and Charles Michel, president of the European Council, spent three hours in “frank discussions” with the Turkish leader during a rare visit to Ankara yesterday. They agreed that a five-year-old deal under which Turkey was given €6 billion to stop the flow of migrants to Greece would be extended, with more money being provided. Exact details have yet to be made public, but an EU financing package that will help Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan to care for refugees will be announced soon.

The pair offered an olive branch to Erdogan after years of tense relations marked

title: Mandatory sex education gives certainty at a difficult time for children
text:
With all the anxiety about the impact of Covid-19 on children’s mental health and opening schools safely, one piece of good news for children and young people hasn’t received the attention it deserves. The introduction of mandatory relationships and sex education (RSE) in every secondary school in England.

Brook has been campaigning for this change for decades. Much of the evidence demonstrates that good-quality sex education has a range of positive outcomes. It delays sexual intercourse; reduces risk-taking; increases the use of condoms and contraception; and instils healthy attitudes to sexual and reproductive health. Its introduction in schools is something to celebrate and that is exactly what we are doing for this year’s Sexual Health Week.

title: Biden dismay as Turkey pulls out of accord to protect women
text:
Women protesters clashed with police during a demonstration against Turkey’s withdrawal from the Istanbul Convention

Europe and the US have denounced the Turkish government for pulling out of an international accord to protect women, with the US president calling it “disheartening”.

Turkey, where killings of women have surged in recent years, signed the Istanbul Convention, a Council of Europe agreement to prevent, prosecute and eliminate domestic violence and promote equality, in 2011.

Sponsored

Now the government of President Erdogan says that domestic laws, not outside fixes, will protect the rights of women.

After the withdrawal on Saturday thousands of women protested in Istanbul and other cities.

President Biden said Turkey’s decision was a “disheartening step backward” for the movement to end violence against women ERIN SCOTT/REUTERS

In a White House statement, President Biden said Turkey’s withdrawal from the convention was “sudden and unwarranted”.

“This is a disheartening step backward for the international movement to end violence against women globally,” he said.
summary:

title: CDC Group using British foreign aid to fund elite hospitals and gyms
text:
Millions of pounds in British aid money is funding hospitals in south Asia that have been criticised for overcharging or turning away coronavirus patients.

A private Indian hospital that was formally censured by the local government for failing to offer beds to people with Covid-19, and another in Pakistan charging hundreds of pounds a day for rooms with ventilators, have been given British development funding.

Sponsored

CDC Group, the government’s development finance division, has made investments worth more than £400 million in the healthcare sector. It has a mandate to tackle poverty but has been criticised for funding private hospitals which are unaffordable for patients with low incomes. Other investments include a private hospital in Zimbabwe used by the country’s elite and a Brazilian gym

title: Measures needed to cut persistent sexual violence
text:
Tougher measures to tackle gender-based violence are needed in Scotland, campaigners and politicians have said after figures highlighted blackspots for sexual offences.

A breakdown of crimes, including rape and assault, last year shows that the highest number, 203, were recorded in the Anderston/City/Yorkhill area of Glasgow, followed by Edinburgh’s Liberton/Gilmerton ward, with 102. Govan, in Nicola Sturgeon’s Glasgow Southside constituency, had 100, as did Buckhaven, Methil and Wemyss villages in Fife.

Sponsored

A total of 13,240 incidents were reported last year, an average of more than 1,000 a month. When the number of sexual offences is adjusted to account for population, the highest rate was recorded in the police division of Fife, with 32.3 crimes for every 10,000 people. A “rape culture” has become established at Scotland’s oldest university, fuelled by toxic male-dominated societies, a campus organisation has claimed.

title: ‘They are hunted like birds here’: killings of women soar in Turkey
text:
Pinar Gultekin’s parents knew that something was wrong the moment she didn’t answer her phone. Their daughter was 27 years old, and had just graduated from university in Mugla, a city in southwestern Turkey — spending her days hanging out with friends and posting laughing pictures on Instagram. Though her parents lived in Istanbul, they would speak to her almost every day.

At 4pm on July 16, Pinar’s mother called her. They chatted briefly and hung up. At 5pm she called again. Pinar didn’t answer. That day, according to a police report, she was beaten and murdered — her body stuffed into a bin, set on fire and covered in cement.
