title: South Africa: No end to lockdown, insists Ramaphosa
text:
South Africa’s leader resisted growing calls to quickly ease one of the world’s most severe lockdowns which business and union leaders have warned risks an “economic firestorm”.

President Ramaphosa broke a near three-week silence to go on television last night to defend his shuttering of much of the economy, which critics argue now threatens to outweigh the damage wrought by the coronavirus.

title: Would you go commando in this season’s must-have dress?
text:
How long after having a baby is it acceptable to wear a dress without knickers? That was the question I asked my 60,000-plus followers on Instagram last month while wearing the TchikiBoum pants-free dress by the cult Parisian brand Marcia. We’ve gone bra-less, embraced the G-string bikini and allowed crop tops to creep into almost every dress code. But the new frontier of risqué chic requires a little more gusto (with an emphasis on the gusts). Not since Alexander McQueen’s bumsters has the absence of 50 per cent of your lingerie set been so flagrant.

Surprisingly, the digital response to my query was resoundingly positive. While my post-partum tum was fairly obviously on display, few people blanched at the sight of me sans culottes.

How long after having a baby is it acceptable to wear a dress without knickers?

While my post-partum tum was fairly obviously on display, few people blanched at the sight of me sans culottes.

title: Ireland will not take more refugees from Greece, says minister despite medics’ plea
text:
Campaigners say conditions at a new refugee camp on Lesbos, which was set up after another was destroyed by fire, are “arguably worse”

The government has no plans to accept additional refugees from Greece despite an open letter from health professionals.

The letter to Roderic O’Gorman, the equality and integration minister, was signed by hundreds of health workers calling for Ireland to expand its response.

O’Gorman said: “The government pledge of last October to resettle up to 50 people from Lesbos was in addition to the commitment that Ireland had already made with the UNHCR [United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees] to resettle 2,900 refugees to Ireland between 2020 and 2023. It is not planned to consider accepting any additional refugees from Greece.”

He added: “My department is working with the Greek authorities and other relevant stakeholders to effect their relocation to Ireland as soon as possible,

title: South Africa needs to talk about its drink problem, says Ramaphosa
text:
South Africa’s president said “drastic measures” would be needed to combat alcohol abuse as violence against women and children rose after a lockdown ban on drink sales was lifted.

Trauma admissions to hospitals plunged by about 60 per cent during the 66-day ban, which was intended to free resources for coronavirus patients. Violent crime, gender-based violence and vehicle accidents all showed dramatic decreases before rebounding after restrictions were eased on June 1.

In a stern address to the nation this week, President Ramaphosa said it was “deeply disturbing” that an increase in violence, especially towards women and children, had accompanied the end of the hard lockdown. text:
A guard closes the Iberian Gate in Red Square. Moscow has lifted most of its coronavirus restrictions

Russia

Moscow’s health department said today that the city had 5,260 coronavirus deaths in May, a figure far higher than the official toll of 1,895 for last month.

Russia’s Covid-19 taskforce says there have been a total of 3,085 deaths in Moscow since the start of the pandemic. It was unclear when or if the official figures would be updated.

The total number of fatalities in Moscow for May was 15,713, or 61 per cent higher than the number of deaths for the month over the past decade, health officials said. The number of deaths was even higher than in 2010, when Moscow was engulfed in a toxic smog.

title: Bring home ‘trafficked’ Isis families, MPs urge
text:
This month the Court of Appeal ruled that the east London schoolgirl Shamima Begum, who married an Isis fighter in Raqqa, should be allowed home to challenge the removal of her UK citizenship

Senior Conservative MPs are campaigning for the return of British Islamic State brides and their children from Kurdish detention camps, arguing that some are victims of trafficking.

The former cabinet ministers Andrew Mitchell and David Davis and Commons committee chairmen Tom Tugendhat and Tobias Ellwood wrote to ministers demanding urgent action. There are estimated to be about 3,000 foreign citizens held in prison camps in northeast Syria. Fewer than 40 of these are thought to be British, the “vast majority” of whom are women and young children, the MPs said.

title: Nicola Sturgeon isn’t the feminist she’d have us all believe
text:
After Nicola Sturgeon released an “unscripted” Twitter video addressing the issue of young people leaving the SNP over failure to support the trans community, the first minister said she would re-evaluate gender recognition reform and that an independent Scotland would be an equal one for all. But can we take her seriously?

Her commitment to what she called woke issues are often celebrated but be careful. On the surface her reforms seem sparkling with promise but underneath sits murky water. I support LGBTQ+ reform but if the slow change in women’s representation under the SNP is anything to go by, change isn’t coming.

She has seen some groundbreaking legislation but if we delve into the power and gender dynamics of Scotland, the picture isn’t so

title: Kenyan girl, 12, forced to marry twice in month
text:
The girl is from the Masai community in Narok county, which has the highest rate of child marriage in Kenya

A 12-year-old Kenyan girl was married off by her father to two men in the space of a month.

The prospect of receiving cows as a dowry had prompted him to find his daughter husbands, the authorities who rescued the girl said.

Sponsored

In an interview with the Standard newspaper, the primary school pupil said that she had ambitions to become a doctor until she was made to marry a 51-year-old man as soon as she turned 12. “Our father had forcefully married off my two elder sisters and I was the only one remaining,” she told the newspaper. “I did not know him before and I did not love him. title: Boris Johnson and Joe Biden can be a powerful force against sexual violence in conflict
text:
Following Joe Biden’s victory in the US election last week, the UK has seen a flurry of comment on what it all means for the prime minister, Brexit, and the future of the relationship between Britain and America.

As the UK government looks for ways to work with the Biden administration over the next four years, its best bet is to drill down into the detail and work out a few key areas where UK and US values are aligned — and, crucially, to develop specific proposals for what steps the two countries can actually take together. Close and regular co-operation, often on fairly technical, nuts and bolts issues, is the bedrock of the “special relationship”.

But it is specific action which will give meaning

title: St Andrews student paper criticised for making light of sex predators
text:
There have been dozens of accounts of alleged rape, sexual assault and harassment at St Andrews

A freshers’ guide that joked about predatory straight men and defended “locker room banter” at the University of St Andrews has been rewritten after provoking criticism from students.

Dozens of first-hand accounts of alleged rape, sexual assault and harassment were posted online in the summer by a group called St Andrews Survivors.

Sponsored

The allegations, at the alma mater of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, prompted a chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi, a US-based fraternity, and the Kate Kennedy Club — the university’s oldest society — to launch investigations.

Linden Grigg, deputy editor of the St Andrews student paper, wrote the article

After the scandal broke the university’s independent student newspaper The Saint published a controversial article which suggested that men and women could never be friends as “the human urge to physicalise emotion will scupper it”.

title: Imran Khan’s hypocrisy betrays Pakistan’s voters
text:
Imran Khan, the former cricketer and professional playboy turned prime minister of Pakistan, is a staggering hypocrite. Khan, who spent his youth in Britain partying in the company of glamorous and often scantily clad women, now blames the way women dress for a rise in rape cases across Pakistan. Khan’s ridiculous advice to women is to cover up to prevent men being tempted, along the lines of the Islamic concept of purdah or modesty, which often involves segregation of the sexes.

Khan’s views, seemingly devoid of any self-awareness, range far and wide in their ignorance. Sexual violence is apparently the fault of societies “where vulgarity is on the rise”, by which he means places like Britain; Hollywood and Indian cinema’s obsession with “increasing obscenity”

title: Film reviews: Sound of Metal; Palm Springs
text:
You know an actor has made it when everyone starts playing the “Yes, but did you see him in X?” game. The British-Pakistani actor Riz Ahmed has appeared in many movies — Jason Bourne, The Sisters Brothers and Rogue One as well as HBO’s The Night Of — but his performance in Darius Marder’s Sound of Metal is the one that has won him an Oscar nomination, which means we all now get to go: “Yes, but I liked him before he was Oscar nominated . . . ” That’s how good he is. He has us squabbling like six-year-olds over who saw him first.

Ahmed plays Ruben, the drummer in a punk-metal band who, when the movie starts, has things pretty much sorted: off

title: Midsomer Murders returns, as whimsical and wicked as ever
text:
Here’s a mystery for you. Which British TV show that isn’t a soap has been running for 24 years? And has been officially declared the UK’s biggest detective export? The answer is Midsomer Murders, the ITV crime drama in which bizarre killings — and oddball killers — lurk beneath the surface of the quaint and picturesque villages of this fictional English county.

The world loves Midsomer Murders. It sells in more than 200 territories (international sales go by territories, not countries): it’s big in Germany — Angela Merkel is a fan; Anglophiles in America lap it up; and they go crazy for it in Denmark, where apparently it’s more popular than The Killing ever was. title: The Warrior and the Prophet by Peter Cozzens review — Tecumseh, the warrior who defied America
text:
They met for the first time at Fort Knox on August 13, 1810. William Henry Harrison was governor of the Indiana Territory, a man small of stature, but large in ego. Looming over him was Tecumseh, a strikingly handsome Native American warrior of dignity and domineering personality. Keen to assert his authority, Harrison motioned Tecumseh to sit down. He refused. An aide repeated the instruction: “Your father, General Harrison, offers you a seat.” Tecumseh feigned indignation at this calculated act of condescension. “My father invites me to a seat? The sun is my father, and the Earth is my mother, and I will repose upon her bosom.”

Tecumseh’s temerity was impressive, but somewhat hollow. In truth, he’d found little opportunity to repose peacefully in Earth’s

title: Diana Russell obituary
text:
In her campaign against pornography Diana Russell took to tearing up magazines in shops and spray-painting businesses

When Ban Ki-moon, the UN secretary-general, referred to “femicide” on the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women in 2015, it marked a turning point in Diana Russell’s war on the “killing of females by males, because they are female”.

Words mattered to Russell, a pioneering scholar who spent her life challenging norms. In 1976 she had mobilised feminists from 40 countries to testify at an event called the International Tribunal on Crimes Against Women, in Brussels. There she redefined and politicised the term “femicide” for the 2,000 women gathered, announcing: “From the burning of witches in the past, to the recent more widespread custom of female infanticide in many societies, to the killing of women for so-called honour, we realise that femicide

title: What inspired a band of women warriors to help defeat Isis?
text:
A soldier of the YPJ preparing for conflict with Isis. Anna Campbell, left, was a British activist who died on the battlefield in 2018 during an operation by the Turkish military

For four months the women fought furiously, day and night, to oust the Islamic State militia from the town of Kobani in northern Syria. The Isis troops dug in with tanks, artillery and Humvees. The all-female Kurdish Women’s Defence Units had no such weapons: clad in camouflage green, they fought with old Russian Kalashnikovs, handmade grenades and rudimentary artillery platforms, cobbled from construction vehicles and pick-up trucks. American special forces were awed by the bravery of these female warriors.

Finally, on January 26, 2015, the Isis forces retreated, leaving an estimated 2,000 dead on the battlefield. The women and their male Kurdish comrades-in-arms danced the traditional dabke among the ruins and burnt-out Isis tanks.

The siege of Kobani is seen as a turning point in

title: How podcasts are helping to crack real-life crimes
text:
Josh Dean was frustrated. He had spent nearly a year chasing a con artist suspected of swindling more than a million dollars out of people in the entertainment industry, relaying this story of outlandish deception for his podcast Chameleon: Hollywood Con Queen. Every time he got close, the suspect moved on, took on another alias and shut down social media accounts.

The FBI was on the case too. The Hollywood Con Queen had been luring producers, make-up artists, aspiring screenwriters and actors over to Jakarta to shoot fake blockbusters since 2013 by impersonating female Hollywood executives. Dean reckons there are up to 100 victims. But by last November there was still no arrest. Dean and the many victims he spoke to were losing faith
summary:
Josh Dean was frustrated.
Every time he got close, the suspect moved on, took on another alias and shut down social media accounts.
The Hollywood Con Queen had been luring producers, make-up artists, aspiring screenwriters and actors over to Jakarta to shoot fake blockbusters since 2013 by impersonating female Hollywood executives.
Dean reckons there are up to 100 victims.

text:

The person accused of shooting dead a custody sergeant inside a police station is a reclusive young autistic man from a middle-class family.

Louis De Zoysa, 23, is in a critical condition in hospital after allegedly killing Sergeant Matiu Ratana inside Croydon custody suite in south London early last Friday.

Sponsored

A man suspected of supplying Mr De Zoysa with the revolver used in the murder was arrested in Norwich early yesterday morning as the police investigation intensified.

Officers blew the doors off a former Second World War bomb storage unit on a Surrey farm as they swooped on new locations connected to the suspect.

Police cordoned off the area where Mr De Zoysa was arrested before allegedly killing Sergeant Matiu Ratana GRANT FALVEY/LNP

Mr De Zoysa was arrested close to his family home at about 1.30am on Friday and taken to the police station

title: William Boyd: ‘For me, the Sixties represented a time of frustration’

The Sixties — or at least the swinging bits — swung by, barely touching most people. It was something happening somewhere else, probably on lurid shag-pile carpets, to good-looking people (and Serge Gainsbourg).

William Boyd, the author of bestsellers such as Any Human Heart, certainly didn’t disabuse me of this notion when I spoke to him via Zoom last week. His latest novel, Trio, published this week, is set in 1968. And it very much captures the groovy, hectic spirit of the age. So did the Sixties swing for him?

title: Times letters: Pride in achievements of the British Empire
text:
Sir, It is reassuring to learn that Matthew Parris is unapologetic about the British Empire (“I won’t be decolonising, I’ve no shame about empire”, Notebook, Apr 7). I was born in 1931 and was brought up to have pride in our achievements, which was confirmed when, as a young soldier, I served in, or visited, several of our colonies. As children we celebrated Empire Day each year with a parade and usually a half-day holiday from school. We celebrated the way we had brought sound governance, the rule of law, schools and colleges as well as more tangible benefits such as roads and railways. In some colonies we started new industries such as tin and rubber in Malaya or cotton in Uganda.

It was not
summary:

I was born in 1931 and was brought up to have pride in our achievements, which was confirmed when, as a young soldier, I served in, or visited, several of our colonies.

title: Italy’s mafia trial of the century
text:
From left: the special courtroom in Lamezia Terme, Calabria, on January 13, the opening day of the trial; Cinquefrondi in Calabria

Italy’s biggest mafia trial in 30 years got off to a deceptively low-key start in Calabria last month as hundreds of lawyers filed into a converted call centre on an industrial estate to defend 355 ’NDrangheta syndicate suspects. Covid restrictions on travel meant the cages set up to hold the accused were empty. Instead, video screens hanging from the ceiling of the huge room lit up as defendants stuck in jails across Italy were patched in for a very unusual Zoom conference.

As is customary on the first day of big Italian trials, no evidence was heard as judges and lawyers discussed court procedures, and by mid-afternoon bored journalists were taking shelter from the rain outside, smoking and knocking back espressos served at the makeshift

title: Russell T Davies on It’s A Sin: ‘Aids was like everything people said about you became true in the shape of a virus’
text:
When Russell T Davies was a teenager in Swansea, he heard about a gay sauna in Newport. “I used to think, I could go and have lots and lots of sex in that sauna right now. I was 17, I was a virgin. How horny are you at 17? You’d have sex with a letterbox.” He thought about the sauna a lot. Eventually, one afternoon in 1980, he travelled to Newport alone, found his way to its door — but at the last moment lost his nerve and walked on by.

“I was too scared to go in.” Not because of Aids; the disease hadn’t yet been identified. “I was simply scared of men and sex and becoming what I am.” At the time Davies

title: What happens at a royal funeral?
text:
What are the different types of royal funeral?

A state funeral is generally limited to sovereigns but may, by order of the sovereign, and on the recommendation of parliament which votes on money to fund it, be extended to exceptionally distinguished persons. State funerals are the responsibility of the Earl Marshal to deliver, with the support of the College of Arms.

A royal ceremonial funeral is granted by the sovereign to members of the royal family who hold high military rank, consorts of the sovereign and those deemed appropriate. One was held for Diana, Princess of Wales. They are funded by the Queen and are the responsibility of the lord chamberlain, the senior officer of the royal household.

Sponsored

The differences between the two are not
summary:
What are the different types of royal funeral?
A state funeral is generally limited to sovereigns but may, by order of the sovereign, and on the recommendation of parliament which votes on money to fund it, be extended to exceptionally distinguished persons.
State funerals are the responsibility of the Earl Marshal to deliver, with the support of the College of Arms.
A royal ceremonial funeral is granted by the sovereign to members of the royal family who hold high military rank, consorts of the sovereign and those deemed appropriate.
They are funded by the Queen and are the responsibility of the lord chamberlain, the senior officer of the royal household.

title: Trust us, it’s the changing face of Britain
text:
The program analysed nearly 2,000 pictures in the National Portrait Gallery from 1505 to 2016

Henry VIII’s run of marital strife suggests that he was not particularly interested in being seen as dependable. Now an algorithm seems to have confirmed it.

The program analysed portraits of hundreds of figures from British history to assess the trustworthiness of the faces that appeared. It found a distinct trend: for five centuries, prominent people chose to be depicted as ever more truthful and reliable.

Sponsored

The researchers behind the work believe that the movement towards more positive scores, which mean that somebody looks more dependable, sheds light on a fundamental shift in the nature of western society.

Mary English, the businesswoman and adventurer, was given a trustworthiness rating of 2.61. The algorithm, which looks for features that people find trustworthy, gives a score of between minus 3 and plus 3 ALAMY

Figures such as Henry VIII who strode the corridors of power during the 16th century appear to have lived by Niccolò Machiavelli’s cutthroat dictum that it was

The program analysed nearly 2,000 pictures in the National Portrait Gallery from 1505 to 2016Henry VIII’s run of marital strife suggests that he was not particularly interested in being seen as dependable.
Now an algorithm seems to have confirmed it.
The program analysed portraits of hundreds of figures from British history to assess the trustworthiness of the faces that appeared.
It found a distinct trend: for five centuries, prominent people chose to be depicted as ever more truthful and reliable.

title: Emirates lift Sharia to allow alcohol and ban honour killings
text:
Drinking alcohol and cohabiting outside marriage are to be allowed in the United Arab Emirates after the state announced a relaxation of its strict Islamic laws.

So-called honour killings, in which men murder female relatives who are deemed to have brought shame on the family, have also been criminalised under laws that have come into immediate effect. There will also be harsher punishments for men who harass women.

Sponsored

The move is part of a long-running drive to attract western tourists and investment despite the strict Sharia-based legal system. About 8.4 million foreigners, including 250,000 Britons, live in the UAE, outnumbering locals by nine to one. Dozens have been persecuted in the past for kissing in public, homosexuality or breaking alcohol and drugs laws. More recently
summary:
Drinking alcohol and cohabiting outside marriage are to be allowed in the United Arab Emirates after the state announced a relaxation of its strict Islamic laws.
So-called honour killings, in which men murder female relatives who are deemed to have brought shame on the family, have also been criminalised under laws that have come into immediate effect.

title: Myanmar tyrant partied on Bloody Saturday as troops opened fire on children
text:
As guests in ceremonial uniforms and traditional Burmese silk finery took their seats for the open-air gala dinner, an illuminated portrait lit the night sky above Naypyidaw, Myanmar’s capital.

A swarm of drones depicted the features of General Min Aung Hlaing in a dot-to-dot display of the vanity and delusion of the diminutive dictator, who had just unleashed a reign of terror on his own citizens. By the time the banquet was over, his security forces had killed 141 unarmed civilians, including several children, in the bloodiest day since he staged a coup on February 1.

title: Henry ‘Chips’ Channon: The Diaries 1918-1938, edited by Simon Heffer review — snobbery, gossip and Hitler worship
text:
In 1936 Henry “Chips” Channon, the greatest British diarist of the 20th century, visited Berlin during the Olympic Games. There he encountered, in swift succession, three famous Germans: the first he described as “a loveably disarming man”; the second was “dark, intelligent”. But it was the third personage that really made Channon swoon: “One felt one was in the presence of some semi-divine creature.”

These were Hermann Goering, Joseph Goebbels and Adolf Hitler.

Sponsored

As for the Nazi Olympic Games, Channon recorded that, “Mankind has never staged anything so terrific, or so impressive.”

Channon had all the qualities of a fine diarist: he was supremely well connected, astute, occasionally lyrical, indiscreet and unsparing in his portraits of himself and others, people he loved and admired as

title: Father beheads girl, 14, who ran away with older lover
text:
Romina Ashrafi told police who took her home that she feared violence from her father

A 14-year-old girl has been beheaded by her father after she ran away with a man 20 years her senior.

Romina Ashrafi was killed in her sleep after leaving her home in Talesh, northwest Iran, and being returned by police. Her father, Reza Ashrafi, is said to have vowed not to harm her, although she had told police she feared violent punishment.

Sponsored

The case has prompted politicians including President Rouhani to call for stricter laws against so-called honour killings. Mr Ashrafi is in custody and will probably face trial, with a sentence of up to ten years in jail if he is found guilty.

title: Light sentence for ‘honour killer’ dad stirs rage in Iran
text:
Romina Ashrafi was asleep at home in northern Iran when her father came into her room. Aged 14, she had run away with an older boyfriend in his late twenties but had been found and brought back.

For weeks, according to local reports, her father had tried to convince his wife to force Romina to kill herself to save the family’s “honour”.

Sponsored

When his wife refused, he took matters into his own hands. That night in May, the former farmer picked up a sickle, went to his daughter’s bedroom and beheaded her.

Last week he was sentenced to nine years in jail by a district court, sparking outrage at the light sentence.

Romina’s mother, Rana Dashti, told the Iranian Labour News Agency, “I am going

Romina Ashrafi was asleep at home in northern Iran when her father came into her room.

title: Times letters: New lockdown and the No 10 briefing chaos
text:
Sir, It is clear that this next lockdown is now necessary, if rather late. If it is not to be repeated, the time must be used to build a local, effective test, trace and isolate system. The present mostly central one, largely run by private companies, has had enough time to prove itself and is clearly not working. Countries that have succeeded in moderating the spread of the virus have all had a rigorous, local system. In the UK, we already have a local system of healthcare covering every citizen — the long established network of GP surgeries. It is a mystery to me why GPs have been sidelined in the management of this pandemic. Think how much better it would be if everyone could

title: Justine McCarthy: Finucane family deserve justice, not more lies
text:
If the British government were a second-hand car salesman, would you be inclined even to discuss the price of his dangling, furry dice? Chances are, once you got them home, you’d find spots on only five sides of each cube and, on the sixth, the legend: “sucker”.

Boris Johnson leads a government that has no scruples. Less than a year after signing the Brexit withdrawal agreement, Brandon Lewis, the Northern Ireland secretary, shamelessly told the House of Commons that the UK Internal Market Bill contravened international law underpinning the deal. This week, Johnson’s government intends forging ahead with separate taxation legislation designed to break that very same law, the aim of which was to protect the Good Friday agreement and peace in Northern Ireland.

Sponsored

If
summary:

title: Po-faced office culture is killing our sense of humour
text:
With a turn of phrase so deadly that it encapsulates its own meaning and would send Ken Dodd sobbing into therapy, Stanford University academics say that in the corporate world laughter is “under-leveraged”. They run an MBA course on “enhancing influence and status” through office humour: it earns as many credits as their managerial accounting module. People, in short, must laugh with colleagues not from companionable joie de vivre but to earn more money and “leverage”. Shades of Ricky Gervais in The Office. Or the despised management stooge Gus in Drop the Dead Donkey, forever cooing “Office banter, great!” as his colleagues mock him.

The Stanford team seem puzzled that laughter decreases at the age of 23, only to return in old age.
summary:
With a turn of phrase so deadly that it encapsulates its own meaning and would send Ken Dodd sobbing into therapy, Stanford University academics say that in the corporate world laughter is “under-leveraged”.
They run an MBA course on “enhancing influence and status” through office humour: it earns as many credits as their managerial accounting module.
People, in short, must laugh with colleagues not from companionable joie de vivre but to earn more money and “leverage”.
Or the despised management stooge Gus in Drop the Dead Donkey, forever cooing “Office banter, great!” as his colleagues mock him.
The Stanford team seem puzzled that laughter decreases at the age of 23, only to return in old age.

title: Letters to the Editor: dump the ignoble nobles and ban the tarnished gongs
text:
Unlike your leader writer (Editorial, last week), I am delighted to see the

appalling Peter Cruddas “elevated” to the House of Lords. I also hope Boris Johnson ennobles still more IRA and KGB acolytes, the rest of his family and the entire chumocracy.

Those beacons of entrepreneurial excellence, Sir Philip and Lady Green, deserve a peerage apiece; and by looking further afield — Lord Putin of St Petersburg, perhaps, and some ermine-clad Chinese kleptocrats — we would show the world that post-Brexit Britain is truly open for business.

Sponsored

Much more of this, and we might even get an elected second chamber, like every other democracy. Go on, Boris, you can do it.

Rosemary Sealey, Canterbury

The ennoblement of Peter Cruddas delighted at least one Sunday Times reader REX/SHUTTERSTOCK

Chopping block

I do not know where to

My Father and Me

When the acclaimed documentary film-maker Nick Broomfield was young his photographer father, Maurice, let him have a camera of his own. He closely monitored Nick’s work and once insisted that a picture the youngster was very proud of — a miserable-looking donkey staring behind a wire fence — was a waste of film. Young Nick disagreed and it’s a story that encapsulates father and son’s intense but not always easy relationship. Maurice was a former factory worker who specialised in powerful and rather romantic pictures of postwar British industry and had the eye and temperament of a perfectionist. title: Honour: ITV’s true-life drama about an honour killing
text:
On January 24, 2006 three men tortured, raped and then strangled to death a 20-year-old woman in the sitting room of her parents’ home in southwest London. It was just as her father and uncle had intended. It was also what Banaz Mahmod had herself predicted when in December she had visited a police station to report that her family were plotting to kill her.

Thirteen years later, on the afternoon of October 1, 2019, one of the nation’s favourite actresses, Keeley Hawes, is dressed in a navy blue trouser suit and striding down a bleak corridor in the old BT building in Watford. She enters what on ITV’s Honour, a dramatisation of the investigation, will pass for a police incident room in Lewisham,

title: There’s no one less Irish than an expat Republican
text:
We like to claim Ernesto “Che” Guevara as one of our own. Guevara was an Argentina-born guerrilla fighter who helped Fidel Castro overthrow the American-backed Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista in 1959. He had an Irish ancestor, Patrick Lynch, who was born in Galway in 1715. So thrilled are we by this connection that, in 2012, a Che statue was proposed by Galway city council, and a stamp was issued here in his honour five years later.

The uncomfortable reality that Guevara killed lots of people does not count against him in Ireland. Revolutionary violence has always had a certain romantic allure for those of a socialist persuasion, and helps explain why that famous image of him by the artist Jim Fitzpatrick has adorned the walls
summary:
We like to claim Ernesto “Che” Guevara as one of our own.
Guevara was an Argentina-born guerrilla fighter who helped Fidel Castro overthrow the American-backed Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista in 1959.
He had an Irish ancestor, Patrick Lynch, who was born in Galway in 1715.
So thrilled are we by this connection that, in 2012, a Che statue was proposed by Galway city council, and a stamp was issued here in his honour five years later.
The uncomfortable reality that Guevara killed lots of people does not count against him in Ireland.

title: Sir Kim Darroch: how Donald Trump and Boris Johnson led our man in Washington to quit
text:
Lord Darroch of Kew is surveying his garden in Richmond. There are pink geraniums and Japanese anemone, crocosmia and pots of tomatoes and squash. The lawn is lined, mantis-green, bowling club-even. Come autumn, he will divide the beds.

But Sir Kim, 66, has not spent the year since his inflamed exit as UK ambassador to the United States just gardening. Good grief, no. He’s spent it penning a book about his final five days in the Foreign Office, writing in a tearing fury about the “monster” experience, “The worst of my life. Like being trapped in a nightmare.”

Sponsored

With Donald Trump in Washington, 2019 TWITTER.COM/KIMDARROCH

Indeed, it’s hard to imagine a more brutal ending to such an unblemished 42-year career – a career that included posts such as national security adviser

title: Napoleon lecturer Oleg Sokolov caught with dead girlfriend’s arms in bag
text:
Oleg Sokolov was drunk when he fell into a river while trying to dispose of his girlfriend’s body in St Petersburg

A Russian expert on Napoleon who enjoyed dressing up as the French emperor and asked colleagues to call him “sire” was found guilty yesterday of killing and dismembering his student girlfriend and was sentenced to 12 and a half years in a penal colony.

Oleg Sokolov, 64, a university lecturer, was caught by police with a rucksack containing the arms of Anastasiya Yeshchenko, 24, as he attempted to dispose of them in St Petersburg’s Moyka river. He had fallen in because he was drunk. Divers later found other parts of the victim’s body downstream.

title: My stay with John Mappin, the QAnon hotelier
text:
Back in 2006 I was introduced to a man called John Mappin. He was, at that time, a prominent figure in the Church of Scientology and lived in a suite of rooms with his wife, Irina, in a grim and rather dreary Victorian hotel on a stunning bit of north Cornish coastline. The hotel itself was unprepossessing really, hovering between two and three stars, although it had a grandly auspicious name: Camelot Castle.

title: The rise of Mohammed bin Salman, in 10 steps – from $50 million parties to the murder of Jamal Khashoggi

1 Throw a $50 million party for your friends

Mohammed bin Salman had hit Riyadh harder and faster than any prince in recent memory. He had taken charge of Saudi Arabia’s economy, been given carte blanche to spend its billions, made commander of the armed forces and launched a war in Yemen. By now, in 2015, the deputy crown prince was mentioned so frequently by the media he needed an abbreviation: MBS. It was time to celebrate.

title: Police sergeant Matt Ratana shot by handcuffed killer
text:
Sergeant Matiu Ratana with his partner, Sue Bushby, was shot dead yesterday at Croydon custody centre, south London

A police officer who was less than two years from retirement was shot dead yesterday by a handcuffed suspect previously flagged to the Prevent extremism programme.

Sergeant Matiu Ratana, 54, was shot in the chest at Croydon custody centre in south London as he began checks on the 23-year-old man who then shot himself in the neck with the revolver.

Sponsored

He is the first officer to be killed by a suspect inside a police station.

Police were about to search the man with a mobile metal detector when he carried out the attack despite his hands being secured behind his back. He was seen removing the weapon from his jacket but may have concealed it in his underwear.

title: David Quinn: We swapped Catholicism for faith in the holy EU
text:
When Britain became the first country in the world to give the green light to the Pfizer-BioNtech Covid vaccine, it looked like it was stealing a march on the EU. “Look at us,” the decision seemed to say, “we are much more nimble than those over-regulated clodhoppers in Brussels.”

At this stage, it seems the EU will not approve the Pfizer vaccine before December 29, and that it won’t be available for use anywhere in the bloc until January. So we must look on as people in Northern Ireland and Britain get their jabs. The question therefore arises: has the UK been too quick off the mark, or is the EU being too slow?

summary:
When Britain became the first country in the world to give the green light to the Pfizer-BioNtech Covid vaccine, it looked like it was stealing a march on the EU.
“Look at us,” the decision seemed to say, “we are much more nimble than those over-regulated clodhoppers in Brussels.”At this stage, it seems the EU will not approve the Pfizer vaccine before December 29, and that it won’t be available for use anywhere in the bloc until January.
So we must look on as people in Northern Ireland and Britain get their jabs.
The question therefore arises: has the UK been too quick off the mark, or is the EU being too slow?

title: Nawal El Saadawi obituary
text:
Nawal El Saadawi was six years old when she was circumcised. She cried for her mother until she saw her standing with her aunts, watching and smiling. “Since I was a child that deep wound left in my body never healed,” she wrote long after the traumatic event.

Other episodes in her childhood outraged her too. She was furious when her grandmother declared that “a boy is worth 15 girls at least . . . girls are a blight” and angry at her parents’ favouritism towards her older brother. When told at school that she had to use her father’s family name, not her mother’s, she became upset again. Aged seven, she wrote a letter to God in which she stated: “If you are not

title: Stories of Bloody Sunday victims ‘forgotten’ 100 years on
text:
The Dublin Gaelic football team was playing Tipperary at Croke Park when British forces shot into the crowd

The victims of the Bloody Sunday massacre must be remembered to avoid the “fetishisation” of the Irish War of Independence, a historian said.

Mary McAuliffe, a historian and lecturer in gender studies at University College Dublin, said that poverty and the way that Bloody Sunday was sensationalised by the old Irish Republican Army (IRA) to create propaganda led to the victims of the massacre being forgotten.

Sponsored

“We need to understand those stories because it gives us an idea of the impact of war on families and communities,” she told The Times. War, she said, was often “glorified” and “fetishised” without understanding the traumas inflicted on individuals.

title: He was made an OBE for youth work. Now he peddles anti-lockdown lies
text:
An anti-lockdown protest group that falsely claims hospitals are empty and rails against the Covid-19 vaccine is led by a charismatic public speaker honoured by the Queen for his youth work.

Before the pandemic struck, Chris Preddie, 33, toured schools to encourage troubled pupils to turn away from violence and crime. He could speak from experience: his older half-brother, Andrew, was shot dead in a gang-related murder, and two of his cousins, Ricky and Danny, were jailed in 2006 for the killing of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor.

Sponsored

Preddie, who was appointed an OBE in 2012, has emerged as the leading figure in a protest group calling itself the People’s Lockdown.

Chris Preddie with his OBE REBECCA NADEN/PA

Each day he updates social media pages with video monologues, interspersed with clips from conspiracy theorists

title: Prince Philip obituary
text:
‘He looked,” recalled his aide and friend Michael Parker, “as if you’d dropped half the world on him.” Prince Philip and the young Princess Elizabeth had travelled to Kenya at the beginning of 1952 at the start of a royal tour, standing in for King George VI, who was too ill to travel. News reached them of the King’s sudden death, aged 56. The duke’s wife was 25 and he was 30. Born to privilege but not to duty, he would now and for the years to follow embrace duty. His life had changed key. Until its end he would be a tireless consort to the Queen. It was a responsibility that he had not expected so young, yet which thereafter he shouldered with energy,

title: The West can’t ignore Macron’s call to action
text:
Another day, another outrage on the streets of a European city. Five years on from the Bataclan attacks in Paris, Vienna this week joined a victims’ club that includes Brussels, Nice, Berlin, London and Manchester. The response has been the same in each of these cities: bafflement that jihadist cells still exist, followed by a tweak in policing and counterterrorism tactics.

The political imperative, though, is to move on as soon as decently possible. Any deeper self-examination could polarise society and spread xenophobia, runs this tired and defeatist logic.

Sponsored

And so the attacks will continue, as inevitable as bad weather. Europe is a soft target for any killer who wants to drum up maximum publicity for the lowest possible cost. That’s why we should be
summary:
Five years on from the Bataclan attacks in Paris, Vienna this week joined a victims’ club that includes Brussels, Nice, Berlin, London and Manchester.
The response has been the same in each of these cities: bafflement that jihadist cells still exist, followed by a tweak in policing and counterterrorism tactics.
Any deeper self-examination could polarise society and spread xenophobia, runs this tired and defeatist logic.
SponsoredAnd so the attacks will continue, as inevitable as bad weather.
Europe is a soft target for any killer who wants to drum up maximum publicity for the lowest possible cost.

title: Non, Macron, we Muslims are not all demons — though I do tell killer jokes
text:
“Every time we hear there has been a terrorist attack, we Muslims say to ourselves, ‘Let it not be someone who says they have done it in the name of Islam,’” said Samia Orosemane, a popular French comedian of Tunisian descent. “Because if it is, it is followed by a wave of hatred against Islam. It is always like that.”

Instantly recognisable in her colourful headscarf worn like a turban, Orosemane is in sombre mode. We are sitting in a Paris café in the aftermath of the latest attack, the decapitation 10 days ago of history teacher Samuel Paty by an 18-year-old of Russian-Chechen origin. The killing, near Paris, has shaken France and prompted Emmanuel Macron, the president, to declare “war” on militant Islam.

Sponsored

French-born

title: The truth hurts, says Samantha Crompvoets, who lifted lid on Australian special forces
text:
Samantha Crompvoets said being outside the military got her access to stories of alleged atrocities

She works in an airy office of women across a lake from Canberra’s commanding towers that house the overwhelmingly male military headquarters.

Dr Samantha Crompvoets, a military sociologist and founder of a small consultancy of female professionals in the Australian capital, infiltrated and won the trust of the toughest men soldiers. It would lead to the uncovering of an alleged war crimes scandal that for years eluded generals and others in command.

The thoughtful, softly-spoken 44-year-old is credited by defence chiefs with first learning the secrets held by serving and former special forces members about the series of alleged unlawful killings they said they had witnessed in Afghanistan.

Kerry Stokes, the majority owner of Seven Network, one of Australia’s most popular television networks, has extended an A$1.9 million loan to Ben Roberts-Smith, the country’s most decorated living soldier

title: George Floyd’s family lawyer Ben Crump on America’s year of soul-searching
text:
When Ben Crump describes himself as “black America’s attorney-general”, he really means it. In one blockbuster case after another the Florida lawyer has become the face of the African-American struggle against police brutality and extrajudicial killings. In 2020, a year unlike any other, that role put him at the very centre of American life.

When the 29-year-old Jacob Blake was shot seven times in the back during a police encounter in Kenosha, Wisconsin, Crump took to the airwaves on his behalf. When Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old black woman, was shot dead by police raiding her Kentucky apartment in March, Crump represented her family. Responding to a gunshot fired by her boyfriend, the officers shot Taylor six times while entering her home as part of a

title: Two brothers charged over ‘honour killing’ of sister
text:
Two brothers have been charged with the murder of their 16-year old sister in a rare example of a so-called honour killing in Indonesia.

Rosmini binti Darwis was beaten and hacked to death with a machete after reportedly confessing to an affair with a distant male relative on the island of Sulawesi. Her brothers, Rahman, 30, and Surianto, 20, have been charged with her murder.

Sponsored

“The suspects said they were outraged when their sister admitted she had sex with a man who is their distant relative,” the local police chief, Wawan Sumantri, said. “This is a case of honour killing.”

Ms Rosmini died last month in the Bantaeng region of South Sulawesi. She had been in poor health, having suffered from nausea and dizziness, and

title: Armed militias on US streets as racial divisions widen
text:
Heavily armed black militias marched on the Kentucky Derby and white protesters carrying guns clashed with Black Lives Matter activists as violence erupted in cities across America.

A right-wing group led by a man known as the Angry Viking and a black brigade that calls itself the Not F***ing Around Coalition manoeuvred through the streets of Louisville on Saturday during what was regarded as the strangest Derby Day in history.

Sponsored

In Rochester, upstate New York, where a video emerged last week of a black man dying during an arrest, police said helmeted protesters, some carrying bin lids, hurled bottles, rocks and fireworks at officers, who responded with rubber bullets and tear gas.

In Portland, Oregon, where 100 nights of protest have been staged in response

text:

In one video, a soldier whose identity has been hidden by the Australian authorities is seen shooting and killing an unarmed Afghan man who is clutching red prayer beads as he cowers in a field. title: Black mothers unite over pain of US police killings
text:
Ilhan Omar, the Democratic congresswoman, left, holds hands with Valerie Castile, who supports other mothers whose children have been killed by police

It is not a club that any mother would want to join. Even so, its membership grows. Valerie Castile joined on July 6, 2016, when her son Philando Castile, 32, was shot dead by a police officer during a traffic stop. Katie Wright joined it last Sunday when an officer killed her son, Daunte Wright, 20.

“Why do black mothers have to keep seeing their children slaughtered by police?” asked Castile in the week that the ranks of African Americans killed by the police grew again. “What’s happening in the US goes against all principles of the right to life and dignity.”

title: War: How Conflict Shaped Us by Margaret MacMillan, review — why we fight
text:
The man’s name is Ötzi, the Iceman. You can find him in the Alpine town of Bolzano, Italy, where his frozen body was found in 1991. He is the oldest known individual European, older than the Pyramids. When he died he was wearing a cloak and a leather cap, had recently eaten dried meat and fruit, and was carrying some baskets and tools. At first archaeologists assumed he had lost his way in a snowstorm. Then they found the arrowhead in his shoulder.

For the Oxford historian Margaret MacMillan, best known for her prizewinning account of making of the Treaty of Versailles, Ötzi’s fate, like the Bible story of the mark of Cain, is a metaphor for human history. In the West most of us
summary:
The man’s name is Ötzi, the Iceman.
You can find him in the Alpine town of Bolzano, Italy, where his frozen body was found in 1991.
When he died he was wearing a cloak and a leather cap, had recently eaten dried meat and fruit, and was carrying some baskets and tools.

For the Oxford historian Margaret MacMillan, best known for her prizewinning account of making of the Treaty of Versailles, Ötzi’s fate, like the Bible story of the mark of Cain, is a metaphor for human history.

Sky Atlantic

title: Pakistan PM Imran Khan prompts outrage with rape comments
text:
Imran Khan has grown increasingly conservative since returning to his home country from Britain and entering politics

In his playboy days as a handsome cricket star in 1980s London, Imran Khan was renowned for chasing models and actresses around the nightclub circuit. Decades on, the 65-year-old prime minister of Pakistan has provoked outrage with comments blaming women’s dress for a surge in rape cases in his home country.

During a televised interview, the Oxford-educated Khan fielded a question from a caller asking what his government was doing to combat a rise in sexual violence in Pakistan. Lashing out at declining standards of modesty among women, the prime minister replied that an increase in rape indicated the “consequences in any society where vulgarity is on the rise”.

Conceding that rape attacks were increasing in Pakistan, he urged women to cover up to avoid

title: 114 reported killed as Myanmar forces crack down on anti-coup protesters
text:
Myanmar’s security forces mowed down unarmed anti-coup protesters today as junta leaders celebrated Armed Forces Day with a show of military might on the parade ground and lethal force in the streets.

On the bloodiest day since the February 1 coup, at least 114 people, including a five-year-old boy and a 13-year-old girl, were reported to have been killed in towns and streets across the country.

Sponsored

The widespread protests also served as a stark illustration of the failure of the generals to impose control on the country nearly two months after overthrowing the government of Aung San Suu Kyi.

“Today is a day of shame for the armed forces,” said Dr Sasa, the international envoy of a parallel government established by deposed MPs.

The crackdown

title: Baroness Williams of Crosby obituary
text:
As a politician Shirley Williams always seemed as ready to listen as talk, and this despite her possession of a huskily mellifluous voice. She also gave the impression that fussing about her appearance did not feature high on her list of priorities. In the sexist Seventies, her diminutive form would pointedly surface in newspaper photographs — hair tousled, head tilted, ear cocked, with the whole of her attention evidently fixed on someone else.

title: Younger murderers face whole-life sentences in justice reforms
text:
A judge sentencing Hashem Abedi, the younger brother of Manchester Arena bomber Salman Abedi, said he was prevented from handing out a whole-life sentence

Teenagers who commit murder could be given whole life terms under justice reforms closing the loophole that prevented the Manchester arena terror attack mastermind from being jailed for life.

Plans to lower the age at which murderers can receive life in jail without parole from 21 to 18 are being unveiled by the government and could become law next year.

The move follows the failure to jail Hashem Abedi— found guilty of murdering 22 people in the Manchester Arena attack — for life because he was 20 at the time of his crime in May 2017.

Boris Johnson, the prime minister, also said the proposals include plans to prevent criminals who become radicalised in prison from being eligible for early release.

title: Covid in Wuhan: how the city survived and tried to return to normal
text:
A year ago the central Chinese city of Wuhan became notorious as a new and deadly virus took hold there. A year on, the city is doing everything it can to put the past behind it.

With the coronavirus largely contained in China, an exhibition has opened in Wuhan’s conference centre, which was once used for quarantine. The displays are hagiographic in their praise of President Xi. China’s premier is congratulated for having had the courage to lock down the city of 11 million people and for his tender heart when, supposedly, mindful of the plight of the Wuhan people he couldn’t sleep on the eve of the Chinese New Year.

Sponsored

The exhibition ends with a wall of heart-shaped sticky notes congratulating officials and healthcare

A year on, the city is doing everything it can to put the past behind it.

The displays are hagiographic in their praise of President Xi.

title: Otto Dov Kulka obituary
text:
As a foremost historian of Jewish life during the Nazi era, Otto Dov Kulka never once told his students he had survived Auschwitz-Birkenau. He did not like the term Holocaust, had not seen the film Shoah nor had he visited the Yad Vashem memorial to the victims in his home city of Jerusalem.

Kulka did not relent on this “stance of remoteness” until the age of 80 when he published an account of what his internment at Auschwitz had meant to his 11-year-old self. Landscapes of the Metropolis of Death (2013) would be the most acclaimed memoir of life in a Nazi concentration camp since Primo Levi’s The Periodic Table in 1975.

Sponsored

title: Frenchman who murdered wife and burnt her body jailed for 25 years
text:
A Frenchman who claimed his wife had been killed by a stranger while she was out jogging was sentenced to 25 years in jail on Saturday for her murder in a high-profile case that has gripped the country, highlighting the scourge of domestic violence.

Jonathann Daval, 36, was impassive after he was found guilty of killing his wife, Alexia, 29, and then taking her body to woods and partly burning it. The prosecution had demanded he be jailed for life.

Sponsored

“It is a good decision, exactly what we hoped for. I think this will allow us to move on,” the victim’s mother, Isabelle Fouillot, said afterwards, surrounded by her family. Her husband, Jean-Pierre, said justice had “done its job and understood our pain”.

Daval had

title: Pleas to protect police as attacks hit record high
text:
Lissie Harper, the widow of PC Andrew Harper, is campaigning for killers of emergency workers to get automatic life imprisonment

Attacks on police officers had hit record levels and become increasingly violent before the fatal shooting yesterday, prompting victims’ families to demand greater protections.

Nine out of ten officers have been attacked during their career, with 30,679 assaults last year in England and Wales — amounting to 84 a day.

Sponsored

A report from the National Police Chiefs Council revealed that officers took 71,308 sick days in 2018-19 as a result of assaults.

Data released by the Ministry of Justice this year revealed that offenders jailed for assaulting emergency workers were sentenced to less than 12 weeks in prison on average.

The most recent killing was that of PC Andrew Harper, 28, who was dragged to his death behind a car of fleeing thieves in Berkshire
summary:
Lissie Harper, the widow of PC Andrew Harper, is campaigning for killers of emergency workers to get automatic life imprisonmentAttacks on police officers had hit record levels and become increasingly violent before the fatal shooting yesterday, prompting victims’ families to demand greater protections.

title: Edgard Tupët-Thomé obituary
text:
On August 27, 1944, Lieutenant Edgard Tupët-Thomé and his small team of men flew in an RAF Stirling towards the Jura mountains on the Swiss border. They were members of the British-trained “French SAS” and they were on a mission to assist embattled maquisards of the French Resistance. Although injured during his parachute jump, Tupët-Thomé joined his men in attacking the heavily defended village of Clerval. They killed 30 Germans and destroyed a Panzer tank.

The following month he was assigned to assist the US 7th Army as a reconnaissance officer in the Alsace-Lorraine region on the French- German border where, on September 23, he dragged a wounded American soldier to safety under heavy enemy mortar fire and killed “several scores of Germans”, according to
summary:

title: Vienna terror attack: Europe will not give in to its enemies, says defiant Macron
text:
President Macron has had to contend with three Islamist terrorist attacks in France in the past six weeks

President Macron was swift to deliver a message of support to Austria and defiance in the face of terrorism last night.

Mr Macron telephoned Sebastian Kurz, the Austrian chancellor, to “express his total solidarity and support and to offer the help of France if necessary,” the Élysée Palace said.

The French president’s words had particular resonance after three terrorist attacks in France in the past six weeks, all carried out by Islamists. France is seeking to rally the EU around its uncompromising line on Islamist terrorism.

title: Man accused of killing Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe ‘told a litany of lies’
text:
Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe was given a state funeral after he died in January 2013

The man accused of murdering Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe “wore the shooting like a badge of honour” when he moved to America and believed he was “beyond the long arm of the law”, a court was told.

Lorcan Staines SC, for the prosecution, in his closing speech told the court that Aaron Brady was a “skilled and practised liar” who told a “litany of lies” to gardaí and to the jury.

Sponsored

He said that when Mr Brady moved to America he used the shooting of Detective Garda Donohoe to “intimidate and curry influence” and talked about it in front of a number of people on different occasions, “sometimes crying, lamenting in drink or bragging with his chest puffed out”.

He said Mr Brady was confident

title: I still live in fear for my life every day
text:
On Monday ITV begins broadcasting Honour, a dramatisation of the police hunt for the murderers of a 20-year-old Kurdish Londoner called Banaz Mahmod. Her only crime had been to fall in love with a man not of her family’s choosing, thereby drawing upon it “shame” within the community. Banaz’s older sister Bekhal, who testified in court against her killers — one of them her father — is unlikely to feel strong enough to watch the Keeley Hawes two-parter, although the producers sent her a preview, which she liked.

“But it was very, very hard to watch,” she says, speaking by phone from a location she cannot disclose. “I did choke up and get really emotional. It brought back a lot of memories from bitter,

title: Sir John Bailey obituary
text:
John Bailey was unaccustomed to the lack of courtroom courtesy in Australia. The treasury solicitor was in the country in 1987 to argue the British government’s case in the infamous Spycatcher trial, an attempt to stop Peter Wright, a former MI5 officer, publishing his memoir there.

Malcolm Turnbull, the future Australian prime minister but then a 34-year-old lawyer, was determined to take on the British establishment, snarling: “I’d get to work covering my backside if I were you, Bailey. You’ll wish you’d never heard of Peter Wright by the time I’m finished with you.” Bailey was far too polite to distinguish such a crass comment with a response.

Sponsored

title: Letters to the Editor: Roy Greenslade’s IRA hypocrisy is a stain on the press
text:
Roy Greenslade has become the Anthony Blunt of British journalism. His admission that he was a secret supporter of the IRA while working as a senior editor on a succession of newspapers, including The Sunday Times, was shocking (News Review, last week).

He retains his belief that attacks on innocent members of the public were justified despite what he calls a “painful moment” when the journalist Philip Geddes, 24, was blown apart by an IRA bomb outside Harrods in 1983. I used to sit on the next desk to Philip at the Daily Express. For us, it was beyond “painful”. It was devastating.

Sponsored

Rarely have two journalists been so mismatched. One young, talented, honest; the other a man who lived a lie —
summary:
Roy Greenslade has become the Anthony Blunt of British journalism.
His admission that he was a secret supporter of the IRA while working as a senior editor on a succession of newspapers, including The Sunday Times, was shocking (News Review, last week).
I used to sit on the next desk to Philip at the Daily Express.
For us, it was beyond “painful”.
One young, talented, honest; the other a man who lived a lie —

title: Evelyn Waugh’s Somerset home is on sale for £5.5m
text:
On Easter morning 55 years ago tomorrow, Evelyn Waugh said his last Deo gratias. After assisting his priest at a Latin mass in the Somerset town of Wiveliscombe, Waugh returned to his home in Combe Florey, seven miles away, for a family lunch in a rare jolly mood. At some point before the lamb was served, he went to his library and was never seen alive again.

The greatest novelist of his generation, as Graham Greene described him in The Times — or “the nastiest-tempered man in England” according to the architectural historian James Lees-Milne — was found dead in the downstairs toilet. Biffed while on the thunder-box, as Brigadier Ben Ritchie-Hook, the one-eyed maverick in his Sword of Honour trilogy, would have put

title: Martin Bashir, Diana’s interviewer, was elusive, contradictory and a target of hostility
text:
Martin Bashir became a star in his own right after landing high-profile interviews

If there was a single moment that encapsulated the unsettling mixture of awe, mistrust, envy and hostility that has long shaded the stellar television career of Martin Bashir, it came during an after-dinner speech to an audience of journalists in Chicago in 2008.

Bashir was at the height of his renown, arguably the most famous interviewer in the world after his mesmerising encounters with Diana, Princess of Wales and with Michael Jackson — the sometime King of Pop. Lured to America by a seven-figure pay cheque and a high-profile role with ABC News, Bashir was a guest of honour at the annual convention of the Asian American Journalists Association.

Sponsored

As an interviewer, he was widely he was widely hailed for his discreet and sensitive handling

title: Democrats prepare to impeach Donald Trump
text:
The New York National Guard forms up on Monday as part of increased security at the Capitol

Democrats will proceed with the second impeachment of President Trump after appealing to the vice-president to act with a majority of the cabinet and remove him.

Members of the House of Representatives were called back to Washington by Nancy Pelosi, the Speaker and senior Democrat, who said she planned to give Mike Pence 24 hours to use the 25th Amendment, a mechanism to remove a president no longer able to fulfil his duties.

Sponsored

If Mr Pence fails to respond a vote to impeach Mr Trump could take place in the House as soon as Wednesday but Democrats may delay his trial in the Senate for months to avoid overshadowing Joe Biden’s new administration.

Nancy Pelosi, the House Speaker, said President Trump was an “imminent threat” to the constitution and democracy ERIN SCOTT/REUTERS

“In protecting our constitution and our democracy, we will act with urgency,

Arriving in London in December 1960 for the premiere of Spartacus, in which Douglas gave perhaps his most memorable performance, as the rebellious slave

When Anne Buydens met Kirk Douglas on the set of the film Act of Love in Paris in 1953, there was an instant attraction between them that she was determined to resist.

Douglas, who was playing Robert Teller, an American soldier, in the movie, was divorced from his first wife, the actress Diana Dill, and in a relationship with the Italian actress Pier Angeli. Anne, who was working as a publicist on the picture, was married.

text:

He wears the No 7 shirt synonymous with David Beckham, one of the club’s owners, was named its Most Valuable Player (MVP) in his debut season and recently agreed a new three-year contract with the praise of Phil Neville, his new manager, ringing in his ears.

title: Ethiopian fugitives to leave Italy’s embassy after 30 years
text:
Two former leaders of Ethiopia’s Mengistu regime are preparing to end their 30-year stay as self-invited “guests” at Italy’s embassy in Addis Ababa after their death sentences were commuted.

Berhanu Bayeh, 82, a former foreign minister and Marxist ideologue, and Addis Tedla, 74, a former chief of the general staff, were among a group who sought refuge in the embassy in May 1991 as the military dictatorship of Mengistu Haile Mariam was overthrown.

Sponsored

The men were sentenced to death for complicity in the crimes of the USSR-backed regime, which is accused of killing up to two million Ethiopians during its 14-year rule.

Mengistu, 83, who lives in Zimbabwe, was one of a group of military officers who overthrew Emperor Haile Selassie in 1974. He consolidated

title: 2020: A year to forget that we will remember forever
text:
In early 2020, few could have predicted what lay ahead for Ireland and the wider world. A pathogen in China seemed like a distant threat. On February 27, when news broke of the first case of Covid-19 on the island of Ireland, there was still a sense that life would continue as normal.

In March, Luke O’Neill, an immunology expert with whom we would become far more familiar as the year wore on, appeared on The Late Late Show. “If you’re not infected, there’s no reason to wear a face mask,” he told Ryan Tubridy. “Wearing the face mask might make you feel a bit better, but there’s no evidence it will stop you catching the virus.” He added: “It’s an evil virus that

title: What’s on TV and radio tonight: Tuesday, March 2
text:
Viewing guide, by Ben Dowell

Your Honor

Sky Atlantic/Now TV, 9pm

Bryan Cranston is probably best known for the superb drama Breaking Bad in which he played a cancer-stricken chemistry teacher who turns to drug production partly out of a twisted sense of reclaiming his male pride. This drama by the British writer Peter Moffat is in a vaguely similar vein, only Cranston this time plays a gentle and liberal New Orleans judge called Michael Desiato. His life with his teenage son Adam seems happy enough on the surface, even though he has lost his wife (also Adam’s mother) in circumstances that appear to have been horrible and sudden. title: TV review: Young Wallander; Strike: Lethal White; All Creatures Great and Small; Away
text:
Back-to-school anticipation isn’t quite the same this year, the innocent September thrill of a new pencil case ruined by its potential role as a brightly coloured vector of disease. For a pure hit of old-fashioned autumnal atmosphere, though, there is Strike: Lethal White, the fourth adaptation of JK Rowling’s series of crime novels written as Robert Galbraith. From the opening credits — the Formica yellows and browns of a 1960s coffee bar, the front of a great lost folk album selling for hundreds of pounds on eBay — it’s a symphony in sepia, perfectly co-ordinated with its creeping mood of mulched decency and moral decay.

Even the picture-perfect wedding that started the series was a kind of withering: the beautiful, vibrant Robin (Holliday Grainger)

title: What’s on TV: Monday
text:
CRITICS’ CHOICE

Honour (ITV, 9pm)

One way to ensure that real-life crime dramas don’t veer into sensationalism is to focus on dogged police work. That is the approach of Gwyneth Hughes’s examination of the 2006 murder of Banaz Mahmod, yet the police are not always heroes here: DCI Caroline Goode (Keeley Hawes) is horrified to realise that her “missing person” repeatedly told officers her life was threatened by family members after she left an abusive marriage. Turning Mahmod’s story into a police procedural could soften her story’s edges, but Honour keeps the victim in focus and does not shy from the reality of violence against women. Victoria Segal

title: Juliette Gréco obituary
text:
The Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet thought he had pulled off a coup by persuading Juliette Gréco to sing in Santiago in 1981. He had not counted on her performance consisting of songs against his regime. “I went off [stage] to dead silence,” she recalled with glee. “It was the greatest triumph of my career.”

Gréco was a child of the left, and protest songs, including those railing against French military adventures in Algeria and Vietnam, formed a central plank of her repertoire. Yet audiences knew and adored her for singing wistfully of men, love and the passing years. Numbers such as Si tu t’imagines (If You Figure) and Bonjour tristesse (Hello Sadness), became standards in France, her smoky, whispered singing infusing them with mystery and

title: Armenian fears grow as Turkish flags flutter in ‘Otherbaijan’
text:
A woman cries next to the grave of her son, a soldier killed in the fighting over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh

In front of the Armani store by Port Baku mall, a tiny dog pulled on its lead as its owner — wearing white denim and a significant number of gold chain necklaces — air-kissed a passing acquaintance. A group of four women with expensive noses sat drinking espressos under a large parasol. Baku’s reputation as an international capital of bling, thanks to its oil wealth, is well deserved.

Under normal circumstances, ordinary Azerbaijanis have so little in common with the wealthy elite that some joke they live in “Otherbaijan”. But for the past three weeks, since fighting began in the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, a tide of martial fervour has brought billionaires and peasants together in an outpouring of national unity

title: Black Lives Matter: Democrats demand reforms to restore faith in American police
text:
Nancy Pelosi, the US speaker, leads senior Democrats who knelt in Washington. They stayed for eight minutes and 46 seconds, the time that George Floyd fought for life as a policeman knelt on his neck

The Democrats have proposed police reforms after the “martyrdom” of George Floyd but stopped short of radical demands from street protesters to slash budgets or even disband entire forces.

The proposals, designed to restore confidence in US law enforcement at a moment of national soul-searching about racism and police behaviour, highlighted a contrast with the Republicans, who rejected blanket measures in response to the death of Mr Floyd.

President Trump and his allies seized upon moves to cut police funding in Democrat-controlled cities including New York and Los Angeles as “radical left craziness” that would backfire and help him win re-election in November.

title: Nice terror attack: migrant tried to behead victims
text:
Vincent Loquès, 54, a lay worker at the Notre Dame basilica in Nice, was one of three people killed

A Tunisian illegal immigrant who had arrived in France in the past few weeks stabbed to death a caretaker and two women in a church in Nice yesterday, attempting to behead two of the victims.

The attacker was identified by police as Brahim Aouissaoui, 21, who had travelled to France after landing by boat on the Italian island of Lampedusa in September, where he was placed in quarantine before being released with an order to leave Italian territory.

title: Families mourn media workers killed in Afghanistan as militant onslaught continues
text:
Shahnaz Raufi, left, Mursal Waheedi, top right, and Saadia Sadat were killed on their way home from work, apparently by the Afghan Isis affiliate

Grieving relatives and colleagues of three female journalists shot dead in Afghanistan this week have spoken of their determination to honour the victims and keep working despite a wave of targeted killings to terrorise women out of the workplace.

Mursal Waheedi, Saadia Sadat and Shahnaz Raufi, who worked for the local broadcaster Enikass TV, were gunned down as they walked home from the studios in the eastern city of Jalalabad on Tuesday. The women were buried on the same day, in a city reeling with grief and fear. The onslaught shows no sign of abating as a female doctor, Sadaaf Elyasi, 28, was killed today by a bomb attached to a rickshaw in which she was travelling to work.

Sponsored

The latest attacks targeting women follow

title: This month in the Times photographic archive: February 2021
text:
Valentine’s Day proved to be a socially distanced affair this year with national Covid-19 restrictions still in place. We uncovered some amusing and emotive images as we searched our archives for images themed around love and public displays of affection.

In 1983 Sally Soames was en route to photograph imagery of the impending general election when she encountered young lovers on the platform at Bournemouth train station. The ingenuity of the press photographer once more on display, camera in hand, documenting anything that catches her eye. In this case, a snatched few frames of lovers embracing. By the time she clicks the shutter on the last frame she appears to have attracted the attention of the youngsters. Similarly, Allan Ballard was in Margate photographing a
summary:
Valentine’s Day proved to be a socially distanced affair this year with national Covid-19 restrictions still in place.
We uncovered some amusing and emotive images as we searched our archives for images themed around love and public displays of affection.
In 1983 Sally Soames was en route to photograph imagery of the impending general election when she encountered young lovers on the platform at Bournemouth train station.
The ingenuity of the press photographer once more on display, camera in hand, documenting anything that catches her eye.
By the time she clicks the shutter on the last frame she appears to have attracted the attention of the youngsters.

title: Cicely Tyson on racism, Hollywood and marriage to Miles Davis
text:
Cicely Tyson, left, with Miles Davis attending the premiere of her film The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter in New York in July 1968 and, right, receiving the Medal of Freedom from President Obama in 2016

The year Miles Davis died, Cicely Tyson felt he was haunting her. Each time she climbed into a New York taxi, entered a lift or a department store, she’d hear a snatch of ’Round Midnight or Blue in Green. “It was as though Miles was following me around,” she says. “Everywhere I went, his music would be playing. I’d say to him, ‘OK, OK, I know you’re with me.’ ”

At the age of 96, Tyson is publishing her autobiography, Just As I Am, which charts a life beginning in the slums of Twenties Harlem and follows her seven-decade acting career whose rewards include an honorary Oscar, three Emmys and the Medal of Freedom from President Obama. Oprah Winfrey and fellow TV producer

text:
France has been told it is at war against an enemy “within and without” and to expect more Islamist attacks, as police arrested a man with links to a Tunisian who murdered three people at a church in Nice.

As the country absorbed the shock of the latest gruesome attack on its soil, Gerald Darmanin, the interior minister, said: “We are in war against an enemy that is both inside and outside. We need to understand that there have been and there will be other events such as these terrible attacks.”

title: Times letters: noise pollution and the lockdown’s respite
text:
Sir, The fine article by Jenni Russell (“We can’t go back to our old noisy world”, May 21) highlights the problems of noise but also possible solutions. Many of the latter cost little but have never been implemented. It costs nothing to reduce the number and volume of announcements on public transport; lowering speed limits is not a matter of cost but of political will; cycle lanes are among the cheapest pieces of transport infrastructure to build. Even aircraft noise can be tackled by rotating flight paths. The challenge now is for national and local government and the transport operators to seize this moment to put in place low-cost solutions to ensure that we do not return to our old noisy world.

John Stewart

Sponsored
summary:
Sir, The fine article by Jenni Russell (“We can’t go back to our old noisy world”, May 21) highlights the problems of noise but also possible solutions.

title: Knifeman kills three at church in new French terror
text:
A man shouting “Allahu akbar” knifed to death the sexton and two women in a church in Nice today in the third terrorist attack in France since the opening last month of the trial of suspects in the massacre at Charlie Hebdo magazine.

The suspect was identified by police as Brahim Aoussaoui, 21, a Tunisian who left his native country in the summer and arrived in France early this month. He had landed in September on the Italian island of Lampedusa, where he was placed in virus quarantine by the authorities before being released with an order to leave Italian territory, police told French media.

Sponsored

President Macron flew to the scene at the Notre-Dame basilica and the country was put on higher terrorism

title: Radio review: Private Passions; BBC Proms; In the Studio; From the Mayflower to the Moon (And Back Again)
text:
Private Passions is always a good listen. Last Sunday’s with Brian Moore was fiercely good. The show’s host, Michael Berkeley, led Moore carefully through the phases of his life: as a rugby international, adopted son, solicitor, father. Sports fans will have known bits of it. What Berkeley got Moore to share was the feel of it, the lessons it taught. Some of these are well known, partly because Moore wrote an award-winning autobiography some years ago, partly because the revelation of his sexual abuse as a child made national news at the time.

title: Ghislaine Maxwell demands new bail hearing
text:
The evidence against Ghislaine Maxwell should be presented in court at a new hearing to determine whether she should be granted bail, her lawyer demanded yesterday as he appealed against a judge’s decision to keep her in jail before her trial this July.

Maxwell, 59, has made three attempts to secure bail and has been refused each time by Judge Alison Nathan, who said the case against her was strong and that she presented a flight risk.

Sponsored

Appealing against that decision in a court filing yesterday, David Markus, a lawyer for the British socialite, argued that the judge based this assessment on an indictment which alleged that she assisted Jeffrey Epstein in his abuse of three minors between 1994 and 1997. An additional indictment filed
