title: The books that made us cry, from A Little Life to Never Let Me Go
text:
TikTok, the video sharing app that is quickly becoming the social media of choice for those under 25, is most often credited with popularising dance moves and music styles such as K-pop or, bizarrely, sea shanties. But books, too, can go viral on TikTok, it turns out. “BookTok” is apparently a thing (although we’re far too old and uncool to know much about it) and the key to BookTok fame is to film yourself crying over a book. So, in a probably ill-fated attempt to be down with the kids, here are some of our favourite tear-jerking books.

This Booker-shortlisted tale of four college friends is a literary soap opera. Car crashes, spousal abuse, sickness, child abuse... you name it, the characters endure it as

title: Soft Power by Robert Winder review — Max Hastings on a new method of global dominance
text:
Influential: Coca-Cola is recognisable in any language around the world

I once spent a grim morning in Gaza, hearing a procession of Palestinians denounce the iniquity of the United States for indulging Israel’s occupation policies. Inside those hate-filled people’s houses, however, I glimpsed their children sitting before televisions, gripped by Hollywood movies.

Likewise, the Americans suffered humiliating military defeat in Vietnam, but today’s Vietnamese embrace US culture, commerce and values with an enthusiasm that persuades me that, where B-52s and Spooky gunships failed, Scarlett Johansson and McDonald’s have proved invincible.

Sponsored

text:
Officers at the scene in Florida where two FBI agents were killed while serving a search warrant

Two FBI agents were shot dead in a raid, a married couple were killed in an argument about snow shovelling, and a famous private eye was fatally injured in a street robbery.

They were only five of the latest victims of a surge in violence that pushed the US murder rate up by an “unprecedented” amount last year, according to a report.

title: Back to school, back to work, back to fun — give us the date
text:
This is the week, we have been led to believe, when the government will finally set out how the country will emerge from the coronavirus lockdown. That it needs to do so should not be in doubt, as we have regularly pointed out. We have had a tumbleweed economy for weeks, with shuttered shops, deserted town centres and a public made fearful of venturing beyond its front doors. This is not sustainable for the economy and the public finances, for the future of children and young adults and for those with serious non-coronavirus health conditions.

In his first press conference since his return to work, delivered on Thursday, Boris Johnson promised a “comprehensive plan” to restart the economy. It would, he said, “explain how

title: Kids Company undermined by false claims of sexual abuse, says judge
text:
Camilla Batmanghelidjh, Alan Yentob and six former trustees of Kids Company were vindicated after a ten-week hearing at the High Court

The charity Kids Company would have succeeded but for unfounded claims of sexual assault, a judge said as trustees including Alan Yentob and Camilla Batmanghelidjh received the all clear to run companies.

Yentob, Batmanghelidjh and six former trustees faced a ten-week hearing at the High Court after the official receiver argued that they should be banned from being company directors. The case detailed claims of politically driven briefings designed to bring about the downfall of the charity by figures such as Dominic Cummings, and “planted” stories alleging sexual assault.

title: John McLean trial: How Dublin’s young rugby players crossed paths with the devil
text:
A group of sixth-year boys had gathered during a class break in 1979 at Terenure College, a fee-paying school run by the Carmelite order in south Dublin. From their vantage point in the common room, situated near the stage in the concert hall, they watched with horror as John McClean, the 34-year-old English, drama and rugby teacher, inappropriately touched some of the junior boys while preparing them for a school play.

Alarmed, the Leaving Cert students debated what they should do. They knew McClean had ready access to younger boys, both as a classroom teacher and as rugby coach. title: Father powerless to get paedophile smears removed
text:
Guy Babcock, a software engineer, lives a quiet life in an Oxfordshire village with his wife and ten-year-old son. He is not part of a family of paedophiles, fraudsters and thieves. But Google his name and you get a very different impression.

Babcock, 59, is the victim of a malicious online campaign that has portrayed him as a child abuser. His wife, brother, sister, brother-in-law, aunt, cousin and teenage nephew have also been called paedophiles, scammers, sociopaths and racists.

title: Football’s Darkest Secret was most heart-rending TV I’ve ever watched
text:
I don’t think I’ve ever watched such painful TV as the BBC’s Football’s Darkest Secret. The graphic retelling of what these English footballers — Andy Woodward, Paul Stewart, David White, Ian Ackley and others — suffered as children at the hands of paedophile coaches was enough to reduce you to tears. This three-part documentary made for harrowing viewing.

Apart from the physical torture suffered by these children — in some cases being subjected to hundreds of rapings — was the heart-rending testimony provided by the victims’ mothers. Some of them are elderly now, and have to live with the fact that, when their children were young and suffering, they knew nothing, their child being too embarrassed — or too threatened by the abusing coach —

title: Anger as Facebook fail to ban ‘racist abuser’
text:
Campaigners have reacted furiously after Facebook confirmed that a person who racially abused Swansea City’s Yan Dhanda would be allowed to return to the social media platform.

Dhanda, 22, received the abuse on Instagram, which is owned by Facebook, after Swansea’s FA Cup defeat by Manchester City on Wednesday. He is one of Britain’s most high-profile players from an Asian background.

title: Dozens charged with West Yorkshire child sex abuse
text:
Many of men who have been charged with sexual offences are from Kirklees

Thirty-two men have been charged with nearly 200 sexual offences against eight girls aged 13 to 16.

It is alleged that the men, who are mostly from Kirklees, committed 196 crimes. Some of the victims have said they were also targeted as young adults.

Sponsored

The charges have been brought as part of Operation Tourway, an investigation into non-recent child sexual exploitation in West Yorkshire. It has looked at offences alleged to have been carried out between 1999 and 2012 in Kirklees, Bradford, Wakefield and other locations.

The charges include rape, sexual assault, trafficking, sexual activity with a child, false imprisonment and the supplying of drugs.

According to West Yorkshire police, the 32 men are due to appear in Kirklees magistrates’ court today and next week.

A survivor of child sex abuse says he feels cheated after the alleged perpetrator, a former headmaster of a prestigious Dublin private school, was found dead four days before his trial was due to begin last week.

title: Ban sport coaches having sex with teenagers they train, urge children’s charities
text:
Charities have said that children were being put at risk by the failure to reform the law

Campaigners are demanding the closure of a legal loophole which prevents the prosecution of sport coaches and faith leaders who have consensual sex with the young people they instruct.

Children’s charities and a leading criminal lawyer are urging minsters to further safeguard 16 and 17-year-olds from potential abuses of power.

Sponsored

In Westminster legislation is being amended to expand the definition of “people in a position of trust”, which at present only applies to professionals such as teachers or care staff. The UK government is extending the law to cover any adult who has regular and direct contact with children and is in a position of authority over them.

Under the Sexual Offences (Scotland) Act 2009 the definition does not include roles such as sport coaches
summary:
Charities have said that children were being put at risk by the failure to reform the lawCampaigners are demanding the closure of a legal loophole which prevents the prosecution of sport coaches and faith leaders who have consensual sex with the young people they instruct.
Children’s charities and a leading criminal lawyer are urging minsters to further safeguard 16 and 17-year-olds from potential abuses of power.
SponsoredIn Westminster legislation is being amended to expand the definition of “people in a position of trust”, which at present only applies to professionals such as teachers or care staff.
The UK government is extending the law to cover any adult who has regular and direct contact with children and is in a position of authority over them.
Under the Sexual Offences (Scotland) Act 2009 the definition does not include roles such as sport coaches

Madeleine McCann vanished from the apartment in Praia da Luz. Christian Brückner, the main suspect, allegedly gave teenagers drugs for sex in Barao de Sao Joao

An employee at the resort where Madeleine McCann was abducted may have watched her family and passed information to Christian Brückner so he could burgle their apartment, reports suggest.

Portuguese police believe that an alleged accomplice told Brückner, the prime suspect in Madeleine’s disappearance, that the family had left valuable items in the ground floor apartment where the three-year-old slept with her 18-month-old twin siblings. Their parents, Kate and Gerry McCann, were at a restaurant in the Ocean Club complex.

Witnesses have said they saw someone matching Brückner‘s appearance monitoring the resort in the days leading up to Madeleine’s disappearance BEN GURR FOR THE TIMES

Yesterday Correio da Manha reported that an ex-employee provided information to Brückner about the McCanns’ routine,

title: The Times view on regulating the tech giants: Safer Surfing
text:
The web is tightening. Announcing the Online Harms Bill in parliament yesterday Oliver Dowden, the culture secretary, spelt out legislation with teeth. Ofcom, the regulator, is to be responsible for ensuring that tech firms live up to their legal responsibilities. Where they do not, they may be blocked or face fines of up to 10 per cent of global turnover. In the case of giants such as Google or Facebook, this could mean billions. Until now, the only legislation that will have come close to so impacting Silicon Valley is the European Union-led General Data Protection Regulation, or GDPR.

Online harm is a more subjective issue than data protection. In some areas, such as child protection, the risks and responsibilities are clear-cut, and this bill
summary:
Announcing the Online Harms Bill in parliament yesterday Oliver Dowden, the culture secretary, spelt out legislation with teeth.
Ofcom, the regulator, is to be responsible for ensuring that tech firms live up to their legal responsibilities.
Until now, the only legislation that will have come close to so impacting Silicon Valley is the European Union-led General Data Protection Regulation, or GDPR.
Online harm is a more subjective issue than data protection.
In some areas, such as child protection, the risks and responsibilities are clear-cut, and this bill

title: QAnon: this online cult is a danger in the real world
text:
Earlier this month, General Michael Flynn, former director of the US Defense Intelligence Agency and national security adviser, took an al fresco oath of loyalty with family and friends and posted it on Twitter, using the hashtag TakeTheOath. At the end of the oath, they vowed, in a phrase that sounds like an overtranslation from The Three Musketeers: “Where we go one, we go all.”

Readers of The Times may not know what many of those reading, retweeting or “liking” the general’s video know: that the phrase and the hashtag indicate his support for an online conspiracy theory network that is becoming a cult. It’s known as QAnon. You’ll see its supporters at rallies for Donald Trump, and if you look for its #WWG1WGA
summary:

title: The Times view on the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse: Too Timid
text:
Until now the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse has left no stones unturned in its pursuit of those suspected of historical abuse of children. Its investigation into child sexual abuse at Westminster delved deep into the past to examine allegations against long dead politicians such as Sir Cyril Smith and Sir Peter Morrison, who were prominent in the 1980s and 1990s. Similarly its investigation into the Catholic church focused forensically on allegations of child abuse by monks at prominent Catholic schools such as Downside and Ampleforth reaching back more than 50 years. Much to the distress of his family, it is currently conducting an investigation into allegations against the former Labour MP Lord Janner of Braunstone, who died in 2015. The inquiry has 15

title: Times letters: Travelling abroad during the pandemic
text:
Sir, Matthew Parris’s paean to international travel (“A trip abroad is nothing to be ashamed of”, Mar 13) missed that it’s all about volume, timing and managing expectations. When he, I and the private jet-owning minorities set off on planes, ferries and trains over the past year, our risk calculations factored in that very few others (ie the 70-odd per cent that he cites) would be doing the same. The moment the summer floodgates opened it presaged the grim winter we have just experienced. We now know enough about the coronavirus to acknowledge that our previous risk assessments were almost entirely self-serving. Vaccine or no vaccine, in many of the places we would love to visit we can no longer plead personal imperatives as pretexts

Sponsored

title: Colet Court: Sex-charge prep teacher found dead
text:
Tim Harbord resigned from Colet Court in 2013 after concerns were raised about his conduct

A former teacher at one of Britain’s leading preparatory schools has died shortly after being charged with a historical sex offence.

Tim Harbord spent 25 years at Colet Court, the junior division of St Paul’s School, in Barnes, southwest London. He resigned after concern was raised in 2013 about his closeness to a pupil. It later emerged that a complaint against him had been made as early as 1990 but no action was taken.

Sponsored

Mr Harbord, 67, was arrested in 2013 on suspicion of the sexual grooming of a child. A year later he was again arrested and questioned about the alleged sexual assault of a child.

The second arrest was part of Operation Winthorpe, a police inquiry launched after The Times revealed multiple allegations

text:
A report found 275 known or suspected abusers who worked at Scouting Ireland’s predecessor organisations

Senior figures in Scouting Ireland helped to cover up cases of child sex abuse and some had a “sexual interest in young people”, a damning review of the organisation has found.

The body apologised yesterday, admitting that it had failed victims, many of whom had previously attempted to come forward.

title: Forensic psychiatrist Dr Richard Taylor on his most disturbing cases
text:
The young mother with Munchausen

While I was working as a junior doctor, a young woman, Tamara Atkinson, was admitted to the medical ward suffering with poorly controlled epilepsy. She’d been accused of poisoning her own child with her anti-epileptic medication and then presenting the child to the doctor with unexplained symptoms. When the child had been admitted to a paediatric ward for observation, Tamara had tampered with the drip, causing a life-threatening infection by contamination of the infusion and putting her child in intensive care.

Next Tamara suffered an apparent seizure in police custody and was transferred to the emergency room. Admitted to the ward, she continued to have uncontrolled fits despite adequate treatment and we hastily ordered brain scans and a brain-wave test,
summary:

title: Times letters: Planning shake-up and the housing crisis
text:
Sir, The government’s planning reforms, which will water down requirements for affordable homes and do away with agreements that benefit local communities, represent a lost opportunity for social mobility (“Homes target places Johnson on collision course with Tory shires”, Aug 7). Research on successive generations in Britain reveals a growing home ownership divide opening up once again: today’s adults are now far less likely to own a home if their parents were not themselves homeowners. This is part of a wider wealth divide in society and mirrors the decline observed in social mobility levels.

If we are to have any chance of improving social mobility for future generations we need both greater opportunities overall but also targeted help for the less fortunate. That is as
summary:
Sir, The government’s planning reforms, which will water down requirements for affordable homes and do away with agreements that benefit local communities, represent a lost opportunity for social mobility (“Homes target places Johnson on collision course with Tory shires”, Aug 7).
Research on successive generations in Britain reveals a growing home ownership divide opening up once again: today’s adults are now far less likely to own a home if their parents were not themselves homeowners.
This is part of a wider wealth divide in society and mirrors the decline observed in social mobility levels.
If we are to have any chance of improving social mobility for future generations we need both greater opportunities overall but also targeted help for the less fortunate.

text:
As if he needed any more publicity at the moment, Winston Churchill was in the spotlight again this weekend after a technical glitch removed his photo from Google searches for British prime ministers. text:
The full harrowing horror of football’s sexual abuse scandal will be laid bare in a three-part BBC documentary series starting next week, a few days after the FA finally publishes the long-awaited independent review into the crisis.

title: Honour: ITV’s true-life drama about an honour killing
text:
On January 24, 2006 three men tortured, raped and then strangled to death a 20-year-old woman in the sitting room of her parents’ home in southwest London. It was just as her father and uncle had intended. It was also what Banaz Mahmod had herself predicted when in December she had visited a police station to report that her family were plotting to kill her.

Thirteen years later, on the afternoon of October 1, 2019, one of the nation’s favourite actresses, Keeley Hawes, is dressed in a navy blue trouser suit and striding down a bleak corridor in the old BT building in Watford. She enters what on ITV’s Honour, a dramatisation of the investigation, will pass for a police incident room in Lewisham,
summary:
On January 24, 2006 three men tortured, raped and then strangled to death a 20-year-old woman in the sitting room of her parents’ home in southwest London.
It was just as her father and uncle had intended.
It was also what Banaz Mahmod had herself predicted when in December she had visited a police station to report that her family were plotting to kill her.
Thirteen years later, on the afternoon of October 1, 2019, one of the nation’s favourite actresses, Keeley Hawes, is dressed in a navy blue trouser suit and striding down a bleak corridor in the old BT building in Watford.
She enters what on ITV’s Honour, a dramatisation of the investigation, will pass for a police incident room in Lewisham,

title: Justine McCarthy: Society looked away as children were raped
text:
During the 23 years when James O’Reilly was starving, beating and raping his daughters and his younger sister, Ireland’s dirty little secret of child sexual abuse refused to stay silent any longer. When the horror stories began exploding, they shook the country out of its see-no-evil slumber — or so we thought. There were landmark court trials, state investigations and reams of reports recommending reforms. A new government department for children was established and a referendum was passed to enshrine their constitutional rights. As far back as 1994, Albert Reynolds’s government collapsed over the case of Brendan Smyth, a rampaging paedophile priest.

Throughout it all, O’Reilly kept brutalising his own flesh and blood. He abused his eldest daughter when she was just four years old,
summary:
During the 23 years when James O’Reilly was starving, beating and raping his daughters and his younger sister, Ireland’s dirty little secret of child sexual abuse refused to stay silent any longer.
When the horror stories began exploding, they shook the country out of its see-no-evil slumber — or so we thought.
There were landmark court trials, state investigations and reams of reports recommending reforms.
A new government department for children was established and a referendum was passed to enshrine their constitutional rights.
As far back as 1994, Albert Reynolds’s government collapsed over the case of Brendan Smyth, a rampaging paedophile priest.

title: Times letters: Meghan, social media and magic of the monarchy
text:
Sir, There are few people in public life who haven’t suffered at the hands of social media. Meghan Markle was no different but as an actress she had a Hollywood agent to protect her. When she became part of the “family firm” she imagined she would be similarly protected. Instead she became a prime target. It eventually consumed her as it did Diana, who told me how she came to dread engagements as they involved meeting people who might have read negative stories about her. And that was before social media.

I fully understand Meghan’s angst, having recently been on the receiving end myself. But Meghan’s abuse came too thick and fast and she allowed herself to sink into a dark place. The Palace advisers
summary:
Sir, There are few people in public life who haven’t suffered at the hands of social media.
Meghan Markle was no different but as an actress she had a Hollywood agent to protect her.
And that was before social media.
I fully understand Meghan’s angst, having recently been on the receiving end myself.
But Meghan’s abuse came too thick and fast and she allowed herself to sink into a dark place.

text:
Dozens of police have been hurt in riots that started in loyalist areas

Downing Street is considering intergovernmental talks over rising tensions in Northern Ireland despite concerns that involving Dublin would further inflame unionist anger.

Boris Johnson has not ruled out travelling to the province if the disorder continues but any visit might be delayed until the official mourning period for the Duke of Edinburgh has concluded.

title: BBC will reform to stay relevant, promises new director-general Tim Davie
text:
The new director-general of the BBC has pledged to prioritise impartiality and reform as the national broadcaster seeks to reset relations with the government to defend the licence fee.

It was announced yesterday that Tim Davie, 53, will take charge from September, having spent the past seven years leading its commercial arm, BBC Studios. Despite his insider status, Mr Davie made clear that the status quo could not continue, saying that the BBC needed to “accelerate change” to survive in a fast-moving world.

It must “continue to reform, make clear choices and stay relevant”, he added, indicating cuts are likely.

His commitment to creating content of the “highest quality and impartiality” was welcomed by ministers following a series of bias allegations against programmes, most recently

title: Our weak tech laws have made children easy prey for abuse
text:
In 2008 I was commissioned by the government to investigate the harms, some shocking, that children face online. I made more than 30 recommendations, all accepted but many still not realised. Over a decade later the online risks to children have grown immeasurably but we are still waiting for tech firms to take responsibility.

That could all change in the coming months. In December the government revealed proposals for a new Online Safety Bill, which will enforce a duty of care on companies to protect children.

Sponsored

As a clinical psychologist, I see the devastating impact abuse has on children who, via online platforms, are groomed, exploited, abused and left broken. We would not give free rein to child abusers in any other part of society
summary:
In 2008 I was commissioned by the government to investigate the harms, some shocking, that children face online.
Over a decade later the online risks to children have grown immeasurably but we are still waiting for tech firms to take responsibility.

title: ‘A player called my abuser a paedophile — yet I defended him’
text:
Shortly after 9.30am on January 7, 2019, a car drove into a tree near the village of Bottisham in Cambridgeshire. It was a red Mazda 3, and had left the A1303, without skid marks or signs of any other vehicle being involved, on a straight stretch of quiet country road.

It travelled along a grass verge for almost 50 metres before smashing against the tree. Passers-by, paramedics and an air ambulance crew tried to save the driver, but in vain. He was a 75-year-old man, dressed in a pinstripe suit and tie, who that morning had said goodbye to his wife, Pauline, and left their home in Cambridge, ostensibly for Peterborough.

Sponsored

The A1303 near Bottisham, however, was in the opposite direction and 45 miles away

title: Readers’ boarding-school stories: ‘The cruelty scarred me for life. At 75, I am still hurting’
text:
My heartfelt thanks go to the hundreds of people who have responded to the request for their verdicts on their time at British boarding schools. Your response has been generous. First, it is heartening that many people reported having been perfectly happy. Others have taken the position that it wasn’t exactly paradise, but that there were positive things that made the experience worth it. Outstanding teachers are gratefully named.

However, although one has to beware of a survey of self-selecting contributors, the overwhelming impression from the responses is that violence and sexual abuse was widespread and often horrific. Many people report a lifetime of being unable to connect emotionally. In my own case it also made me hostile to all authority. For people like us,
summary:
My heartfelt thanks go to the hundreds of people who have responded to the request for their verdicts on their time at British boarding schools.
First, it is heartening that many people reported having been perfectly happy.
Others have taken the position that it wasn’t exactly paradise, but that there were positive things that made the experience worth it.
However, although one has to beware of a survey of self-selecting contributors, the overwhelming impression from the responses is that violence and sexual abuse was widespread and often horrific.
Many people report a lifetime of being unable to connect emotionally.

title: Gardaí appeal for information on mother and baby home criminal acts
text:
Catherine Corless, the woman who uncovered the Tuam mother and baby home scandal, said it would be fantastic if survivors contacted gardaí and people were held to account for their actions

Gardaí yesterday issued an appeal urging anyone who knows of criminal acts which took place in the state’s mother and baby homes to contact them.

The decision to begin an inquiry was made after a review of the 2,800-page report by the commission of investigation, published in January, which concluded that 9,000 children died in the homes where unmarried women were sent to deliver their babies in secret.

Sponsored

About 56,000 people, including girls as young as 12, were sent to the institutions where some 57,000 children were born. The homes were run by religious organisations but overseen by the state.

Drew Harris, the garda commissioner, yesterday told a meeting of the Policing Authority that he believed an investigation was warranted having read the stories published
summary:

title: Holyrood ministers ‘knowing best’ delayed child abuse inquiry
text:
John Scott, QC, said government record keeping and advice on the subject of abuse was inaccurate and inadequate

The Scottish government was guided by a “regrettable degree of paternalism” towards child abuse survivors when deciding against establishing an inquiry.

Closing submissions were being given to the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry in Edinburgh yesterday, which examined ministers’ actions surrounding the issue between 2002 and 2014.

Sponsored

title: Why it’s time to join Generation Woke
text:
In 1965, on the hokey children’s show Lost in Space, the castaway family’s robot spoke for the citizens of the planet they had left behind. “It does not compute,” he grumbled, whirring his way into television folklore. Back on Earth, you had to be a very intelligent robot or else a pretty young human being to compute what was going on. All of a sudden a generation was disagreeing with the generation above it, on everything. Parents sent their children to school one morning in short trousers and pinafores; that afternoon they returned in kaftans and miniskirts, their hair now as unruly as their music and their politics. Upstairs in their bedrooms, they made love (rather than war) beneath posters of (the armed revolutionary)

title: Tech companies must be forced to protect children
text:
It’s now more than 12 years since I was asked to investigate the risks children face online and what needs to be done to keep them safe. I called for urgent action and co-operation between government and tech companies to protect children. But of the 38 recommendations I made to those in power, only 13 have been fully implemented.

Much has changed since I first reported back to the government; technology has developed exponentially while apps and sites like Instagram, Snapchat and WhatsApp have been created and become huge global phenomena. The teenagers I wanted to help keep safe online have become adults. Many will now have children of their own, who will be entering the online world earlier and more frequently.

summary:
It’s now more than 12 years since I was asked to investigate the risks children face online and what needs to be done to keep them safe.
I called for urgent action and co-operation between government and tech companies to protect children.
But of the 38 recommendations I made to those in power, only 13 have been fully implemented.
The teenagers I wanted to help keep safe online have become adults.
Many will now have children of their own, who will be entering the online world earlier and more frequently.

title: Our pick of the latest fiction: three new novels, March 2021

We followed the Vietnam War photographer Jonathan in The Gun Room, then the Far Eastern wartime horrors experienced by his father, Charlie, in Land of the Living. You don’t need to have read them to enjoy her latest, though. It’s the 1970s and Jonny has returned to the family farm in Norfolk from his east Asian travels; not far behind him comes Kumiko, his Japanese girlfriend. His mother, Claire, and his taciturn elder brother, Robert, who runs the farm, have to adjust to this bright, attentive new presence, drawing them out of the grief that still envelops them, years after Charlie’s sudden death.

text:
Adam Pettitt between Simon Cowell and Sir Philip Green during a work experience event at Highgate School in 2015

When Adam Pettitt arrived as head teacher at Highgate School in 2006, it was seen as a “mid-tier” private institution that looked on longingly at more well-heeled establishments such as Westminster and Eton.

Since then he has overseen an ambitious rejuvenation project, turning it into one of the most sought-after “destination schools”, with fees rising to £21,600, in line with its reputation.

One of the most damning claims within the 230-strong dossier of rape culture allegations

title: Scottish Opera’s Hansel and Gretel opera film
text:
Those of us disappointed by the lack of even medium-scale opera work by our big subsidised national companies during lockdown can take comfort from Scottish Opera’s second opera film of the season, Humperdinck’s Hansel and Gretel. A semi-staging of Mozart’s Così fan tutte in the autumn can still be watched on the company’s website.

The new film is directed by Daisy Evans, a rising figure in the world of operatic accessibility, with Kitty Whately and Rhian Lois as the titular children, nemesis of Nadine Benjamin’s Mother and Witch. Like the Così, the production was filmed in the company’s home, Glasgow’s Theatre Royal.

title: The Times view on the appointment of Tim Davie to lead the BBC: New Director-General
text:
The job of director-general of the BBC has become such a poisoned chalice that it is a wonder so many candidates seek it. The BBC board yesterday announced that its 17th boss, when Lord Hall of Birkenhead steps down in September, will be Tim Davie, an internal candidate who runs the corporation’s commercial activities as head of BBC Studios. Mr Davie will take on the task of ushering the corporation through the greatest technological revolution it has experienced since the invention of broadcasting itself.

In its wisdom the board decided to reject two outside candidates and play safe with an insider. One of Mr Davie’s key objectives will be to seek alternative sources of revenue as the argument for the compulsory licence fee becomes less

title: Scouting Ireland abuse: a damning verdict, but there is more to be found
text:
Yesterday’s damning review into Scouting Ireland, and the organisation’s subsequent apology, will hopefully be some relief to the hundreds of victims of child sexual abuse.

Not only did it confirm a legacy of abuse and cover-up spanning decades, it also found that victims had previously tried to come forward but had been ignored or not believed.

Sponsored

Scouting Ireland said it was aware of 275 known or suspected predators who abused children over a period spanning decades at the Catholic Boy Scouts of Ireland (CBSI) and the Scout Association of Ireland (SAI).

These two organisations merged in 2004 to form Scouting Ireland, which has apologised unreservedly to the 356 victims who have, so far, come forward.

The organisation also said it was well on its way

title: Police ‘pick hunting grounds’ for speed cameras to raise money
text:
The sites where speed cameras are placed suggest that some are being used as cash cows rather than as tools to reduce accidents, according to a watchdog report.

A wide-ranging review of roads policing claims that some cameras have been placed at sites without a history of collisions or other vulnerabilities and so may be being used for revenue raising. Inspectors were told that they were deployed at certain locations because these were “good hunting grounds”, rather than accident hotspots. They found that drug drivers were “tolerated” and the use of breathalyser tests had slumped yet the number of fixed-penalty tickets issued for excessive speed had risen sharply in recent years.

Sponsored

The report by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Constabulary and Fire and Rescue, published yesterday,

title: The best podcasts to listen to in 2021
text:
There are almost a million podcasts. This is madness. How are you supposed to know what to listen to? This is how. In this list I’ve picked the shows that I love and that I think are really worth your time. My criteria is: is this the sort of podcast that has me anxiously checking my phone every week to see if a new episode has landed yet? If the answer is yes, it goes on the list.

title: Rise in youngsters seeing domestic abuse, children’s charity reveals
text:
A total of 377 domestic abuse reports were made to the police and social workers between April 1 and December 31

Reports of children living in homes affected by domestic abuse have risen more than 30 per cent during the pandemic, according to research.

Figures from the NSPCC show that the average number of reports of children living in such homes rose from 32 a month between January and March of last year to 42 a month throughout the rest of 2020.

title: ‘It’s not going to help Hearts in the long term if I fall out with people’
text:
When Dundee turn up at Tynecastle for the opening game in the Championship their directors will get a friendly welcome in the Hearts boardroom. No, really. They won’t need to worry about vinegar in the tea or salt in the coffee. “Absolutely,” says Andrew McKinlay, Hearts’ new chief executive, laughing at the very notion. “I’m sure we will be as hospitable as we would be to any directors. I think we’re just all looking forward to getting the football started. It’s interesting that Dundee are first.”

title: Charles Hazlewood: Like me, Beethoven was abused as a child
text:
Throughout my entire conducting career, every time I prepare a piece of Beethoven — without exception — he and I fight like dogs. He turns my world upside down. It has taken me most of my life to realise why I have such a troubling time with his music: we are both survivors of childhood abuse.

I approached Sky Arts with the idea for a film about this with trepidation and anxiety. I have long had a deep-set instinct that there was more to this torment I experienced, and as I learnt more about Beethoven’s life and the abuse he suffered I started to notice similarities between us, certain behavioural traits that I now recognise as personality disorders. Virtually every bar of his music carries
summary:
Throughout my entire conducting career, every time I prepare a piece of Beethoven — without exception — he and I fight like dogs.
He turns my world upside down.

title: Nimco Ali on Boris, Carrie and her campaign to end violence against women
text:
For Nimco Ali, the personal has always been political. She is a black, Muslim, 38-year-old survivor of female genital mutilation who has become one of the world’s most effective campaigners against the barbaric practice of cutting girls. Describing herself as the “chief fanny defender”, she has been awarded an OBE by the Queen for her work. She arrived in Britain at the age of four as a refugee from Somalia, grew up supporting Labour, once stood as a candidate for the Women’s Equality Party, and at the last election voted Green. Now she has become one of Boris Johnson’s most trusted allies and his fiancée Carrie Symonds’ closest friend. She is godmother to the prime minister’s son Wilfred and, before the lockdown, played ping-pong regularly

Sponsored
summary:
For Nimco Ali, the personal has always been political.
She is a black, Muslim, 38-year-old survivor of female genital mutilation who has become one of the world’s most effective campaigners against the barbaric practice of cutting girls.
Describing herself as the “chief fanny defender”, she has been awarded an OBE by the Queen for her work.
Now she has become one of Boris Johnson’s most trusted allies and his fiancée Carrie Symonds’ closest friend.
She is godmother to the prime minister’s son Wilfred and, before the lockdown, played ping-pong regularlySponsored

title: One trial for 11 people accused of child abuse in Munster
text:
The defendants, who are on bail, will all appear at the central criminal court on July 13

The cases of six women and five men accused of multiple offences relating to the alleged abuse and neglect of children will be run as a single trial, a court hearing was told.

The 11 defendants, who range in age from 76 to 25, face more than 200 charges. The charges include sexual assault, sexual exploitation and child cruelty and neglect under Section 246 of the Children Act 2001.

Sponsored

The alleged victims are all juveniles and the offences are alleged to have happened at locations in Limerick on dates between 2014 and 2016.

The defendants, who have addresses in several counties across Munster, were arrested and charged earlier last year. Books of evidence were served on them at a district court sitting last November.

The

The 11 defendants, who range in age from 76 to 25, face more than 200 charges.

title: Foster care: how memory boxes help to heal fractured childhoods
text:
Trauma steals memory,” says Lemn Sissay, 53, the poet and broadcaster who grew up in the British care system. Born in Wigan to a single 22-year-old student from Ethiopia, he was put in foster care shortly after birth and placed at seven months old with foster parents, the Greenwoods, on the promise of adoption. In January 1980 they cast him out of their home at the age of 12, on the spurious notion that he didn’t love them enough. There was no fond farewell. Sissay’s foster mother, her hands held flatly by her sides, watched her “son” leave without a hug and without wanting to see him again.

“I lost everybody,” he says. He was taken to Woodfields children’s home near Wigan. All he carried
summary:
Trauma steals memory,” says Lemn Sissay, 53, the poet and broadcaster who grew up in the British care system.
Born in Wigan to a single 22-year-old student from Ethiopia, he was put in foster care shortly after birth and placed at seven months old with foster parents, the Greenwoods, on the promise of adoption.
In January 1980 they cast him out of their home at the age of 12, on the spurious notion that he didn’t love them enough.
Sissay’s foster mother, her hands held flatly by her sides, watched her “son” leave without a hug and without wanting to see him again.
He was taken to Woodfields children’s home near Wigan.

title: German AI posts fake child-abuse videos online to catch abusers
text:
The images have been used to gain access to digital child abuse networks

Police have used a computer to generate fake videos of child abuse to help them to infiltrate an online paedophile ring.

The controversial technique, which was legalised by the Bundestag in January, allows artificial intelligence (AI) software to “watch” a database of tens of thousands of impounded clips of sexual violence against children. Over time the AI learns to produce its own video, which undercover investigators can use to win the confidence of paedophiles on secretive internet forums.

Sponsored

Ministers argue that this is often the only way to break open digital child abuse networks, which frequently refuse to admit new members unless they upload their own material. The artificial images can be deployed as a last resort when there is no realistic alternative for

text:

The former Play School presenter, now a Liberal Democrat peer, had lunch with the monarch when she visited Exeter University, where Baroness Benjamin was chancellor in 2012. They sat together and chatted about food, children, the House of Lords — and racism.

title: Porn sites used by children show ‘criminal’ sex acts
text:
Sites such as Pornhub are more popular than eBay, PayPal and LinkedIn

The most popular porn sites are bombarding users with sexually violent material depicting rape, upskirting and other abuse, according to a landmark study.

An analysis of 131,738 titles on the homepages of Pornhub, XHamster and XVideos found that one in eight showed non-consensual or incestuous acts, including where the subjects were described as drugged, unconscious or “very young”.

Sponsored

More than 8,000 titles referred to physical aggression or forced sexual activity, even when the researchers excluded representations of consensual bondage, discipline and sadomasochism (BDSM) practices.

The study, published today in the British Journal of Criminology, is one of the most in-depth analyses of online porn to date and draws on the largest sample of mainstream material yet collected. Swathes of material depicting degrading and extreme violence

title: How to Love Animals by Henry Mance review — think you love animals? So why aren’t you vegan?
text:
We should probably never have bought Fluffy. It’s not that the Cooke family were negligent pet owners. We tried to give him a comfortable life — a wendy house with a heat lamp and a bed of straw, a garden in which to roam and two hens for company. But he was as disdainful of the Yorkshire weather as the next giant African tortoise, and made this clear by staying inside for days on end.

title: The secret to sporting greatness can often be found in childhood trauma
text:
Fracture is a new book by Matthew Parris, my esteemed colleague at The Times, which looks at how great lives take root in trauma. From Lenin experiencing the hanging of his brother in Saint Petersburg, to the orphanage childhood of Coco Chanel, to Rudyard Kipling being sent away by his parents, aged five, into the cruel care of others, it examines how trauma, affliction and isolation can be foundations for greatness, for genius.

Dozens of extraordinary achievers — Abraham Lincoln, Charlie Chaplin, Freddie Mercury and many more from politics, literature, the military and beyond — are shown to have triumphed not in spite of childhood chaos or shock but because of it.

text:
Two Dublin-based companies that are part of Pornhub’s business empire are being sued in America for allegedly profiting from the dissemination of child-abuse videos.

The two companies — MG Billing and MindGeek Content RT — are ultimately owned by Pornhub’s Canadian parent company, MindGeek. Up until January they were using the Dublin headquarters of the accountancy firm Grant Thornton as an address.

Grant Thornton, which has been paid at least €61,700 in fees for audit work for the companies, resigned from its auditor position following queries from this newspaper last December. The Irish companies have since changed their address to a nearby serviced office at 77 Sir John Rogerson’s Quay.

title: Priti Patel plans police league tables as serious crime crackdown starts
text:
The Home Office’s “relentless focus on cutting crime” will involve measuring police performance on six crime types

Priti Patel is drawing up league tables ranking police forces on their success in cutting serious crime in a move that chief constables warned was a return to targets.

Police chiefs have been told they will be measured on six crime types including homicide, serious violence and cybercrime. The Home Office will compare their performance against national benchmarks in what it said was a “relentless focus on cutting crime”.

Sponsored

The scheme will add to concerns that the home secretary is encroaching on operational independence. Some chiefs have complained she went too far when she demanded forces increase enforcement of protests and coronavirus restrictions.

The new system of “national crime and policing measures” was described by senior officers as a return to the culture of targets
summary:

title: Payouts for survivors of abuse in care
text:
A Quarriers home for children: the organisation Former Boys and Girls Abused of Quarriers Homes said the redress scheme will acknowledge the harm done

Survivors of historical child abuse in care will be able to apply for payouts of up to £80,000 under new proposals.

The legislation aims to provide “tangible recognition” of harm caused to those who were abused as children in residential care settings before December 1, 2004. It proposes setting up an independent body, Redress Scotland, to assess applications for compensation.

Sponsored

Survivors can apply for a fixed-rate payment of £10,000 or an individually assessed redress payment which will involve a more detailed examination of their experience, with payment levels set at £20,000, £40,000 and £80,000.

John Swinney, the deputy first minister, said: “For decades, many children were failed by the institutions and people entrusted to look after them. Financial redress is an important part of doing

title: We must wrap our arms around those whose home is not a safe haven
text:
Over the past few weeks life as we knew it has changed. For most of us Coronavirus has provided some additional challenges — home working, home schooling and not being able to see family and friends, but it has been nothing that the great resolve and perseverance of the British people have not been able to handle.

However, for some people, the government’s guidance to stay at home as much as possible brings particular anxiety, because home for them is not the safe haven that it should be. That is why the prime minister is hosting the Hidden Harms Summit today to look at how we can better protect those most at risk.

Sponsored

This virtual initiative aims to shine a light on the added challenges

Over the past few weeks life as we knew it has changed.
For most of us Coronavirus has provided some additional challenges — home working, home schooling and not being able to see family and friends, but it has been nothing that the great resolve and perseverance of the British people have not been able to handle.
However, for some people, the government’s guidance to stay at home as much as possible brings particular anxiety, because home for them is not the safe haven that it should be.
That is why the prime minister is hosting the Hidden Harms Summit today to look at how we can better protect those most at risk.

The Police Scotland investigation started when Susie Henderson made allegations against some of the country’s leading lawyers

A Scottish lawyer is set to be extradited from America to face charges of child sexual abuse.

John Watt, QC, a former prosecutor, is accused of sexual assaults on four children in the 1970s and 1980s.

Mr Watt, 70, could be in Scotland by October after a US judge approved his removal despite his claims that his extradition should be stopped for “humanitarian” reasons due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: How do we stop men harming women?
text:
There was a wearying familiarity to many of the stories dominating the news agenda around the world last week. In America, away from the fallout from the vigil for Sarah Everard, the 33-year-old abducted from south London and murdered, New York’s governor, Andrew Cuomo, a former Democratic Party favourite, has been mired in sexual assault allegations.

France, which has been undergoing a moral purge for some time, was struck by yet another scandal. This time it was the news anchor Patrick Poivre d’Arvor, a fixture on television screens for more than 20 years. He has been accused of raping a young female colleague. In Australia, the attorney-general is also facing rape claims, with thousands of women marching in protest at the handling of the allegations
summary:
There was a wearying familiarity to many of the stories dominating the news agenda around the world last week.
France, which has been undergoing a moral purge for some time, was struck by yet another scandal.
This time it was the news anchor Patrick Poivre d’Arvor, a fixture on television screens for more than 20 years.
He has been accused of raping a young female colleague.
In Australia, the attorney-general is also facing rape claims, with thousands of women marching in protest at the handling of the allegations

title: Catherine Martin issues warning notes against abuse online and at music festivals
text:
State funding for music festivals may be linked to required procedures for dealing with complaints of sexual harassment

Google, Facebook and Twitter will face fines of up to €20m if they fail to remove abusive or harmful online content, under new legislation being prepared by the minister for arts and media.

In an interview with The Sunday Times, Green Party deputy leader Catherine Martin said the issue of online abuse, such as that suffered by her colleague Hazel Chu, the lord mayor of Dublin, must be tackled. “We need to look at how quickly we can take that [abuse] down and what are the sanctions,” she said. “We’re looking at setting the maximum fine at €20m.”

Sponsored

Under the Online Safety and Media Regulation Bill, which Martin intends publishing “in the coming months”, a newly established Media Commission would be able to levy fines
summary:

title: The science is becoming clear: lockdowns are no longer the right medicine
text:
When reports emerged of an epidemic in Wuhan, the capital of China’s Hubei province, policy-makers had to make far-reaching decisions based on extremely limited information. Terrifying statistics led many global leaders to shut their economies and quarantine entire populations.

The World Health Organisation declared at first that the Covid-19 death rate was 3.4%. Modelling at Imperial College London — based on early, unreliable data — suggested more than 500,000 people could die in the UK unless drastic action were taken.

Sponsored

Since then academics have been working hard to understand more about Covid-19 and we have seen remarkable progress. Here are some of the key findings.

First, it’s clear that Covid-19 is much more common than first assumed. The vast majority of people infected have mild
summary:
When reports emerged of an epidemic in Wuhan, the capital of China’s Hubei province, policy-makers had to make far-reaching decisions based on extremely limited information.
The World Health Organisation declared at first that the Covid-19 death rate was 3.4%.
Modelling at Imperial College London — based on early, unreliable data — suggested more than 500,000 people could die in the UK unless drastic action were taken.
SponsoredSince then academics have been working hard to understand more about Covid-19 and we have seen remarkable progress.
First, it’s clear that Covid-19 is much more common than first assumed.

title: Killer John du Pont visited abuser George Gibney’s swim club in Dublin, reveals Netflix show
text:
Du Pont (in foreground) and Schultz at Foxcatcher in Pennsylvania

An American billionaire found guilty of murdering an Olympic champion wrestler visited the Irish swimming club run by child-abusing coach George Gibney in the late 1980s, it has emerged.

Film footage showing John Eleuthère du Pont, an eccentric sports philanthropist, being introduced to young Trojans Club members at the poolside in Blackrock, Co Dublin, features in a Netflix documentary entitled Team Foxcatcher.

Sponsored

Du Pont, an heir to one of America’s richest family fortunes, was convicted of murdering Dave Schultz, a gold medal winner at the 1984 Olympics, whom he shot dead in January 1996. The murder was the subject of the Hollywood movie Foxcatcher in 2014, starring Steve Carell as du Pont and Mark Ruffalo as Schultz.

The connection with Gibney came to light

title: Slalom review — child abuse drama is as credible as it is unnerving
text:
★★★★☆

A classic sports movie in the Rocky mould about a plucky outsider who rises through the ranks and morphs into something far more sinister in this astounding French debut. The writer and director Charlène Favier tells the story of the gifted 15-year-old skier Lyz (Noee Abita), the daughter of a neglectful mother and absent father who nonetheless becomes a slalom champ under the tutelage of the no-nonsense coach Fred (Jérémie Renier).

Midway through the film, however, at a ski camp in the French Alps, Fred begins the grim and systematic sexual abuse of Lyz in a manner that, thanks to his slow grooming process of assurance and trust-building, is as credible as it is unnerving.

title: Child rapist Aaron McWilliams used Gumtree ads to get jobs as nanny
text:
One of the UK’s most “devious” paedophiles was able to perpetrate five years of child sex abuse after advertising his services as a male nanny on Gumtree and social media sites.

Aaron McWilliams, 28, raped or molested at least 24 children, including a four-month-old baby, after parents hired him unwittingly. Detectives at Scotland Yard found he had duped families across the country and as far afield as Italy and Germany, sometimes by providing forged references.

Sergei Furgal, 50, was shown being pulled from his vehicle by masked investigators wearing camouflage in footage broadcast by state media. He has not commented on allegations that he ordered the killings of businessmen in 2004-05.

title: Britain can’t afford to miss this chance to clean up the web
text:
For all the good the internet brings — and over the past few months it’s been a lifesaver for many — we all know there’s a dark and harmful side to the web. Yet for too long successive governments have lacked the will to do anything about it. It’s a complicated issue but there is finally something approaching a consensus about online harms. This is a moment the government cannot afford to miss if it’s serious about tackling some of the most pervasive social ills.

Our lives are increasingly lived online but we have surprisingly little protection from the content we allow into our homes. Internet companies are obliged to take down illegal material like terrorist propaganda and child abuse imagery but the vast grey

title: A child, Keon Lincoln, killed by children — we cannot accept this
text:
There’s been a news story flickering at the edges of my consciousness for the past three days. Every time I heard about it I was horrified, and every time I quickly pushed it away and tried to think of something else. The story concerns a 15-year-old boy killed by a mob close to his home in Birmingham last Thursday. He was reportedly shot and stabbed. It was half past three in the afternoon. Two 14-year-olds are in custody.

The boy’s name was Keon Lincoln. He had four siblings. His mother works as a cleaner at a school and is “inconsolable”.

Sponsored

The story, and many others like it involving communities where violence seems quotidian and almost ordinary, causes my brain to make a tiny, self-comforting adjustment

title: UK Sport launches investigation into claims young gymnasts were abused
text:
Lyons said she had been hit with a stick as a 12-year-old and shut in a cupboard by her coach

British Gymnastics has launched an independent QC-led inquiry into reports of physical and emotional abuse of young gymnasts by their coaches.

Jane Mulcahy, QC, who has watchdog roles in cricket, tennis and boxing, will lead the review after Catherine Lyons, 19, a former junior European champion, said that she had been hit with a stick as a 12-year-old and shut in a cupboard by a coach.

Sponsored

Other gymnasts have also reported being bullied and shamed about their weight by members of the coaching staff.

UK Sport has warned that any safeguarding failures could lead to funding being withdrawn from the sport, which received £16.5 million in preparation for the Tokyo Olympics.

text:
The Church of England’s position that sex should only be between a married man and woman left two elderly neighbours vulnerable to seduction by a manipulative churchwarden, an official review said today.

Benjamin Field, 29, emotionally abused Peter Farquhar, 69, before seducing his neighbour, Ann Moore-Martin, 83, in the village of Maids Moreton, Buckinghamshire. Field was convicted of the murder of Mr Farquhar in October last year.

Sponsored

An independent review commissioned by the Diocese of Oxford recommends greater awareness of social isolation and “need for intimacy” of older people and to challenge ageism and attitudes towards homosexuality within the church.

It found that Field had “groomed” the vicar and the entire congregation at Stowe parish church.

title: Believe complaints of abuse, police told in new advice after ‘Nick’ case
text:
The new guidance warns detectives not to go “trawling” for victims of abuse

Senior police officers have stood by the policy automatically to believe alleged victims of abuse in new national advice, despite inquiries in which fantasists were trusted and reputations traduced.

Detectives investigating historical allegations of child abuse will be told that “the intention is that victims are believed”. The College of Policing guidance, to be published today, emphasises that “those reporting crimes will be treated with empathy and their allegations will be taken seriously”.

Sponsored

Automatic belief has been highly controversial since detectives in Scotland Yard’s Operation Midland were taken in by a fantasist known as Nick and his false claims of a Westminster abuse ring.

The new guidelines have been under consideration for nearly four years since the retired judge Sir Richard Henriques reviewed Operation Midland

text:

The sexual abuse of children online increased during the coronavirus lockdown, a Police Scotland report has said.

Other crimes including common assault and road traffic offences fell, while the overall number of calls to the police rose.

title: Madeleine McCann case: police seek a ‘knockout blow’ to charge suspect Christian Brückner
text:
Mobile phone records placed Christian Brückner in Praia da Luz on the night Madeleine McCann vanished, police said

The German paedophile suspected of abducting Madeleine McCann is said to have been placed under surveillance in jail in the hope that he will confess to the notorious crime to a fellow prisoner.

Police believe that Christian Brückner might inadvertently blurt out enough details about his involvement in her disappearance to allow them to charge him with her kidnapping and murder.

Sponsored

Madeleine disappeared from her family’s holiday apartment in Praia da Luz 13 years ago AP

Brückner, 43, is behind bars in Kiel in northern Germany for a drugs offence, but his history of rape and child sex abuse has made him the prime suspect for Madeleine’s disappearance from the Algarve 13 years ago.

Although there is significant circumstantial evidence linking him to the crime, police are lacking a “knockout blow”, according to an informed source.

Brückner was publicly identified

title: Hey, rock’n’roll — it’s time for your Me Too moment
text:
There was a moment when, beyond the downfall of the rapist Harvey Weinstein and the seismic backlash against sex abuse in Hollywood, the world swivelled its eyeballs towards the music industry and raised a brow. Hey, rock’n’roll, are we overdue here? The business most notorious for immoral conduct — think Little Richard, Gary Glitter, Jimmy Savile, Jonathan King, Michael Jackson, Phil Spector et al — looked set to erupt in a comparable Me Too blaze. It flared, but faded.

I can’t be the only one who has been holding my breath ever since. Did rock stars get away with it or are a sizeable number twitching nervously behind the nets, rueing the days when birth certificates were not mandatory down at Top of the Pops
summary:

title: Highs and lows of reporters on screen
text:
The “bad journalist” is a stock character in Hollywood movies. Deceitful, corrupt and immoral, they make up quotes, take bribes, or use blackmail and threats to get stories. Think of the character Walter Burns in The Front Page, Kirk Douglas’s amoral hack in Billy Wilder’s Ace in the Hole, or the reporter played by Sally Field in Absence of Malice.

Yet none of these, I would argue, is as “bad” as the journalist in Godless, a western drama mini-series made for Netflix. AT Grigg, the editor of the Santa Fe Daily Review, as portrayed by actor Jeremy Bobb, may just be the most evil journalist yet seen on screen.

title: Police reveal sordid crimes of Madeleine McCann prime suspect Christian Brückner
text:
Madeleine McCann disappeared from her family’s holiday apartment in Portugal in May 2007

German prosecutors said yesterday they were presuming that Madeleine McCann was dead as it emerged that the prime suspect in her abduction had raped a woman in the same area of Portugal 18 months before.

Christian Brückner, 43, who is a convicted child sex offender, wore a mask when he broke into a 72-year-old American expat’s home in Praia da Luz, beat and raped her before stealing cash.

Sponsored

Christian Brückner was said to have been in Praia da Luz, Portugal, when Madeleine disappeared BILD BUND

A German official on the case confirmed to The Times that Brückner, who is serving a jail term for drug offences, is the suspect at the centre of Scotland Yard’s inquiry into the missing child.

title: Suicide denies justice to those who suffered
text:
In January 2018, at the court hearing of disgraced US Gymnastics doctor Larry Nassar, Izzy Hutchins stood up and directed the end of her testimony at another man — John Geddert, her former coach, the man she claimed had physically and emotionally abused her for years. “We will come for you next,” she said to him.

She was right. Last week, the Michigan attorney general announced wide-ranging criminal charges against the coach who led the US Gymnastics team to gold at the London 2012 Olympic Games. The charge sheet included human trafficking and sexually assaulting a teenage girl.

title: Let’s hope this is end of the McCanns’ ordeal
text:
The phrase “Scotland Yard detectives are due to fly to Portugal tomorrow” must now be one of the most familiar news lines in Britain. Almost anyone out of school will instantly know what it means. That there’s a possible development in the case of Madeleine McCann. And having been heard so many times over the last, long 13 years, it is likely to be greeted with scepticism, since all the other stories and leads have turned to dust.

But perhaps this time it’s different. Possibly the German paedophile named as Christian Brückner is, finally, the answer to the mystery. As I write this, news updates on the story are making my Apple watch vibrate every few minutes. The German authorities in Braunschweig have been confident
summary:
The phrase “Scotland Yard detectives are due to fly to Portugal tomorrow” must now be one of the most familiar news lines in Britain.
Almost anyone out of school will instantly know what it means.
That there’s a possible development in the case of Madeleine McCann.
Possibly the German paedophile named as Christian Brückner is, finally, the answer to the mystery.
As I write this, news updates on the story are making my Apple watch vibrate every few minutes.

title: The Archers: a 70th birthday tribute
text:
On Friday, January 1 The Archers turns 70 and Radio 4 is planning a party for the world’s longest-running drama. Immediately after the special anniversary episode — details strictly under wraps — listeners will be treated to the half-hour Archers Anniversary Quiz hosted by Kenton and Jolene (Richard Atlee and Buffy Davis) in the Bull. Then on January 2, at 8pm, Radio 4 will broadcast an hour-long programme, A Social History of the Archers, that will look at how the show has reflected the immense changes that have taken place since 1951 — socially, culturally, politically and, not least, agriculturally. Who could have imagined that a BBC radio soap designed to educate farmers in the aftermath of the Second World War would end

Sponsored

On Friday, January 1 The Archers turns 70 and Radio 4 is planning a party for the world’s longest-running drama.

title: Sexual abuse is not just schools’ problem, say heads
text:
Zan Moon has put together a dossier of claims about leading schools

The secondary school headteachers’ union says much teenage sexual abuse happens at parties and that it is not for schools alone to address incidents of sexual abuse and harassment.

Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said today that parents, the justice system and social media firms also had to take responsibility.

Sponsored

His comments came as the number of testimonies about abuse on the Everyone’s Invited website exceeded 11,000, with more than 2,000 of those being posted in the last 24 hours.

Barton said: “The testimonies posted on the Everyone’s Invited website are utterly horrifying and the behaviour described is not only unacceptable but in many cases constitutes a serious sexual offence.

title: Madeleine McCann police send divers down 50ft wells
text:
British police still regard Madeleine McCann as missing; German prosecutors say they have evidence she is dead

Police searching for Madeleine McCann have used divers to examine wells on land close to where the German paedophile suspected of her abduction had stayed.

The land is off a road leading to the Boca do Rio and Barranco beaches on the Algarve coast where Christian Brückner often parked his motorhome at the time of Madeleine’s disappearance 13 years ago.

Sponsored

The land contains more than 20 wells. Police and firefighters searched the site on Thursday with divers focusing on three 50ft (15m) wells full of rubbish and vegetation.

Information from the German police and Scotland Yard’s Operation Grange investigation into Madeleine’s disappearance had prompted the search, Correio da Manha reported.

The site is six miles from the resort of Praia da Luz, where Madeleine, who

title: Male survivors of sexual abuse deserve better
text:
While developing a report on child sexual abuse and exploitation, I have been fortunate to benefit from the advice of a group of survivors who can speak to failings in our system with an expertise we all wish they did not have. Brave and brilliant men and women from all walks of life pulling together to try to drive up standards for the children of today. I have developed nearly 100 policy recommendations to improve our response to these awful crimes with their support and guidance.

We have discussed at length the public conversation on sexual violence that has taken place over the last few weeks: the outpourings of testimony from women and girls on violence and abuse they have endured, the desperate statistics on

title: QAnon cultists believe they’re in a battle between the light and darkness
text:
If the storming of the Capitol was part tragedy and part farce, its enduring symbol was the bare-chested man in buffalo horns. This was an Arizonian called Jake Angeli, a voiceover artist also known as the QAnon Shaman.

QAnon is a conspiracy theory-turned-cult whose adherents believe that there is a deep state plot run by a paedophile cult whose leaders include the Clintons and the Obamas. This plot was “revealed” online a few years ago by someone calling themselves “Q”, supposedly a security establishment insider. Q has also let it be known that there is a counterplot by freedom-loving Americans and that this is led by none other than Donald Trump. Its supporters believe that the final showdown between the forces of light and darkness

title: Historical sexual abuse: There is no defending football over all of this
text:
If I were Dominic McKay, the incoming Celtic FC chief executive who is due to take up the reins in the summer, there is one aspect of the job I would dread above all others: steering the club across the ongoing, appalling terrain of historic child sex abuse.

McKay, of course, will be guided by lawyers on this matter but, as a key corporate public figure at Celtic, he will almost certainly be dragged into the mire. It is an unspeakable tragedy in which no right-minded individual would wish to become involved.

title: London Oratory School is accused of fostering ‘rape culture’
text:
The headteacher wrote to parents reminding them of the virtues of “chastity” and the “sacrament of marriage”

The London Oratory has become the latest leading school to face accusations of fostering a rape culture among its pupils.

An Instagram account has been set up to share the testimonies of girls who join the Roman Catholic school in the sixth form, which include claims of rape and sexual assault.

Sponsored

The headteacher of the school in Fulham, west London, has been accused of failing to address the matter properly after responding to pupils and parents reminding them of the virtues of “chastity” and the “sacrament of marriage”.

Despite being a state school the London Oratory has a low uptake of children from deprived homes. It counts the actor Simon Callow and the children of Tony Blair and Nick Clegg among its alumni.

title: Football abuse victims need answers now, SFA told
text:
The results of an independent review of child sexual abuse in football have been delayed on several occasions

The distress faced by survivors of sexual abuse in Scottish football is being compounded by delays to a review of paedophilia within the sport, MSPs have claimed.

The Scottish Football Association (SFA) commissioned an independent report into sexual abuse which was due to be released in 2018. A draft was published that year but the final version with victim testimony has been held back several times, prompting anger from those who gave evidence.

Sponsored

Fulton MacGregor, the convener of Holyrood’s cross-party group on the future of football in Scotland, said that he had raised the issue with Ian Maxwell, the SFA chief executive.

Fulton MacGregor, with Nicola Sturgeon, said the delay was causing anxiety

title: Times letters: Sir Ian Botham and cronyism in the Lords
text:
Sir, I am stumped to understand the logic behind Sir Ian Botham’s forthcoming appointment to the House of Lords (“Botham given peerage as reward for Brexit loyalty”, July 18). The award of a peerage should not be a “thank you” to chums, as it carries with it significant governmental responsibility, and should be reserved for those who have clearly demonstrated the wisdom, statesmanship and experience for such high office.

Ironically, at the same time that we see populism and cronyism dominating the recent honours lists, many who have faithfully served their country are being denied appropriate recognition. The present chief of the air staff, Air Chief Marshal Mike Wigston, who has been in post for a year, has yet to receive a knighthood;
summary:
Sir, I am stumped to understand the logic behind Sir Ian Botham’s forthcoming appointment to the House of Lords (“Botham given peerage as reward for Brexit loyalty”, July 18).
The award of a peerage should not be a “thank you” to chums, as it carries with it significant governmental responsibility, and should be reserved for those who have clearly demonstrated the wisdom, statesmanship and experience for such high office.

title: Children are finally being recognised as domestic abuse victims — now they need support
text:
Children are victims of domestic abuse, but for too long they have been labelled “witnesses” or “bystanders”. The assumption has been that unless children were in the same room when domestic abuse occurred they weren’t affected.

However, as the years have gone by our thinking has evolved to understand the multiple forms domestic abuse can take, including coercive and controlling behaviour. And for children it isn’t only about seeing or hearing domestic abuse, it’s about the impact of growing up in the toxic environment domestic abuse creates — the feeling of waking up scared, and treading on eggshells, of feeling unsafe.

Sponsored

Growing up in a household with domestic abuse normalises harmful behaviour and warps the idea of what a relationship should be. Not only does
summary:
Children are victims of domestic abuse, but for too long they have been labelled “witnesses” or “bystanders”.
The assumption has been that unless children were in the same room when domestic abuse occurred they weren’t affected.
However, as the years have gone by our thinking has evolved to understand the multiple forms domestic abuse can take, including coercive and controlling behaviour.
And for children it isn’t only about seeing or hearing domestic abuse, it’s about the impact of growing up in the toxic environment domestic abuse creates — the feeling of waking up scared, and treading on eggshells, of feeling unsafe.
SponsoredGrowing up in a household with domestic abuse normalises harmful behaviour and warps the idea of what a relationship should be.

title: Church shepherds have lost their flocks
text:
It is the time of year when many of us re-read TS Eliot’s Murder in the Cathedral, the drama about the martyrdom of Thomas Becket on December 29, 1170. Many resonances this year! “We have had enough of waiting from December to dismal December,” is a line the whole country could echo though few, alas, would sincerely add, as does the speaker in Eliot’s play, “The Archbishop shall be our head, dispelling dismay and doubt”.

title: Celtic FC face legal action over historical sex abuse at boys’ club
text:
Legal action has been launched against Celtic FC in connection with “insidious” sexual abuse at its feeder club.

Thompsons Solicitors has lodged official papers on behalf of one survivor who is seeking damages from the Parkhead club.

Sponsored

The firm, which represents more than 20 individuals who claim they were molested at Celtic Boys’ Club over three decades, claims it represents the largest child abuse scandal in British football.

The first test case will now be heard at the Court of Session in the coming months.

Four senior figures at the boys’ club have been convicted of molesting dozens of young players.

title: Jim Torbett: Celtic chief vouched for abusive coaches in 1970s
text:
The man who authorised the creation of Celtic’s scandal-hit feeder club assured parents that their children would come to “no harm” if they joined.

As chairman of Celtic FC Sir Robert Kelly vouched for the coaching staff at Celtic Boys Club, describing them as men of “vast character”.

Sponsored

Jim Torbett, whom Kelly allowed to launch and lead the boys’ club in 1966, was later convicted of sexually abusing young players between 1967 and 1974.

However, it has emerged that in 1971 Kelly, a former president of the Scottish FA, told parents that their boys were at no risk of harm if they signed up. The fact that he felt obliged to say so suggests that concerns for child welfare at the club had been circulating
summary:
The man who authorised the creation of Celtic’s scandal-hit feeder club assured parents that their children would come to “no harm” if they joined.
