title: Facebook is a playground for abusers, charity warns
text:
The NSPCC said that social media sites such as Facebook were not doing enough to stop abusers contacting children

Facebook has been accused of “enabling offenders” after 10,000 child grooming offences were recorded by police under new online harms laws.

The NSPCC said that social media sites such as Facebook and Snapchat are not providing enough protection to stop abusers contacting children.

Sponsored

Figures obtained by the charity showed that there were 10,119 offences of sexual communication with a child recorded between the law’s introduction in April 2017 and October 2019.

The means of communication was reported by the police in 5,784 incidents, of which 55 per cent took place on Facebook apps, including Instagram, Whatsapp and Facebook Messenger. A further 1,060 took place on Snapchat.

The charity called on the government to renew its pledge to introduce duty of care laws to protect children
summary:
The NSPCC said that social media sites such as Facebook were not doing enough to stop abusers contacting childrenFacebook has been accused of “enabling offenders” after 10,000 child grooming offences were recorded by police under new online harms laws.
The NSPCC said that social media sites such as Facebook and Snapchat are not providing enough protection to stop abusers contacting children.
The means of communication was reported by the police in 5,784 incidents, of which 55 per cent took place on Facebook apps, including Instagram, Whatsapp and Facebook Messenger.
A further 1,060 took place on Snapchat.
The charity called on the government to renew its pledge to introduce duty of care laws to protect children

title: Police watchdog ‘tried to destroy career’
text:
Mick Creedon was involved in investigations into the late Labour MP Lord Janner, above

One of Britain’s most senior former police officers has claimed that he was subjected to an “amateur and irrational” inquiry by the police watchdog after he investigated VIP sexual abuse allegations.

Mick Creedon, the chief constable of Derbyshire for a decade, indicated that the Independent Office of Police Conduct (IOPC) and Leicestershire police tried to traduce his reputation and destroy his career.

He was placed under criminal investigation for the best part of five years after his involvement in investigations into the late Labour MP Lord Janner of Braunstone.

title: Letters to the Editor: Getting children back to nature
text:
Natural England’s People and Nature survey has found that children from low-income and ethnic-minority backgrounds are less likely to spend time outside (“Natural history GCSE to tempt pupils outdoors”, News, last week).

This is one of the reasons we are creating a nature recovery network, to afford every child the opportunity to play in nature-rich places near their home.

Sponsored

My first job in conservation in 1984 was working with schoolchildren. It led me to believe that fostering a love of nature at school can create connections that last a lifetime, and is the surest way to encourage the changes needed to restore the web of life on which we all depend.

Tony Juniper, chairman, Natural England

Wild things: the poor and ethnic minorities are missing out RICHARD DRURY

Testing ground

We welcome the spirit and ambition
summary:
Natural England’s People and Nature survey has found that children from low-income and ethnic-minority backgrounds are less likely to spend time outside (“Natural history GCSE to tempt pupils outdoors”, News, last week).
This is one of the reasons we are creating a nature recovery network, to afford every child the opportunity to play in nature-rich places near their home.

title: Gordonstoun housemasters were trusted too much, abuse panel told
text:
Lisa Kerr, the first female principal of Gordonstoun, said that the level of autonomy prevoiusly granted to staff was “unacceptable”

The principal of Gordonstoun believes the trust in and autonomy of housemasters in boarding schools in the Sixties and Seventies was “astonishing and unacceptable” by today’s standards.

Lisa Kerr told the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry that it was not hard “to draw a line” from the level of autonomy housemasters were given to the peer-on-peer bullying that some students experienced.

Sponsored

Kerr said: “I think the level of autonomy that was granted to the housemasters, in that era, is at a level that these days, we’d find astonishing and completely unacceptable.”

Andrew Brown QC, senior counsel to the inquiry, said: “It is clear that the way individual houses were run impacted [on] the degree of reported abuse or abuse discovered looking through the records. Some weren’t

title: Retired headmaster Arthur Hutchinson filmed himself raping sedated girl
text:
Arthur Hutchinson first abused the girl in Thailand when she was eight

A former head teacher who filmed himself raping and abusing a girl during almost a decade of sexual assault has been jailed for nine years.

Arthur Hutchinson, 74, moved to Thailand after retiring and there began to molest the child when she was eight. The abuse escalated into repeated rapes. On some occasions the girl was unconscious after he used a cloth soaked in lighter fuel to sedate her.

Sponsored

He amassed a collection of photographs and more than 50 hours of videos showing the abuse, which were found by police on his computer after she moved to Scotland for university. The victim, now 18, opened up to a counsellor after an argument with Hutchinson and sobbed as she revealed the abuse. Police were contacted and

title: Keir Starmer in row over 20-minute ‘racial bias’ lessons
text:
Sir Keir Starmer has been working to dispel accusations of a blindspot on anti-black racism

Sir Keir Starmer faces a new row over Labour’s handling of racism allegations. He has been accused of “making a mockery” of racial injustice after introducing a compulsory 20-minute course on unconscious bias for Labour MPs and peers last night.

He promised to “lead from the top” and undergo the training himself on Monday, amid fierce criticism of his response to the Black Lives Matter protests, which he appeared to dismiss in an interview last week as a “moment”.

A Church of England bishop could face a life ban from office after being accused of telling the victim of a paedophile bishop to “forget it and move on”.

The Bishop of Beverley, the Right Rev Glyn Webster, 69, has been criticised in a report for allegedly failing to investigate reports that the late Victor Whitsey, a former Bishop of Chester, had repeatedly sexually abused a boy in the 1970s, starting when he was 14.

title: Honours erased in decade of disgrace
text:
The Queen is stripping honours from increasing numbers of recipients in a process that critics say is “shrouded in secrecy” and values dignity over transparency.

Last year nine people had honours revoked, marking the end of a decade in which a record 70 people had their honours “cancelled and annulled”, a Times investigation shows.

Sponsored

This is more than three times as many as any previous decade since the Second World War — except for the 1950s, when the total was 26.

Last year’s list, which included Harvey Weinstein, the convicted sex offender and film producer, who lost his honorary CBE, was the third highest annual figure in the postwar period.

Other notable figures include John Stonehouse, the former minister in Harold Wilson’s government who

title: There’s no bigotry in trying to protect children
text:
In the film Cuties, a bunch of misfit girls in a Paris banlieue form a dance troupe and enter a contest where, in sexy costumes, they perform a twerking, crotch-fingering routine. The problem is these characters, and the actresses who play them, are 11 years old.

The French-Senegalese director Maïmouna Doucouré says she was exploring how pornified popular culture grooms children. Yet whatever her moral intent, the film was undeniably created by getting real little girls to spread their legs, hump the stage and caress their vulvas before cast and crew. The routine is prolonged and disturbing, and undoubtedly some of Netflix’s 193 million subscribers will bookmark it for personal “use”.

title: Scourge of the investment scammers
text:
Investment scams have nearly quadrupled during lockdown as scammers use ever more sophisticated methods to dupe ordinary savers into parting with their cash.

Almost £10 million was lost to the frauds last month, up from about £4million in July, according to the Investment Association. The total number of reported scans has jumped from 300 to 1,175 over the same period, affecting about 200 people, the group said.

Sponsored

Scammers are taking advantage of more people working from home where online security may be less robust than in their workplace. With Christmas shopping well under way and lockdown forcing more of us to buy online, there is a rich seam for criminals to exploit.

Criminals are cloning genuine investment management companies, using their logos and website designs

title: This flawed inquiry assumes Janner was guilty
text:
The Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse yesterday started a hearing about allegations against the late Lord Janner of Braunstone, QC, a former Labour MP. As a result, the inquiry risks committing an unprecedented abuse of process and natural justice.

At the time of Janner’s death in 2015 at the age of 87, he was facing 22 charges of child sexual abuse relating to nine different boys. He had consistently denied the allegations but had been too ill with dementia to stand trial. A report the following year by the retired judge Sir Richard Henriques concluded that three opportunities had been missed to prosecute Janner for sexual offences.

title: Evy Poumpouras interview: the former Secret Service agent who wants to make us all bulletproof
text:
As a former Secret Service agent whose job was to protect the leader of the free world, Evy Poumpouras doesn’t advocate violence but knows it is sometimes necessary. Once, during a G20 summit, she blocked a Chinese official from interrupting a meeting between Barack Obama and the Chinese president, Xi Jinping. The deranged delegate threw her through the door into the room where the two men were mid-discussion. Poumpouras battled back. “He may have walked over, but I was going to make sure he’d be limping back.”

Poumpouras, 43, has interrogated terrorists, gone undercover posing as a sex trafficking victim and coaxed confessions out of prolific child abusers. She practises Brazilian jujitsu (with her husband, who works in government security) and learnt Arabic (on top

title: Kieran Creaven: Former RTÉ producer faces 17 child abuse charges
text:
Kieran Creaven, who was charged yesterday, worked for RTÉ for nearly 20 years

The former RTÉ producer Kieran Creaven been charged with 17 child abuse offences in Ireland and outside the state.

Mr Creaven, 58, was arrested at his home in Dún Laoghaire early yesterday. He faces two charges of sexual assault of a child and two charges of sexual exploitation of a child outside the state in 2014; three charges of sexually exploiting a child in Ireland in 2017; five charges of possessing child abuse material in 2017; and four charges of using IT and communications technology for the purpose of facilitating child sexual exploitation, inside and outside the state in 2017.

text:
Bruce is the latest person in football to reveal he has received death threats via social media

The pressure on Twitter and Facebook to tackle online abuse has been stepped up after football’s leaders launched a direct attack on the platforms’ chief executives for their failure to act and the Newcastle United manager Steve Bruce revealed that messages had been sent to his family wishing him dead.

text:
Daphne Caruana Galizia, with her son Matthew, was the inspiration for the fictional journalist Gail Vella, right

Viewers attempting to unravel the knotty plot of Line of Duty may be intrigued to learn that the murder victim at its centre is based on a real person.

Jed Mercurio, the writer of all six series of the BBC police drama, has been scrolling through Twitter to congratulate fans who have spotted the resemblance between the fictional journalist Gail Vella and Daphne Caruana Galizia.

The Maltese investigative reporter died in 2017 when her car was rigged with explosives. One man has been imprisoned and a further three charged in a case that has been linked to organised crime and senior political figures.

One Twitter user, using the name Loredana, asked Mercurio whether the current series was “somewhat inspired from the unresolved murder case

title: Tracking down Pornhub to its HQ ... in Uxbridge
text:
Visa and Mastercard have stopped providing Pornhub card payment services after it was accused of making money from ‘unlawful content’

Not long ago, nervous teens walked into Wellington House in Uxbridge to sit their driving theory tests. Today, a black coating on the exterior of the office block gives the building in northwest London a more brooding feel — perhaps in keeping with its new tenant.

This unremarkable property is the UK home of MindGeek, the vast Canadian tech conglomerate behind Pornhub, which stands accused of making money from revenge porn, rape footage and underage sex.

In recent days, Visa and Mastercard have stopped providing card payment services to the world’s leading pornography site, with 42 billion visits a year.

title: Police shut down ‘eBay of the dark web’ in Germany
text:
The gang had converted a former military bunker near Koblenz into a “cyberbunker” containing 400 computer servers

The largest illegal bazaar on the global dark web, likened to an eBay for criminals, has been shut down after its alleged mastermind was arrested in Germany.

Darkmarket had more than half a million users and 2,500 vendors exchanging illicit goods such as drugs, stolen credit card details, counterfeit money and hacking tools.

Sponsored

It was taken offline on Tuesday as the Australian man believed to be its ringleader — identified as Julian K, 34 — was caught while attempting to cross the border from Denmark.

More than 20 of its computer servers, based in Ukraine and Moldova, were also confiscated in an operation involving the German police, the FBI and Scotland Yard.

The website had existed on the “dark” section of the internet, accessible only
summary:

text:

Tony Blair had proposed that the Lords be reformed in two stages. Stage 1 was the departure of all hereditaries. Stage 2 would introduce further, unspecified reforms.

title: FA leaves vulnerable referees exposed by failing to stand up for Mike Dean
text:
When grassroots football resumes, so will the abuse of the 27,000 referees, some of them teenagers, trying to keep order in matches in local parks. The abuse may even be worse, given the angry state of the nation and the vitriol presently directed at elite referees.

Grassroots officials are so angered by the level of abuse — endured even before lockdown — that they are lobbying the Sentencing Council for England and Wales for tougher tariffs for those who assault referees. They also want courts to issue Football Banning Orders. Modest fines are meaningless. The physical and mental health of referees is at risk.

Sponsored

The FA has launched a welcome and timely campaign “to promote positive mental health for match officials across the grassroots game”

title: RTÉ gives Uefa a free pass on the handling of discrimination in football
text:
An hour-long documentary on RTÉ2 last night highlighting the ongoing problems of discrimination in European football threw up a few issues closer to home as well. There is plenty that was good about it, but the fact that the documentary was made by Uefa and unsurprisingly casts the European governing body of football in a sympathetic light should have been enough to raise questions about whether the national broadcaster should be handing over such a prominent platform to Uefa’s in-house media team.

Outraged: Football’s Discrimination dealt with four main areas of prejudice — against footballers who are black, female, gay or from a refugee background — and had strong production values, befitting a super-wealthy organisation such as Uefa. Some big hitters were in the interview

title: The online harms bill misses the point
text:
The coronavirus pandemic has highlighted our almost complete reliance on the Internet, whether keeping business wheels turning, educating our children or contacting friends and family.

But the darker side of this digital dependency has been an exponential increase in illegal and legal online harms — from child abuse material to anti-vax disinformation and hate speech.

Sponsored

Before the pandemic, the UK launched an online harms white paper in 2019 that raised hopes of a safer digital future. Almost two years on, the government’s much anticipated proposals have finally been published; heavy with soundbites but short on detail, they will disappoint many.

Though impossible to please everyone, the shock-and-awe penalties in the paper — including swingeing fines and last chance saloon threats to target senior management —

title: Child abuse claims against Greek theatre director shine light on migrant plight
text:
Dimitris Lignadis, the former director of Greece’s national theatre, is accused of two rapes, one of a 14-year-old boy

In the seedy centre of Athens, a short stocky man approached a towering drag queen. He leans in to her, whispers something, and then, visibly irate, the transvestite points to the end of the street. The man, wearing grey trousers and a matching hat, moves down Omonia Square, and then stops before a yellow phone booth, spotting Mussa, a 17-year-old refugee boy.

He whispers something and they move off together. “It’s just sex,” Mussa tells me later. He has been stuck in Greece for four years, unable to reunite with family and friends in France, since fleeing his homeland, Algeria. “I have to survive.”

title: Most big religions start off as cults — could QAnon ever go mainstream?
text:
I hesitate to write about QAnon. Why offer the oxygen of publicity to a bizarre online conspiracy theory that claims there is a vast paedophile network orchestrated by the political and business elites that will eventually be taken down by Donald Trump? Shouldn’t we ignore such delusions or, perhaps, even censor them?

I am not so sure. I think we have something to learn from QAnon — about ourselves and our relationship with truth. Moreover, I suspect the more that powerful institutions such as Twitter and the US government seek to suppress it, the faster it will grow, at least in the short term, spurred on by its underdog status, finding ever more purchase in the nooks and crannies of digital culture.

Perhaps the
summary:
I hesitate to write about QAnon.
Why offer the oxygen of publicity to a bizarre online conspiracy theory that claims there is a vast paedophile network orchestrated by the political and business elites that will eventually be taken down by Donald Trump?
Shouldn’t we ignore such delusions or, perhaps, even censor them?
I am not so sure.
I think we have something to learn from QAnon — about ourselves and our relationship with truth.

title: Ampleforth college barred from new pupils
text:
Concerns about bullying and physical abuse were raised about the school in a report last year

The leading Catholic school Ampleforth has been temporarily banned by the government from taking on new pupils because of safety concerns.

The boarding school is challenging a poor Ofsted report but the government said it was too slow in making improvements highlighted by repeated inspections dating back to March 2018.

A plan of action drawn up by the school was rejected.

title: Britain deserves a 21st-century police force
text:
The pressures on the police are relentless. During the pandemic, they have had to enforce stringent new restrictions on civil liberties and police a wave of protests, while continuing to deal with violent crime and county lines drug dealing.

Handling all these tasks simultaneously, while seeking to retain the confidence of communities, is difficult. And the job has been growing more challenging and complicated in recent years.

title: The Act of Living by Frank Tallis review — listen, here’s the case for the talking cure
text:
Life is complicated and reality sucks. As a little girl with secular parents told the psychologist Bruno Bettelheim, “I know there is no Santa. And no Tooth Fairy who puts a dime under my pillow.” Then she burst into tears. “I hate reality.” This led Bettelheim to write (as quoted by Frank Tallis) that “unrelieved reality becomes just too unbearable for the young — and for quite a few of the not so young”. And many in this January of 2021 will be thinking “Amen” to that.

The approach to the admissibility of similar fact evidence in family proceedings was the same as the approach in civil proceedings.

title: Naya Rivera: Mom went swimming and never got out, Glee star’s son tells police
text:
Police divers have resumed searching for a star of the hit TV musical Glee who is feared to have drowned after her four-year-old son was found alone on a boat on a Californian lake.

Naya Rivera, 33, who played the lesbian cheerleader Santana Lopez, was last seen at about 1pm on Wednesday when she rented a pontoon boat at Lake Piru, 50 miles north of Los Angeles.

title: Karen Elson: ‘They would say, you’re ugly but we like it — it was humiliating’
text:
If you know anything about models, if you know your Christy Turlington from your Linda Evangelista, you probably know two things about Karen Elson. She’s a redhead, and she’s from Oldham. Elson was 15 when she started modelling, and she’s now a 42-year-old mother of two living in Tennessee, but we’ll get to how she got there later.

For now, she has a bone to pick. Plenty of people have criticised the fashion industry for its obsession with size. Consumers rail against it, editors wring their hands and too many designers effectively shrug. Yet few models have been willing or indeed financially able to bite the hand that feeds them and say “enough”. To lay bare the toll that fashion takes on their mental health,
summary:
If you know anything about models, if you know your Christy Turlington from your Linda Evangelista, you probably know two things about Karen Elson.
She’s a redhead, and she’s from Oldham.
Elson was 15 when she started modelling, and she’s now a 42-year-old mother of two living in Tennessee, but we’ll get to how she got there later.
Yet few models have been willing or indeed financially able to bite the hand that feeds them and say “enough”.

title: Bumbling Stasi agents made up reports and put lovers on payroll
text:
East Germany’s secret police force, the Stasi, ran one of the most formidable surveillance states in modern history, with an informant for every seven members of the public at the height of its powers.

However, a collection of previously secret tapes from its elite training school suggest that it was also riddled with leaks, insecurities, petty corruption and bumbling incompetence.

Sponsored

Its spies put their lovers on the payroll, struggled to keep secrets and sometimes wrote up reports on their targets without setting foot outside the office, the recordings show. They also illustrate the obsessive attention to detail the Stasi was capable of applying when it chose to, with agents pumping the former neighbours of potential recruits for gossip about their favourite toys in infancy and
summary:
East Germany’s secret police force, the Stasi, ran one of the most formidable surveillance states in modern history, with an informant for every seven members of the public at the height of its powers.

title: Madeleine McCann: suspect named as Christian Brückner
text:
Christian Brückner, who is serving seven years in jail, is at the centre of Britain’s investigation into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann

The German suspect in the abduction of Madeleine McCann can be named as Christian Brückner, a sex offender and drug trafficker who is in jail for the rape of a 72-year-old pensioner.

The 43-year-old man, who is serving a seven-year sentence for a violent attack in the Algarve, is the suspect at the centre of Scotland Yard’s investigation into the missing girl.

Sponsored

Yesterday German and British police launched a fresh appeal for information on a serving prisoner thought to have been in Praia da Luz when Madeleine was abducted from her family’s holiday apartment in May 2007. title: Doctors paid thousands for mother and baby home trials
text:
Both Wellcome and Glaxo were subsumed into GlaxoSmithKline in 2000

Two doctors who blocked a state inquiry into vaccine trials they conducted on hundreds of children in mother and baby homes received personal cheques from the British pharmaceutical companies involved, last week’s report on the institutions shows.

Two other doctors who ran vaccine and baby-milk trials in homes in Dublin and Cork were offered money and a free flight for a holiday in England.

Sponsored

Patrick Meenan, a former president of the Medical Council of Ireland, and Irene Hillary, who led the National Virus Reference Laboratory in University College Dublin (UCD), made successful court challenges after being called as witnesses to the Laffoy Commission on child abuse in residential institutions. As a result, its investigation of vaccine trials for Glaxo Laboratories and the Wellcome Foundation between

title: Tusla fined €40,000 for data breach over letter of alleged abuse
text:
A DPC investigation into use of CCTV schemes by all local authorities has found a number of breaches of GDPR

Child and family agency Tusla has accepted a €40,000 fine from the Data Protection Commission (DPC) for a breach that involved it mailing a letter detailing allegations of abuse to a third party who then posted the correspondence on social media.

The fine is just the second that the DPC has issued since 2018, when the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) came into force across the European Union. The DPC’s first fine of €75,000 was also against Tusla.

Sponsored

Tusla reported the most recent case to the DPC last November. The agency confirmed last week that it would not be appealing against the fine, of which it had been notified earlier this month. Details of the case are set out in a two-year review of the

title: The prosecution of child victims of human trafficking had been unfair
text:
European Court of Human Rights

Published March 17, 2021

VCL and AN v United Kingdom

Before Y Grozev, President and Judges T Eicke, F Vehabovi, I A Motoc,

A Harutyunyan, P Pastor Vilanova and J Schukking

Section Registrar: A Tamietti

(Application Numbers 77587/12 and 74603/12)

Judgment February 16, 2021

The prosecution in England of potential victims of trafficking who were minors and had been found working on cannabis farms had been a violation of articles 4 and 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which prohibited forced labour and guaranteed the right to a fair trial, respectively.

Sponsored

The European Court of Human Rights so held in upholding claims brought by the applicants VCL and AN, both Vietnamese nationals, against the United Kingdom.

Both applicants

title: Alex Renton on exposing transatlantic slave traders – in his own family
text:
Anyone attempting to discuss Britain’s historic involvement in the transatlantic slave trade, in which we sent some three million Africans in shackles across the ocean, faces a wall of whataboutery and deflection. I’ve recently attempted to spark conversation with my book Empireland and have met furious resistance, with people objecting even to discussing the history on the grounds that Spain/Portugal did it first, that France/Belgium did it more brutally, that slavery had a long history predating the British Empire with the Greeks/Romans/Ottomans/Mughals /Americans/Brazilians/Cubans all taking slaves, that the awfulness was counterbalanced by the good that Empire did, that Africans are ultimately to blame as they did the enslaving, that the Irish/British working classes actually had it worse, that it’s more important to focus on the

Sponsored

title: Delay reopening of schools, unions urge after Gavin Williamson U-turn
text:
Gavin Williamson backtracked on his plan to keep some London primary schools open

Schools should close for two weeks after the Christmas holidays, England’s biggest teaching union has said after the education secretary was forced into another U-turn.

Two days after announcing plans to keep open many primary schools in London despite surging coronavirus case numbers, Gavin Williamson backtracked yesterday and announced that all London primaries would remain closed after the break.

Sponsored

The National Education Union said all secondary and primary schools should follow suit. So did the GMB and National Association of Head Teachers.

Mary Bousted, joint general secretary of the National Education Union, said: “What is right for London is right for the rest of the country.” She added: “It is welcome that, albeit in their usual last-minute fashion, ministers have corrected an obviously nonsensical position:

title: Parking tickets more costly than wives in Utah
text:
Utah has recategorised bigamy as an infraction, punishable by community service or a maximum fine of $750

Bigamy is no longer a serious crime in Utah and now counts as an offence on a par with a parking ticket.

A state law came into effect this week that recategorised the practice as an infraction, punishable by community service or a maximum fine of $750, after decades during which it was classed as a felony and offenders could face five years in prison and a $5,000 fine.

Sponsored

The shift in the state’s approach was opposed by groups who argued that polygamy is abusive to women and children, but it passed the state legislature in February with massive support and was signed into law by Gary Herbert, the state governor, in March.

Deidre Henderson, a Republican state senator who sponsored the bill, said she
summary:

text:
The child abuser Barry Bennell was convicted of 52 charges in 2018

A victim of the convicted child abuser Barry Bennell has expressed anger and revulsion over plans to call him to give evidence on behalf of Manchester City’s legal team.

Bennell, 67, is serving a 34-year sentence for molesting young footballers on an “industrial scale” between 1979 and 1991 while he was a coach.

He has been asked to appear as a defence witness in a case brought by eight men who allege that Bennell was employed by Manchester City when he abused them.

title: Scotland needs more safeguards to support the ‘spy cops’ Bill
text:
Westminster is considering UK legislation allowing confidential informants working for police and security services to be authorised to break the law.

As the Covert Human Intelligence Sources (Criminal Conduct) Bill stands, I cannot recommend that the Scottish parliament consent to its provisions.

Sponsored

Such informants are known as covert human intelligence sources. They can be vital to the gathering of sometimes lifesaving intelligence that cannot be gained any other way, or to disrupting serious crime and security threats to the nation.

In Scotland, such activity could include police officers working undercover in organised crime groups involved in drugs and weapons running, human trafficking, child sexual abuse rings and terrorism plots, or being a member of an extremist organisation. Their participation in criminal activity may at times
summary:

title: Gymnastics star Simone Biles ‘would not let child represent US’ after abuse
text:
Simone Biles says USA Gymnastics has still not done enough three years after Larry Nassar was jailed

The world’s greatest gymnast has said she would not allow a daughter to compete for the American team, arguing that not enough had been done to stop the sexual abuse of young athletes.

Simone Biles, 23, was one of hundreds of competitors abused by Larry Nassar, the former US gymnastics team doctor who three years ago was sentenced to more than 100 years in prison after being convicted of child sexual assault and possessing child pornography.

title: Crossing the Line by John Sutherland review — don’t blame the police for crime, blame politicians
text:
One imagines John Sutherland rolling his eyes in despair, perhaps with a murmur of “here we go again”, at the mad spectacle that has unfolded in the past few weeks — of police officers not out catching murderers, robbers, rapists or wife-beaters, but forced to patrol parks in case people were sunbathing too long, or perhaps picnicking with intent. Sutherland, you see, has written an entire book about the unremitting frustration of being a police officer in a society full of problems that the police can do absolutely nothing about. Problems, moreover, that self-serving, short-sighted politicians make much worse by daft decisions or macho posturing.

And he knows whereof he writes. Until 2018 he was a chief superintendent in the Metropolitan Police, and his career

title: Child abuse inquiry ‘scared of racist tag’
text:
Sarah Champion says victims were let down

The national inquiry into child abuse refused to investigate Britain’s most notorious sex-grooming scandals and barred key witnesses from giving evidence, it has been revealed.

Victims and experts blamed the decision not to examine mass offending in Rotherham and Rochdale on a “cowardly” reluctance to look at a pattern of group crimes in which men of Pakistani heritage have been over-represented.

Those dismayed by the public inquiry’s failure to hear their evidence include Sarah Champion, the campaigning Rotherham MP, and Nazir Afzal, a former chief crown prosecutor who brought to justice the Rochdale sex-grooming gang.

title: Labour must do more to deal with the antisemitism that drove me out
text:
A year ago, I did the unthinkable. I resigned from the Labour Party after 55 years as a member and 50 years as an elected representative, driven out by the ugly antisemitism that became normalised with the entry of the far-left following the election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader.

The change in Liverpool Riverside, then my constituency, was speedy and traumatic. Membership increased from 500 to 2,700. The atmosphere in the regular meetings became deeply unpleasant. It was made clear that I was the target and I was to be removed.

text:

title: Mastercard “allegedly linked to phantom transactions”
text:
The allegations are in a report for a bank that had links with Wirecard

A Mastercard executive allegedly was involved in a money-laundering operation at a bank accused of terrorist financing and organised crime that had links to Wirecard, the disgraced German payments group.

A report commissioned by the owners of FBME Bank in Cyprus uncovered evidence of apparent criminal activity, including an alleged operation designed to trick the international card payments system into processing high-risk and potentially illegal transactions.

Sponsored

Private investigators found the “apparent involvement of a senior Mastercard employee in criminal activities” and recommended that the bank’s shareholders tell prosecutors in the United States that a source of the problem “may be with Mastercard”.

The investigation, called Project Waxwing, was commissioned after the US Treasury’s Financial Crimes Enforcement Network froze FBME out of the American banking

title: Facebook isn’t getting the message on child abuse, says Priti Patel
text:
Priti Patel will tell the main technology companies to “take the safety of children as seriously as they do the business of selling advertising”

Priti Patel has accused Facebook of “blinding” itself to the issue of child abuse on its platforms by adopting new security measures that will make it more difficult to catch paedophiles.

The home secretary will call today for the company to rethink plans for all messaging on its platforms to be “end-to-end” encrypted. She will also tell the main technology companies to “take the safety of children as seriously as they do the business of selling advertising, phones and online games”.

Sponsored

title: Howard Weitzman obituary
text:
It is an old Hollywood adage that the two essential requirements to make it to the top and stay there are talent and a smart attorney — and the legal fixer many of the entertainment industry’s biggest stars turned to in times of trouble was Howard Weitzman.

Among his clients was Michael Jackson, whom he defended against allegations of sexual abuse. Eloquent but with a serrated legal mind, Weitzman could be aggressive and adversarial or congenial and charming in the court room, as the occasion demanded. He also knew how to cut a deal and make a case “disappear”. After a 14-year-old boy accused the singer of molesting him, Weitzman and his fellow defence lawyer Johnnie Cochran Jr settled out of court and arranged for

title: Facebook moderators speak of Covid risk in Dublin office
text:
Sheryl Sandberg gives a glossy image of Facebook, but its Covalen contractors say they are not treated as well as staff

Contract staff working as moderators for Facebook in Dublin have complained about the conditions in their Sandyford office, after two people went down with the coronavirus.

Message boards seen by The Sunday Times show that workers engaged by Covalen in the Nova Atria building are unhappy about the working conditions imposed on them. Covalen is owned by the CPL group.

Sponsored

The moderators, most of whom earn less than €30,000 a year, have complained about being required to be present in the office; about the difficulties of social distancing with so many co-workers; and about the office staying open after two people tested positive for Covid.

The staff were sent home to work at the end of March but were told to return to the office

title: Prophet cartoon was shown at Batley Grammar School ‘a week before row’
text:
When Batley Grammar School sent an email to parents apologising for any offence caused after a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad was shown in a religious studies lesson, they might have hoped that would be the end of the matter.

Instead protests took place for two days outside, government ministers intervened and the teacher suspended over the incident went into hiding with fears that he might never be able to return to the area. It emerged last week that the cartoon had been shown at the West Yorkshire school in a previous year by another member of staff.

Sponsored

Instead protests took place for two days outside, government ministers intervened and the teacher suspended over the incident went into hiding with fears that he might never be able to return to the area.

title: Prince Andrew, Epstein and the Palace by Nigel Cawthorne review — the royal pariah
text:
There’s a vignette about Prince Andrew’s childhood in this new book by the journalist Nigel Cawthorne that seems telling. The royal family were watching Coronation Street and as the barmaid Bet Lynch had an argument, Andrew cried: “Oh God, look at all those common people.” This two-tiered view of humanity was not something he shed as he aged, the book implies: there’s royalty and the plebs; his daughters and the girls abused by his paedophile friend.

In Prince Andrew, Epstein and the Palace, Cawthorne charts Andrew’s descent from the “royal who could do no wrong” to the “pariah prince”. This is not a book teeming with revelations or even fresh interviews; instead it relies heavily on newspaper reports. However, seeing the scandal laid out

title: Police failings left Rotherham predator Arshid Hussain free to abuse girls
text:
Multiple failings left a violent predator free to target, groom and sexually abuse vulnerable children in Rotherham, a report by the police watchdog has found.

South Yorkshire police knew in 2000 that Arshid Hussain had “a number of relationships with young girls in foster care”. The force took no action against him until one of his child victims, Sammy Woodhouse, told her story to The Times in 2013.

Sponsored

Her account, using the pseudonym Jessica, triggered the inquiry that exposed the town’s child exploitation scandal, finding that 1,400 girls suffered appalling abuse by groups of men who were “almost all” of Pakistani heritage.

Hussain, 45, was jailed for 35 years in 2016 for 23 offences against nine girls including Ms Woodhouse. The judge said his victims
summary:

title: Abuse trials pushed back to 2023 as backlog grows
text:
The justice secretary, Robert Buckland, told MPs in December that no cases were listed as far ahead as 2023

At least 15 crown court trials, some involving offences against children, have been delayed until 2023 as court officials fight a losing battle with a growing backlog of cases.

Specialist barristers fear that criminals are avoiding justice and victims are dropping cases as trials are delayed for more than two years in an underfunded system struggling to deal with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

Sponsored

Fears are especially acute regarding allegations of child abuse with the memories of young witnesses likely to fade the longer trials are delayed.

Ministry of Justice officials have acknowledged that 15 cases involving serious criminal charges will have to wait at least two years to come before a jury.

title: Abuse inquiry: Welfare fears about postwar child migration
text:
UK local authorities were reluctant to take part in child migration to Australia after the Second World War because of concerns over welfare, an inquiry has been told.

Mark Davies, of the UK government’s Department of Health and Social Care, told the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry he had found evidence that councils were hesitant to send children in their care and had raised concerns over the level of welfare they were receiving.

Sponsored

Mr Davies told Colin MacAulay, QC, senior counsel to the inquiry: “It is quite clear that many of the authorities did not send children to Australia after the Second World War. It looks very likely that the majority were of the opinion migration was not suitable for children.”

The inquiry was told that

title: ‘Cardinal Vincent Nichols has failed victims of abuse and must step down’
text:
In October 2016 a woman approached the Catholic Church to report the sexual abuse and rape she had suffered at the hands of a priest from the age of 15.

She knew it would take all her strength to relive what had happened. What she did not expect was to be “retraumatised” by the church.

Sponsored

Safeguarding officers for the diocese of Westminster, which handled her case, described the woman, now in her fifties, as “needy” and “manipulative” in internal emails.

She pleaded with Cardinal Vincent Nichols, the head of the diocese and the leader of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, to help her with her case. She was ignored. Requests for meetings fell on deaf ears for months. After submitting a formal request
summary:

She knew it would take all her strength to relive what had happened.

title: Times letters: Everard’s death and male attitudes to women
text:
Sir, I found Matthew Parris’s article quite disheartening (“Men share the pain over Everard’s death”, Comment, Mar 20). Women know that not all men harass, abuse and attack us but a number of men do, I suspect rather more than he would like to admit. I am 17 and for some years now have been regularly catcalled by men of all ages — from builders to men my father’s age in suits to boys my own age. This is an experience that is commonplace among girls and women. Each time a man harasses us in the street, we don’t know where it will end. No matter how we react, it has the risk of escalating. title: The podcast that lifts lid on ‘forgotten’ George Gibney abuse scandal
text:
In the opening minutes of the first episode of the podcast Where is George Gibney? the host Mark Horgan answers that titular question. Waiting in the dark in a parked car outside a house in Florida at six o’clock in the morning, he sees a figure get into a car and begins to follow him.

That long sought-after conclusion, however, is the starting point for this podcast, a ten-part investigative series that tracks down one of the most notorious figures in Irish sport, alleged child abuser George Gibney. title: Child rapist jailed for drugging and attacking boys
text:
Mr Justice Paul McDermott at the central criminal court in Dublin said the man sought out children for his own gratification

A child rapist who used his membership of a voluntary paramedic organisation to target two boys who he then drugged and sexually assaulted has been jailed for nine and a half years.

The 29-year-old Co Kildare man used an oxygen mask to force one 15-year-old victim to inhale a pain relief drug before sexually assaulting him. In a second attack the accused raped the unconscious child while another man recorded it on his mobile phone.

Sponsored

The man, who cannot be named to protect the identity of the victims, pleaded guilty at the central criminal court in Dublin to oral rape of one boy at a place in Co Laois on May 7, 2018. He also admitted meeting the child for the purpose of sexual exploitation

title: Dario Gradi ‘didn’t think hands down trousers was assault’
text:
The Football Association has confirmed for the first time that Dario Gradi has been suspended indefinitely from football since 2016, with Wembley officials explaining that such bans are imposed when a “particular individual could potentially pose a risk of harm to children”.

Detailed in the report by Clive Sheldon QC is the fact that Barry Bennell, the football coach at the centre of football’s sexual abuse scandal, claimed in a civil court case in 2003 that Gradi and other senior figures at Crewe Alexandra knew he was a paedophile. Sheldon’s report finds that Gradi did not act improperly and he did not know about Bennell’s abuse.

title: Scottish teacher-parent partnerships offer lessons in teamwork
text:
It has been a hard year for families: this time last year, many of us were thinking about next year’s holiday; instead, we spent most of 2020 within our own four walls, much of it with children who were frustrated at being unable to attend school or see their friends. But, a study I carried out with my team at Glasgow University, shows that greater co-operation between parents and teachers could offer children more tailored educational support in 2021 and beyond.

I am a psychiatrist for children and adolescents, so when lockdown happened in March my team was worried about how families were coping. Would the sudden proximity increase family stress or even child abuse? We launched a study to find out, conducting telephone interviews

title: The child labourers risking their lives in Ghana’s illegal gold mines
text:
Sophie stands on a mound of mud, looking over the poisoned water to the jungle beyond. The afternoon heat scorches through the clouds, the air so humid it feels almost solid in the mouth. All across the clearing, teams of two or three men are at work, their skin splattered with a light beige slurry. Some hold hoses to blow apart the lumps of clay, others operate a yellow digger. They are looking for tiny particles of gold buried in the mud.

This is an illegal mine, one of a myriad in Ghana where thousands of children work. Sophie has no team and no digger, so she piles mud into a sieve and carries it to one of the pools where she can sluice it
summary:
Sophie stands on a mound of mud, looking over the poisoned water to the jungle beyond.
All across the clearing, teams of two or three men are at work, their skin splattered with a light beige slurry.
Some hold hoses to blow apart the lumps of clay, others operate a yellow digger.
They are looking for tiny particles of gold buried in the mud.
This is an illegal mine, one of a myriad in Ghana where thousands of children work.

title: Teacher caught on sex site may lose licence
text:
Iain Parkinson, 56, who taught religious education at Kirkcaldy High School in Fife, sent ‘horrible’ messages on a swingers’ website

A religious education teacher has admitted that he joined a swinging website to meet a couple for a bisexual threesome.

Iain Parkinson, 56, told a General Teaching Council for Scotland (GTCS) panel that he joined the Fabswingers website for “adulterous purposes”.

Sponsored

The GTCS hearing is considering whether he should lose his teaching licence over claims that he made references to engaging in sexual activity with a 14-year-old girl. Mr Parkinson strenuously denies these claims and said that he thought he was meeting up with a couple known as “Lisa and Kev”.

Lisa and Kev were undercover police. Mr Parkinson claims he “joined in with unpleasant” talk about an underage girl because he wanted to find out if there were “really people doing these horrible things”.
summary:

title: Tina Turner at 81: ‘I am done, I am tired, I just want to live in retirement’
text:
Anna Mae Bullock, the woman the world knows as Tina Turner, leads a quiet life now. She is 81 and retired from performing more than a decade ago. Yet that does not mean she has been idle. She published a new volume of autobiography, My Love Story, in 2018. Last year two more books arrived, one a handsome pictorial autobiography entitled That’s My Life, the other, Happiness Becomes You: A Guide to Changing Your Life for Good, a genial overview of the Buddhist beliefs that have been part of her daily routine for decades. title: ‘A rugby genius’ – Christophe Dominici found dead at age of 48
text:
Christophe Dominici, the France wing who played 67 times for his country and played a starring role in one of the great World Cup games, died yesterday aged 48.

He was found in a park in the Saint-Cloud area on the outskirts of Paris. Police say they are not looking for anyone else in connection with his death.

Sponsored

Only six players scored more times for France than the 25 tries he managed in an international career that began in 1998 and included appearances in three World Cup semi-finals and the 1999 final against Australia. In the semi-final that year, he scored a memorable try in France’s remarkable comeback to beat New Zealand at Twickenham, skilfully claiming a bouncing ball and sprinting home from 30 metres,

title: Time to listen, change and say sorry to abuse victims
text:
Beth Tweddle’s bronze medal-winning performance at the London 2012 Olympic Games lives large in the memory of gymnastics fans across the UK. It was a defining moment for British gymnastics — our first women’s Olympic medal in more than 70 years. Beth’s success paved the way for an incredible seven-medal haul four years later in Rio.

Delve behind the gold and glory and you’ll find an underbelly fuelled by intimidation and abuse, where a culture of fear and humiliation has bubbled below the surface for decades, which I believe was encouraged and concealed by our governing body, British Gymnastics.

Sponsored

All four artistic gymnastics medal-winners who contributed to Britain’s greatest Olympics in Rio have spoken out publicly about the culture of fear. And it’s not just

title: Church loses mass appeal as Sunday worship in Dublin falls 30%
text:
Attendance at Sunday mass in the Catholic Church was declining before the pandemic, according to new figures released by Dublin’s archdiocese, with a 30 per cent drop between 2014 and 2019.

Approximately 153,000 people attended Sunday mass each week during 2014, but this number fell to 135,000 the following year, and was down to 112,000 by 2018. The most recent figures show that about 107,000 people attended Sunday mass each week in 2019.

Sponsored

The Dublin archdiocese said: “Each parish is asked to carry out the church attendance survey over three consecutive weekends, and these figures are then used to find the average attendance per parish.”

title: Paedophile ordered to pay for fantasy-controlling eye therapy
text:
A judge at Grimsby crown court deferred the sentence of a paedophile to assess his response to the therapy

A judge has ordered a paedophile who looked at indecent images to undergo special eye treatment to curb his fantasies.

Antony Akid, 35, who admitted possessing abusive images of children, was told that he should go through eye desensitisation therapy, a treatment that helps patients overcome psychological trauma.

Sponsored

Judge Ahmed Nadim deferred his sentence at Grimsby crown court in order to assess Akid’s response to the therapy, which he must pay for himself or obtain through the NHS.

The judge was told that it was the second time in six years that Akid had been convicted of possession of indecent images of children. In 2014 he admitted eight charges of possession and one of distribution of indecent images and was given a 12-month jail sentence
summary:
A judge at Grimsby crown court deferred the sentence of a paedophile to assess his response to the therapyA judge has ordered a paedophile who looked at indecent images to undergo special eye treatment to curb his fantasies.
Antony Akid, 35, who admitted possessing abusive images of children, was told that he should go through eye desensitisation therapy, a treatment that helps patients overcome psychological trauma.
SponsoredJudge Ahmed Nadim deferred his sentence at Grimsby crown court in order to assess Akid’s response to the therapy, which he must pay for himself or obtain through the NHS.
The judge was told that it was the second time in six years that Akid had been convicted of possession of indecent images of children.
In 2014 he admitted eight charges of possession and one of distribution of indecent images and was given a 12-month jail sentence

title: Line of Duty review — the police drama feels like a constipated echo of itself
text:
Line of Duty

BBC1

This Is My House

BBC1

Football’s Darkest Secret

BBC1

Line of Duty isn’t supposed to be the biggest police drama in the country. This is where we’ve gone wrong. It’s supposed to be a cult pleasure, at the arse end of BBC2. This is because, really, it is not a police drama at all, but a police meta-drama. It’s a commentary on all other police dramas. That’s implicit even in the way that AC-12 are police who investigate other police, which makes them police police, or police2.

title: Actor Richard Berry accused of abuse by daughter
text:
Richard Berry, a leading French actor, has been accused by his daughter of sexually abusing her as a child, opening a new episode in a series of claims against French public figures over paedophilia and incest.

Berry, 70, who has appeared in more than 100 films, was first to air the allegations by his daughter Coline, 45. He denied them in a bitter statement that accused her of lying and he urged prosecutors to expose the truth.

Sponsored

“I unambiguously and with all my strength deny these unspeakable accusations. I have never had inappropriate or incestuous relations with Coline, nor with any of my children,” the actor said on his Instagram account.

Coline Berry, also an actress, said she filed a criminal complaint with prosecutors
summary:
Richard Berry, a leading French actor, has been accused by his daughter of sexually abusing her as a child, opening a new episode in a series of claims against French public figures over paedophilia and incest.
Berry, 70, who has appeared in more than 100 films, was first to air the allegations by his daughter Coline, 45.

title: Child sexual abuse cases rise by nearly a third in five years
text:
The figures show girls were five times as likely to be victims, and there were 1,588 offences against children under 13

Sexual offences against children in Scotland have increased by almost a third over the past five years.

Police Scotland data obtained by the NSPCC show there were 5,311 recorded offences in 2019/20 — an average of 15 a day and up 30 per cent in the five years since 2014/15.

Sponsored

This include instances of rape, online grooming and sexual assault.

The figures show girls were five times as likely to be victims, and there were 1,588 offences against children under 13 — 45 per cent of the crimes where age was recorded.

Matt Forde, NSPCC Scotland’s head of service, said: “Every day, children in Scotland are being sexually abused and having to live with the devastating impacts of this abuse on their lives.

“Urgent
summary:
The figures show girls were five times as likely to be victims, and there were 1,588 offences against children under 13Sexual offences against children in Scotland have increased by almost a third over the past five years.

SponsoredThis include instances of rape, online grooming and sexual assault.
The figures show girls were five times as likely to be victims, and there were 1,588 offences against children under 13 — 45 per cent of the crimes where age was recorded.

title: Cheer on the return of kids’ sport — just don’t be a touchline tyrant
text:
If lockdown offered a respite from Sunday mornings nursing a takeaway coffee beside a muddy pitch, well, bad luck, because organised youth sport kicks off again tomorrow. For many there is a feeling of excitement as matches and events are scribbled in the diary, but for a few children it brings fear: what if we lose? What if I am not good enough? What if I let my dad down?

Sport is supposed to be about fun, movement and improving mental health. It helps youngsters develop resilience and teamwork and other skills to take them into adult life. But researching my book on sport psychology for teenagers, one statistic stuck out: up to a third of athletes aged 10 to 17 drop out each year.
summary:
If lockdown offered a respite from Sunday mornings nursing a takeaway coffee beside a muddy pitch, well, bad luck, because organised youth sport kicks off again tomorrow.
For many there is a feeling of excitement as matches and events are scribbled in the diary, but for a few children it brings fear: what if we lose?
Sport is supposed to be about fun, movement and improving mental health.
It helps youngsters develop resilience and teamwork and other skills to take them into adult life.
But researching my book on sport psychology for teenagers, one statistic stuck out: up to a third of athletes aged 10 to 17 drop out each year.

text:

title: Seven sex attacks in women’s jails by transgender convicts
text:
Trans men and women committed seven of the 124 sex attacks recorded in prisons between 2010 and 2018

Transgender prisoners are five times more likely to carry out sex attacks on inmates at women’s jails than other prisoners are, official figures show.

Male prisoners who were transferred to women’s jails during gender reassignment and women inmates who are transitioning committed seven of the 124 sex attacks recorded between 2010 and 2018. They occurred at HMP Low Newton in Co Durham, Foston Hall in Derbyshire, Peterborough, Bronzefield in Middlesex and New Hall, West Yorkshire.

Sponsored

Karen White, a child abuser who dressed as a woman but was still legally a man, was jailed for life in 2018 for sexually assaulting two prisoners at HMP New Hall and the rape of a woman while he was outside jail.

Lord Keen of Elie, the Ministry of Justice
summary:
Trans men and women committed seven of the 124 sex attacks recorded in prisons between 2010 and 2018Transgender prisoners are five times more likely to carry out sex attacks on inmates at women’s jails than other prisoners are, official figures show.
Male prisoners who were transferred to women’s jails during gender reassignment and women inmates who are transitioning committed seven of the 124 sex attacks recorded between 2010 and 2018.

title: Lord Janner: Family of former Labour MP accused of trying to stop public inquiry into child abuse claims
text:
Daniel Janner, QC, Lord Janner’s son, “vilified and insulted the inquiry, day after day”, it was claimed

The family of a former Labour MP and peer was accused yesterday of using “friends in high places” to try to stop a public inquiry into child abuse allegations against him.

The children of the late Lord Janner of Braunstone were accused of insulting his alleged victims and vilifying the efforts of the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA) to examine the claims.

Sponsored

Lord Janner died aged 87 from Alzheimer’s disease in December 2015, while awaiting a “trial of the facts” on 22 sexual offence charges.

The allegations on the indictment came from nine men, most of whom were former residents of Leicestershire children’s homes who claimed they were sexually assaulted when Lord Janner was a Labour MP in Leicester between 1970-97.

IICSA’s investigation

text:
The public will be excluded from a public inquiry next week as it takes evidence about sex abuse allegations against the late Labour peer Lord Janner of Braunstone.

The controversial inquiry will take place almost entirely in closed session to protect the identities of complainants even though none of those who accused Janner of abusing them will be called to give evidence.

Sponsored

title: New George Gibney abuse investigation stirred up by BBC Sounds podcast
text:
George Gibney, who was Ireland’s national coach, escaped prosecution in 1994 on 27 charges of raping and sexually assaulting young swimmers

Gardai are investigating new complaints of child sexual abuse against George Gibney, after being contacted by victims who listened to a podcast series about the former Olympic swimming coach.

Two former swimmers living in different countries have made statements to gardai after hearing Where Is George Gibney?, a BBC Sounds series made by Irish media company Second Captains.

Sponsored

Gibney, who was Ireland’s national coach, escaped prosecution in 1994 on 27 charges of raping and sexually assaulting young swimmers when the Supreme Court found that he could not adequately defend himself because some of the charges related to incidents dating back as far as 1967.

He has been living in America for 25 years and volunteers at a hospice near the home he shares in Orlando,

title: Mare of Easttown review — Kate Winslet is tremendous: weary, monosyllabic, full of grit
text:
Mare of Easttown

Sky Atlantic



Call the Midwife

BBC1



Make-up: A Glamorous History

BBC2



Ackley Bridge

Channel 4

The great thing about killing people is that you can do it anywhere. On a boat, in space, in a palace, on the old American wild frontier, in a medieval abbey with a massive library, wherever. So if the aim of your story is the place and the people, and they are all rich and granular and evocative and fascinating, but you STILL can’t think of any particular reason to actually be telling anybody about them, hey presto. Kill somebody. And suddenly, there’s a point.

title: Barry Bennell victim Ian Ackley helping to rebuild lives of other sexual abuse survivors
text:
Ackley, pictured in 2016, is heading up the Survivors of Abuse service

“Bold and brave,” Ian Ackley says of the move by the FA and Professional Footballers’ Association to hire him to help rebuild the shattered lives of hundreds of survivors of sexual abuse. Bold, brave and necessary.

“We know we have another two decades of people coming forward on this scale,” Ackley says, as he talks of his work already helping dozens of former footballers cope with profound and lasting effects of childhood sexual abuse from suicidal thoughts to homelessness, depression and addiction.

title: Report into gymnastics abuse allegations reveals 3,500 complaints since 2008
text:
Amy Tinkler won bronze in Rio but has since said her medal was not worth what she went through as a gymnast

The publication of an interim report has laid bare the scale of abuse allegations against gymnastics clubs and coaches in the UK, revealing that almost 400 individuals answered a call for evidence and that 39 cases have been referred to statutory authorities.

The Whyte Review, an independent inquiry commissioned by Sport England and UK Sport after claims of emotional and physical abuse in gymnastics began to surface in the summer, published an interim report yesterday detailing the evidence it has received, which the NSPCC called “worrying”.

Sponsored

It confirms that the review has received reports of “reoccurring issues” in the sport, including “bullying, extreme weight management, regular overstretching, use of excessive physical force, training on serious injuries, gaslighting, and coercive control”.

title: Cardinal George Pell knew about child abuse, inquiry finds
text:
Cardinal George Pell knew that children were being sexually abused by Catholic priests as early as the early 1970s but failed to take action, an Australian inquiry has found.

The cardinal, 78, once appointed the Vatican’s third in charge by Pope Francis, had been “conscious” of child sexual abuse when he was a young priest and failed to act on complaints about abusive priests, a royal commission said. Cardinal Pell has denied the commission’s findings.

Sponsored

Cardinal Pell was released from prison last month after his conviction for child sexual abuse in 2018 was quashed. He was acquitted after a successful appeal to the High Court and has always maintained his innocence.

The publication of the report today was delayed while the criminal case was concluded.
summary:
Cardinal George Pell knew that children were being sexually abused by Catholic priests as early as the early 1970s but failed to take action, an Australian inquiry has found.
The cardinal, 78, once appointed the Vatican’s third in charge by Pope Francis, had been “conscious” of child sexual abuse when he was a young priest and failed to act on complaints about abusive priests, a royal commission said.
Cardinal Pell has denied the commission’s findings.
SponsoredCardinal Pell was released from prison last month after his conviction for child sexual abuse in 2018 was quashed.
He was acquitted after a successful appeal to the High Court and has always maintained his innocence.

title: Boxer Callum Hancock: my fight to overcome childhood sexual abuse
text:
Callum Hancock is a boxer from Eckington, a small town just south of Sheffield on the Derbyshire-Yorkshire border. He is 29 years old, 6ft 3in tall and has a perfect record at professional level: ten fights, ten wins, one knockout. In person he is modest and gently spoken but knows there is no point in pretending that, under the right circumstances, he is anything other than dangerous. “I’m tall. I’ve got long, powerful shots. I’ve got a good straight jab. My work rate is relentless. My speed, my timing, my reflexes… Everything’s on point,” he says calmly, without bravado. “When I fight, I feel like I’m in tune.”

Violence has dominated Hancock’s life for a very long time. When he unpacks himself it is there,

Callum Hancock is a boxer from Eckington, a small town just south of Sheffield on the Derbyshire-Yorkshire border.
He is 29 years old, 6ft 3in tall and has a perfect record at professional level: ten fights, ten wins, one knockout.
I’ve got long, powerful shots.
My speed, my timing, my reflexes… Everything’s on point,” he says calmly, without bravado.

title: Boris Johnson backtracks on prosecuting tech bosses who fail children
text:
Molly Russell, 14, killed herself in 2017 after viewing self-harm images on social media. Her father, Ian Russell, said that without the threat of criminal liability the new regulatory regime would be “half-hearted”

Boris Johnson has been accused of diluting plans for laws that would leave social media executives facing prosecution for failing to protect children.

The government is due to publish its response to a consultation on a proposal to regulate tech giants within the next fortnight.

Sponsored

Ministers will introduce a statutory duty of care, which will be enforced by Ofcom, the broadcasting regulator. Companies that breach the duty could face multimillion-pound fines or be blocked from operating in Britain.

However, a plan for “senior management liability”, under which executives could be prosecuted for failing to protect users, will apply only to illegal material such as child abuse and terrorism.

Companies that host “legal but harmful” material such as self-harm videos, or which allow cyberbullying, will not

title: Unfettered smartphone porn is fuelling abuse, say head teachers
text:
Former Haberdashers’ Girls pupils Sophie Max, left, and Philippa Lawford, say their time there was marred by sexual harassment and misogyny from boys at the next-door school

Children’s “unfettered access” to pornography on their phones and the film Fifty Shades of Grey are partly to blame for the crisis of sexual abuse at private schools, head teachers warn today.

Rose Hardy, headmistress of Haberdashers’ Aske’s School for Girls in Hertfordshire, and Gus Lock, headmaster of the neighbouring Haberdashers’ Aske’s Boys’ School, said children were able to watch porn “often depicting aggressive, violent and degrading acts against women [which] have played their part in the burgeoning crisis”.

title: Predator who killed two women in east London and hid bodies in freezer is jailed for life
text:
The bodies of Mihrican Mustafa, 38, left, and Henriett Szucs, 34, were found in a freezer in east London last year

A sexual predator who murdered two vulnerable women and hid their bodies in a freezer has been sentenced to life in prison.

Zahid Younis, 36, had a history of violence and coercion towards women when he lured his victims to his flat in Newham, east London. He beat Henriett Szucs, 34, to death in 2016 and strangled Mihrican “Jan” Mustafa, 38, a mother of three, two years later.

Sponsored

Zahid Younis was an “arch-deceiver”, the judge said PA

Police found their bodies in a small, padlocked chest freezer in a cupboard under the stairs in April last year during a search for Younis, who had been reported missing.

Yesterday the killer was jailed for life to serve a minimum of 38 years. He had sacked his legal team twice and refused to appear for sentencing
summary:
The bodies of Mihrican Mustafa, 38, left, and Henriett Szucs, 34, were found in a freezer in east London last yearA sexual predator who murdered two vulnerable women and hid their bodies in a freezer has been sentenced to life in prison.
Zahid Younis, 36, had a history of violence and coercion towards women when he lured his victims to his flat in Newham, east London.
He beat Henriett Szucs, 34, to death in 2016 and strangled Mihrican “Jan” Mustafa, 38, a mother of three, two years later.
Yesterday the killer was jailed for life to serve a minimum of 38 years.
He had sacked his legal team twice and refused to appear for sentencing

title: Extradited QC John Watt due in court on child sex abuse charges
text:
On his flight to Glasgow John Watt was escorted by three Police Scotland officers

A senior Scottish lawyer has been extradited from the United States to face charges of historical child sex abuse.

John Watt, QC, a former prosecutor, is accused of attacking four children in the 1970s and 1980s. Among his accusers is Susan Henderson, whose claims of a paedophile ring in the Scottish legal world led to a high-profile police inquiry.

Sponsored

Mr Watt, 71, was flown from the US to his native Scotland on Friday. He spent the weekend in police cells before a scheduled appearance at Edinburgh sheriff court this morning.

On his flight to Glasgow Mr Watt was escorted by three Police Scotland officers who had travelled to New York last week. He had been transferred there from Oklahoma, where he lived and was arrested
summary:

John Watt, QC, a former prosecutor, is accused of attacking four children in the 1970s and 1980s.
Among his accusers is Susan Henderson, whose claims of a paedophile ring in the Scottish legal world led to a high-profile police inquiry.
He spent the weekend in police cells before a scheduled appearance at Edinburgh sheriff court this morning.
On his flight to Glasgow Mr Watt was escorted by three Police Scotland officers who had travelled to New York last week.

text:
Lord Steel will say that independence should be put aside in favour of federalism

The House of Lords must be replaced to enable federalism across the UK as an alternative to Scottish independence, the former Liberal leader David Steel will say.

In a lecture next Tuesday to the Scottish Liberal Club, which Lord Steel “assumes” will be his last political speech, he will call for the House of Lords to be replaced with a senate elected by proportional representation (PR).

title: Ian Mitchell obituary
text:
When the 17-year-old Ian Mitchell was recruited to join the Bay City Rollers, it seemed that all his teenage dreams of pop stardom had come true.

By the time he joined the tartan-clad Scottish boy band they had already achieved nine UK Top-Ten singles, including Bye Bye Baby and Give A Little Love, as Rollermania swept Britain, with screaming pre-pubescent girls creating scenes of hysteria reminiscent of the heyday of the Beatles.

title: Covid kids: the hidden casualties of lockdown
text:
“It’s not all doom and gloom: ‘some have enjoyed the academic pressure being off and a sense of freedom’”

It is nearly a month since schools reopened after the latest coronavirus lockdown and at Surrey Square primary in Southwark, children are running around the playground, delighted finally to be back with their friends. Teachers take their temperatures, enforce strict hand-washing regimes and monitor the one-way systems. A banner outside the school has a picture of a rainbow with a promise to “spread positivity and hope” and all pupils have been given a “perseverance certificate”.

But a few students in this deprived south London borough are having real difficulty adjusting to being back in the classroom. “They are very withdrawn, daydreaming, finding it difficult to focus and engage,” says the head teacher, Nicola Noble. “It’s too painful for them to be ‘in the moment’. We
summary:
“It’s not all doom and gloom: ‘some have enjoyed the academic pressure being off and a sense of freedom’”It is nearly a month since schools reopened after the latest coronavirus lockdown and at Surrey Square primary in Southwark, children are running around the playground, delighted finally to be back with their friends.
Teachers take their temperatures, enforce strict hand-washing regimes and monitor the one-way systems.
A banner outside the school has a picture of a rainbow with a promise to “spread positivity and hope” and all pupils have been given a “perseverance certificate”.
But a few students in this deprived south London borough are having real difficulty adjusting to being back in the classroom.
“They are very withdrawn, daydreaming, finding it difficult to focus and engage,” says the head teacher, Nicola Noble.

title: Redress plan gives survivors an ultimatum, lawyers claim
text:
A new bill would provide survivors of childhood abuse in residential care before 2004 a fixed-rate payment of up to £80,000

A scheme that will provide redress payments to survivors of childhood sexual abuse could mean that they forfeit their right to further legal action, giving them an “abhorrent ultimatum”, a law firm has said.

The Redress for Survivors (Historical Child Abuse in Care) (Scotland) Bill is in its final day of consultation on Friday. It aims to provide survivors of childhood abuse in residential care before 2004 a fixed-rate payment of £10,000, going up to £80,000 based on more detailed examinations of their experience. The scheme would be administered through a new body called Redress Scotland.

Sponsored

Digby Brown Solicitors says that those who accept these payments will have to waive their right to take further legal action that could result in larger awards. Kim Leslie,
summary:

The Redress for Survivors (Historical Child Abuse in Care) (Scotland) Bill is in its final day of consultation on Friday.
It aims to provide survivors of childhood abuse in residential care before 2004 a fixed-rate payment of £10,000, going up to £80,000 based on more detailed examinations of their experience.
The scheme would be administered through a new body called Redress Scotland.

title: The ripple effect of Where Is George Gibney?
text:
The success of the podcast has led to abuse complaints being made to gardai by two former Olympic swimmers

More than 25 years after he eluded charges of raping and sexually abusing children and fled to America, the story of one of Ireland’s most notorious fugitives from justice has gone global.

The 10-part BBC Sounds podcast Where Is George Gibney?, about Ireland’s former national and Olympic swimming coach, has been downloaded more than a million times. It has been this country’s most listened-to podcast since August, while drawing audiences in 160 other nations, including the UK, America, Australia, Canada, Singapore and across Europe. Such is its success, the BBC is simultaneously broadcasting the series on Radio5 Live on Saturday nights.

Sponsored

It’s possible that Gibney, seated, will be extradited to face new charges

title: The Case of the Married Woman Caroline Norton by Antonia Fraser, review — the wives’ champion
text:
When Queen Victoria married Prince Albert in 1840 she insisted on keeping the traditional form of the service where the wife promises to love, honour and obey her husband, even though the Archbishop of Canterbury wondered if such a pledge was really appropriate in her case. Victoria, however, insisted; it was her way of demonstrating that she was getting married not as a queen but as an ordinary woman.

Of course, there was no comparison between Victoria’s situation and that of “ordinary” wives of the period, who at the time of marrying lost all rights, becoming in law their husband’s property. Full divorce was available only through an act of parliament, and a wife who left her husband had no rights over their children, as
summary:

Christian Brückner is suspected of kidnapping Madeleine in May 2007

Video footage of the man suspected of abducting Madeleine McCann raping and sexually assaulting women was found at his rented farmhouse shortly before the youngster went missing.

title: Crewe Alexandra board members urged to resign by MP over handling of sexual abuse scandal
text:
The Sheldon report found the Crewe hierarchy should have done more when rumours first circulated about Bennell

Board members of Crewe Alexandra have been urged to stand down by their local MP over their much-criticised handling of the child sexual abuse scandal at the club.

Last week the independent report published by Clive Sheldon, QC, said that the Crewe hierarchy should have done more when rumours first circulated about Barry Bennell. A youth team coach at Crewe in the 1980s and 1990s, Bennell is serving 34 years in prison for raping and sexually abusing young boys.

Sponsored

Now Dr Kieran Mullan, the member of parliament for Crewe and Nantwich, says that John Bowler, the Crewe chairman, and other members of the board who were there in the Nineties “should consider their positions”.

Bowler and his colleagues have come in for heavy criticism since

title: Exorcism at home is the devil of a job, says church
text:
The Russian Orthodox Church has warned against do-it-yourself exorcisms after a video emerged of a couple attempting to expel a “demon” from their distressed ten-year-old son with the help of garlic and holy water.

The video, filmed in a flat in the Volgograd region, shows the boy’s parents taking turns to restrain the screaming child by gripping his hands behind his back and pushing his face into a sofa. Exorcisms have resulted in at least two deaths in Russia since 2011.
