title: The Times view on the race review: Minority Report
text:
George Floyd’s death sparked a period of protest and self-examination SCOTT OLSON/GETTY IMAGES

It has long been difficult to have a frank and fair conversation about the realities of racial discrimination in modern Britain. The backlash to the release of the landmark review by Boris Johnson’s Commission on Race and Ethnic Disparities yesterday proves that the period of protest and self-examination that followed the killing of George Floyd last summer has made it no easier.

Sponsored

Even before publication, it was dismissed in some quarters as an attempt to deny or belittle the existence of racism in this country. While not without fault, it does nothing of the sort. It is a serious attempt to move the national conversation beyond polarisation and towards practical solutions.

title: Emily Mortimer on giving period drama a modern twist in The Pursuit of Love
text:
Spoiler alert: if you google the BBC adaptation of Nancy Mitford’s The Pursuit of Love, you will find phrases from previews such as “a romantic comedy-drama about love and friendship”, “a tale of love and loss and family unity set between the wars” and even “if you miss Downton Abbey, then The Pursuit of Love has your name all over it”. Are these descriptions accurate? Yes, but in an important sense no.

title: Tackling racism in the Church of England is my personal priority
text:
Archbishop Cottrell before acquiring his recent stubble. His new book asks people to suspend their disbelief in God

The Most Rev and Right Hon Stephen Cottrell sports trendy-vicar stubble. Judging by recent photos, it’s a new look for the man installed last year as Archbishop of York. The fleece that fits tightly over his priestly shirt and dog collar makes him look more like a cyclist seeking lockdown exercise than one of the favourites to be the next Archbishop of Canterbury.

Yet Cottrell’s move to the See of York, effectively No 2 to Justin Welby, feels like a breakthrough in terms of exploding Trollopian vestiges of the C of E’s stuffy image. After all, how many bishops have spoken on Russell Brand’s popular, if cod philosophic, podcast on spirituality?

title: Sir Ron Brierley pleads guilty to child abuse charges
text:
Sir Ron Brierley leaves court in Sydney yesterday. He will be sentenced on April 30 and faces a jail term of up to ten years

The New Zealand-born businessman Sir Ron Brierley has pleaded guilty to child sex abuse charges in connection with images and vidoes found on his computers.

Jacinda Ardern, prime minister of New Zealand, has moved to remove the knighthood from Brierley, which was bestowed on him in 1988.

Sponsored

Brierley, 83, gained a reputation as corporate raider in the 1980s, waging battles for control over companies such as Air New Zealand, Woolworths, the retail chain, and AGL Energy, the utilities company. In 2001 he opposed the failed £21 billion merger of the London Stock Exchange with Deutsche Börse.

The tycoon, who has never married, pleaded guilty in a brief appearance in a court in Sydney yesterday to three counts of possessing child abuse material. An additional 14

title: Silencing pupils over abuse was ‘a disgrace’, says headmaster
text:
The headmaster of Queen Victoria School offered an apology to any pupils affected by abuse

The headmaster of a military boarding school said that discouraging pupils from reporting abuse was a disgrace, as he offered an apology to those affected.

Donald Shaw, of Queen Victoria School (QVS) in Dunblane, told the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry yesterday that he had mistakenly presumed the investigation would be about adult sexual assaults on children.

Sponsored

title: Social media sites face £18m fine over child users
text:
Molly Russell‘s father has campaigned for social media reform since his daughter’s death in 2017

Social media companies face huge fines if they fail to stop children using their services under new proposals.

The government has told tech firms they will need to find much more effective ways to stop children accessing their platforms, other than just asking for a date of birth.

Most social media sites say their services are for people aged at least 13. UK and US law prohibits websites and apps from collecting personal data of anyone under 13 without parental consent.

A survey showed that about 60 per cent of eight-year-olds and 90 per cent of 12-year-olds in England say they use private messaging services that have a minimum age limit of 13.

title: Pope claims gossip is worse than coronavirus
text:
The Pope repeated his frequent complaint about the “plague” of gossip in his weekly blessing

The Pope has said that gossip is a “plague worse than Covid” that he believes is seeking to divide the Roman Catholic church.

He strayed from his prepared text in his weekly blessing yesterday to reiterate his frequent complaint about slander within church communities and the Vatican bureaucracy.

Sponsored

Without citing examples, he continued at some length to say that the devil was the “biggest gossiper” and was seeking to split the church with lies.

Francis, 83, said: “Please brothers and sisters, let’s try to not gossip. Gossip is a plague worse than Covid. Worse. Let’s make a big effort: no gossiping!”

The Pope was elaborating on a gospel passage about the need to correct others privately when they do something wrong.

text:
The changes will affect Facebook Messenger and Instagram

Facebook is “blinding itself to serious crime” with plans for stronger encryption that will help child abusers, a former counterterrorism chief said.

Sir Mark Rowley, who was assistant commissioner at the Metropolitan Police, said that the social media company’s decision to use end-to-end encryption “will make it easier for criminals to flourish on their platform”.

Sir Mark gave the warning before today’s annual meeting at which shareholders are expected to endorse Mark Zuckerberg’s plans to use end-to-end encryption by default, increasing privacy and protecting users from hackers.

It means that messages can be viewed by only the sender and receiver, which has alarmed officials who rely on Facebook to flag up criminal content.

title: Tusla fined by Data Protection Commision over three GDPR breaches
text:
Tusla, the child and family agency, has become the first body to be fined in Ireland for a data protection breach using new powers given to the regulator following the introduction of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

On Friday, the Data Protection Commission (DPC), which is led by Helen Dixon, filed a Circuit Court action against Tusla to confirm a fine of €75,000 against the state agency over three data breaches. Tusla has accepted the punishment.

summary:

title: My daughter can’t bear the sounds my husband makes
text:
Q My teenage daughter has very sensitive hearing. Some sounds are extremely irritating to her, to the point of panic, anger and ultimately tears.

Specifically she finds the noises made by her father, a generous and loving (if complex) man, utterly repulsive. His breathing, eating, speaking on the phone, cutlery on the plate reduce her to tears. She can barely be in the same room as him.

Sponsored

This is so hard to navigate. I have the same sensitive hearing. In younger years I ended relationships because of this problem. I fear she has inherited sensitive hearing from me and picked up this revulsion for her father from me. I have developed ploys to manage this sensitivity — I wear earplugs, listen to the radio at
summary:
Q My teenage daughter has very sensitive hearing.
Some sounds are extremely irritating to her, to the point of panic, anger and ultimately tears.
Specifically she finds the noises made by her father, a generous and loving (if complex) man, utterly repulsive.
I have the same sensitive hearing.
I fear she has inherited sensitive hearing from me and picked up this revulsion for her father from me.

title: Head issues plea to save Ampleforth College
text:
Robin Dyer is the fifth head of Ampleforth in five years

A head teacher brought in to overhaul Britain’s leading Catholic college after an abuse scandal says it could close if a ban on taking new pupils is not lifted, because fees are its only income.

Robin Dyer said that it would be a tragedy if Ampleforth, which was founded in 1802, were forced to shut after so much work had gone into reforming the day and boarding school. Dyer, the fifth head in five years when appointed in 2019, said that he was leading “root and branch” change.

The ordeal began last October after their eight-month-old rolled off a double bed in their home near Wrexham, north Wales, and broke his leg.

title: Beautiful Things by Hunter Biden review — rich, privileged and utterly wretched: the tragic story of the president’s son
text:
They love each other. Boy, they do. Sweaty Irish-American love; between strutting powerful busy men. Love squeezed in between Navy Reserve duty and law school. Between running the nation and putting in a bathroom or stripping down a car. Brothers, fathers, sons. Big hugs. Women loved too, and kids — dozens of them. The kids scooped up and endlessly scooted from pillar to post to be loved some more: driven from house to compound and back across the vastness of the US where they run free and love each other. The guys grab each other. The women have to fend them off, or encourage them, or swap their affections from one guy to the next.

Hey, I’m an only child. I found Hunter Biden’s memoir
summary:
Sweaty Irish-American love; between strutting powerful busy men.
Love squeezed in between Navy Reserve duty and law school.
Between running the nation and putting in a bathroom or stripping down a car.
Women loved too, and kids — dozens of them.
The women have to fend them off, or encourage them, or swap their affections from one guy to the next.

text:

Liberals, and Muslims such as Baroness Warsi, do society a disservice when they place a fear of offence before tolerance for diversity of thought. It is an unhealthy and dangerous exchange.

Soraya Gray, London W6

title: What’s going on in your teenager’s brain — this young man knows
text:
Ben Brooks is pretty knowledgeable about teenage boys, and not just because he has been one more recently than many experts. His path through those years was more turbulent than most, involving drug and alcohol abuse and depression as he grew up in Gloucestershire.



Now 28 and an award-winning children’s novelist, who has already bagged the Somerset Maugham award and a Jerwood Fiction Uncovered prize, he wants us all to know what might have helped him — and his parents — to avoid the bear traps. It’s why his 12th book (for which he interviewed hundreds of teenagers) is a parenting manual called Every Parent Should Read this Book, published next month.

Organised criminals are extending their reach and forcing victims of sex trafficking into county lines drug dealing and other crimes, senior police said.

They no longer focus on one enterprise but are spreading their operations across drug trafficking, child sexual exploitation and modern-day slavery.

Naya Rivera’s four-year-old son said that they had been swimming together but that she did not return to the boat

An actress who played one of the main roles in the hit TV musical Glee is feared to have drowned after a boat she rented yesterday was found on a lake in California.

Naya Rivera, 33, who played Santana Lopez, rented a boat at Lake Piru, near Los Angeles, and took it out on the water with her four-year-old son. The boy was found alone in the boat about three hours later. He told investigators that he and his mother were swimming but that his mother never got back into the boat.

title: A smart doorbell? No need. The neighbours practise surveillance
text:
‘Porch pirates” who pinch parcels from doorsteps have become the great pandemic pariahs. To combat these miscreants, Amazon is developing smart doorbells to shriek at thieves. Isn’t this the system deployed by the giant in Jack and the Beanstalk? But also: no, just no. Surely this year of living in each others’ pockets has yielded enough mutual scrutiny. I’m prepared to sacrifice the odd pink Himalayan salt purchase for the right not to be assailed by a screaming doorstep.

Covid has meant that all of us now occupy villages. With everyone confined to barracks, noses pressed against windows, ambient rage the product of our competing mental health issues, I’d like to see someone try to pinch a parcel in my neck of the woods.
summary:
‘Porch pirates” who pinch parcels from doorsteps have become the great pandemic pariahs.
To combat these miscreants, Amazon is developing smart doorbells to shriek at thieves.
Isn’t this the system deployed by the giant in Jack and the Beanstalk?
Surely this year of living in each others’ pockets has yielded enough mutual scrutiny.
I’m prepared to sacrifice the odd pink Himalayan salt purchase for the right not to be assailed by a screaming doorstep.

title: Survivors needed more from a report that missed targets
text:
To Boris Johnson, it may be money and resources “spaffed up the wall”. To the survivors of horrific sex abuse, the Sheldon report is a necessary but (even at 710 pages) very incomplete insight into a time and a culture that devastated the lives of hundreds of young boys and their families.

It was hard to know what to expect after more than four years waiting for Clive Sheldon, QC, to deliver his “Independent Review into Child Sexual Abuse in Football 1970-2005” but, if many of the reactions were of immense frustration at what was not concluded, perhaps one report never could hope to address the vast scale of damage, pain and injustice. Or even come close.

title: End the closed-door culture within clubs, pleads abuse victim
text:
Michelle Kinneavy clearly remembers the culture at the gymnastics club she attended as a child. “Parents should be outside,” she says. “My dad would drop me off at the door and the door would be closed, firmly, if not locked. You almost give up ownership of your child once they’re in this space.”

Kinneavy was nine years old when she was sexually assaulted by her gymnastics coach in the 1980s. She reached a substantial settlement with British Gymnastics (BG) last year and waived her right to anonymity in the hope of creating change for the next generation of gymnasts. She says a culture of “closed doors” helped to enable her abuser and has added her voice to those of former gymnasts and parents in calling

title: Domestic abuse rises in isolation
text:
Concerns about children trapped with adults who might harm them have fuelled a rise in reports

Concerns about children being locked indoors with an adult who may cause them harm have contributed to a rise in police calls to investigate domestic abuse during the coronavirus crisis.

There were 17,244 reported incidents of domestic abuse between April and June, a 15 per cent increase above the five year average, according to Police Scotland’s latest quarterly update.

However, the number of crimes detected remained broadly in line with the five year trend at 10,001.

The update stated: “Police Scotland were aware that lockdown would potentially increase the risk of domestic abuse as people observed isolation and physical distancing guidance.

title: Times letters: Henry Marsh and the case for assisted dying
text:
Sir, One sympathises with Dr Henry Marsh after his terminal diagnosis and wishes him the best of care (“The law insists that I suffer until the end”, Apr 2). However, this campaigner’s wayward arguments for assisted dying should not pass unchallenged.

He accuses politicians of a “striking lack of compassion by being unwilling to consider a public inquiry”, but the issue has been considered by parliament for almost 30 years, including by two select committees of the House of Lords. Campaigners have repeatedly petitioned the courts. Their arguments have, in short, received repeated, close and careful consideration, and have failed.

title: The Times view on Facebook’s lack of action on child abuse: Online Harm
text:
Children could be at greater risk of online harm under plans to encrypt social media messages GETTY IMAGES

Criminals congregate where they can be confident of not being detected. An increasingly safe domain for them is cyberspace. Priti Patel, the home secretary, will today, at an event hosted by the NSPCC, warn the tech giants that they must take seriously their responsibility to child welfare. Ms Patel and children’s charities are worried by the plans of Facebook and other tech companies to make all messages from their platforms end-to-end encrypted, and thus enhance their security. As Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, has candidly acknowledged, end-to-end encryption on messaging services would “prevent anyone, including us, from seeing what people share”.

title: British UN official accused of raping girl escapes prosecution
text:
A woman and child wait to receive the ebola vaccination in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where peacekeepers and other officials face claims of sexual abuse

A British United Nations official escaped prosecution for alleged sexual exploitation of a teenage girl in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) despite an investigation finding credible evidence against him.

The man was working for the UN’s peacekeeping mission in the DRC in 2017 when he is alleged to have given a 16-year-old girl money and goods in exchange for sex.

Sponsored

The allegation was reported to the Congolese authorities and investigated by the UN’s internal affairs unit, which concluded that the allegations were substantiated. UN records showed the man paid $5,000 to the girl’s family.

The employee was dismissed and Britain’s delegation to the UN in New York was alerted to the case. His identity, whereabouts and present employment status are not known.

Dame Barbara
summary:
A woman and child wait to receive the ebola vaccination in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where peacekeepers and other officials face claims of sexual abuseA British United Nations official escaped prosecution for alleged sexual exploitation of a teenage girl in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) despite an investigation finding credible evidence against him.

Hundreds of families whose children suffer from the debilitating condition ME have faced child protection investigations in the past decade, The Times has learnt.

Campaigners say that ignorance of, or disbelief in, myalgic encephalomyelitis, also known as chronic fatigue syndrome, leads to families being referred by schools or doctors to social services on suspicion of child abuse and neglect.

title: ‘Crystal-ball social work’ doubles number of babies taken into care
text:
Taking your first baby home from the maternity ward in a car seat is a rite of passage for thousands of new parents every year. For one mother, the walk to the hospital car park in July last year felt the longest of her life. She was about to strap her 10-day-old daughter into a social worker’s car and say goodbye.

The 40-year-old mother from the northwest of England, who must not be named for legal reasons, is one of a growing number of parents forced by court order to give up their babies in the first weeks of their lives because of concern from social services. The pandemic has made the brutal experience even more painful, with parents unable to see their children —

title: Face to face with the cycle of abuse: one foster carer’s chance encounter
text:
Whenever I hear the term “toxic masculinity”, I think of a little boy called Charlie, a frequent visitor to our house when I was a young teenager. Charlie was the son of Jill, a neighbour my mother had befriended who was a victim of domestic abuse. It wasn’t unusual for Jill to seek sanctuary with our family after closing time, her pale face creased with pain as she ushered her bleary-eyed son into our house.

I’ll never forget the evening I responded to a frantic knocking at the door and found her in a pitiful state, a distraught Charlie clasped to her hip. Heavily pregnant, she had managed to rescue the child from the crossfire of a particularly vicious attack and had escaped before her

It wasn’t unusual for Jill to seek sanctuary with our family after closing time, her pale face creased with pain as she ushered her bleary-eyed son into our house.
I’ll never forget the evening I responded to a frantic knocking at the door and found her in a pitiful state, a distraught Charlie clasped to her hip.
Heavily pregnant, she had managed to rescue the child from the crossfire of a particularly vicious attack and had escaped before her

title: Bill to seal Ryan commission abuse testimonies put on ice after survivors’ campaign
text:
The government has decided to delay planned legislation putting evidence given to the Ryan Commission investigating residential child abuse under state seal, following a campaign by survivors who want their stories made public.

Micheál Martin, Leo Varadkar and Eamon Ryan, the coalition leaders, agreed at a meeting on Monday to “delay and re-examine” the Retention of Records Bill 2019, according to a government spokeswoman.

Sponsored

Some of the testimonies were given to a confidential committee of the Ryan Commission, and to a separate redress board. The plan to lock away the testimonies under seal in the National Archives for 75 years was proposed in draft legislation published in 2015.

A full bill was introduced in February 2019 by Joe McHugh, while minister for education.

Survivors argued
summary:
The government has decided to delay planned legislation putting evidence given to the Ryan Commission investigating residential child abuse under state seal, following a campaign by survivors who want their stories made public.
Micheál Martin, Leo Varadkar and Eamon Ryan, the coalition leaders, agreed at a meeting on Monday to “delay and re-examine” the Retention of Records Bill 2019, according to a government spokeswoman.
SponsoredSome of the testimonies were given to a confidential committee of the Ryan Commission, and to a separate redress board.
The plan to lock away the testimonies under seal in the National Archives for 75 years was proposed in draft legislation published in 2015.
A full bill was introduced in February 2019 by Joe McHugh, while minister for education.

title: Magnum photo agency in row over ‘child sex abuse images’ in archive
text:
Olivia Arthur, president of Magnum Photos, said that standards had “evolved”

One of the world’s leading photographic agencies is facing a reckoning over what it admits may be problematic material in its archive.

Magnum Photos has launched an internal review of its archive after attention was drawn to its promotion of what are alleged to be images of child sex workers.

Olivia Arthur, president of the 75-year-old agency, said that photography was “entering an unprecedented period of self-reflection” and that standards for what was acceptable “have evolved”.

It began the review after the photography website Fstoppers accused it of promoting sexually explicit images of children as well as featuring records of child sexual abuse.

A series of photographs documenting sex workers in Thailand in the 1980s had caused particular concern.

title: Magdalene laundries survivors will be able to request access to personal records
text:
An event to commemorate the women who lived and died in Magdalene laundries was held at Glasnevin cemetery in Dublin last year

All institutional survivors, not just those who were in mother and baby homes, will be able to use European data privacy law to request their personal information.

This could allow survivors from institutions such as Magdalene laundries to access records that were to be sealed for decades.

Sponsored

Micheál Martin, the taoiseach, said yesterday that GDPR, the EU data privacy legislation, will apply to personal records that were held by commissions. The Data Protection Commissioner, the state privacy regulator, told The Times yesterday that the legislation applies to “any organisation that processes personal data”.

Under GDPR, people may make requests to organisations for access to any record that may contain their personal information.

The government had previously insisted that GDPR would not apply to records held
summary:

title: Scandal of widespread sexual abuse in schools reveals urgent need for guidance
text:
The widespread abuse described on the website Everyone’s Invited undoubtedly signifies a failure or inability of schools and government to educate pupils and students in the definition and potential effects of such incidents.

The collective experiences posted on the website include the commission of criminal offences — many of them of a sexual nature.

Sponsored

Given that by the age of ten children are deemed capable of committing criminal offences, the curriculum needs to include guidance about what constitutes an offence, especially a sexual one, and what sort of sentences and orders the courts can impose.

Teachers and parents also need to be educated in this area. Children of primary school age need to be taught about what makes relationships healthy, respectful and safe. Children
summary:
The widespread abuse described on the website Everyone’s Invited undoubtedly signifies a failure or inability of schools and government to educate pupils and students in the definition and potential effects of such incidents.
The collective experiences posted on the website include the commission of criminal offences — many of them of a sexual nature.
SponsoredGiven that by the age of ten children are deemed capable of committing criminal offences, the curriculum needs to include guidance about what constitutes an offence, especially a sexual one, and what sort of sentences and orders the courts can impose.

title: I believe Meghan — the trope of the difficult woman is too old, and too familiar
text:
I believe Meghan Markle. Apparently, this is because I am a millennial, and a snowflake, and woke, and I drink oat milk, probably. An older generation think she’s a publicity chaser, but the younger generation are on her side because we all want to be princesses, or famous, or we’re obsessed with calling everyone racist and everything abuse and “speaking our truth”.

I don’t feel particularly strongly either way about the royals, and never thought much about them until I started out as a fashion journalist. I was working at a celebrity magazine in the months after Kate Middleton married Prince William, and saw the public demand for a story — any story, every story — about her, even one about her earrings.

text:
A review of historical records at Merchiston Castle School found it had failed to protect some children from abuse in the past

The head of a boys-only independent boarding school has told an inquiry that concerns of a “predatory culture” are an issue for all schools.

Jonathan Anderson, headmaster at Merchiston Castle School in Edinburgh, said it was “not fair” to single out boys-only schools over the issue.

title: Times letters: Racism, inequality and the Sewell report
text:
Sir, The Sewell review is the first government-commissioned study on race seriously to engage with the family, finding that educational failure and crime required an upstream response “to family breakdown as one of the main reasons for poor outcomes” (News, Mar 31 & Apr 1). It is important to challenge the metropolitan elite’s enduring reluctance to acknowledge the considerable contribution that dysfunctional relationships, fractured families and father absence make to most if not all social problems. The report highlights family hubs, which play a vital role in preventing family challenges from escalating. The government needs to be far more ambitious in fulfilling its manifesto commitment to champion them. The report concludes that “family is also the foundation stone of success for many ethnic minorities”. Getting

Sponsored
summary:
Sir, The Sewell review is the first government-commissioned study on race seriously to engage with the family, finding that educational failure and crime required an upstream response “to family breakdown as one of the main reasons for poor outcomes” (News, Mar 31 & Apr 1).
It is important to challenge the metropolitan elite’s enduring reluctance to acknowledge the considerable contribution that dysfunctional relationships, fractured families and father absence make to most if not all social problems.
The report highlights family hubs, which play a vital role in preventing family challenges from escalating.
The government needs to be far more ambitious in fulfilling its manifesto commitment to champion them.
The report concludes that “family is also the foundation stone of success for many ethnic minorities”.

title: Police ‘try to cut payouts’ for officers with PTSD
text:
Peter Merritt and Paul Settle accuse the Met of playing down mental injury

A decorated counterterrorism officer and a respected child abuse detective have accused their forces of trying to cut pension payouts for those suffering career-ending psychological injuries.

Peter Merritt, 45, who attended the Russell Square Tube carriage after the July 7 bombings and contracted severe post-traumatic stress disorder, says the Metropolitan Police showed “a complete lack of psychological support”.

Sponsored

Paul Settle, former head of the Met’s paedophile unit, contracted PTSD after being “unceremoniously sacked” in 2015 for questioning the evidence against Lord Brittan of Spennithorne. Operation Midland, the VIP paedophile inquiry, turned out to be based on lies.

Traumas including an IRA bomb came flooding back while on gardening leave, during which he attempted suicide after feeling abandoned.

The detectives and other mentally injured officers accused

title: Celtic magazine article ‘demolishes’ club’s abuse defence, claim lawyers
text:
Celtic FC funded its scandal-hit feeder team and employed one of its key figures, prompting lawyers representing victims to claim it “demolishes” the club’s defence before a legal battle.

Celtic Boys Club has been engulfed by allegations of systematic sexual misconduct over three decades, prompting claims that it represents the largest child abuse scandal in British football.

The test case is expected to be heard at the Court of Session within months.

text:

An SNP MP has told of how she feared for her life as she suffered months of harassment from a serial stalker of female politicians.

title: Cardinal Vincent Nichols ‘lacked compassion over child sex scandals’
text:
Cardinal Vincent Nichols put the reputation of the Church first, an inquiry said

The most senior Roman Catholic clergyman in England and Wales faced calls for his resignation yesterday after a report accused him of failing to show leadership or compassion in his handling of child abuse scandals.

Cardinal Vincent Nichols showed no personal commitment to reform, lacked compassion for abuse survivors and prioritised the protection of the Church’s reputation, the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse said.

Sponsored

“As a senior leader and the figurehead for the Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales, Catholics look to Cardinal Nichols to lead by example,” the inquiry’s report said. “It is difficult to exercise good leadership if you engage in bad practice.”

There was also strong criticism of the Vatican for refusing to provide a witness statement over its knowledge
summary:

title: Alex Salmond and others argued over the value of child abuse inquiry
text:
Alex Salmond was one of those against holding an inquiry into the abuse of children in care, John Swinney said

Alex Salmond and other influential figures in the Scottish government were against holding an inquiry into the abuse of children in care, John Swinney has said.

Speaking at the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry yesterday, the deputy first minister said there was clear division between ministers on the decision to hold a public investigation.

Sponsored

He said that an inquiry was authorised “after the change of first minister had taken place”.

James Peoples, QC, senior counsel to the inquiry, said that on Thursday Mike Russell, the minister for the constitution, told him “influential figures, including Alex Salmond, Kenny MacAskill and the then lord advocate Frank Mulholland were not persuaded” of the need for an inquiry. text:

In the past few days alone we have seen campaigns to increase vaccine take-up among ethnic minorities and heartwarming tributes to Captain Sir Tom Moore — but also horrendous racist abuse of black footballers and continuing disinformation from antivaxers.

How can we keep free societies like the UK as safe as possible as the internet — with all its opportunities and challenges — becomes increasingly integral to every part of our lives?

title: Film reviews: Stray; Memories of My Father; Made in Italy; Tom & Jerry: The Movie; Violation; Retaliation; The Banishing; Malmkrog
text:
Stray

Amazon, Apple TV, BFI Player, Curzon Home Cinema, Dogwoof

18, 72 mins

★★★★

Conveying a strong sense of what life as a homeless drifter might feel like, Elizabeth Lo’s documentary might impress you even if you’re no great fan of its starring species: dogs. Shot in Istanbul, it tracks a dignified mongrel, Zeytin, and a few other mutts as they wander the streets. Their encounters with humans, including three young Syrian refugees, help to broaden the film’s scope, but so do other factors. Even when dogs are the only creatures on screen, the images are resonant.

title: My father threatened to disinherit my children — and now I can’t forget the past
text:
Q I am in my sixties with a number of younger brothers. A few years ago, my father, who is 90, required assistance after an operation and we all agreed that we would take turns to stay with him. I was due to have an urgent investigation, but I chose to ignore my health and care for my father.

While looking after him he mentioned that should any of us children predecease him anything that was left to them would not pass to their next of kin, but would be redistributed to other siblings (some are not married and have no children). I was shocked and asked him outright, “So you would disinherit your grandchildren?” He replied yes and added that he was just looking

The website that exposed the scale of sexual harassment and abuse in schools is turning the spotlight on universities.

title: Pupils at Fornethy House for sick girls ‘abused and made to eat vomit’
text:
Police are investigating the claims of historical abuse at the institution in Angus

Police are investigating allegations of historical physical and sexual abuse at a Scottish residential school for ill girls.

Victims told how they were regularly attacked by staff at Fornethy House, which was run by Glasgow’s local authority in Kilry, Angus, after being told they were going to a holiday camp.

Sponsored

Sick children as young as five would be taken to the school 90 miles from the city for “convalescent” breaks after it opened in 1961. Forty former pupils, now aged between their forties and their sixties, have come forward to claim they were force-fed, made to eat vomit and ordered to walk around naked.

Marion Reid, 63, was sent to the school with her older sister and claims to have been frequently punched and slapped
summary:
Police are investigating the claims of historical abuse at the institution in AngusPolice are investigating allegations of historical physical and sexual abuse at a Scottish residential school for ill girls.

title: Harry Dunn’s mother calls on UK to stand ground against America
text:
Harry Dunn died after a collision with a car driven by the wife of a US intelligence official

The mother of the motorcyclist Harry Dunn has said that Britain will be on the “road to ruin” if it backs down in its row with the US over the extradition of the driver charged with killing him.

Charlotte Charles described the US government as bullying and said “we have to stand up to them” as it emerged that Britain has agreed to extradite two fugitives to America. The US government refuses to hand over Anne Sacoolas, the wife of a US intelligence official, who has admitted causing the crash.

Sponsored

American officials are said to be furious that British police issued an international wanted notice for Mrs Sacoolas, who was charged in December with causing death by dangerous driving. She collided with Mr Dunn,

title: Crewe’s bid to shut down sex abuse apology from manager David Artell
text:
Crewe Alexandra yesterday appeared to take steps to suppress the reporting of an apology made by their manager David Artell to the victims of child sexual abuse at their club. A Crewe official told The Times that the club had intervened yesterday because their directors were “uncomfortable with the ‘sorry’ thing”.

A report published this week said Crewe could have done more to prevent sexual abuse carried out in the 1990s by their former coach Barry Bennell, who is serving a 30-year prison sentence for his crimes. In response, the club issued a carefully worded statement that did not apologise directly to survivors, instead saying sorry “if there were in fact any warning signs that ought to have led the club to do more”.

Sponsored

The

title: Facemasks in schools: Head teachers demand clear guidance
text:
Boris Johnson, who visited Castle Rock School in Coalville, Leicestershire, on Wednesday, has drawn criticism over the facemask policy

Head teachers are urging ministers to produce consistent guidelines on facemasks after being censured for deciding that pupils must wear them.

The government says pupils and staff at secondary schools in lockdown areas should wear coverings, but has left it up to other head teachers to choose whether to introduce them or not.

Sponsored

A survey of schools by The Times has found some will insist all secondary pupils wear them in corridors and other communal areas, with one making them mandatory in the classroom.

Grant Shapps, the transport secretary, said the decision by head teachers on whether to make pupils wear face coverings would depend on factors including “the width of corridors”. “It will depend on the layout of the school and local factors,
summary:
Boris Johnson, who visited Castle Rock School in Coalville, Leicestershire, on Wednesday, has drawn criticism over the facemask policyHead teachers are urging ministers to produce consistent guidelines on facemasks after being censured for deciding that pupils must wear them.
The government says pupils and staff at secondary schools in lockdown areas should wear coverings, but has left it up to other head teachers to choose whether to introduce them or not.

title: Trials without juries will ease backlog, Sir Richard Henriques, QC, argues
text:
Lord Burnett of Maldon, the lord chief justice, said that reducing the number of jurors in individual cases from 12 to 7 was a possibility

Judges should sit without juries for criminal trials during lockdown, a top lawyer has argued.

Writing in The Times today, Sir Richard Henriques, QC, who last year published a report into the Metropolitan Police’s investigation of child sex abuse claims against senior figures, has backed a radical move that has not been seen since the height of the Troubles.

Sponsored

The justice secretary, Robert Buckland, QC, indicated yesterday that jury trials could be restarted later this month, as concern mounts over the backlog of crown court cases.

Jury trials were halted in March as part of measures to curb the spread of the virus. Sir Richard writes: “There is a simple and economical solution which would permit our crown courts to get back to work
summary:
Lord Burnett of Maldon, the lord chief justice, said that reducing the number of jurors in individual cases from 12 to 7 was a possibilityJudges should sit without juries for criminal trials during lockdown, a top lawyer has argued.
Writing in The Times today, Sir Richard Henriques, QC, who last year published a report into the Metropolitan Police’s investigation of child sex abuse claims against senior figures, has backed a radical move that has not been seen since the height of the Troubles.

title: Help us find Maddie’s body, German prosecutor urges Christian Brückner
text:
Christian Brückner became angry during a discussion about Madeleine McCann, a former colleague said

There is evidence that Madeleine McCann is dead, a German prosecutor said yesterday as he appealed for help to identify the prime suspect’s former homes so her body could be found.

Hans Christian Wolters believes that Christian Brückner carried out sex attacks on other victims, including Britons, and urged them to contact police.

Sponsored

“All indication we have got that I can’t tell you points in the direction that Madeleine is dead,” he told Sky News. “We’ve got things we cannot communicate that speak for the theory that Madeleine is dead, even if I have to admit that we don’t have the body.”

He said there was not enough “hard evidence” for Brückner to go on trial and that finding the body was crucial.

Madeleine, from

title: What I’ve learnt: Paris Hilton on building a business empire, challenging abusers — and finding love
text:
Businesswoman and socialite Paris Hilton, 40, is the great-granddaughter of the Hilton Hotels founder, Conrad Hilton. She co-starred in the 2003 reality television series The Simple Life with fellow It girl Nicole Richie. She is one of the world’s highest paid female DJs and has a multimillion-dollar beauty brand. A documentary about her life, This is Paris, was released last year on YouTube. She lives in Los Angeles with her fiancé, Carter Reum, and their eight dogs.

I’m not the dumb, ditzy blonde you saw on The Simple Life. That was just a character I played. But I understand why people would think that, because I was good at pretending. I’m proud of the empire I’ve built and I’m about to launch my

She co-starred in the 2003 reality television series The Simple Life with fellow It girl Nicole Richie.

title: Ghislaine Maxwell’s bail request rejected by appeal court
text:
A courtroom sketch of Ghislaine Maxwell from earlier this month. A torch is shone into her cell every 15 minutes, she claims

Ghislaine Maxwell’s latest request for bail has been rejected by a US appeals court, despite claims by her lawyer that she sleeps with a sock over her eyes to block out the torchlight that is shone into her jail cell every 15 minutes during the night.

The court in New York said that the 59-year-old British former socialite should appeal to District Judge Alison Nathan, who oversees her criminal case, if she was being deprived of sleep.

Sponsored

Maxwell has been held at a jail in Brooklyn since last July on charges, which she denies, that she assisted the American financier Jeffrey Epstein in his abuse of under-age girls.

title: Facebook moderators with family vulnerable to Covid-19 forced into office
text:
Two cases of Covid-19 were identified at the Dublin office of Covalen, which employs moderators for Facebook

Facebook moderators have been told to work in the office even if they live with vulnerable relatives.

The Sunday Times reported this week that two cases of Covid-19 had been identified in the Sandyford office in Dublin where Covalen, the company that employs moderators on Facebook’s behalf, is based.

Sponsored

Staff had been working from home but were told to return to the office at the end of July.

Covalen emailed staff last month to inform them that everyone must attend the office, including workers with family members deemed at risk of Covid-19. Correspondence sent by human resources on September 9 and seen by The Times said: “As previously communicated the safety of our employees is the number one priority and as a result for the

title: Cardinal Becciu ‘stole funds to bribe witnesses’ in sex abuse case against rival George Pell
text:
Cardinal Giovanni Angelo Becciu denies the claims. Meanwhile, 38 recruits were sworn in to the Pontifical Swiss Guard at St Peter’s Basilica yesterday after the ceremony had to be postponed in May

A senior Catholic cardinal has been accused of using €700,000 of Vatican funds to bribe witnesses to secure a sex abuse conviction against a rival.

Italian media have reported that Cardinal Giovanni Angelo Becciu, 72, is suspected of wiring the cash to recipients in Australia who helped to ensure hostile testimony in the abuse trial of Cardinal George Pell, who was accused of molesting choir boys in Melbourne in the 1990s.

Sponsored

The scandal cast a shadow yesterday over the publication of a key Vatican document calling for a more caring and sharing society and denouncing the evils of war.

Before he returned to Australia in 2017 where he was tried, jailed and acquitted on appeal, Cardinal Pell, 79, served as finance minister at

title: Conductor Charles Hazlewood reveals childhood sex abuse
text:
Charles Hazlewood paid tribute to his family for helping him to deal with the abuse

The conductor Charles Hazlewood reveals today that he had been a victim of sexual abuse “through most of my childhood” but found comfort listening to Mozart.

The musician, who has headlined at Glastonbury and presented the Proms for the BBC, has never spoken in public about the abuse but decided to use Radio 4’s Desert Island Discs to talk about it.

Sponsored

Hazlewood, 53, says he could not discuss the abuse with anyone else at the time: “Abuse is something which thrives on secrecy. That’s the toxic energy which it derives its power from.”

His behaviour, aged 10, was so “unmanageable” as a result of the abuse that his parents sent him to boarding school in West Sussex.

“For the first few years I was there,
summary:

title: Philip Roth: The Biography by Blake Bailey review — the William Wordsworth of self-abuse
text:
“I knew that all those hours I spent locked behind the bathroom door just couldn’t come to nothing,” Philip Roth said of his most famous creation, Alex Portnoy and his “flying fist”. Portnoy’s Complaint did for compulsive masturbation what Wordsworth did for daffodils. This 1969 novel was not Roth’s first but it was the one that made his reputation, selling 420,000 copies in hardback and 3.5 million paperbacks over the next five years.

Despite that success, Roth, who died in 2018, was indignant he never won the Nobel prize, although he did receive a fan letter from Kirk Douglas. Dozens of other fellowships, medals, honorary degrees, writer-in-residence scams and awards came his way, and Roth published 31 books between 1959, with Goodbye Columbus,
summary:
“I knew that all those hours I spent locked behind the bathroom door just couldn’t come to nothing,” Philip Roth said of his most famous creation, Alex Portnoy and his “flying fist”.
Portnoy’s Complaint did for compulsive masturbation what Wordsworth did for daffodils.

title: Scottish football delaying child abuse report, rape victim claims
text:
A rape survivor who was abused by an assistant referee after being invited to the Scottish Cup final has demanded that Scottish football’s governing body release its delayed report into child sexual abuse within the sport.

Pete Haynes, 54, alleges that he was abused by Hugh Stevenson, a top-flight linesman and coach, after attending the match at Hampden in 1979.

Sponsored

Mr Haynes reported the allegations to the police in 1993 and 1996 and informed the Scottish Football Association (SFA) but Stevenson died in 2004 without facing any charges.

The report of the Independent Review of Sexual Abuse in Scottish Football was due to be released in 2018 but has been held back on several occasions.

Martin Henry, chairman of the review, handed over the finalised
summary:

title: Too many children wrongly taken into care, admits chief social worker Isabelle Trowler
text:
Babies and children are still being removed from families unnecessarily, according to the chief social worker for children and families in England.

Isabelle Trowler, 53, said social work needed “a reset” because it was “devastating” for families to have a child taken into care when they did not need to be. She branded as “an injustice” the practice under which some authorities take away babies who could be safely supported at home.

Sponsored

In an interview Trowler said that dire warnings of a dramatic surge in children suffering neglect and being taken into care after the first lockdown had not come to pass. Instead there had been a shift to “kinder” social work, which supported families rather than taking away their children. The aftermath of the
summary:
Babies and children are still being removed from families unnecessarily, according to the chief social worker for children and families in England.
Isabelle Trowler, 53, said social work needed “a reset” because it was “devastating” for families to have a child taken into care when they did not need to be.
She branded as “an injustice” the practice under which some authorities take away babies who could be safely supported at home.
SponsoredIn an interview Trowler said that dire warnings of a dramatic surge in children suffering neglect and being taken into care after the first lockdown had not come to pass.
Instead there had been a shift to “kinder” social work, which supported families rather than taking away their children.

title: Archbishop of York: we must pay up for abuse
text:
The Most Rev Stephen Cottrell said that the report was “shocking” and “terribly revealing”

Compensating victims of abuse will cost the Church of England a lot of money but a failure to support them will “cost us our soul”, the Archbishop of York has said.

Last week the Church of England was criticised in a report by the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA), which said that it had spent decades covering up abuse by paedophiles, ignoring victims and neglecting the safety of children in favour of protecting its own reputation.

Sponsored

Yesterday the Most Rev Stephen Cottrell, the church’s second most senior clergyman, who took up the post in July, said that some people’s confidence in the institution had been “completely destroyed” by its failure to stamp out abuse and paedophilia by some members of its clergy.
summary:
The Most Rev Stephen Cottrell said that the report was “shocking” and “terribly revealing”Compensating victims of abuse will cost the Church of England a lot of money but a failure to support them will “cost us our soul”, the Archbishop of York has said.
Last week the Church of England was criticised in a report by the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA), which said that it had spent decades covering up abuse by paedophiles, ignoring victims and neglecting the safety of children in favour of protecting its own reputation.
SponsoredYesterday the Most Rev Stephen Cottrell, the church’s second most senior clergyman, who took up the post in July, said that some people’s confidence in the institution had been “completely destroyed” by its failure to stamp out abuse and paedophilia by some members of its clergy.

title: Spare us the mess of a grand Covid inquiry
text:
In the lexicon of political cliché there are some phrases so irritating, so alien to everyday parlance that it is a wonder those in Westminster continue to wheel them out. “Let me be frank” (prior to fudge), “Let me be clear” (prior to obfuscation), “Hard-working families” (translation: those people who drive white vans and eat budget sausage rolls). The worst offender has to be “lessons will be learnt”, its ghastly glibness indicating that instead of reflecting or apologising, the speaker intends to kick the can well beyond the horizon. Now, we are told, “lessons will be learnt” from the pandemic, with an independent inquiry at some point down the line.

At prime minister’s questions last week Boris Johnson said that although now is not the
summary:

title: Ex-military bunker in Germany was key centre for dark web
text:
The cyberbunker’s 400 servers were allegedly used to trade drugs, stolen credit card details and fake identity cards

A gang of cyberexperts turned a former German military bunker into one of Europe’s biggest hubs for the “dark web” and a superhighway for at least a quarter of a million offences, including drug trafficking and the falsification of identity papers, a court has been told.

Four people from the Netherlands, three Germans and a Bulgarian are accused of creating a digital safe haven in which criminals could operate with impunity.

Sponsored

The “cyberbunker” trial is a landmark for the authorities as they seek to dismantle the physical infrastructure that underpins online criminal activity.

In 2013 the group took over the heavily fortified site of a former cartography centre for the German armed forces in Traben-Trarbach, a town on the river Mosel near Koblenz.

Prosecutors told
summary:

title: Sexual abuse isn’t problem for us alone, insist heads
text:
Dulwich College contacted police after being told that abuse had been perpetrated by its pupils

Much sexual abuse among teenagers happens at parties so it is not for schools alone to address incidents of harassment, according to a teaching union.

Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, the secondary school head teachers’ union, said that parents, the justice system and social media companies also had to take responsibility.

Sponsored

His comments came as the number of testimonies on the Everyone’s Invited website exceeded 11,000. More than 2,000 were posted in the past 24 hours with allegations involving pupils as young as five.

The claims include one alleged assault by a child at the £22,000-a-year Fulham Preparatory School in west London.

title: Child sex criminals escape prosecution
text:
Modern slavery laws were only used for underage offences 30 times in a year

Child sexual exploitation prosecutions have almost halved in three years and police action against offenders is “disappointingly low”, a charity has said.

The Children’s Society has disclosed that modern slavery laws — designed to target those, such as county lines drugs traffickers, who criminally exploit children — were only used for underage offences 30 times in a year, despite fears of rising abuse.

Sponsored

The charity warned that the scale of exploitation, whether sexual or criminal, remained “stubbornly high” while the number of perpetrators being charged and prosecuted for exploitation of children was “disappointingly low”. It called for a new law to help capture more offenders.

title: Caitlin Moran’s Celebrity Watch: When Parky saw a ghost
text:
As lockdown eases, and the phrase “Shall we go to the pub?” involves a fractional upgrading of pleasure — from “Shall we stand near a closed pub?” to “Shall we sit outside an open pub, dressed as if on the Shackleton expedition to the Pole, drinking an inadvisably cold drink while gradually losing sensation in our face, toes, fingers and stomach?”— the world is forced, yet again, to confront its attitude to alcohol.

Has it become problematic during lockdown? Is that pub pint now not even “touching the sides”? Or — conversely — as a “social drinker”, largely abstemious in the past year, is that first pub pint making you say “WOOOO!” a lot as a prelude to bursting into song, then losing a shoe?
summary:
As lockdown eases, and the phrase “Shall we go to the pub?” involves a fractional upgrading of pleasure — from “Shall we stand near a closed pub?” to “Shall we sit outside an open pub, dressed as if on the Shackleton expedition to the Pole, drinking an inadvisably cold drink while gradually losing sensation in our face, toes, fingers and stomach?”— the world is forced, yet again, to confront its attitude to alcohol.
Has it become problematic during lockdown?
Is that pub pint now not even “touching the sides”?
Or — conversely — as a “social drinker”, largely abstemious in the past year, is that first pub pint making you say “WOOOO!” a lot as a prelude to bursting into song, then losing a shoe?

title: The New Mutants review — their superpower is the ability to make you yawn
text:
★★☆☆☆

In this listless franchise reboot, a fresh batch of would-be X-Men are imprisoned in an institution by a sinister woman while they learn to control their demons. You could call it One Flew Over the Mutant’s Nest if it had an ounce of wit or personality. What we actually get is a combination of splashy horror and turgid teenage soap as our angsty charges, supervised with ferocious blankness by Dr Reyes (Alice Braga from City of God, failing to channel Nurse Ratched), shuffle through their superhero puberty.

Directed by Josh Boone, who made the adolescent cancer flick The Fault in Our Stars, the film uses mutants to explore an exhausting list of social issues: depression, inclusivity, homosexuality, self-harm, child abuse, racism and
summary:

title: Ofsted to look at sexual abuse in schools as NSPCC launches helpline
text:
Pupils stage a protest against rape culture at Highgate School in London. Rachel de Souza said the government must be careful not to kick the problem of sexual abuse in schools into the long grass

The government has announced a review into sexual abuse in schools after thousands of girls shared testimonies of their experiences.

The NSPCC will set up a dedicated helpline to provide support to victims and Ofsted has been asked to examine school safeguarding policies immediately.

Sponsored

Victims will be better supported to refer allegations to the police if they wish, Gavin Williamson, the education secretary, said this afternoon.

The dedicated phone line will go live tomorrow to provide both children and adults, who have experienced sexual abuse in schools, with the appropriate support and advice.

The government has also asked Ofsted to undertake an immediate review to look at the extent and the severity of the issue and ensure that schools have appropriate processes in place to
summary:

title: ‘Instagram for kids’ backlash
text:
Instagram is working on a new “safe” version of its app for children under 13

In March 2019, Chris McKenna, founder of online advocacy group Protect Young Eyes, created a fake Instagram account of a 12-year-old girl. It included a couple of selfies, some “liked” photos and some hashtag searches.

“Within weeks,” he told Congress, “we had dozens of men sending us images of their genitals, telling us they were horny and sending us hardcore pornography though direct messages, even after we told all of them we were only 12. They were relentless.”

Sponsored

title: ‘Cavalier’ Facebook accused of putting children at risk with end-to-end encryption
text:
Monika Bickert of Facebook admitted that end-to-end encryption would help groomers

Facebook has been accused of taking a “cavalier approach to child safety” after it admitted that new security measures on messaging services would make it harder for police to catch paedophiles.

Conversations between users on Facebook Messenger and Instagram are scanned for images of child sexual abuse, which are reported to the police.

Sponsored

However, in 2019 Mark Zuckerberg announced his intention to encrypt all of the firm’s messaging services as part of the company’s “tilt to privacy”.

On Wednesday Monika Bickert, vice-president of global policy management at Facebook, admitted that the introduction of end-to-end encryption would help to protect the identities of groomers.

Asked by Yvette Cooper, chairwoman of the home affairs committee, whether the number of reported instances of child sexual abuse

text:
Business leaders have said they will fund a court battle aimed at forcing the Scottish government into releasing secret legal advice about its botched investigation of Alex Salmond.

The former first minister last week shared his lawyers’ advice with a Holyrood committee examining how the government unlawfully handled claims of sexual assault against him. Mr Salmond demanded that ministers do the same after weeks of deadlock.

title: Rape victims may be denied justice by courts backlog
text:
Lawyers said delays in bringing cases to court will have a serious impact on the reliability of evidence

Rape and other crimes involving sexual violence are being made more difficult to prosecute by the huge delays in jury trials caused by the pandemic.

Victims’ groups fear that some women who have waited years for justice will drop proceedings after being told that their cases have been postponed either indefinitely or for many months.

Sponsored

Witness testimony, meanwhile, will become less reliable as the time between alleged offence and court date lengthens, according to lawyers.

Some defendants have received a lighter sentence after deciding to plead guilty and avoid going to trial.

Osman Basri, 47, a convicted sex offender, was sentenced to only 10 months in prison at Wood Green crown court, north London, in July, after admitting stalking with intent to cause distress. The
summary:

Victims’ groups fear that some women who have waited years for justice will drop proceedings after being told that their cases have been postponed either indefinitely or for many months.
SponsoredWitness testimony, meanwhile, will become less reliable as the time between alleged offence and court date lengthens, according to lawyers.
Some defendants have received a lighter sentence after deciding to plead guilty and avoid going to trial.
Osman Basri, 47, a convicted sex offender, was sentenced to only 10 months in prison at Wood Green crown court, north London, in July, after admitting stalking with intent to cause distress.

title: Irish charity uncovers child sexual abuse in 32 countries
text:
The Irish charity Hotline there needed to be cross-border co-operation in the fight against online child sexual abuse

An Irish charity uncovered child sexual abuse material from 32 countries including Ireland last year.

Hotline.ie is the Irish national centre of expertise for combating illegal content online, providing a web-reporting service on which members of the public can securely report child sexual abuse material (CSAM) and activities.

Sponsored

Hotline.ie revealed its findings in response to a consultation by the European Commission. The commission is exploring whether to establish a European centre to prevent and counter child sexual abuse.

In July 2020, the commission published a strategy for a “more effective fight against child sexual abuse”. It includes eight initiatives for the 2020-2025 period including to put in place a strong legal framework, strengthen the law enforcement response and facilitate a co-ordinated approach across the many

text:
Harry Robertson admitted at Glasgow sheriff court to possession and creating indecent images of children

A former dentist who sent indecent images to his lawyer to apparently expose a paedophile chat room has walked free from court.

Harry Robertson, 59, was out on license at the time after a previous conviction concerning images of child sex abuse in July last year. He also sent the two indecent images of young boys to a friend.

Sponsored

Robertson was struck from the dental register in 2014 for hiding his HIV diagnosis and then was caught in 2017 with 215 still and moving indecent images of children.

Robertson, who practised in Paisley and Dumfries, admitted at Glasgow sheriff court to possession and creating indecent images of children. He also admitted distributing or showing indecent images of children.

title: Online predators thrive during lockdown
text:
Child grooming and fraud rose online during lockdown as paedophiles and scammers gained unprecedented access to a captive internet audience.

Police recorded a higher number of online child sexual abuse crimes in June than in any other month on record. A similar rise was seen in March when the tough lockdown was imposed.

There were 530 online child abuse crimes recorded between April and June, with 226 in June alone, according to the latest quarterly update submitted to the Scottish Police Authority. This was an increase of 21 per cent against the same period last year and 34 per cent higher than the five-year average.

Tom Watson said he hoped he could convince his critics as head of the UK Music industry group

Tom Watson has defended his appointment as head of the music industry’s lobbying group as anger over his new role intensified.

The former deputy leader of the Labour Party acknowledged yesterday that “mistakes were made” when he supported a fantasist who made false allegations of child sexual abuse against celebrities and politicians. Mr Watson added that he hoped he could convince critics that he could “do a good job”.

title: Nudes, porn, abuse – the toxic culture in UK classrooms
text:
One of the many unexpected benefits of home schooling, Sophie found, was being able to go up the stairs in peace. There was no upskirting. No one was competing for photos of her knickers – the more intimate the shot, the better the trophy to share around Whatsapp groups and the more lad points to win among their friends.

There were plenty of other things she didn’t miss about Highgate, the private school in north London where, as a 13-year-old, teachers measured her skirt with a ruler, and boys dominated the common room with loud boasts of “smashing” girls and “banging” girls and “thrusting” into their drunken mouths, while the quiet ones laughed along.

title: Leading private schools admit failings over abuse of pupils
text:
Fettes College offered an unreserved apology for the sexual, physical and emotional abuse of pupils

One of Scotland’s most prestigious private schools has admitted it failed to act “responsibly or appropriately” when evidence of sexual and emotional abuse by former teachers came to light.

Representing Fettes College in Edinburgh, Jonathan Brodie QC said that the school offered an unreserved apology to those who suffered abuse.

Sponsored

“While words of apology may have limited worth, we fully accept and recognise in the past there was sexual, physical and emotional abuse of pupils while at Fettes College,” he said. “That has been the result of certain members of staff and by failing to prevent peer-to-peer bullying.

“The school recognises that on occasions it did not act responsibly or appropriately when evidence of abuse came to light. It is a matter of profound regret.
summary:

text:
Nawal El Saadawi was six years old when she was circumcised. She cried for her mother until she saw her standing with her aunts, watching and smiling. “Since I was a child that deep wound left in my body never healed,” she wrote long after the traumatic event.

Other episodes in her childhood outraged her too. She was furious when her grandmother declared that “a boy is worth 15 girls at least . . . girls are a blight” and angry at her parents’ favouritism towards her older brother. title: Survivors of child abuse need support as well as justice
text:
By my late twenties I had worked all over the world, a dream of mine, before landing a regular presenter’s slot on Sky Sports. But my achievements in adulthood concealed a childhood racked with trauma.

When I spoke out about the sexual abuse I suffered as a child, I did so because I believe these conversations need to take place in the open. Stigma and isolation are an abuser’s best friend. The abuse I endured left me feeling lonely and ashamed, even though the shame was my abuser’s to bear.

title: Sexual abuse rises in Thailand during pandemic
text:
A street in Bangkok, Thailand. Police say that cases of child abuse increased by as much as 40 per cent last year

Cases of online sexual abuse of children in Thailand have risen dramatically as the pandemic leaves more and more potential victims at home unsupervised, bored and spending large amounts of time on their phones.

Police and child protection organisations say that cases of abuse, including the extracting of pornographic images from children, increased last year by as much as 40 per cent.

Sponsored“The lockdown allows minors, usually aged between ten and 18, and who have a mobile phone, to be easily abused online,” said Boom Mosby of the Hug Project, which fights sexual abuse and human trafficking.
Perpetrators contact young people via social media sites under the guise of friendship and inveigle them into sending indecent photographs.

title: Ian Wright on white privilege, forgiveness — and growing up in a violent home
text:
The loneliest point in Ian Wright’s life came just as his dreams were coming true. From the age of ten he had longed to play professional football. Growing up on a south London estate, school was a struggle and home life worse; abandoned by his father at 18 months, he lived in fear of his violent, hard-drinking stepfather, who regularly roughed up his mother. Time after time throughout his teens Wright would show up at a club for another trial, alone, only to be rejected again.

“In all that time there was not a lot of love, not a lot of support, not a lot of empathy towards me,” he says.

“In all that time there was not a lot of love, not a lot of support, not a lot of empathy towards me,” he says.

title: The Vatican has failed to stop abuse. Now the law must
text:
Good news for Catholics and for the parents of the 970,000 children in Britain who attend Catholic schools: the Pope has clamped down on child abuse. He has issued a document condemning paedophile behaviour by clergy and setting out procedures to punish it.

This would be reassuring, if not for one thing. The document — Crimen Sollicitationis, in its grand Latin name — was issued by Pope John XXIII in 1962.

title: Teacher fired unfairly after images arrest
text:
The man was charged with possession of indecent images after police searched his home in December 2015 but was later told no action would be taken

A teacher who was sacked after being charged with possession of child abuse images has won a claim of unfair dismissal.

The man, who cannot be named for legal reasons, denied that he had downloaded images onto a computer.

Sponsored

He was charged with possession of indecent images after police searched his home in December 2015. He told his employers the images had been found but he did not know how they had got there. In April 2016 he was told by the Crown Office no further action would be taken but the possibility remained it could be in future.

In December 2016 he was sacked by the local authority he had worked for nearly 20 years. The teacher launched an employment tribunal for unfair dismissal

title: Breeder loses dogs in private prosecution
text:
Nicola Palmer said she thought the two adopted dogs “were entirely mine”

The first private prosecution of unlicensed dog breeding, launched by an animal charity, has led to a breeder being forced to give up two rescued pets.

Nicola Palmer was the subject of the legal action by Phoenix Rehoming after she breached her adoption contract by failing to remove the reproductive organs of male and female dogs brought to the UK from Romania.

Sponsored

Palmer, 39, had no licence to breed the dogs but allowed them to have nine puppies, five of which sold for £300 each. The rest were given to family members. Phoenix Rehoming sought help from the charity Animal Protection Services, which organised the private prosecution.

title: Secret police reports ‘show Nadia Comaneci was starved by her coach Bela Karolyi’
text:
Nadia Comaneci was the first gymnast to score full marks at the Olympics but her success came at a high price, a Romanian researcher has claimed

In 1968 the Romanian gymnastics coach Bela Karolyi saw a six-year-old girl executing immaculately graceful cartwheels during her break at a small rural school.

Afterwards he went from classroom to classroom until he found her, and signed her up for his training facility. Eight years later the girl, Nadia Comaneci, became the first gymnast to score full marks at the Olympic Games, an achievement once thought to be unattainable.

Sponsored

Yet the relentless pursuit of perfection that drove Comaneci to the top of her sport allegedly had a darker side: a historian has claimed that she and the other young pupils in Karolyi’s charge were frequently starved, beaten and psychologically abused. title: Theresa May’s inquiries have cost £300m but none has completed its report
text:
The inquiry into the fire at Grenfell Tower in 2017 is one of several set up by Theresa May

The cost to the taxpayer of public inquiries set up by Theresa May has exceeded £300 million, with none yet to produce a final report.

As home secretary and prime minister Mrs May set up inquiries into child abuse, the Grenfell Tower fire, the conduct of undercover police and the infected blood scandal. She also established an independent review into the unsolved murder in 1987 of Daniel Morgan, a private detective.

Sponsored

Mrs May left government in 2019 but none of the inquiries she established has yet completed its work and there are questions about their expense and effectiveness.

Financial reports put the overall cost of the inquiries at more than £271 million but those figures are months out of date and

title: Child rapist alleged to be IRA man seeks appeal against conviction
text:
An alleged IRA man jailed for raping teenage boys at a Republican safe house more than two decades ago was initially held on 23-hour lock-up and subjected to “severe” verbal abuse by other prisoners, the Court of Appeal has been told.

Seamus Marley, from Belfast, appeared at the three-judge court yesterday where his legal team argued he should be given more time to lodge an appeal against his conviction.

Sponsored

According to the judge who jailed him last year, Marley used his standing in the republican movement to silence his victims. Mr Justice Paul McDermott said the movement was “well capable of clandestine killings”.

Marley, 46, who lived at Belfield Court, Stillorgan Road, Dublin, before being jailed, had denied sexually assaulting and raping the two boys

title: Strip bishops of powers to police Church of England abuse, says inquiry report
text:
The report said the responsibility for the investigation of abuse allegations should be passed to lay safeguarding officers within local dioceses

Bishops should be stripped of powers to investigate and punish abusive priests, according to a report that found the Church of England had created a culture where sex offenders were “able to hide”.

The church harboured hundreds of paedophiles over almost 70 years, the report said, adding that it had undermined its “moral purpose” as a Christian institution by “neglecting the wellbeing of children in favour of protecting its own reputation”.

A review by the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA) found that, between 1940 and 2018, 390 priests and other church workers were convicted of sex offences against children, while 2,504 concerns about the safety of children or vulnerable adults were raised with the church in 2018 alone .

text:
Rangers have yet to make an apology to survivors of child sex abuse at the club and have denied wrongdoing

Scotland’s sports minister has warned Rangers and other football clubs that they cannot stay silent over the “abhorrent” sexual abuse that has scarred the national game.

An independent report commissioned by the Scottish FA ordered clubs who had failed to protect young players to offer an “unequivocal and unreserved” public apology to survivors.

title: Social media must protect users and free speech under new law
text:
Molly Russell, 14, killed herself in 2017 after seeing self-harm on social media

Social media companies will have a duty to be impartial and will be barred from “arbitrarily” removing comments because they are controversial, the government will announce next week.

Ministers will announce plans on Tuesday for a statutory duty of care, which will be enforced by Ofcom, the broadcasting regulator. Companies that fail to meet the duty could face multimillion-pound fines or be blocked from operating in Britain.

text:
Lady Smith said that her findings about the Christian Brothers case study were being prepared for publication

The cost of the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry has now exceeded £40 million, according to the latest figures.

Data show that over 92 days the inquiry, led by Lady Smith, received £27,505.53 per day.

title: Times letters: Research into chronic fatigue syndrome
text:
Sir, It is excellent news that £3.2 million is now being put towards a project by British scientists to try to understand ME, otherwise known as chronic fatigue syndrome (“Search for genetic clues to ME”, Jun 23). When I was health secretary I met families devastated by the onset of a disease that was sometimes dismissed as being a fabrication. It is to the credit of Dame Sally Davies, who was then the chief medical officer, that she took the concerns of such families seriously and started a process that led to this announcement.

This reminds me that in medicine and science it is often as important to be honest about what you don’t know as it is to be certain of what you do
summary:
Sir, It is excellent news that £3.2 million is now being put towards a project by British scientists to try to understand ME, otherwise known as chronic fatigue syndrome (“Search for genetic clues to ME”, Jun 23).
When I was health secretary I met families devastated by the onset of a disease that was sometimes dismissed as being a fabrication.
It is to the credit of Dame Sally Davies, who was then the chief medical officer, that she took the concerns of such families seriously and started a process that led to this announcement.
This reminds me that in medicine and science it is often as important to be honest about what you don’t know as it is to be certain of what you do

title: Salome at La Scala review — a fascinating, gripping streamed staging of Strauss
text:
As the Royal Opera announces its first fully staged work in a year — a new production of Mozart’s late opera seria, La clemenza di Tito, directed by Richard Jones, conducted by Mark Wigglesworth and sung by “a distinguished international cast” (opening after May 17) — several of its international counterparts have already streamed large-scale new work behind closed doors. While La Scala in Milan, the Vienna State Opera and the Bavarian State Opera in Munich are far more lavishly subsidised than the RO, a concert performance of Handel’s Ariodante (last November), operatic highlights with piano accompaniment and small-scale “studio” opera seem meagre compared with Milan’s new production of Richard Strauss’s Salome, Munich’s bold attempt to bring Weber’s Der Freischütz to life online

Sponsored

text:
Tommy Burns was appointed manager of the Parkhead side “because of the support given to him by the former Celtic Boys Club president”

A former senior figure at Celtic FC’s feeder team played a key role in ensuring that Tommy Burns was appointed manager of the Parkhead side, further undermining claims that the two clubs were separate entities.
