title: It’s time to revive our tainted honours system
text:
We need new words. Dis-honoured perhaps? De-knighted? Dis-ordered? Apparently when the monarch removes one of our Ruritanian honours from a misbehaving individual the formal term is “cancelled and annulled”. It happens every year, lately more often. Not that we’d notice except in the most dramatic cases; one chap’s two-medal forfeiture only went public via the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse.

Elizabeth Yardley, professor of criminology at Birmingham City University and Lord Lexden, a constitutional expert, have called for this stiff-upper-lipped manoeuvre to be more transparent. “Secret disgrace is no disgrace at all” says the latter, suggesting that baddies who surrender their medals deserve more credit than those who have to have them prised from their hands. It also turns out that a criminal
summary:

Not that we’d notice except in the most dramatic cases; one chap’s two-medal forfeiture only went public via the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse.

title: Paedophile hunters did not breach offender’s human rights, Supreme Court rules
text:
A vigilante group did not breach the rights of a paedophile after they trapped him by using the social media profile of a fake teenager, senior judges have ruled.

The Supreme Court yesterday found that the group, which called itself Groom Resisters Scotland, did not violate Mark Sutherland’s right to privacy when they lured him to a meeting in Glasgow after he exchanged messages with a fake profile of a 13-year-old boy on the Grindr app.

Sponsored

The court heard that the vigilantes confronted Sutherland, 37, at the meeting in 2018 then passed copies of his communications to the police. Sutherland appealed against his subsequent conviction for trying to communicate indecently with an older child, meaning that they were over 13 but under 16.

Five judges
summary:

title: Child removal fuels female drug deaths
text:
The average number of women who died per year rose from 94 to 299 between 2005 and 2019

A rapid rise in drug deaths among working-age women in Scotland is being driven by those who become lonely after their children are taken into care, researchers have found.

An investigation paints a picture of isolated mothers devastated by the removal of their offspring. The experts recommended improvements to how children are taken into care to ensure parents are supported.

Sponsored

Some mothers who were interviewed said that they had travelled home alone after seeing their children for the last time. They felt suicidal and their drug-taking increased as they tried to cope with grief and shame.

title: Domestic abuse victims in Ireland to receive rent supplement without means testing
text:
Emergency calls for help relating to domestic violence have increased by 25 per cent this year, according to garda statistics

Victims of domestic violence will be able to access the state’s rent supplement payment without a means test, the government has said.

Under changes announced by the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection, victims of domestic violence can get immediate access to rent supplement for a three-month period to ensure that they are not prevented from leaving their home because of financial concerns.

Sponsored

The department said that the usual rent supplement means test would not apply to this period. After that a further three-month extension may be provided, subject to the usual rent supplement means assessment. title: Sara Khan: ‘There is no right not to be offended... and no one should live in fear for doing their job’
text:
Sara Khan said it was “just horrifying” that the religious studies teacher was “hounded” after children were shown a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad

Sara Khan knows how it feels to face death threats and messages of hate. The Muslim from Bradford who was appointed this week as Boris Johnson’s independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience has had many since she began campaigning against extremism. On police advice she installed a fireproof letterbox at her home, having been attacked by the hard left and far right as well as Islamist groups.

The protests outside a school in Batley, West Yorkshire, after children were shown a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad have, however, made her more determined to challenge intolerance. “There is no right not to be offended,” she says. “The teacher was hounded and I found that just horrifying. No teacher should find themselves in a situation where
summary:
Sara Khan said it was “just horrifying” that the religious studies teacher was “hounded” after children were shown a cartoon of the Prophet MuhammadSara Khan knows how it feels to face death threats and messages of hate.
On police advice she installed a fireproof letterbox at her home, having been attacked by the hard left and far right as well as Islamist groups.
The protests outside a school in Batley, West Yorkshire, after children were shown a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad have, however, made her more determined to challenge intolerance.
“There is no right not to be offended,” she says.
“The teacher was hounded and I found that just horrifying.

title: Sexual abuse in football ‘can happen again’ warns player who helped convict Barry Bennell
text:
One of the first people to blow the whistle on football’s sexual abuse scandal has warned that it would be a “disaster” for any sports organisation to believe serial abuse cannot happen again.

Ian Ackley, whose testimony to police helped put football coach Barry Bennell behind bars in 1998, was speaking ahead of the publication of the FA’s independent review into historical sexual abuse conducted by Clive Sheldon QC today.

Sponsored

Ackley has said he felt let down by the FA and the clubs for failing to investigate the full scale of the abuse in football when he first reported it more than 20 years ago. Sheldon’s report will look at how the FA, clubs and individuals handled reports of abuse made to them between 1970
summary:

title: French philosopher Michel Foucault ‘abused boys in Tunisia’
text:
Michel Foucault was one of the first celebrity intellectuals of the 20th century remembered not only for his controversial analyses of prisons, madness and sexuality but for signing a petition in 1977 to legalise sex with children aged 13

The philosopher Michel Foucault, a beacon of today’s “woke” ideology, has become the latest prominent French figure to face a retrospective reckoning for sexually abusing children.

A fellow intellectual, Guy Sorman, has unleashed a storm among Parisian “intellos” with his claim that Foucault, who died in 1984 aged 57, was a paedophile rapist who had sex with Arab children while living in Tunisia in the late 1960s.

Sponsored

Sorman, 77, said he had visited Foucault with a group of friends on an Easter holiday trip to the village of Sidi Bou Said, near Tunis, where the philosopher was living in 1969. “Young children were running after Foucault saying ‘what about me? take me, take me’,” he recalled last week in an interview with The Sunday Times
summary:

title: What to do if your child’s mental health is suffering during the pandemic
text:
As a mental health clinician and trustee of the NSPCC, I can see that children’s mental health has clearly been disproportionately affected by the pandemic. With children and young people already at greater risk of developing mental health issues than adults due to the significant period of brain development they are going through — 50 per cent of mental health problems establish by age 14 and 75 per cent by age 24 — research from the University of Oxford highlights that in July 2020 one in six children and young people were experiencing a mental health difficulty compared with one in nine in 2017. The increase was evident in boys and girls.

The pandemic has negatively impacted the mental health of our children and young
summary:

title: Warrant was served to obtain government’s Salmond papers
text:
Some documents were ruled inadmissible at Alex Salmond’s trial, at which he was cleared of all charges

Prosecutors resorted to serving a warrant on the Scottish government to obtain documents linked to the investigation into sexual assault allegations against Alex Salmond, it has emerged.

The Crown Office issued the warrant last autumn as it built its case against the former first minister and exchanged correspondence with officials over the requested disclosure. A spokesman for the Scottish government insisted that they had asked for the warrant to be issued to ensure “legal certainty” in providing the documents.

Sponsored

The documents were disclosed before court hearings against Mr Salmond but a number of them were ruled inadmissible in his trial at the High Court in Edinburgh. In March, Mr Salmond was cleared of all charges.

title: Tusla: Child protection agency needs legal backing, says report
text:
The special rapporteur on child protection highlighted gaps in the Child Care Act covering the nature of Tusla’s obligation to investigate complaints

Tusla should have an “express obligation” under law to receive, assess and investigate complaints of child sexual abuse, a report has said.

The annual report of the special rapporteur on child protection, published yesterday, found that the Child Care Act 1991 did not provide a “sufficiently robust legal basis” for the work of Tusla, the state’s child protection agency.

Sponsored

Under the Act, Tusla needs only to: “Take such steps as it considers requisite to identify children who are not receiving adequate care and protection and coordinate information from all relevant sources relating to children in its area.”

The report says: “[The Act] contains no detail about the nature of Tusla’s obligation to investigate complaints; about the procedural requirements that such an investigation should adhere
summary:

title: Clive Myrie survived war zones, came home to be a BBC anchorman — and got racist abuse and death threats
text:
‘Articulate” does not begin to describe Clive Myrie of BBC News. He is the best writer in its reporters’ room — I cite in evidence the moment when, over footage of a ramshackle tent village in Sudan, he asked viewers to “imagine what those displaced are running from if this is what they are running to”. He possesses its finest speaking voice: a deep, warm baritone. Out of his special assignments he makes sophisticated mini documentaries where others merely go on a bit longer than usual. In the presenter’s chair, when Huw Edwards is not around, he exudes attention and authority, and must surely be the frontrunner eventually to succeed him.

Nevertheless, it is the word “articulate” that Myrie brings up when we begin to

title: Dulwich College turns boys into sexual abusers, former pupil claims
text:
Billie Errington says Dulwich boys ‘trolled’ a Facebook page she set up when at school

Dulwich College is today accused of being a “breeding ground for sexual predators” in an open letter organised by a former schoolboy that contains more than 100 anonymous accounts of assault, harassment and sharing intimate photos online.

The letter, written by Samuel Schulenburg, 19, a former pupil at the south London private school, said “experiences of assault, revenge pornography and slut shaming were exacerbated by ... young men who ... laughed at stories of sexual violence”.

Sponsored

His letter includes about 100 anonymous testimonies written by girls who went to neighbouring schools, such as James Allen’s Girls’ School (Jags). One claims there was “an established rape culture” at the school.

In a statement issued yesterday, Dr Joe Spence, master at Dulwich, said the school “condemned unreservedly”

title: Govan GPs found model to handle tough cases but rollout failed
text:
When John Montgomery, a GP, met Nicola Sturgeon, he says she backed the new approach he and colleagues were taking.

The team at Govan Health Centre were doing just what the first minister envisaged: working with other health and social care staff to look after vulnerable patients in a bid to reduce the pressure on emergency healthcare.

Sponsored

Yet when the three-year pilot, funded by the Scottish government, ended in 2018, the doctors could not get the funding and staff needed to continue. The new approach has stalled, and patient requests for appointments are soaring. “It was a great shame,” Montgomery said.

title: Sports coaches barred from having sex with teens in their care
text:
It is hoped that the ban will help to stop cases such as that of Barry Bennell, who was sentenced to more than 30 years in prison in 2018 for hundreds of sexual offences

Sports coaches and religious leaders will be banned from having sex with 16 and 17-year-olds in their care under changes to child abuse laws introduced to parliament today.

The Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill will close a legal loophole by bringing them in line with teachers, doctors, carers and other adults in positions of trust. Ministers decided not to extend the ban to occupations such as driving instructors and music teachers, amid fears that expanding it too widely would in effect increase the age of consent to 18.

Sponsored

text:
The headmaster of Dulwich College, one of England’s most famous private schools, was warned that teenage boys were allegedly harassing and abusing girls five years before the latest claims that his school was “a breeding ground for sexual predators”.

title: Pressure on police to investigate sex crime allegations
text:
British police have been under pressure to investigate allegations of sex crimes involving celebrities since the Jimmy Savile scandal.

The former DJ and Jim’ll Fix It presenter escaped prosecution when he died in 2011. He had been questioned by detectives two years earlier over allegations of child sex abuse in the 1970s.

Sponsored

An official report published many months after Savile’s death described him as “a predatory sex offender” who had carried out hundreds of assaults over five decades, including in hospitals and at BBC studios. His victims included women and children as young as eight.

The authorities’ failings led to the creation of Operation Yewtree at Scotland Yard and a series of spin-off investigations into allegations of historic abuse by VIPs.

summary:
British police have been under pressure to investigate allegations of sex crimes involving celebrities since the Jimmy Savile scandal.
The former DJ and Jim’ll Fix It presenter escaped prosecution when he died in 2011.
He had been questioned by detectives two years earlier over allegations of child sex abuse in the 1970s.
His victims included women and children as young as eight.
The authorities’ failings led to the creation of Operation Yewtree at Scotland Yard and a series of spin-off investigations into allegations of historic abuse by VIPs.

title: Times letters: Political grandstanding over AstraZeneca
text:
Sir, When AstraZeneca and Oxford University announced that their vaccine would be produced at cost there seemed some hope for the world. When the vaccine turned out to be both very effective and easy to transport and store, this hope looked like turning into reality; altruism trumping greed (Iain Martin, Mar 25). Subsequent events have shown that political ambition and greed can still outweigh the urgent need to protect us all. What other explanation can there be for repeated attempts to call the vaccine’s effectiveness into question? Europe is also in the absurd position of being locked in a contractual struggle with AstraZeneca for a vaccine that its leaders have successfully and wrongly sought to discredit with their citizens.

Britain has made many
summary:

title: Australia apologise to India over alleged racial abuse by fans
text:
Cricket Australia apologised to the India team today and launched a probe into allegations visiting players were subjected to racial abuse by part of the crowd during the third test at Sydney Cricket Ground.

Mohammed Siraj, the fast bowler, approached the umpire pointing towards the stands and the action was paused as police ejected six fans from the ground.

An official complaint had been lodged after close of play on Saturday, with Siraj and fellow quick Jasprit Bumrah both complaining of hearing racist slurs while fielding near the boundary rope. CA launched a parallel investigation with New South Wales Police, promising to take the “strongest measures” against anyone found guilty of vilification.

title: We must restore public trust in justice

As attorney-general, I oversee two key partners of the criminal justice system in England and Wales — the Crown Prosecution Service and the Serious Fraud Office — which are responsible for securing justice for hundreds of thousands of victims annually.

title: Parents at war should make own decisions
text:
A rule requires separating couples to attend mediation before advancing their case, but a report says it must be enforced

Separating couples should head to court to resolve disputes only as a last resort, the most senior family judge has said, as cases and delays spiral.

Sir Andrew McFarlane, the president of the family division, has warned of “unprecedented” demand as a “startling and worrying” number of separating couples — 40 per cent — are asking judges to determine issues about their children’s care, rather than exercising parental responsibility and sorting problems out themselves.

title: Police in Madeleine McCann case dig up Christian Brückner’s garden
text:
German police investigating the disappearance of Madeleine McCann have used sniffer dogs and two mechanical diggers to search a private garden allotment in Hanover.

“I can confirm that this measure is being taken in connection with the Madeleine McCann case,” a spokeswoman for the Brunswick prosecutor’s office told The Times.

Sponsored

The office said last month that it believed that Madeleine was dead and identified Christian Brückner, a convicted paedophile, as its prime suspect. It declined to reveal its evidence and made a public appeal for information to help convict him. Yesterday’s search, which may continue today, was a joint operation between the Brunswick office and federal criminal police (BKA).

title: Shaming boys just for being male is a sorry situation
text:
As a father of two boys and one girl, my heart breaks when I think about any of them navigating today’s world of relationships. Never have I felt more strongly the desire, common to all parents at some time or another, to bind them in bubble wrap and keep them away from a world impossible to understand.

An assembly was held recently at Brauer College, a school in rural Warrnambool, in southwest Victoria, Australia, during which its boy pupils, some as young as 12, were made to stand up and apologise to the girls for crimes of rape, sexual abuse and harassment committed by men against women. Despite the boys in question not being accused of any wrongdoing, they were asked to stand up and
summary:
As a father of two boys and one girl, my heart breaks when I think about any of them navigating today’s world of relationships.
Never have I felt more strongly the desire, common to all parents at some time or another, to bind them in bubble wrap and keep them away from a world impossible to understand.

title: Madeleine McCann: Prosecutors examine link to missing German girl
text:
The disappearance of Inga Gehricke in 2015 is being linked to that of Madeleine McCann

Prosecutors are examining whether the paedophile suspected of murdering Madeleine McCann was involved in the disappearance of a five-year-old blonde girl in Germany in 2015.

Inga Gehricke, known in the media as the German Maddie, vanished from a family party in Wilhelmshof near Stendal in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt. At the time Christian Brückner was using a property in the region.

Sponsored

Yesterday it emerged that two years before Inga’s disappearance he wrote in an online chat room that he wanted to “grab himself a little something and abuse it for days”, Der Spiegel reported. When his anonymous friend said that it would be dangerous, he is reported to have replied: “Ah, [but not] if the evidence is exterminated afterwards.”

The public prosecutor in Stendal
summary:

Inga Gehricke, known in the media as the German Maddie, vanished from a family party in Wilhelmshof near Stendal in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt.
At the time Christian Brückner was using a property in the region.

title: Facebook’s $52m for moderator trauma ‘is partial victory’
text:
Campaigners in Ireland and the UK have cautiously welcomed Facebook’s decision in the United States to compensate content moderators for mental health issues they developed on the job.

Facebook has agreed to pay $52 million to 11,250 moderators past and present. Each moderator will receive a minimum of $1,000 and will be eligible for more compensation if they are diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder or related conditions.

Sponsored

A similar case has been lodged at the High Court in Ireland by Chris Gray, a former Facebook moderator who said he became “numb and desensitised to the horrific content” he had to view at work. Moderators are exposed to graphic content ranging from child sexual abuse to terrorism and animal cruelty.

Mr Gray is seeking damages from
summary:
Campaigners in Ireland and the UK have cautiously welcomed Facebook’s decision in the United States to compensate content moderators for mental health issues they developed on the job.
Facebook has agreed to pay $52 million to 11,250 moderators past and present.
Each moderator will receive a minimum of $1,000 and will be eligible for more compensation if they are diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder or related conditions.
SponsoredA similar case has been lodged at the High Court in Ireland by Chris Gray, a former Facebook moderator who said he became “numb and desensitised to the horrific content” he had to view at work.
Moderators are exposed to graphic content ranging from child sexual abuse to terrorism and animal cruelty.

title: Times letters: Vaccine refuseniks and the steps to freedom
text:
Sir, Clare Foges is right (“Vaccine certificates are vital step to freedom”, Comment, Mar 1). I do not wish to sit beside anyone in a concert hall, restaurant or cinema who has not been vaccinated. These people have the choice to refuse the vaccine and put themselves at greater risk, but surely the rest of the population who accept the vaccine, and want to keep themselves safe, should not have their health put at greater risk by having to be in close proximity with these foolish people. I had my first jab on Feb 1 and will have my second on April 12: I am grateful for it and for all those who have made it possible.

Roderick Boggs

Belfast

Sir, Clare Foges has produced
summary:

title: Sewell review is an overdue step in the right direction on race
text:
Thomas Sowell said: “When you want to help people, you tell them the truth. When you want to help yourself, you tell them what they want to hear.” It’s a fitting mantra to underpin the kind of race debate that has recently been raging.

The report by the Commission on Race and Ethnic Disparities is out today. Evidence-based, it tells truths that some don’t want to hear. Truths like racism still exists in the UK, but disparities don’t always arise because of it. Truths like geography and socioeconomic factors are far more likely to drive unequal outcomes. And truths like it is family breakdown that’s at the heart of some of the worst statistics in education and crime — the ones that most damage our
summary:
Thomas Sowell said: “When you want to help people, you tell them the truth.
When you want to help yourself, you tell them what they want to hear.” It’s a fitting mantra to underpin the kind of race debate that has recently been raging.
The report by the Commission on Race and Ethnic Disparities is out today.
Evidence-based, it tells truths that some don’t want to hear.
Truths like racism still exists in the UK, but disparities don’t always arise because of it.

title: Forty children rescued from Australian sex abuse ring
text:
Fourteen men have been arrested and face charges relating to “abhorrent” abuse

More than 40 children have been rescued, including 16 from a childcare centre north of Sydney, after a child sexual abuse network was uncovered in Australia.

Police in three states have arrested 14 men. They now face 828 charges related to what investigators have described as “abhorrent” sexual abuse.

Sponsored

Among those arrested was a 27-year-old male childcare worker, who faces 303 charges related to child sexual intercourse and indecent assault of 16 children — more than half of those at the centre where he worked.

He is due to face a court in Port Macquarie, 250 miles north of Sydney, in January. His 22-year-old male partner also faces charges.

Some of the men charged are alleged to have sexually abused the 46 children, who range
summary:

title: Madeleine McCann inquiry gives hope to father of missing German girl
text:
The father of a missing German girl said yesterday that he hoped the Madeleine McCann inquiry’s focus on Christian Brückner would lead to a breakthrough in his daughter’s case.

Inga Gehricke, five, vanished in 2015 during a family trip to woodland on the eve of it being eight years since Madeleine disappeared.

Sponsored

Brückner, 43, was living in a dilapidated former factory 30 miles from where Inga disappeared.

Khubaib-Ali Mohammed, the lawyer acting for Inga’s father, Jens-Uwe Gehricke, said: “It is a thread in the life of [Brückner] that whenever children disappear, he always finds himself near the crime scene; not just Maddie, not just Inga. My client hopes with all this momentum . . . the whole thing will be looked at more closely

title: Domestic abuse victims need help now more than ever
text:
Being an outreach support worker for Women’s Aid during the lockdown has been a strange experience. No more face-to-face visits in women’s homes or the community and with new referrals, I have to imagine what the person on the other end of the phone might look like. I worried that home working would be difficult, that I would struggle to fill my time and questioned how effective I could be.

The reality has been very different. Women face the unenviable challenges of staying safe while locked down with an abuser all day every day, escaping if they can for an hour’s exercise or shopping and finding ways to protect their children and themselves.

title: What parents need to teach their sons in 2021
text:
It’s the question on every parent’s lips. In the light of the murder of Sarah Everard, and the subsequent outpouring of feeling from women and girls who are fed up with feeling threatened and unsafe, how should we raise our sons? And, more specifically, how should we raise sons who are able to challenge misogyny and sexism?

I really want to know the answer. I came of age writing for lads’ magazines in the 1990s, when every edition was stuffed with semi-naked models. Now, I’m the father of three sons, aged 13, 16 and 18. When Kit Malthouse, the policing minister, said this week that not only should sex-education classes include teaching boys to respect women, but that all adults had a duty to
summary:
It’s the question on every parent’s lips.
In the light of the murder of Sarah Everard, and the subsequent outpouring of feeling from women and girls who are fed up with feeling threatened and unsafe, how should we raise our sons?
And, more specifically, how should we raise sons who are able to challenge misogyny and sexism?
I came of age writing for lads’ magazines in the 1990s, when every edition was stuffed with semi-naked models.
Now, I’m the father of three sons, aged 13, 16 and 18.

title: Diana Russell obituary
text:
In her campaign against pornography Diana Russell took to tearing up magazines in shops and spray-painting businesses

When Ban Ki-moon, the UN secretary-general, referred to “femicide” on the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women in 2015, it marked a turning point in Diana Russell’s war on the “killing of females by males, because they are female”.

Words mattered to Russell, a pioneering scholar who spent her life challenging norms. In 1976 she had mobilised feminists from 40 countries to testify at an event called the International Tribunal on Crimes Against Women, in Brussels. There she redefined and politicised the term “femicide” for the 2,000 women gathered, announcing: “From the burning of witches in the past, to the recent more widespread custom of female infanticide in many societies, to the killing of women for so-called honour, we realise that femicide

title: Tortured Zimbabwean opposition MP Joanah Mamombe sent back to jail
text:
Joanah Mamombe said that she was “ready to die for the struggle” against the state’s harsh attack on dissent

A female opposition MP in Zimbabwe was returned to jail following her 129th appearance in court in a 12-month campaign of persecution that began with her kidnap and torture by state thugs.

The targeting of Joanah Mamombe, 27, who is serving her seventh prison stretch in the space of a year, is seen as typical of the regime of President Mnangagwa which is now more feared than the era of Robert Mugabe it replaced. In a letter to her mother smuggled out of her cell, Mamombe said that she was “even ready to die for this struggle” against the state’s harsh and unrelenting attack on dissent.

Sponsored

Mamombe, the MP for Harare West, has spent the past 40 days in custody with Cecilia Chimbiri, an activist
summary:

title: Almost a third of chief constables quit before police and crime commissioner elections
text:
Almost a third of chief constables are being replaced as a series of senior officers leave before next month’s police and crime commissioner elections.

In the biggest shake-up to policing in years, some of the most experienced chief officers have already said they are leaving. Others will await the outcome of the May 6 elections of police and crime commissioners (PCCs), who have the power to fire them.

Sponsored

Of the 42 PCC or mayoral posts up for grabs, analysts expect about half will result in the election of new figures to oversee policing. Some candidates have been openly critical of policing in their areas and senior police know they want to bring in their own chiefs.

title: Charges pressed over French incest scandal
text:
A paedophile scandal that has rocked the Paris establishment escalated yesterday when the stepson of a politically connected academic and broadcaster filed a criminal complaint against him over allegations of child sexual abuse.

Antoine Kouchner, 45, an astrophysics professor at Paris university, pressed charges less than three weeks after his twin sister, Camille, published a book that set out to expose Olivier Duhamel for abusing him from the age of 14 in the late 1980s.

Sponsored

Prosecutors have opened an investigation into suspected rape and sexual abuse of a minor by a person in authority. title: Work with us, police tell child abuse vigilantes
text:
William Meek, who had arranged to meet a 13-year-old girl for sex, was caught by vigilantes

Paedophile hunters should work with the police by sharing evidence of grooming rather than posting it online, a senior officer has said.

Hundreds of suspected sex offenders have been confronted by vigilantes in Scotland, resulting in dozens of child abuse cases coming to court.

Sponsored

Groups such as Wolf Pack Hunters have attracted thousands of followers on social media by broadcasting live “exposés” of alleged child sex offenders.

Their members pose as children online and arrange to meet men with whom they have exchanged sexual messages. They then film the ambush.

In July the Supreme Court ruled that vigilantes had not breached the rights of a paedophile after they used a fake social media profile of a teenager to trap him in a covert sting operation.
summary:
William Meek, who had arranged to meet a 13-year-old girl for sex, was caught by vigilantesPaedophile hunters should work with the police by sharing evidence of grooming rather than posting it online, a senior officer has said.

Their members pose as children online and arrange to meet men with whom they have exchanged sexual messages.

title: How podcasts are helping to crack real-life crimes
text:
Josh Dean was frustrated. He had spent nearly a year chasing a con artist suspected of swindling more than a million dollars out of people in the entertainment industry, relaying this story of outlandish deception for his podcast Chameleon: Hollywood Con Queen. Every time he got close, the suspect moved on, took on another alias and shut down social media accounts.

The FBI was on the case too. The Hollywood Con Queen had been luring producers, make-up artists, aspiring screenwriters and actors over to Jakarta to shoot fake blockbusters since 2013 by impersonating female Hollywood executives. Dean reckons there are up to 100 victims. But by last November there was still no arrest. Dean and the many victims he spoke to were losing faith
summary:
Josh Dean was frustrated.
Every time he got close, the suspect moved on, took on another alias and shut down social media accounts.
The Hollywood Con Queen had been luring producers, make-up artists, aspiring screenwriters and actors over to Jakarta to shoot fake blockbusters since 2013 by impersonating female Hollywood executives.
Dean reckons there are up to 100 victims.
Dean and the many victims he spoke to were losing faith

title: Facebook’s plans to encrypt messages will hide abusers
text:
Lockdown has reminded us that the digital world of video calls, social media and messaging services has dramatically improved our ability to connect. Sadly, for all the positives these services provide, there are those who exploit them for criminal purposes. Paedophiles use these same services to identify and groom their victims; terrorists to plot attacks. Tomorrow, at Facebook’s AGM, shareholders will discuss plans that will make it easier for criminals to flourish on their platform.

Last year, Mark Zuckerberg announced his intention to move Facebook’s three messaging services to end-to-end encryption, meaning that serious criminal activity conducted through Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp messaging services would not be visible to the company. Law enforcement agencies in the UK, US and Australia have decried this move, saying
summary:
Lockdown has reminded us that the digital world of video calls, social media and messaging services has dramatically improved our ability to connect.
Sadly, for all the positives these services provide, there are those who exploit them for criminal purposes.
Paedophiles use these same services to identify and groom their victims; terrorists to plot attacks.
Tomorrow, at Facebook’s AGM, shareholders will discuss plans that will make it easier for criminals to flourish on their platform.
Last year, Mark Zuckerberg announced his intention to move Facebook’s three messaging services to end-to-end encryption, meaning that serious criminal activity conducted through Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp messaging services would not be visible to the company.

title: Ex-garda chief Karl Heller to help male victims of domestic abuse group Men's Aid
text:
A former senior garda who led investigations into child and domestic abuse has joined Men’s Aid, an organisation that provides support services to male victims of domestic violence and coercive control, writes John Mooney.

Karl Heller, a former chief superintendent who once commanded the force’s community relations branch, has been recruited to work as a “court accompaniment” who will provide support services to abuse victims.

Sponsored

The role involves attending in camera hearings at the family courts where victims apply for protection and barring orders against wives, partners and girlfriends who engage in violent and threatening behaviour.

Heller’s work will include supporting men who have been denied access to their children or subjected to violence and psychological abuse. “Domestic violence doesn’t discriminate by sex,” he said.
summary:
A former senior garda who led investigations into child and domestic abuse has joined Men’s Aid, an organisation that provides support services to male victims of domestic violence and coercive control, writes John Mooney.
Karl Heller, a former chief superintendent who once commanded the force’s community relations branch, has been recruited to work as a “court accompaniment” who will provide support services to abuse victims.
SponsoredThe role involves attending in camera hearings at the family courts where victims apply for protection and barring orders against wives, partners and girlfriends who engage in violent and threatening behaviour.
Heller’s work will include supporting men who have been denied access to their children or subjected to violence and psychological abuse.
“Domestic violence doesn’t discriminate by sex,” he said.

title: David Quinn: University cancel culture leaves no room for debate
text:
Back in 2006 I debated Richard Dawkins on RTE Radio. His bestselling book The God Delusion had just been published and was receiving massive coverage just about everywhere. It was a no-holds- barred attack on religion, so we had a bit of a donnybrook. You can still find it on YouTube.

Dawkins rarely pulls his punches about anything. He has compared raising a child as Catholic with sexual abuse. Yes, really. He has described the Catholic Church as “a disgusting institution, the second most evil religion in the world”. The God of the Old Testament is a “genocidal, filicidal, pestilential, megalomaniacal, sadomasochistic, capriciously malevolent bully”, he reckons.

text:
Last month Darren Drysdale finally snapped. The referee locked heads with Alan Judge after suffering abuse from the Ipswich Town midfielder that Drysdale described as “the worst he had experienced” at a disciplinary hearing last week. The language in the rest of his statement is too strong to write here, so I’ll substitute the swear words for innocent ones, like my grandma would.

Drysdale said his act of aggression came after he blew his whistle and Judge charged towards him screaming: “It’s a ducking penalty you cheating bald currant.” He did well not to headbutt him, like my grandma would.

title: The opaque world of online advertising needs a strong light shining on it
text:
It is an understatement to say we live in worrying times. With an abundance of conflicting information available to us all, it can be hard to know where to turn for accurate and trustworthy news and information. Highly regulated television news offers a safe harbour in this storm.

In the weeks since the lockdown began in the UK, television news has been reaching massive audiences. ITV News has reached 44 million viewers — nearly 70 per cent of the TV population of the UK. Viewing to Sky News more than doubled across both its TV and digital platforms. Channel 4 saw record news audiences and increased its total young audience by 164 per cent.

title: Catholic Church transfers final properties to state in child abuse deal
text:
The deal to transfer Church properties to the state was made by Michael Woods, then Fianna Fáil education minister, in 2002

The final two properties the Catholic Church agreed to transfer to the state to allow it to be indemnified against abuse cases will finally be handed over 18 years after the deal was made.

In 2002, Michael Woods, then Fianna Fáil education minister, signed a deal with 18 religious congregations who agreed to pay €128 million in return for a state indemnity against all future actions by people who, as children, had been in institutions run by them. Compensation so far has cost the state more than €1.4 billion.

Sponsored

In a 2019 RTÉ documentary Rome vs Republic Michael McDowell, the attorney-general at the time, said the state had “effectively signed a blank cheque” when it agreed the deal. Mr Woods has defended the agreement.

So
summary:

title: Wording on sexual offences policy not unlawful
text:
Court of Appeal

Published March 22, 2021

Regina (End Violence Against Women Coalition) v Director of Public Prosecutions

Before Lord Burnett of Maldon, Lord Chief Justice, Lord Justice Holroyde and Lady Justice Laing

[2021] EWCA Civ 350

Judgment March 15, 2021

Changes in guidance and training with regard to prosecutions for rape and other serious sexual offences, made by the Director of Public Prosecutions in 2016, had not altered the effect of the existing policy and were not unlawful.

Allen v Farrow

Sky Documentaries

★★★☆☆

Woody Allen has never stood trial for allegedly molesting his adopted daughter Dylan, but here, in Allen v Farrow, we saw in ugly detail the full case for the prosecution. It was at times excruciating to watch.

Sponsored

No matter how filmically it was shot, with intermittent dreamy bucolic scenes in the Connecticut family home, you wanted to look away. Especially from the jerky home video made by Mia Farrow when seven-year-old Dylan said that Allen had taken her to the attic and “touched my private parts”.

Mia Farrow and her daughter Dylan in the Allen v Farrow series

Gordon Neely, a youth coach, was dismissed from Rangers for indecently assaulting a 14-year-old boy in 1991

A prolific paedophile continued to abuse children and reinvented himself as a champion of vulnerable youngsters after being sacked by Rangers FC.

The Glasgow club has repeatedly insisted the police were informed after they dismissed Gordon Neely, a youth coach, for indecently assaulting a 14-year-old boy in 1991.

President Macron’s wife said that she strongly backed demands to tackle incest, which arose after allegations in a book published two weeks ago ended the career of Olivier Duhamel, a leading academic, broadcaster and confidant of the leftwing political elite.

text:
Dundee sheriff court was told the videos showed children extremely distressed and trying to escape from underneath her

An RAF serviceman posed as a stuntman and film-maker to persuade a woman to video herself sitting on babies for his sexual gratification.

Andrew Kerr, 35, told the woman he met on Facebook that she would be paid more for the most bizarre and cruel videos. She sent him seven videos.

Kerr tried to incite a second woman to carry out the same acts on young children and had sexual images of children on devices at RAF bases.

title: Madeleine McCann suspect told friend he ‘wanted to grab something and abuse it for days’
text:
Madeleine McCann vanished from her parents’ holiday apartment in Praia da Luz, Portugal, in May 2007

The paedophile who is suspected of abducting Madeleine McCann said on a web chat that he wanted to “grab himself a little something and abuse it for days”, a German magazine has reported.

Christian Brückner, 43, a serial criminal suspected of snatching the three-year-old girl from a holiday apartment in Portugal in 2007, is also being investigated over the disappearance of a five-year-old German girl in 2015.

Sponsored

Der Spiegel reported today that Brückner fantasised in an online chatroom two years earlier about the kidnapping and sexual abuse of a child. When his anonymous friend commented that it would be dangerous, Brückner is said to have countered: “Ah, [but not] if the evidence is exterminated afterwards.”

The German word he used, vernichten, is the same

title: Secretary at east coast Celtic feeder club was child abuser
text:
Celtic FC launched Celtic East Youth Club in 1989 to match its “excellent counterpart”

Celtic FC created and funded a second feeder club which became embroiled in its own child abuse scandal, The Times can reveal.

The Parkhead club has repeatedly distanced itself from systemic abuse at Celtic Boys Club in which four members, including the founder, Jim Torbett, were convicted of molesting dozens of children over four decades.

Sponsored

Now evidence has emerged that Celtic FC was behind the launch of a second youth feeder club in Edinburgh, called Celtic East Youth Club.

Neil Strachan became a leader of one of Scotland’s largest paedophile rings

In 1997 Neil Strachan, the secretary of Celtic East, was jailed for sexually assaulting a young boy and gained further notoriety when he was exposed as the ringleader of Scotland’s worst organised abuse network.

Celtic FC has always denied any formal connection with the Edinburgh club,

title: The boy who grew up in the shadow of Elvis
text:
When police in Calabasas, LA County received reports of shots fired at an apartment last Sunday morning, news wires didn’t immediately light up. Sure, the wealthy community is home to Justin Bieber and Khloé Kardashian. Yet reports said that a 27-year-old called Benjamin Keough had shot himself in the stomach, taking his own life. Wait, Benjamin who?

Benjamin Keough was Elvis Presley’s grandson, the second oldest child of Lisa Marie Presley, (he took the surname of his musician father Danny Keough to whom Lisa Marie was married for six years). Benjamin lived a mostly quiet life and avoided the public gaze, but his apparent suicide — joining the grim dead-at-27 roll-call that includes Amy Winehouse, Jim Morrison, Jimi Hendrix, Kurt Cobain and many others —
summary:

Sure, the wealthy community is home to Justin Bieber and Khloé Kardashian.

title: What’s on TV: Friday
text:
CRITICS’ CHOICE

Portillo’s Empire Journey (C5, 9pm)

What has happened to the former Thatcherite arch-patriot? Last week, briefed by Indian historians, he lambasted the East India Company and Raj for 200 years’ exploitation and carnage. Now, again with post-colonial chroniclers as interviewees, he gives an equally damning account of Britain’s slavery-scarred rule in Jamaica, from the 1655 ousting of Spain, to the Windrush and independence 300 years later. With less than an hour to tell the story (and too much on pirates and a bizarre meeting with Rastafarians), much is omitted; but even the fiercest anti-imperialist could not wish for a more critical verdict. John Dugdale

History 101 (Netflix)

Netflix belatedly serves up “bitesize history”, accounts of “scientific breakthroughs, social movements and world-changing discoveries” for

title: Trump’s #war on Twitter
text:
As so often with Donald Trump, it started with a tweet: “There is NO WAY (ZERO!) that Mail-In Ballots will be anything less than substantially fraudulent.”

The president was enraged last Tuesday by a plan in California, America’s biggest state, to ditch physical voting stations and shift the upcoming presidential ballot to an entirely postal operation to curb the spread of the coronavirus. Trump alleged that ballots would be stolen and forged on an epic scale. “This will be a Rigged Election,” he added.

Sponsored

There was little evidence to back up his claims: Justin Levitt of Loyola Law School in Los Angeles analysed more than one billion votes cast between 2000 and 2014. He found 31 incidents of identity fraud.

Twitter — which for years

Recalling his experience of Charterhouse, the poet Robert Graves wrote: “The opposite sex is despised and hated, treated as something obscene.” There is disturbing evidence that this still describes attitudes within independent schools in the 21st century. It is vital that schools are transparent and allow a full external investigation into allegations of sexual harassment of girls.

title: Survivors snubbed in BBC football abuse series
text:
An independent review called on clubs to provide compensation to victims who endured “incalculable” suffering

The BBC has shelved plans to highlight Scottish cases in a primetime series exposing sexual abuse in football, leading to anger from survivors.

Last week a report commissioned by the Scottish FA found that paedophiles infiltrated the national sport with ease and preyed on vulnerable boys and teenagers for more than three decades.

Sponsored

The Independent Review of Sexual Abuse in Scottish Football called on clubs, including Celtic, Rangers and Hibernian, to provide compensation and issue a “clear and unreserved” public apology to the dozens of victims who endured “incalculable” suffering.

Researchers working on a BBC 1 documentary series travelled to Scotland to speak to survivors of abuse at Celtic Boys Club after several senior figures at the feeder team were convicted for molesting young players.

title: Sexual abuse survivors want Dario Gradi to be stripped of MBE
text:
An independent review concluded that Gradi “should have done more” to investigate rumours circulating about Bennell

A support group representing the survivors of sexual abuse in football has written to the Cabinet Office demanding that Dario Gradi have his MBE taken away.

This week an independent review led by Clive Sheldon, QC, concluded that the former Crewe Alexandra manager “should have done more” to investigate rumours circulating about Barry Bennell, the now convicted paedophile who raped and abused young boys under the care of the club’s academy.

Sponsored

The FA confirmed for the first time that Gradi has been suspended indefinitely from football since 2016, with such bans in place when “a particular individual could potentially pose a risk of harm to children”. It is understood that Gradi’s ban concerns his apparent failure to recognise key safeguarding boundaries.

Gradi told The Times

title: Labour will vote against new law that gives more power to police
text:
Labour will vote against new crime legislation amid fears that it will give the police more powers to curb protests.

Sir Keir Starmer abandoned his intention to abstain after the police action at Clapham Common appeared likely to inflame a left-wing rebellion.

Sponsored

David Lammy, the shadow justice secretary, said that the killing of Sarah Everard had “instigated a national demand for action to tackle violence against women”, making it “no time to be rushing through poorly thought-out measures to impose disproportionate controls on free expression”.

Starmer said that the bill contained “almost nothing” about violence against women and girls LEON NEAL/GETTY IMAGES

title: Ireland indicates support for EU Council proposal to allow access to encrypted messages
text:
End-to-end encryption means that only the intended recipient can access the messages sent to them

The Irish government has indicated its support for an EU Council proposal that would seek to allow access to encrypted messaging services for security purposes.

Last week, an Austrian publication published a draft resolution from the EU Council on the matter. The resolution seeks to find a better balance between the security provided by encryption and the need for access to some communications made via apps which utilise the technology.

Sponsored

End-to-end encryption for messaging services such as Whatsapp and Signal means that only the intended recipient can access the messages sent to them. Nobody in between can read the messages.

The Times previously reported that Whatsapp admitted in private documents that it had no way to access encrypted messages.

The rise of encrypted messaging services
summary:
End-to-end encryption means that only the intended recipient can access the messages sent to themThe Irish government has indicated its support for an EU Council proposal that would seek to allow access to encrypted messaging services for security purposes.
Last week, an Austrian publication published a draft resolution from the EU Council on the matter.

title: Victoria Derbyshire on surviving abuse and why she loved I’m a Celebrity
text:
It took three days to wash the smell of fish guts out of her hair. Buckets of it had been poured over her head in a toxic blend of animal offal, blood and hoofs. For two and a half weeks the BBC News presenter Victoria Derbyshire slept in the ruins of a cold, damp Welsh castle sharing one primitive lavatory with a group of strangers. Food was scarce, the only thing to drink was water and they were hungry the entire time. But she loved every minute of it, telling millions of ITV viewers that it was the best thing that had happened to her besides getting married and giving birth to her two sons.

Ever since the ITV reality show I’m a Celebrity .
summary:
It took three days to wash the smell of fish guts out of her hair.
Buckets of it had been poured over her head in a toxic blend of animal offal, blood and hoofs.
Food was scarce, the only thing to drink was water and they were hungry the entire time.
But she loved every minute of it, telling millions of ITV viewers that it was the best thing that had happened to her besides getting married and giving birth to her two sons.
Ever since the ITV reality show I’m a Celebrity .

title: Schools on a mission to allay fears before Monday’s reopening
text:
Magdalen College School in Oxford has set up a station where pupils can take the test under supervision. Elsewhere staff keep up the standard of hygiene and implement social distancing measures

When children return to some schools on Monday they will see familiar faces in the makeshift testing bays — behind the masks of course. Former sixth-formers struggling to find jobs have been employed across schools at one academy trust to administer Covid tests to their old schoolmates.

It has the twofold impact of helping young people who are struggling during lockdown to earn money, and building trust among some suspicious communities that it is safe to be tested.

Sponsored

Schools are using every weapon in their armoury to reopen safely by making TikTok style videos and sending teachers on doorstep missions to convince children to have Covid tests and wear masks.

Tests have already begun in many secondary schools in England so teaching can start swiftly

Magdalen College School in Oxford has set up a station where pupils can take the test under supervision.
Elsewhere staff keep up the standard of hygiene and implement social distancing measuresWhen children return to some schools on Monday they will see familiar faces in the makeshift testing bays — behind the masks of course.

title: Give police a national vote, urges Sir Tom Winsor
text:
Sir Tom Winsor insisted that he was not calling for a national police force but that senior officers could vote on big issues to ensure cohesion

Plans for a US Congress-style voting system for police chiefs that will nationalise key policies and priorities has support in the Home Office, The Times understands.

Sir Tom Winsor, Her Majesty’s Chief Inspector of Constabulary, wants a new system in which strategies would be voted on before the decisions became binding for every police force.

Sponsored

He said that his proposed agreement would help police to operate as a “single and seamless system” despite the difficulties posed by the 43 forces in England and Wales. It will be viewed by some as a step towards a national force, although Sir Tom said that it did not require any boundary changes.

Chief constables are autonomous and cannot be told how to implement their powers, so forces
summary:
Sir Tom Winsor insisted that he was not calling for a national police force but that senior officers could vote on big issues to ensure cohesionPlans for a US Congress-style voting system for police chiefs that will nationalise key policies and priorities has support in the Home Office, The Times understands.

title: Ampleforth College: Catholic school in child abuse scandal fails new inspection
text:
Robin Dyer, the head, says Ampleforth has dropped its “defensive arrogance”

Ampleforth College, the Catholic school that is banned from taking new pupils after a child sex abuse scandal, has failed another Ofsted inspection.

The school said that the latest findings related to “procedural” issues rather than “horrific abuse”.

Sponsored

Ampleforth initially challenged the findings of an inspection in September before dropping its appeal. In November Gavin Williamson, the education secretary, ordered the North Yorkshire school not to take new pupils.

It was reinspected last month but a report published yesterday said that it still did not meet safeguarding standards, despite much improvement.

Ofsted said that inspectors agreed with two recent audits commissioned by the school that found weaknesses. One of the organisations that conducted the audit is giving daily support to the school, the report

title: Delay to Scottish child abuse inquiry was no whitewash, ex-leader says
text:
Lord McConnell of Glenscorrodale said decisions made about abuse survivors was to make sure officials did the right thing

Ministers were not trying to “cover things up” when they resisted calls for an inquiry into the physical and sexual abuse of children in care, a former first minister, has said.

Lord McConnell of Glenscorrodale, who was in office from 2001 to 2007, told the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry that any decisions taken were “trying to do the right things by survivors, and by those who might go into care in the future”.

Sponsored

He said: “The core decision was about trying to do the right thing — not to impress the public, or the parliament, or to cover things up. I think the majority of people involved were trying to achieve the right outcome.”

The latest phase of the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry, heard before

title: FA ‘guilty of inexcusable failure to protect children from sexual abuse’
text:
The Independent Review into Child Sexual Abuse in Football found that the FA acted too slowly to introduce sufficient child protection measure

The FA has apologised after a review found that “inexcusable institutional failures” meant children were not kept safe from sex abusers.

The independent review into child sex abuse in football between 1970 and 2005, led by Clive Sheldon, QC, found that eight professional clubs, including Manchester City, failed to take the right steps after concerns were raised about predatory coaches.

Sponsored

City released their own detailed review by Jane Mulcahy, QC, yesterday and apologised “publicly and unreservedly” to those who were abused by three individuals connected to the club. City are facing a compensation claim in the High Court in October from a lead group of eight survivors.

The Sheldon report criticised the FA’s delays in putting in place child-protection measures and failure to ban two
summary:

title: Lady Brittan says police ‘lacked moral spine’ on botched inquiry
text:
Lord Brittan died before he and his family including his wife were told the case had been dropped

The wife of Lord Brittan has accused Scotland Yard of a “culture of cover-up” over its botched inquiry into false rape allegations that resulted in her home being searched weeks after his death.

Lady Brittan said that the force lacked “a moral spine” after nobody lost their job or was punished over Operation Midland. Lord Brittan of Spennithorne was accused by Carl Beech, a convicted paedophile who would later be found guilty of making false allegations of rape and child abuse against public figures.

Beech was sentenced to 18 years in jail for perverting the course of justice and other offences in July 2019.

title: David Quinn: Turning a blind eye has secured Ireland UN success
text:
The United Nations is one of those organisations that Official Ireland likes to place on a pedestal. We have a deeply ingrained habit of doing this. We want to believe in something that embodies whatever our ideals happen to be at a given time, and are prepared to overlook its flaws, or even pretend they don’t exist. Our starry-eyed belief in the EU is a good example of that, and our misty-eyed view of the UN is another.

Last Friday, Ireland began a two-year term as non-permanent member of the UN security council. It is a moment of pride for the country, admittedly. The member states voted for candidates from different regional panels, and we were up against Norway and Canada. We were elected on
summary:
The United Nations is one of those organisations that Official Ireland likes to place on a pedestal.
We have a deeply ingrained habit of doing this.
Our starry-eyed belief in the EU is a good example of that, and our misty-eyed view of the UN is another.
Last Friday, Ireland began a two-year term as non-permanent member of the UN security council.
The member states voted for candidates from different regional panels, and we were up against Norway and Canada.

title: Foreign aid officials are accused of sexual abuse
text:
There has been a rise in the number of allegations after staff were encouraged to come forward

The Department for International Development has seen a rise in allegations of sexual abuse by its own staff and inside Britain’s aid charities.

The department was alerted to 26 allegations of “sexual exploitation, abuse and harassment” in 2019-20, amounting to one a fortnight. This was up from fewer than five cases the previous year.

Sponsored

Dfid published the figures as part of its annual report this week and claimed that they followed a “strong internal communications campaign” which encouraged staff to report their concerns.

There has also been a surge in the number of allegations reported by aid charities. A total of 452 allegations were reported by charities that work with Dfid in 2019-20, the report said.

Of these, 60 per cent were of sexual abuse
summary:

title: Three decades of abuse — inside the Larry Nassar scandal
text:
Nassar, right, was sentenced overall to more than 175 years in prison

In the video, the young gymnast steels herself, jaw set, eyes narrow. She launches into a sprint, cartwheels, springs into the air and somersaults before landing with a loud, visceral, wince-inducing crack. As she lies on the mat, heaving sobs from the pain, Larry Nassar runs to her. “Dr Larry Nassar on the floor,” the commentator says. “He keeps these women together.”

The year was 2011 and the USA Gymnastics (Usag) doctor was a highly respected medical authority who treated everyone from children in the state of Michigan, where he had trained and lived, to world-class Olympians. He was the man who bandaged the athletes so they could push through the pain to win gold; he was helping them.

Sponsored

What that commentator, and the audience

“Dr Larry Nassar on the floor,” the commentator says.
He was the man who bandaged the athletes so they could push through the pain to win gold; he was helping them.

title: ‘Safeguarding’ used to be the parents’ job

Simon Bailey, the chief constable of Norfolk, certainly is. In recent days, he has been all over the press, radio and television.

Raising the issue of sexual abuse of children by other children in the educational sector, Bailey has said, variously, that it’s “the next big national child sexual abuse scandal”, that the numbers on a website detailing examples of such abuse “are growing exponentially”, that this is “the tip of the iceberg” and that “this could be the biggest explosion of child sexual abuse since Jimmy Savile”. title: Our disjointed police forces cannot keep pace with modern crime
text:
The primary duty of the police is to prevent crime and disorder; that was Sir Robert Peel’s first principle of policing in 1829. It remains true today, and the high cost of failure is sometimes measured in lives shattered or lost.

Prevention is also high in the cold calculations of money spent on policing, the criminal justice system, health and social services.

Sponsored

The imperative is timeless but 191 years on from Peel’s Metropolitan Police, society is very different. So, too, are the means of offending, the reasons people commit crime and what we do with them.

The passions of money, violence, abuse and control will always be present, especially when fuelled by alcohol and drugs, despair and hopelessness. Many who offend are ill not bad,
summary:
The primary duty of the police is to prevent crime and disorder; that was Sir Robert Peel’s first principle of policing in 1829.
It remains true today, and the high cost of failure is sometimes measured in lives shattered or lost.
Prevention is also high in the cold calculations of money spent on policing, the criminal justice system, health and social services.
So, too, are the means of offending, the reasons people commit crime and what we do with them.
The passions of money, violence, abuse and control will always be present, especially when fuelled by alcohol and drugs, despair and hopelessness.

title: Ministers consider privacy law over access to child abuse records
text:
A vigil for people abused in Mother and Baby Homes. Records from the inquiry into them have been sealed

The Department of Education has said it must “consider legal issues” about access to records of the Ryan report under GDPR, appearing to contradict comments from the taoiseach.

The government said last week that the EU data privacy legislation would apply to records gathered by the Mother and Baby Homes Commission. That would mean that survivors could submit requests to access their personal data, which otherwise was to be sealed for 30 years.

Sponsored

Micheál Martin, the taoiseach, said on Wednesday that all survivors of institutional abuse would be able to access their personal data. title: Martin Callinan faces crime probe over ‘false’ evidence at Disclosures tribunal
text:
Martin Callinan, the former garda chief, could face prosecution for giving false or misleading evidence

The National Bureau of Criminal Investigation has launched an inquiry into whether former garda commissioner Martin Callinan should face prosecution for giving false or misleading evidence to the Disclosures tribunal.

Callinan is the first former commissioner to be placed under investigation in the history of the state.

Sponsored

Detectives from the bureau, which investigates serious crime and corruption, have already interviewed a number of witnesses. The gardai are preparing a file for the director of public prosecutions about the written and oral evidence Callinan gave to the tribunal, in which he denied any knowledge of a smear campaign against the garda whistleblower Maurice McCabe.

The tribunal rejected Callinan’s denials of involvement in the campaign, which included falsely accusing McCabe of being a child abuser.
summary:
Martin Callinan, the former garda chief, could face prosecution for giving false or misleading evidenceThe National Bureau of Criminal Investigation has launched an inquiry into whether former garda commissioner Martin Callinan should face prosecution for giving false or misleading evidence to the Disclosures tribunal.
Callinan is the first former commissioner to be placed under investigation in the history of the state.
SponsoredDetectives from the bureau, which investigates serious crime and corruption, have already interviewed a number of witnesses.

title: Education’s MeToo moment must be met with policy change
text:
I was 17 when the MeToo movement really got moving. Now I’m 21, and I can’t say it’s done much to change my life as a young woman in Britain: I’ve still been harassed at work and groped in nightclubs, as have almost all of my friends. So when Chief Constable Simon Bailey told The Times yesterday that the ongoing spate of private school sex abuse revelations is a “MeToo” moment for the education sector, I had to wonder what he meant.

In some ways, the comparison is apt. MeToo gained momentum through personal testimonies shared on Twitter, much in the same way that Everyone’s Invited has provided a virtual space for girls harassed at school to tell their stories. “Instagram justice” has changed who
summary:
I was 17 when the MeToo movement really got moving.
Now I’m 21, and I can’t say it’s done much to change my life as a young woman in Britain: I’ve still been harassed at work and groped in nightclubs, as have almost all of my friends.
So when Chief Constable Simon Bailey told The Times yesterday that the ongoing spate of private school sex abuse revelations is a “MeToo” moment for the education sector, I had to wonder what he meant.
In some ways, the comparison is apt.
MeToo gained momentum through personal testimonies shared on Twitter, much in the same way that Everyone’s Invited has provided a virtual space for girls harassed at school to tell their stories.

title: Pope was right to come out for gay unions
text:
Pope Francis, though probably not on purpose, chose a good moment for a bombshell. Pandemic anxiety, domestic confinement, separations and bereavements have made the world aware of what is good in life. The over-important, the frivolous and the priggishly doctrinaire have been reminded in lockdown months about the value of faithful partnership and honest love. And here is a pope defying Roman Catholic tradition by affirming, alongside broader condemnations of violence and degradation, that homosexual people as “children of God” have a right to family life and legal civil unions. In the same film he is seen encouraging two gay men to come to church with their three children.

Years ago in Buenos Aires he said much the same. Some are puzzled because then and
summary:
Pope Francis, though probably not on purpose, chose a good moment for a bombshell.
Pandemic anxiety, domestic confinement, separations and bereavements have made the world aware of what is good in life.
The over-important, the frivolous and the priggishly doctrinaire have been reminded in lockdown months about the value of faithful partnership and honest love.
And here is a pope defying Roman Catholic tradition by affirming, alongside broader condemnations of violence and degradation, that homosexual people as “children of God” have a right to family life and legal civil unions.
In the same film he is seen encouraging two gay men to come to church with their three children.

text:
The inquiry into historic abuse, chaired by Lady Smith, has already heard damning evidence about the neglect and brutality

Ministers past and present are to face a “grilling” in the latest public hearings of the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry.

The inquiry into historic abuse, chaired by Lady Smith, has already heard damning evidence about the neglect and brutality endured by young Scots over many decades.

Lord McConnell of Glenscorrodale, the former first minister, will give evidence this week, as will Cathy Jamieson, minister for education and young people and justice minister in his successive Labour governments. title: Julie Burchill’s book is ditched by publisher after her comments on Islam
text:
Julie Burchill’s new book criticising “woke culture” will no longer be published by Little, Brown after comments she made on Twitter

A forthcoming book by Julie Burchill, the writer and newspaper columnist, has been dropped by its publisher after she was accused of being Islamophobic on Twitter.

The book, Welcome to the Woke Trials: How #Identity killed progressive politics, was billed as a “characteristically irreverent and entertaining” indictment of the “outrage mob” and its impact on freedom of speech. However, the book itself appears to have become a casualty of the very forces it was describing, after Burchill’s remarks, deemed by many to be racist, caused outrage on Twitter.

Sponsored

Little, Brown, the publisher, announced it would not be publishing the book in April next year, as planned, after Burchill “crossed a line” by accusing Ash Sarkar, a left-wing commentator, of “worshipping a paedophile” because

text:
Detectives had traced him as part of an investigation into a paedophile network sharing child abuse images

A leading academic has been jailed after being caught with 60,000 images of child sexual abuse involving girls as young as ten.

Joseph Crawford had been a respected member of the School of Geography and Sustainable Development at the University of St Andrews. He had moved to Sheffield University but continued to travel back to Scotland.

Crawford amassed the collection over seven years, keeping it on a laptop and four USB sticks that were seized when police raided his home in Falkirk.

title: Independent watchdog to police abusive priests
text:
Measures set out by the Church were described as a “root and branch” overhaul

The Church of England has acknowledged that bishops cannot be trusted to investigate their own priests and will bring back “defrocking” to kick out paedophiles, in an overhaul of how sexual abuse cases are handled.

Bishops will be stripped of their powers to investigate and punish abuse cases after a critical report last autumn found that the church had harboured hundreds of paedophiles over almost 70 years and that allegations against priests had routinely been ignored, minimised or dismissed by church leaders.

Sponsored

The Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA) found that in many cases, abusive priests or bishops were allowed to continue their ministry for decades before finally facing justice, leaving their victims with no support or recognition.

Memory sticks containing more than 8,000 files, including images or videos showing the abuse of infants, children and adolescents, were also found during an investigation into the disappearance of a five-year-old German girl.

title: QAnon lies let real child abusers off the hook
text:
Decent people can be forgiven for innocently throwing their support behind what looks like a campaign to stop child sexual abuse. Who could possibly disagree with the spirit of the hashtag circulating on Twitter to #SaveOurChildren? But what lies behind this innocuous slogan is a baseless and harmful conspiracy theory pushed by followers of QAnon.

QAnon is a set of bizarre conspiracy theories that originated with the cryptic online posts of someone who goes by the alias Q and claims to be a high-ranking US government official. This Q is peddling the theory that the world is controlled by an elite cabal of paedophile movie stars and politicians who abuse and murder children in satanic rituals. Yes, really.

Sponsored

This theory originated on the fringes
summary:

As Donald Trump marks his last Christmas in office by handing out pardons to assorted political supporters, tricksters and killers, he is simultaneously presiding over a huge rise in executions before his term of office ends.

text:
The club have repeatedly distanced themselves from the convicted paedophile but links have been emerging

A prolific sexual predator organised lavish official events with guests including a future cardinal and a bishop to celebrate the careers of Celtic FC players, The Times can disclose.

Jim Torbett, founder of Celtic Boys Club, was found guilty of abusing boys between 1986 and 1994 and jailed for six years in 2018. He was given a two-year sentence a decade earlier for molesting players at the feeder club between 1967 and 1974.

It has now emerged that Torbett, 72, organised testimonial events for Tommy Burns, the former Celtic player, coach and manager, and Sean Fallon, a long-serving assistant manager and player, further undermining claims that Torbett had no connection with the Parkhead club.

Otherwise known as John McClean, an English teacher and rugby coach, “Doc” was jailed for eight years last month for sexually abusing 23 former pupils at the college. title: Ireland finally ratifies child abuse convention
text:
Helen McEntee, the justice minister, confirmed that the Lanzarote Convention would be ratified

The government is to finally ratify an international anti-child exploitation treaty a decade after it came into force, the justice minister has confirmed.

The Lanzarote Convention, a treaty co-ordinated by the Council of Europe, requires the criminalisation of all kinds of sexual offences against children. It was formally agreed in 2007, and came into force in 2010.

Sponsored

The convention sets out that states in Europe and beyond should adopt specific legislation and take measures to prevent sexual violence, to protect child victims and to prosecute perpetrators.

All 47 members of the Council of Europe, which includes countries, including Russia, that are not in the EU, agreed to the convention. According to the fifth annual report on the implementation of the treaty, published in October last

text:

Girls face a growing risk of grooming from predators who bully them into filming sexual acts at home and posting them online, an internet safety organisation says.

text:

title: Bernie Ecclestone celebrates birth of fourth child at age 89
text:
Bernie Ecclestone and Fabiana Flosi, his wife, have named their baby boy Ace

Bernie Ecclestone, the billionaire former Formula 1 boss, is a father for the fourth time at the age of 89.

Ecclestone’s wife Fabiana Flosi, 44, gave birth yesterday to a boy whom the couple have named Ace. Ms Flosi said that the labour “was all so easy”. She added: “The birth was over after 25 minutes. I thank God.”

Sponsored

Ace, Ecclestone’s first son, is 31 years younger than his half-sister, Petra. Ecclestone’s eldest daughter, Deborah, 65, was born to his first wife Ivy Bamford. Petra and his second daughter, Tamara, 35, were born to his second wife, Slavica Radic, a Croatian model.

Ecclestone and Ms Flosi, a marketing director, married in 2012, after meeting at the FIA World Motor Sport Council. They started lockdown

Scottish football clubs face paying millions of pounds in compensation and should make an “unreserved and public apology” to victims of historical sexual abuse within the game.

Two years ago Manchester City announced plans to offer millions in compensation to victims of historical child sexual abuse,

title: Our fixation with true crime stories condemns grieving relatives to a never‑ending sentence
text:
In the early hours of July 15, 2001, a 27-year-old travel agent from Huddersfield was found on a desolate road north of Alice Springs, in the Northern Territory of Australia, by lorry drivers. Her hands were tied and she was terrified. For anyone who was old enough to remember, what followed is well known. Joanne Lees said her boyfriend, Peter Falconio, had been shot by a man who had tried to abduct her before she escaped into the bush.

A huge police investigation was launched; Lees herself became a suspect before, in 2005, Bradley Murdoch, a former drug-runner who had previously been accused of rape and abduction, was found guilty of Falconio’s murder — his DNA was found on Lees’s clothes. Murdoch is in prison
summary:
In the early hours of July 15, 2001, a 27-year-old travel agent from Huddersfield was found on a desolate road north of Alice Springs, in the Northern Territory of Australia, by lorry drivers.
Her hands were tied and she was terrified.

Joanne Lees said her boyfriend, Peter Falconio, had been shot by a man who had tried to abduct her before she escaped into the bush.
Murdoch is in prison

title: Directory of inquiries: how much government probes are costing the Irish taxpayer
text:
As the economy reels from the pandemic and the threat of a no-deal Brexit, one sector continues to thrive: the state inquiries industry. Eleven current tribunals of inquiry, commissions of investigation and ministerial case reviews have run up a collective bill of €106.8m.

That figure is set to grow as it does not include the legal costs of third parties in such commissions as the Nama, IBRC and “Grace” inquiries. Nor does it include any of the costs of a review established last May to examine the 1969 involuntary retirement of Donal de Róiste from the Defence Forces, as no invoices for the work have yet been submitted.

text:
