Almost 5,600 incidents of domestic abuse have been recorded by gardaí in the past two months in a surge of cases linked to Covid-19 restrictions on people’s movement.

New figures provided by An Garda Síochána show gardaí have dealt with 5,592 cases of individuals who have been the subject of domestic abuse since Operation Faoiseamh, the Garda’s dedicated domestic violence operation during lockdown, was launched on April 1.

title: NHS clinic sounds alert over obsessive child videogamers
text:
Ten-year-olds are being referred to the NHS’s first clinic to treat addiction to videogames as parents struggle to limit children’s screen time.

The founder of the National Centre for Gaming Disorders said that young patients were spending up to 14 hours a day on games such as Fortnite and Minecraft, and some had shown such extreme levels of addiction that they had violently abused their parents, self-harmed or threatened suicide when their consoles were taken away. title: Lawyer of the week: Brian Altman, QC, lead counsel to sex abuse inquiry
text:
Brian Altman, QC, at 2 Bedford Row, is lead counsel to the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse. Its public hearings, which have now ended, have led to 53 recommendations of ways to protect children from sexual abuse. The inquiry was set up in 2015 and will publish its final report in 2022.

What were the main issues in this inquiry?

The inquiry’s terms of reference are to consider past institutional failures to protect children from sexual abuse and exploitation. Its central axiom has been to put victims and survivors at the heart of its work. We hope we’ve achieved it.

Sponsored

Brian Altman

What is the best decision you have taken as a lawyer?

Agreeing to join the inquiry in 2017. It was a wonderful opportunity to
summary:
Brian Altman, QC, at 2 Bedford Row, is lead counsel to the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse.
Its public hearings, which have now ended, have led to 53 recommendations of ways to protect children from sexual abuse.
The inquiry was set up in 2015 and will publish its final report in 2022.
The inquiry’s terms of reference are to consider past institutional failures to protect children from sexual abuse and exploitation.
Its central axiom has been to put victims and survivors at the heart of its work.

Second, the legal advice was in fact released for the Scottish child abuse, infected blood and Edinburgh trams inquiries — so there is plenty of precedent for doing so.

text:
The teenage sons of the BBC presenter Victoria Derbyshire have used her Twitter feed to urge victims of domestic abuse to seek help, after their mother suffered years of violence from her father.

Ollie, 16, and Joe, 13, are in charge of their mother’s social media accounts while she is a contestant on the ITV reality programme I’m a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here!, being held in the grounds of a castle in Wales.

title: How ethical investing can be good for your portfolio
text:
The concept of investing ethically has been around for years but has moved into the mainstream lately as consumers have become more socially and ethically aware and demanding. But it is an all-encompassing term that does not really sum up what the movement is about.

Ethical investment can mean different things. The most obvious is investing in causes that concern people.

Sponsored

That could be saving the planet, cutting down on human suffering, protecting wildlife or countless other causes that people can be very passionate about. But ethical investing can also be about avoiding companies and sectors that people may consider harmful, such as the arms industry, oil giants or firms that exploit workers or suppliers.

It can also be about investing in those areas to

title: Eric Joyce: Ex-Labour MP faces prison over child abuse footage of baby
text:
A former MP and army officer is facing a jail sentence after he admitted making an indecent image of children as young as one.

Eric Joyce, 59, of Worlingworth, Suffolk, pleaded guilty yesterday to possessing a film on an electronic device that depicted several children.

Sponsored

He was the Labour MP for Falkirk between 2000 and 2012 and then sat as an independent until 2015. Joyce had spent 21 years in the army, rising to the rank of major. He was arrested in November 2018.

Judge Emma Peters at Ipswich crown court said the single 51-second film “depicts a number of children”. She added that “some are quite young, one is said to be 12 months old”, which was classed as a category-A offence.

She said
summary:
A former MP and army officer is facing a jail sentence after he admitted making an indecent image of children as young as one.
Eric Joyce, 59, of Worlingworth, Suffolk, pleaded guilty yesterday to possessing a film on an electronic device that depicted several children.
SponsoredHe was the Labour MP for Falkirk between 2000 and 2012 and then sat as an independent until 2015.
Joyce had spent 21 years in the army, rising to the rank of major.

title: Too many questions left unanswered for abuse victims let down by football
text:
Four men are on a Zoom call, each with stories so harrowing that it took decades before they could find the words. For Colin Harris, it still pains him to recall hearing his mum ask, ‘What’s happened to our little boy?’ almost 50 years ago. He never could tell her what had transformed him from a promising Chelsea apprentice into a man who talks now of a “long shadow over your life, a very dark shadow”.

Gary Cliffe talks of decades of medication for depression and anxiety, and how sexual abuse at the hands of Barry Bennell when he was a youth player at Manchester City is one reason that he has not brought children into the world.

Also on the call are two more

title: A sibling is not ‘a relevant person’ in relation to a child
text:
Supreme Court

Published July 16, 2020

ABC v Principal Reporter and another

In re XY

Before Baroness Hale of Richmond, Lord Kerr of Tonaghmore, Lord Wilson, Lord Hodge and Lady Arden

[2020] UKSC 26

Judgment June 18, 2020

It was not a breach of the right to family life of a sibling that he was not entitled to the same status as a “relevant person” as parents were when, in Scotland, a children’s hearing was deciding whether to make a compulsory supervision order in relation to a child.

The Supreme Court so held in dismissing appeals against two decisions of the Inner House of the Court of Session (Lord Carloway, Lord President, Lord Drummond Young and Lord Malcolm) in challenges to refusals to make them

title: Ruth Davidson ‘fatherless child’ comments are my free speech, insists teacher
text:
A private school teacher who criticised Ruth Davidson for having a “fatherless child” has defended his comments by saying gay relationships are “undesirable”.

Richard Lucas, a former physics teacher at the £35,000-a-year Merchiston Castle School in Edinburgh, made the controversial comments on a video he posted to his YouTube channel.

title: Times letters: Online teaching and the reform of universities
text:
Sir, Nathan Schultz (Thunderer, Oct 26) recommends that British universities should consider permanently moving much of their teaching online. Before our vice- chancellors rush to follow his advice it is worth digging a little deeper. British universities did re-open and are offering mixed learning that is largely online but with practical sessions face-to-face. I am working with colleagues to provide fieldwork training to 80 second-year geologists, and they are successfully, and safely, working in small groups, out of doors, and catching up on all the missed practical skills from the end of the last academic year.

Students are missing the social experiences of university at the moment but they would be missing social encounters if we had cancelled the year and they were all sitting
summary:

Before our vice- chancellors rush to follow his advice it is worth digging a little deeper.
British universities did re-open and are offering mixed learning that is largely online but with practical sessions face-to-face.
I am working with colleagues to provide fieldwork training to 80 second-year geologists, and they are successfully, and safely, working in small groups, out of doors, and catching up on all the missed practical skills from the end of the last academic year.

title: Child abuse inquiry looks at government’s hesitation
text:
The Scottish child abuse inquiry chaired by Judge Lady Smith will look at why earlier calls for a public inquiry were turned down

The Scottish child abuse inquiry will examine why calls for a public inquiry were initially turned down by the Scottish government.

Hearings which begin in November will look at the actions of the government between August 2002 and December 2014.

Sponsored

It will examine why calls for a public inquiry during this period were turned down. It will also consider petition PE535, which was lodged with the Public Petitions Committee at Holyrood in August 2002 and called for an inquiry into past institutional child abuse and for an “unreserved apology” from the then Scottish executive.

The inquiry was announced by ministers in December 2014.

Hearings will take place in Edinburgh with social-distancing measures in place and are expected to conclude in early December. It is being
summary:

title: TV reviews: Line of Duty; Keeping Up with the Kardashians; The Detectives; The Flight Attendant
text:
What was the overriding emotion as you watched the frantic first episode of the sixth series of Line of Duty? Was it a feeling of awe and bedazzlement that they had managed to recreate the first episode of the fifth series in quite such loving detail? If I remember rightly the last series also began with exactly the same tense convoy of police cars on the way to some inevitably botched operation. It also included last-minute throat-clutching drama in which some unexpected vehicle/event conveniently distracted the head of the convoy at a clinch moment.

title: Young lives have shrunk to the size of a screen
text:
Two weeks into home-schooling my teenage daughter, we have fallen back into a routine first established last spring. Every day begins with me shouting at her to get out of bed and turn on her laptop for school work. Every day ends with me shouting at her to put her phone down. In between, she spends at least 16 hours hooked up to the internet and staring into a device.

Once we worried about what children got up to online. Anxious parents shared tips for limiting screen time. Articles were written about the damage too much exposure to blue light could inflict upon children’s eyes. There was concern that the growth of online gaming was making youngsters more sedentary. Most of all, we worried about
summary:
Two weeks into home-schooling my teenage daughter, we have fallen back into a routine first established last spring.
Every day begins with me shouting at her to get out of bed and turn on her laptop for school work.
Every day ends with me shouting at her to put her phone down.
In between, she spends at least 16 hours hooked up to the internet and staring into a device.
Articles were written about the damage too much exposure to blue light could inflict upon children’s eyes.

title: Soma Sara: ‘Teenage sexual abuse didn’t merely exist when I was at school, it thrived’
text:
Soma Sara spent some of her school holidays in London, where “disgusting behaviour was trivialised — it could be coercion, rape, catcalling, sexual bullying”

Scroll down the testimonials on @everyonesinvited and weep. Eleven-year-olds forced to send nude photos to older boys, 13-year-olds molested in front of cheering pupils in parks, 15-year-olds coerced into having sex at parties, hundreds of children’s desperate stories of rape culture, harassment, assault and sexual humiliation. This is Britain in 2021.

No individual is singled out but the schools named include famous single-sex ones such as St Paul’s School and Harrow, as well as mixed-sex schools such as Latymer Upper School in west London, Wellington College and Bedales, grammar schools and state secondary schools. Students at university have also started posting their experiences at Edinburgh, Exeter, Manchester and Newcastle. This Instagram campaign highlighting teenage sexual abuse has gone viral.

title: Grant Thornton Ireland washes hands of Pornhub subsidiaries that use its Dublin HQ address
text:
The Irish branch of one of the world’s biggest accountancy firms has said it will end an eight-year business relationship with the Irish subsidiaries of Pornhub after recent accusations that illegal content was hosted on the Canadian company’s websites.

Grant Thornton, whose headquarters in City Quay, Dublin, has been used as the office address for 11 of Pornhub’s Irish companies, said it would seek to “disengage” from its client after being contacted by The Sunday Times last week. Since 2012, Grant Thornton has provided an office address and audited the annual accounts for Irish subsidiaries of MindGeek, the Montreal-based owner of Pornhub, the most-used adult site on the internet, and a variety of other pornographic websites.

title: ‘Children abused in bid to make Empire white’
text:
One of the “recurring themes” brought out in the inquiry was the sense of isolation felt by transported children

Many children who emigrated from Scotland to British colonies suffered a “catalogue of abuse” as governments tried to ensure “the Empire was populated by white British stock”, according to an inquiry’s senior counsel.

Colin MacAulay, QC, gave his closing remarks to the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry yesterday, setting out his interpretation of evidence gathered during the child migrant case study.

Sponsored

Mr MacAulay said: “Many child migrants experience a catalogue of sexual abuse, physical abuse, deprivation, inadequate education and many other forms of abuse. There was a desire to ensure that the Empire was populated by white British stock.

“It may be the case that sectarian motives entered, particularly with the Catholic Church in Scotland.”

Judge Lady Smith, chairwoman of the inquiry, described Father William Nicol

title: German paedophile is new suspect in Madeleine McCann case
text:
Madeleine McCann was three when she was abducted from her family’s holiday apartment in Praia da Luz, Portugal, in 2007

A German paedophile was identified last night as the key suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann in the most significant breakthrough in the inquiry since she vanished 13 years ago.

The serving prisoner is thought to have been in the Algarve resort where Madeleine was abducted from her bed shortly before her fourth birthday in May 2007. He is alleged to have discussed her disappearance in an internet chatroom.

Sponsored

German police said that they were investigating the murder of Madeleine and described the 43-year-old suspect as a “multiple criminal sex offender, who has also been convicted of child sexual abuse”.

He is believed to have burgled hotel and holiday rental properties and trafficked drugs while living in the Algarve between 1995 and 2007.

Christian

title: Times letters: Parents, schools and responsibility for abuse
text:
Sir, I went to a similar prep school in the 1960s as described by Louis de Bernières (News & letter, Mar 31). At that time most schools believed in corporal punishment. There was a strong belief that one needed to be toughened up at prep school to survive public school. Homesickness is an intense sadness at any age, but it did teach me how life can be unpleasant and how one has to deal with it. It is wrong to assume every child at boarding school in this period was unhappy, or every master sadistic or perverted because he believed in the merits of corporal punishment.

Parents have different concerns for their children today, and only time will reveal their mistakes made for the best
summary:
Sir, I went to a similar prep school in the 1960s as described by Louis de Bernières (News & letter, Mar 31).
At that time most schools believed in corporal punishment.
There was a strong belief that one needed to be toughened up at prep school to survive public school.
Homesickness is an intense sadness at any age, but it did teach me how life can be unpleasant and how one has to deal with it.
Parents have different concerns for their children today, and only time will reveal their mistakes made for the best

He met Lois, a school teacher, in 2002 and a year later she became his second wife.
However, a church misconduct hearing was told that before the wedding he accused her of cheating on him and called her a “slag” and a “cheap whore”.

title: Caitlin Moran: me and my revolting daughters
text:
I remember my father’s confusion when, in the mid-Nineties, the incoming tide of Britpop resurrected all the things from his teenage years. After decades of punk, synthesizers and acid house, suddenly his teenage daughter and her mates were all into the Beatles and the Beach Boys, Mod parkas, Minis, and minis, and The Italian Job.

“Why are you digging up all of our old stuff?” he would half-complain, half-jeer, as Carnaby Street started to “swing” again, and men I knew scoured vintage shops to, very possibly, buy the old trousers he’d given away in 1969. “The point was that, when we were doing it, it was new: we were rebelling against our parents. You guys can’t rebel by doing something old. You
summary:
I remember my father’s confusion when, in the mid-Nineties, the incoming tide of Britpop resurrected all the things from his teenage years.
After decades of punk, synthesizers and acid house, suddenly his teenage daughter and her mates were all into the Beatles and the Beach Boys, Mod parkas, Minis, and minis, and The Italian Job.
“Why are you digging up all of our old stuff?” he would half-complain, half-jeer, as Carnaby Street started to “swing” again, and men I knew scoured vintage shops to, very possibly, buy the old trousers he’d given away in 1969.
“The point was that, when we were doing it, it was new: we were rebelling against our parents.
You guys can’t rebel by doing something old.

title: Woman raped by priest set to sue over Catholic Church’s response
text:
A woman sexually abused by a priest has threatened legal action against the Catholic church after officials branded her “needy” and “manipulative”.

The abuse, and later rape, began when she was 15 and continued for years. She reported her allegations to the church in 2016 and received a settlement in 2018.

Sponsored

It is understood that the woman has sent a letter threatening legal action on the grounds of personal injury after alleging she was “re-traumatised” at the hands of safeguarding staff when she disclosed the abuse.

The case is against the Archdiocese of Westminster, of which Cardinal Vincent Nichols, leader of the Catholic church in England and Wales, is head. It is understood that Nichols is named repeatedly in the letter. No personal legal liability
summary:
A woman sexually abused by a priest has threatened legal action against the Catholic church after officials branded her “needy” and “manipulative”.
SponsoredIt is understood that the woman has sent a letter threatening legal action on the grounds of personal injury after alleging she was “re-traumatised” at the hands of safeguarding staff when she disclosed the abuse.
The case is against the Archdiocese of Westminster, of which Cardinal Vincent Nichols, leader of the Catholic church in England and Wales, is head.
It is understood that Nichols is named repeatedly in the letter.
No personal legal liability

title: Sex abuse in Scottish football: Rangers apologise to victims
text:
The club’s statement comes after a review commissioned by the SFA ordered clubs to make an “unequivocal and unreserved” apology to survivors of abuse

Rangers FC has apologised to all victims of abuse “within Scottish football” weeks after being urged to do so by authors of an official report into sexual misconduct against children.

An independent review commissioned by the Scottish FA ordered clubs who had failed to protect young players to offer an “unequivocal and unreserved” apology to survivors.

Sponsored

The report, published last month, unmasked Gordon Neely, Rangers’ former head of youth development, as a prolific paedophile.

It found he had sexually assaulted at least three teenagers at Ibrox before being sacked in 1991.

Neely had molested other young players at Hibernian and Hutchison Vale, an Edinburgh youth side, before joining Rangers in 1986.

The Scottish FA, Motherwell, Hibernian, Falkirk, Partick Thistle, the Highland league club Forres

title: Stop Bloody Bossing Me About by Quentin Letts review — waging war on the finger-waggers
text:
People walking past my house and hearing loud rhythmic grunts coming through the window know what I’m doing — voicing loud assent to every sentence written by Quentin Letts, who rants very eloquently about Greta Thunberg (“moody little madam”), the National Trust (stately homes turned into “kiddies’ play areas”), schools that ban pop guns (because they “symbolise aggression”) and the “bossocracy” who have put a stop to drinking straws, dirty weekends in Barcelona and fox hunting (“an act of political spite against Barbour-wearers”), to name only a few targets.

The forebears of our contemporary scene, as Letts sees it, would be Oliver Cromwell, who stamped out revelry, Mary Whitehouse, who didn’t like swearing, and Barbara Woodhouse, who house-trained spaniels. Everywhere pusillanimity and finger-wagging reigns.

Sponsored

Nurseries
summary:

title: Demonising boys won’t change toxic culture
text:
Three weeks ago, my teenage daughter mentioned that her Instagram feed was suddenly full of testimonies from girls talking about appalling sexual abuse they had suffered at school and university. “Read them and weep,” she said, “it’s even worse than I thought.” I was horrified. One of my teenage sons had also seen postings on Everyone’s Invited. “It’s barbaric,” he said.

I eventually tracked down the website’s founder, Soma Sara, who lives with her grandmother in Paris; the 22-year-old was polite, charming and quietly spoken but determined. She’d been trying for nine months to get people to listen to her and her friends’ stories of rape culture. It was only when she started to mention schools by name that Everyone’s Invited went viral on

title: Colonel Killology, David Grossman, is not sheepish about turning US police into wolves
text:
Heavily armed state patrol officers in Minneapolis enforcing a curfew after protests over the death of George Floyd

Revered by some, loathed by others, David Grossman has lost count of how many police officers he has taught “killology” — his psychology of killing — over the past two decades.

America’s most prolific police trainer travels across the country instructing officers how to harness their inner predator and be prepared to use “righteous violence”.

Sponsored

The coronavirus lockdowns have stopped him working while America churns with protests over police killings of black men and women. But threatening emails blame him for the deaths. “You are responsible for a culture of killing among police in this country,” said one.

“So you’re the bitch-ass cop instructor who’s been teaching white cops to kill black people for over 20 years,” said another.

In Grossman’s world, criminals are wolves
summary:
America’s most prolific police trainer travels across the country instructing officers how to harness their inner predator and be prepared to use “righteous violence”.

title: Calls for state inspection of private schools after abuse scandals
text:
Pupils protest this week at Highgate School in north London, which was the subject of a dossier containing 220 testimonies of peer-on-peer sexual harassment and rape

Private school inspections should be overhauled after a series of sexual abuse and harassment scandals, the chairman of the education select committee has said.

Robert Halfon made the comments in response to allegations of abuse across the private school sector. Meanwhile, Dulwich College was said to have threatened pupils with disciplinary action if they joined a planned protest yesterday after some students were reported to police over allegations of sexual harassment.

title: ‘Many people were damaged by Carl Beech’
text:
Vanessa Engle has built a reputation on asking straight questions about knotty subjects. Engle’s television documentaries on the art world, Jews, lefties, Harley Street and domestic violence have been marked out by humanity, curiosity and her disarming, direct interviewing style. The British journalist’s new film, though, is perhaps the most disturbing of her 30-year career. The Unbelievable Story of Carl Beech is one of those rare titles that’s not an exaggeration.

In 2012 Beech, a hospital inspector in his forties from Gloucester, claimed to police that he had been abused, raped and tortured as a boy in the late Seventies and early Eighties by a paedophile ring that included the politicians Edward Heath, Leon Brittan and Harvey Proctor and the senior army officer Lord Bramall.
summary:
Vanessa Engle has built a reputation on asking straight questions about knotty subjects.
Engle’s television documentaries on the art world, Jews, lefties, Harley Street and domestic violence have been marked out by humanity, curiosity and her disarming, direct interviewing style.
The British journalist’s new film, though, is perhaps the most disturbing of her 30-year career.
The Unbelievable Story of Carl Beech is one of those rare titles that’s not an exaggeration.
In 2012 Beech, a hospital inspector in his forties from Gloucester, claimed to police that he had been abused, raped and tortured as a boy in the late Seventies and early Eighties by a paedophile ring that included the politicians Edward Heath, Leon Brittan and Harvey Proctor and the senior army officer Lord Bramall.

title: £4m paid to victims of child abuse
text:
The early payout scheme is aimed at victims of child abuse who are now over 68 or have a terminal illness

More than 400 victims of historic child abuse in care have shared about £4 million in payouts from the Scottish government.

In April 2019, the Advance Payment Scheme was launched, promising £10,000 to those who were abused in care before 2004 and aged over 68 years old or with a terminal illness.

Sponsored

The initiative was put in place ahead of a statutory redress scheme, which is expected to pass the Scottish parliament in March 2021. The advance scheme was set up to ensure that older sufferers of abuse will be able to access the payments while younger victims will be able to access the financial redress in the wider scheme.

John Swinney, the deputy first minister, said: “While clearly nothing can take away the pain

text:
One of the country’s most senior police officers has said he believes that schools have covered up sexual offences to protect their reputations as a task force took charge of the surge in abuse complaints.

Chief Constable Simon Bailey told The Times that the outpouring of allegations was the education sector’s “MeToo” moment and that he feared a “culture of misogyny and sexual harassment” had not been challenged in some schools.

Sponsored

Bailey is the lead officer for Operation Hydrant, the national task force for child sexual abuse investigations in institutions. It will assess allegations of abuse in schools before they are given to individual forces to investigate, with a national hotline for abuse reports to be set up within 72 hours.

title: Counsel children and let them transition as adults
text:
Keira Bell, whose case was heard in the UK, regrets her decision to take puberty blockers

Like Brenda Power, it astounds me that allowing or encouraging young people to take chemical agents to change their body is not regarded as child abuse (“Give children more time, not puberty blockers”, Comment, last week).

As a parent, I would be rightly censured for permitting my child to take drugs or alcohol that would harm them, no matter how much they implored me.

Sponsored

Counselling children until they reach the age of legal agency should be the approach. Then the adult can decide for themselves.

Pauline O’Driscoll, Westcliff-On-Sea, Essex



Sniping attack

Power claims to be motivated by concern for children, yet I could find no ounce of kindness, no attempt at understanding, no iota of empathy in her words. Instead she engaged in vicious sniping

title: Imran Khan’s hypocrisy betrays Pakistan’s voters
text:
Imran Khan, the former cricketer and professional playboy turned prime minister of Pakistan, is a staggering hypocrite. Khan, who spent his youth in Britain partying in the company of glamorous and often scantily clad women, now blames the way women dress for a rise in rape cases across Pakistan. Khan’s ridiculous advice to women is to cover up to prevent men being tempted, along the lines of the Islamic concept of purdah or modesty, which often involves segregation of the sexes.

Khan’s views, seemingly devoid of any self-awareness, range far and wide in their ignorance. Sexual violence is apparently the fault of societies “where vulgarity is on the rise”, by which he means places like Britain; Hollywood and Indian cinema’s obsession with “increasing obscenity”

title: Anne-Marie Hutchinson obituary
text:
If not for Anne-Marie Hutchinson, the High Court might never have heard the case of K, a British Sikh girl who one day vanished. K’s sister, ostracised from her family for entering into a relationship of which they disapproved, asked around her community to find out where K had gone. She was convinced that her parents had sent K to India to force her into marriage. Sure enough, she received a letter from K, telling her that she was imprisoned in a relative’s house in India and about to be married against her will.

K’s sister approached Hutchinson, a solicitor at Dawson Cornwell, in the hope of obtaining a court order to have her returned to Britain before the marriage could take place. Hutchinson knew

Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen wants to talk about falling in love under lockdown. His marriage to Jackie, his wife of more than 30 years, is as solid as ever. What’s on his mind is a rekindled passion for his Gloucestershire manor house.

text:
The long-running British soap opera Emmerdale has landed itself in hot water because a forthcoming episode features a couple deciding to abort a child diagnosed with Down’s syndrome. This has outraged families who have children with this condition, and for good reason.

As Wendy O’Carroll, the founder of UK support charity Ups and Downs, said in an open letter to Emmerdale: “Your proposed story will further serve to encourage and confirm the opinion that ending the life of a baby just because it has Down’s syndrome is perfectly acceptable and understandable because maybe it would be better if fewer people ‘like them’ were in the world.”

title: Oxford college president Dinah Rose under pressure over gay marriage case in Cayman Islands
text:
The president of Magdalen College was accused of representing “homophobia in the Caribbean” after it emerged that she was leading legal efforts to block gay marriage in the Cayman Islands.

Dinah Rose, a renowned human rights barrister, was forced to defend her decision to appear on behalf of the authorities of the British overseas territory as they take their battle to prohibit gay marriage to the privy council. One critic called the QC’s role in the case a “stain” on the reputation of the 563-year-old Oxford college that was once home to Oscar Wilde.

Two years ago Anthony Smellie, the chief justice of the Cayman Islands, ruled that the ban on gay marriage was unconstitutional after a challenge from Chantelle Day and her British partner

title: Viggo Mortensen: Lord of the Rings hottie to director of arthouse film Falling
text:
The Lord of the Rings movie trilogy was many things for many people. For Tolkien fans it was a breathtaking adaptation. For Hollywood bean counters it was an eye-watering payday (almost $3 billion at the box office). For fantasy film nerds it was proof that silly costumes, magical powers and wacky creatures could dominate the multiplex (it paved the way for Marvel’s ascendancy). For Viggo Mortensen, who played the trilogy’s sword-wielding hero Aragorn over 14 months of principal photography in New Zealand and three subsequent years of sporadic reshoots, it was much simpler than that. It was film school.

“On a practical level, that’s what it was,” the 62-year-old Danish-American actor says today, still infuriatingly chiselled, even on a blurry Zoom link from his home
summary:

text:
Fabinho joins Van Dijk and Matip on the treatment table at Melwood

Liverpool’s defensive crisis deepened last night as Fabinho was taken off 30 minutes into their Champions League group-stage victory over Midtjylland with a hamstring injury.

Jürgen Klopp must await scans and tests on his stand-in central defender this morning as he faces the prospect of going into Saturday’s clash against West Ham United with either teenager Rhys Williams or unknown academy product Nate Phillips, 23, experiencing their first taste of Premier League football.

title: Eggs . . . you resigned over eggs, Edwina? My, how times change
text:
Once upon a time, when the nation wasn’t so obsessed with pubs and shopping that they could see little else, we expected “honesty and integrity at the very top”, as Ted Hastings would say, and did say. I trust Ted and do not believe he is “H”. Unless he is. But he isn’t. Unless he is. (He isn’t*.)

Honesty and integrity at the very top seems rather quaint. In fact there’s been such a shift under the current government, past scandals seem rather quaint too. Why did we ever get our knickers in such a twist? Make such a fuss? You wonder if Michael Mates, say, casts his eyes over the day’s headlines and gasps: “I had to resign as a minister in Her Majesty’s
summary:

title: The books that made us cry, from A Little Life to Never Let Me Go
text:
TikTok, the video sharing app that is quickly becoming the social media of choice for those under 25, is most often credited with popularising dance moves and music styles such as K-pop or, bizarrely, sea shanties. But books, too, can go viral on TikTok, it turns out. “BookTok” is apparently a thing (although we’re far too old and uncool to know much about it) and the key to BookTok fame is to film yourself crying over a book. So, in a probably ill-fated attempt to be down with the kids, here are some of our favourite tear-jerking books.

This Booker-shortlisted tale of four college friends is a literary soap opera. Car crashes, spousal abuse, sickness, child abuse... you name it, the characters endure it as

title: What inspired a band of women warriors to help defeat Isis?
text:
A soldier of the YPJ preparing for conflict with Isis. Anna Campbell, left, was a British activist who died on the battlefield in 2018 during an operation by the Turkish military

For four months the women fought furiously, day and night, to oust the Islamic State militia from the town of Kobani in northern Syria. The Isis troops dug in with tanks, artillery and Humvees. The all-female Kurdish Women’s Defence Units had no such weapons: clad in camouflage green, they fought with old Russian Kalashnikovs, handmade grenades and rudimentary artillery platforms, cobbled from construction vehicles and pick-up trucks. American special forces were awed by the bravery of these female warriors.

Finally, on January 26, 2015, the Isis forces retreated, leaving an estimated 2,000 dead on the battlefield. The women and their male Kurdish comrades-in-arms danced the traditional dabke among the ruins and burnt-out Isis tanks.

Sponsored

The siege of Kobani is seen as a turning point in
summary:
A soldier of the YPJ preparing for conflict with Isis.
The Isis troops dug in with tanks, artillery and Humvees.
American special forces were awed by the bravery of these female warriors.
Finally, on January 26, 2015, the Isis forces retreated, leaving an estimated 2,000 dead on the battlefield.

title: Will bongo man and his friends stop banging on?
text:
Before the police began their idiocy, when the Clapham vigil was just hundreds of sad women standing quietly or laying flowers, there was the bongo man. Up on the bandstand he drummed on and on, like a migraine. Whenever a woman stood to speak, he’d bang along, interpreting her words through the medium of bongo.

It was maddening. Just for once, I thought, can’t men stand back and read the room. A woman is dead, other women feel her fate deep in their bones. They have come here in grief and solidarity. Let women set the tone.

Sponsored

title: Brenda Power: Nuns simply do as society asks, so now they take the blame for mother and baby homes
text:
In my convent primary school, there was an elderly, retired sister who would occasionally fill in for our usual kindly nun. That was never a good day. She was hard-faced and cross — in my memory she looks a bit like Samuel Beckett in a wimple — and as she took her seat after morning prayers, she’d place a gnarled knuckle of a furze branch, about a foot long, prominently on her desk. And she would use this, instead of the ruler our usual teacher favoured, to slap us for talking or for not knowing an answer; as little girls aged 8-12, those were the very worst of our transgressions.

The stick, which I often got to see up close, intrigued me. I imagined her
summary:

That was never a good day.

The stick, which I often got to see up close, intrigued me.

title: Christa Ludwig obituary
text:
Christa Ludwig sometimes found singing hard work. Even before opening her mouth she had to deal with claques, clothes and colleagues. The latter could offer barbed compliments, such as Lotte Lehmann who in 1929 had sung the Marschallin in Strauss’s opera Der Rosenkavalier at the Salzburg Festival. They met at a reception after Ludwig’s opening night in that role at Salzburg 40 years later. “I liked you so very much,” gushed Lehmann. “I congratulate you sincerely on your performance — in the Missa Solemnis.”

At least dying on stage could be fun. “How does one fall differently if one is stabbed from the back or from the front?” she mused. There was less levity during rehearsals for Bizet’s Carmen at Covent Garden in 1976
summary:
Christa Ludwig sometimes found singing hard work.
The latter could offer barbed compliments, such as Lotte Lehmann who in 1929 had sung the Marschallin in Strauss’s opera Der Rosenkavalier at the Salzburg Festival.
They met at a reception after Ludwig’s opening night in that role at Salzburg 40 years later.
“I congratulate you sincerely on your performance — in the Missa Solemnis.”At least dying on stage could be fun.
“How does one fall differently if one is stabbed from the back or from the front?” she mused.

title: How accurate is The Crown season 4? What’s true and false in the Netflix series
text:
The fourth season of The Crown stretches from May 1979, when Margaret Thatcher is elected Britain’s first female prime minister, to Christmas 1990, shortly after she has been drummed out of office. Peter Morgan, the show’s creator, tells us: “We do our very, very best to get it right, but sometimes I have to conflate [incidents] . . . You sometimes have to forsake accuracy, but you must never forsake truth.” The forsaking of the truth, the perverting and twisting of known facts, is what has always concerned me throughout the four seasons of this series. It is about real people, often put into fictional situations.

title: Virat Kohli shows there are bigger things than cricket – which was not always the case
text:
When the India captain Virat Kohli married the Bollywood actress Anushka Sharma their choice of honeymoon destination was telling. They went to Rovaniemi, the capital of Lapland in northern Finland. As the official home of Santa Claus, and a place to watch the northern lights in full splendour, no doubt the city has its charms, but the appeal was its remoteness from cricket, about five miles from the Arctic Circle as it is.

For the same reason that Sachin Tendulkar loves coming to London to escape the goldfish bowl that is Mumbai, Kohli and his bride were looking forward to enjoying the freedom that this corner of the world would allow, shorn of paparazzi and cricket lovers as it usually is. Then they strolled into

title: North Korean defector Jihyun Park is Conservative candidate in Bury council election
text:
A woman who fled North Korea but was caught, sent back and tortured is now running for public office in Britain after she escaped again.

Jihyun Park, 52, hopes to represent the Conservatives in a ward in Bury, Greater Manchester. This week her ambition was bolstered after she was selected as the party’s candidate for Moorside, having previously been set to run for a seat in the Holyrood ward. As well as being the area she lives in, Moorside is considered a marginal ward, and her chances of success have increased.

Sponsored

Park, who is now a British citizen and has three children, said that she wanted to “give back” because “Britain has gifted me with so much”.

When she first fled North Korea for China
summary:
A woman who fled North Korea but was caught, sent back and tortured is now running for public office in Britain after she escaped again.
Jihyun Park, 52, hopes to represent the Conservatives in a ward in Bury, Greater Manchester.
This week her ambition was bolstered after she was selected as the party’s candidate for Moorside, having previously been set to run for a seat in the Holyrood ward.

title: For clarity’s sake, here’s what you need to know about face-covering
text:
‘To face-cover, or not to face-cover; that is the question. Whether ‘tis nobler in the mind to suffer the chills and breathlessness of outrageous virus, or to take arms against a second wave, and, by face-covering, end it?”

That’s what Shakespeare didn’t write, but the answer to this question has long been disputed. So much so, in fact, that we are now all terribly confused. I’ve decided, therefore, to take you step-by-step through the different schools of thought in the hope that it may help resolve, once and for all, the argument .

title: ‘Guardian angel’ gives disaffected ultra-Orthodox Jews another choice
text:
Eve Sacks is the self-styled “guardian angel” for unhappy members of the Charedi (strictly orthodox) Jewish community who are trying to get away from the community in which they feel trapped.

The term Charedi refers to the most orthodox Jews, literally those who tremble before God. In practical terms, it encompasses a large number of sects and groupings, who reject many of the tenets of mainstream society. The men are usually distinguished by long black coats and big hats and the women dress modestly with no legs or cleavage on view. The married women wear wigs over their natural hair.

Sponsored

Sacks, an accountant, mother of three and the daughter in law of the late chief rabbi Jonathan Sacks, accepts that many people are happy with
summary:

In practical terms, it encompasses a large number of sects and groupings, who reject many of the tenets of mainstream society.

title: Office romances: ‘A late night drink ended with sex at his flat’
text:
Office romance — a good way to meet your partner or doomed to end in failure and embarrassment?

Damian Whitworth, writer

Back in the days before email, shortly after The Times’s correspondents stopped sending dispatches via pigeon post, we used to communicate by an internal computer messaging system. One day I saw “message pending” on my screen and opened it with a greater than normal sense of anticipation.

Sponsored

The message was from one of the paper’s sharpest investigative reporters, who also happened to be the building’s most outrageous gossip. This should be good, I thought. The note was simple and jolting. “I know all about you and M,” it said. Our office romance was no longer secret.

He was a friend, so I pleaded for discretion, but confirming the truth to him was as good as doing so to the Press Association.
summary:
Office romance — a good way to meet your partner or doomed to end in failure and embarrassment?
Damian Whitworth, writerBack in the days before email, shortly after The Times’s correspondents stopped sending dispatches via pigeon post, we used to communicate by an internal computer messaging system.
One day I saw “message pending” on my screen and opened it with a greater than normal sense of anticipation.

Our office romance was no longer secret.

title: By Georgian! Needlework and piano keep lockdown Lizzies busy
text:
Upper-middle-class women in the time of Pride and Prejudice were expected to be accomplished in traditional arts

To fill the long days spent at home, the heroines in Jane Austen’s novels mastered the arts of needlework, painting and playing the pianoforte. For Mr Darcy in Pride and Prejudice, knowledge of music, singing, drawing and “extensive reading” was the definition of an accomplished woman.

Fast-forward 200 years, and the enforced confinement of a third national lockdown is making many of us feel like we’re living in an Austen novel ourselves.

Sponsored

Retailers report that Britons are buying needlework kits, acrylic paints, novels and even pianos to pass the time. Fatigued by endless video conferences, home schooling and family Zoom chats, a growing rebellion against screen time has also fuelled the nation’s love of physical books as they seek out tech-free hobbies.

title: How Covid prompted a rush to retire early — and can you do the same?
text:
About 18 per cent of people who have retired since the pandemic started said that coronavirus made them realise they wanted a change

The proportion of people planning to retire early has more than doubled since the coronavirus pandemic.

One in ten workers is now planning to give up work between 50 and state pension age, up from one in 25 before the coronavirus crisis, according to research by the UK’s biggest investment manager, Hargreaves Lansdown.

Sponsored

Sarah Coles from Hargreaves said: “The crisis prompted more of us to make crucial decisions about how we want to work in our fifties and sixties. For others, there has been far less control, with many older people forced out of work altogether.”

According to the Financial Conduct Authority, the City regulator, in the six months after the emergence of Covid-19, about 6 per cent of people brought forward their retirement plans.
summary:
About 18 per cent of people who have retired since the pandemic started said that coronavirus made them realise they wanted a changeThe proportion of people planning to retire early has more than doubled since the coronavirus pandemic.
One in ten workers is now planning to give up work between 50 and state pension age, up from one in 25 before the coronavirus crisis, according to research by the UK’s biggest investment manager, Hargreaves Lansdown.

For others, there has been far less control, with many older people forced out of work altogether.”According to the Financial Conduct Authority, the City regulator, in the six months after the emergence of Covid-19, about 6 per cent of people brought forward their retirement plans.

title: Herbert Kretzmer obituary
text:
Herbie Kretzmer did not so much translate Les Misérables as create an English-language version of an obscure French musical that in 1980 had played for a few months in Paris. In the process he read Victor Hugo’s novel in English and worked from a literal translation of Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schönberg’s original script.

“You cannot translate a song,” he explained. “You can translate a textbook and even a novel, but a song is no more than a compendium of nuances and references and illusions, with a resonance within a particular culture. So simply to translate the words into their dictionary meaning isn’t going to work.”

Sponsored

title: Dear Dolly: ‘I’m 30 and have moved home with Mum and Dad. How can I stop feeling lonely about being single?’
text:
Q. I am nearly 30 and during the pandemic I have moved back home with Mum and Dad. I now spend most evenings watching period dramas and going to bed at 9.30pm. Meanwhile, my friends have been getting engaged with big rings and buying houses. I am becoming increasingly worried that I will never meet the right person in time to have children with them. I love my job and my life. How can I stop feeling worried and a bit lonely about being single?

A. It has been pretty tough to be single over the past year. A lot of the perks of being unattached have been taken from us: child-free travel, late nights out with no one to come home to, sex with
summary:

I now spend most evenings watching period dramas and going to bed at 9.30pm.
I am becoming increasingly worried that I will never meet the right person in time to have children with them.
How can I stop feeling worried and a bit lonely about being single?
It has been pretty tough to be single over the past year.

title: ‘I’m being forced to marry my cousin’
text:
Alia said she overheard her father, who has been suffering financially during the pandemic, call her a “burden”

Alia, 16 and from London, was recovering from coronavirus symptoms when she heard her family discuss plans for her marriage.

Her father is in the restaurant trade and has suffered financially during lockdown. Through her bedroom wall she says she heard him complain that she was a “burden” that needed to be married off. “I felt I was going to be sick, I could hear mum, dad and my brother all talking about it. Why would they want me married — I’m too young,” she told The Times.

title: Jordan Belfort: ‘I still feel bad — a little bit. I lost some rich people’s money’
text:
When he was the multimillionaire investor known as the Wolf of Wall Street, Jordan Belfort owned a 167ft yacht named Nadine that sank off the coast of Sardinia after an ill-advised voyage in a freak storm. Belfort didn’t need to make that trip. The yacht’s captain had said they shouldn’t. His wife at the time, Nadine, after whom the yacht was renamed — it was originally built for Coco Chanel — said they shouldn’t, but Belfort was “stoned out of his mind” on the sedative Quaalude and experiencing “a frantic need for movement”. He insisted they sail. “Don’t forget I was on a lot of cocaine too,” he says today. “But yeah, my decision-making was definitely off.”

title: Ian Maxwell on Ghislaine: my sister is not a monster
text:
Family reunions aren’t easy to arrange when there are seven siblings scattered across two continents. So when the surviving Maxwell children got together two summers ago, the mood was celebratory. It was the first time they had all been in a room together in almost a decade, and there was another figure present as well. The reunion fell on June 10, 2019, which would have been Robert Maxwell’s 96th birthday had he not slipped into the Atlantic nearly 30 years earlier.

One person stands out in the photograph they took that day in London. Most of the Maxwell children — Anne, now 73, Philip, 71, twins Christine and Isabel, 70, Ian, 64, and Kevin, 62 have aged, the gloss of their childhood at Headington Hill

title: Robert De Niro: from Mean Streets to bread ads
text:
The showpiece scene in the recently released and mostly excruciating Robert De Niro “comedy” The War with Grandpa arrives midway through. It’s late at night and De Niro, as ornery grandfather Ed, who is locked in an escalating prank battle with grandson Peter (Oakes Fegley), is sleeping soundly in a large double bed.

Suddenly, a strange sixth sense awakens Ed. He turns to the empty space next to him, nervously reaches out and roughly whips back the sheets. Wriggling on the mattress is a live and significantly sized gopher snake, placed there as an intimidating statement by the young and ruthless Peter.

Sponsored

OK, so it’s not quite a horse’s head, but we get it — it’s a Godfather reference. De Niro played young Vito Corleone

title: How to stop the Covid crisis becoming a hunger crisis
text:
The IMF’s updated economic growth projection predicts a striking 4.9 per cent contraction for this year – a much steeper decline than anticipated in April. Little wonder their report is called “a crisis like no other”. Tragically it is not only the numbers that make this unprecedented. So is the feeble global political response.

The G20, created to fight the last crisis, has been modest in ambition and impact. While national economic policy has innovated, international policy, from debt relief to aid flows, has been inert. That makes this week’s G20 finance ministerial meeting a test of whether the international community, including the UK, has what it takes to minimise the damage coming our way.

Sponsored

The International Rescue Committee’s new analysis shows that economic shocks
summary:
The IMF’s updated economic growth projection predicts a striking 4.9 per cent contraction for this year – a much steeper decline than anticipated in April.
Little wonder their report is called “a crisis like no other”.
The G20, created to fight the last crisis, has been modest in ambition and impact.
While national economic policy has innovated, international policy, from debt relief to aid flows, has been inert.
That makes this week’s G20 finance ministerial meeting a test of whether the international community, including the UK, has what it takes to minimise the damage coming our way.

title: The redemption of Bill Clegg: how the literary agent beat drugs and became a father
text:
Bill Clegg, 49, left, and his husband, Van Scott, at their home in the Catskills

We’re about an hour into what’s turning out to be a gloriously long lunch, and I’ve just used the phrase “redemption story”, with no degree of hyperbole. My lunch date, the literary uber-agent and acclaimed author Bill Clegg, is – as anyone with a modicum of modesty would be – demurring a little, without completely disagreeing.

“When I got sober and went back to work, not one writer that I represented didn’t know that I was a crack addict,” he says. “When they would say, ‘Yes, I trust you with my career,’ part of me was like, ‘Really? There’s lots to suggest otherwise.’ So I’m very grateful.”

title: Johnny Depp drags Elon Musk into Amber Heard libel saga
text:
Elon Musk has been told to provide evidence of his contact with Amber Heard

Johnny Depp has dragged the Tesla billionaire Elon Musk into his $50 million libel action against his ex-wife.

The Pirates of the Caribbean star, who previously accused Musk of having an affair with Amber Heard during their tumultuous marriage, has demanded that he be interviewed and hand over details of all his contact with her.

Depp, 57, is suing Heard for $50 million in Virginia over a 2018 op-ed article she wrote for the Washington Post in which she described herself as a victim of domestic violence.

Heard, 34, is countersuing for $100 million, claiming that he tried to destroy her career, including by trying to have her removed from the sequel of the Aquaman superhero movie.

title: Paris judge in sham marriage ordered to retire
text:
Souad Meslem “put her role as a rejected woman above that of a judge”

A judge has been ordered to retire after she admitted getting revenge on an unfaithful partner by staging a sham marriage with a man who impersonated him.

Souad Meslem, 59, deputy head of the criminal court in Colombes, in the western suburbs of Paris, was forced out for ethics breaches as prosecutors continue to investigate how she staged the elaborate plot against the lawyer, with whom she had a son.

Sponsored

Meslem devised the plan after he refused to join her in Réunion, the French island in the Indian Ocean. The couple had planned to move there after she got the posting as a prosecutor.

She learnt, however, that after two decades together her partner was having an affair with another lawyer. His lover was the

title: On the Rocks review — Lost with a crass close relation
text:
★★☆☆☆

The Oscar-winning Lost in Translation team of the actor Bill Murray and the writer-director Sofia Coppola reunite for another freewheeling meditation on relationships, careers and the emotional toll of affluenza. This one is set in the exclusive restaurants, private members’ clubs and gorgeous loft apartments of Lower Manhattan, where young mother and creatively stymied novelist Laura (Rashida Jones) shares marital woes with her wisecracking and eminently charismatic father, Felix (Bill Murray, very Bill Murray). Yet whereas Lost in Translation was a structurally assured, slow-build charmer, this thematic sequel is a strange hybrid, part Woody Allen-inspired character study, part wacky conjugal rom-com, a film of two disparate halves that fails to fully service either one.

It begins on promising form with a nuanced portrait of

title: Film reviews: Sophia Loren in The Life Ahead; Billie
text:
Imagine for a second that Sophia Loren does not appear in Edoardo Ponti’s The Life Ahead. What sort of film do we have on our hands? Adapted from Romain Gary’s popular novel of the same name, it concerns an elderly Italian-Jewish woman who takes in an orphaned Muslim boy and the friendship that blooms between them. In other words, your basic plea for community, tolerance and respect. In short, four-ply mush.

In a poor quarter of the port of Bari, in southern Italy, a 12-year-old Senegalese orphan named Momo (Ibrahima Gueye) snatches the bag of the elderly Madame Rosa at a crowded street market. He is apprehended and forced to return the bag by the neighbourhood doctor (Renato Carpentieri). “The boy needs … a
summary:
Imagine for a second that Sophia Loren does not appear in Edoardo Ponti’s The Life Ahead.
What sort of film do we have on our hands?
Adapted from Romain Gary’s popular novel of the same name, it concerns an elderly Italian-Jewish woman who takes in an orphaned Muslim boy and the friendship that blooms between them.

He is apprehended and forced to return the bag by the neighbourhood doctor (Renato Carpentieri).

title: Andrew Peacock obituary
text:
If any politician looked certain to become prime minister of Australia it was Andrew Peacock. At the age of 27 he was gifted Kooyong, the former seat of Sir Robert Menzies, Australia’s longest serving PM. He became foreign minister in his thirties, then leader of the Liberal Party not once, but twice. Yet both times the party was in opposition and the top job remained just beyond his reach.

Given Peacock’s seemingly effortless rise, good looks and glamour, not to mention a well-publicised affair with the Hollywood star Shirley MacLaine, he was the brunt of many a barbed comment from his Labor Party opponents. These ranged from “the sun lamp kid” to the prime minister Paul Keating’s put-down on Peacock’s return as leader of the
summary:

title: Melanie Bramwell-Popham: I made a promise to Alix’s daughters that I would keep their dad here for as long as possible
text:
Popham, who won 33 caps for Wales, had dementia diagnosed last year in a devastating blow for his young family

Melanie Bramwell-Popham wept on Monday as she read Val Vickerman discuss the death of her son.

Dan Vickerman, who won 63 caps for Australia, took his own life nearly four years ago, at the age of 37. His mother is convinced he died from chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), the degenerative disease found in people with a history of repetitive brain trauma.

Sponsored

“I do believe that if CTE had been spoken about he may have been able to cope with what was happening in his life,” she told The Times.

Bramwell-Popham wept because she agreed. She wept because she recognised so acutely the symptoms Val Vickerman had described. She wept because she knew the same fate could so easily have befallen her husband.

Alix

Popham, who won 33 caps for Wales, had dementia diagnosed last year in a devastating blow for his young familyMelanie Bramwell-Popham wept on Monday as she read Val Vickerman discuss the death of her son.
Dan Vickerman, who won 63 caps for Australia, took his own life nearly four years ago, at the age of 37.

She wept because she knew the same fate could so easily have befallen her husband.

title: Professor John Vincent obituary
text:
Anyone who believes today’s debates about “cancel culture” are new did not see John Vincent attempting to give history lectures at Bristol University in 1986. As many as 300 students from radical groups would break into the lecture room. Manure taken from university gardens was thrown. Vincent, with his wife next to him, used a chair leg to fend off protesters, before eventually legging it down a fire escape to be escorted away by police.

The Times described this disruption as “an act of intellectual vandalism”. Nineteen students faced disciplinary proceedings, and seven were found guilty, but the verdicts were later quashed on a technicality. Vincent was forced to take a year’s leave of absence as protests continued.

title: Missing girl in Pakistan ‘was forced into marriage’
text:
Protests have been held against the treatment of the girl, who is now in a women’s refuge

The police in Pakistan have rescued a missing 13-year-old girl belonging to a Christian minority who was allegedly forced to marry a 44-year-old Muslim man and convert to Islam.

The girl is being cared for in a women’s refuge until the next court hearing, scheduled for today, her parents’ lawyer Jibran Nasir said. She had been missing since early October. Azhar Ali, 44, a neighbour, is in police custody. The girl’s parents accuse him of violating child marriage law and forcible conversion.

title: How Olympic gold medallist Klete Keller ended up storming Capitol with pro-Trump mob
text:
Even when standing on the top step of the Olympic podium, lined up alongside his United States team-mates, Klete Keller stood out unmistakably. At the Athens Games in 2004, where he had just held off a charge from the great Ian Thorpe to anchor the US 4x200m freestyle team to one of the great Olympic relay victories, he was immediately recognisable, with his buzz cut, all-American grin and bare feet on the podium alongside Michael Phelps, Ryan Lochte and Peter Vanderkaay. He was conspicuous again when he won a second gold medal in the event in Beijing four years later, his 6ft 6in frame towering over even his fellow outsize Olympians.

title: The top ten action movies to watch now
text:
1. Speed (Jan de Bont, 1994)

It’s all there in the title, Speed. Sheer momentum. The kinetic energy of a cinematic narrative that’s racing breathlessly from elevator drama, to bus-bomb crisis, to train-chase finale. This is the apotheosis of the action movie — never bettered — where script, style, cast and crew whir together like perfectly fitting cogs, creating a machine of seamlessly unfolding blockbuster beats. Keanu Reeves helps too. His innate softness (“Whatever you say, ma’am!”) is a welcome riposte to the hardman action clichés of yore (Stephen Baldwin, Tom Cruise and Wesley Snipes were all first considered for the role). Reeves’s chemistry with his co-star Sandra Bullock is winning. Dennis Hopper’s villain is suitably crazed. And that bus jump is profoundly

Sponsored

Speed (Jan de Bont, 1994)It’s all there in the title, Speed.
The kinetic energy of a cinematic narrative that’s racing breathlessly from elevator drama, to bus-bomb crisis, to train-chase finale.
This is the apotheosis of the action movie — never bettered — where script, style, cast and crew whir together like perfectly fitting cogs, creating a machine of seamlessly unfolding blockbuster beats.
His innate softness (“Whatever you say, ma’am!”) is a welcome riposte to the hardman action clichés of yore (Stephen Baldwin, Tom Cruise and Wesley Snipes were all first considered for the role).
Reeves’s chemistry with his co-star Sandra Bullock is winning.

title: Australian female passengers forced to undergo examination after baby found at Qatar airport
text:
Australia’s government has protested against the treatment of its citizens after Qatar’s main airport admitted that female passengers were forced to undergo “intimate” examinations following the discovery of a newborn baby in an airport lavatory.

Marise Payne, the Australian foreign minister, complained to the Qatari government after the admission by airport managers, saying the incident was “grossly, grossly disturbing”.

Sponsored

The incident on October 2 came to light after some of the 13 women on board a Qatar Airways flight to Sydney complained they had been removed from the plane and subjected to examination.

One said that she had made a failed attempt to escape after being put in an ambulance and driven off the airport site. A nurse then told her to remove her underwear

title: Rape cases dropped ‘due to police stereotyping’
text:
Of the 55,259 rapes reported last year there were only 2,102 prosecutions and 1,439 convictions

Police and prosecutors are behind a decline in the number of suspects being charged with rape because they are ignoring crucial evidence and stereotyping victims, a report has warned.

The report by a group of women’s justice organisations highlights a litany of errors that they say are denying rape victims justice. They claim that black, Asian and minority ethnic women and disabled people are likely to suffer the worst treatment in the justice system.

Sponsored

The report said that rape cases were being dropped even in situations when the use of weapons and serious injuries were documented, a suspect was shown to be lying or several victims had given testimony against one suspect.

title: Singletons penalised with longer working days and higher costs
text:
People who are not in relationships claim they are expected to work longer and cover more unsociable hours than colleagues

Singletons face everyday discrimination by being forced to work unsociable hours and penalised for having no children, an academic has claimed, amid calls for single people to become a legally protected minority.

The number of people living on their own in the UK has risen significantly in recent years, to more than eight million, a trend reflected in TV programmes such as Fleabag.

Sponsored

Research has shown that single people pay a financial penalty of more than £2,000 a year, with higher costs for holidays, insurance, council tax and gym membership. People who are not in relationships claim they are expected to work longer and cover more unsociable hours than colleagues.

title: Boss ‘incandescent’ after charity hosted anti-gay marriage church
text:
Shonaig Macpherson was said to be angry that after learning that one of her charity’s venues had been booked for services by the Stirling Free Church

The chairwoman of a leading Scottish charity could be challenging to work for, an employment tribunal was told.

Shonaig Macpherson was described as “dynamic” and “forward” by her former chief executive at the Robertson Trust, who claims he was forced to leave his job because of his religious views.

Sponsored

Kenneth Ferguson alleges that Ms Macpherson was “incandescent” and belittled him after learning that one of its venues had been booked for services by the Stirling Free Church, which opposes same-sex marriage, in breach of the anti-poverty charity’s policy.

Mr Ferguson, who is a treasurer and elder at the church, is suing the charity for unfair dismissal, religious discrimination and religious harassment and is said to be seeking about £75,000.

The Robertson Trust gives £20 million

title: The Sunday Times pick of the best historical fiction for October 2020
text:
The Devil and the Dark Water by Stuart Turton (Raven £16.99)



Sponsored

Turton made his name with The Seven Deaths of Evelyn Hardcastle, a genre-bending exercise in crime fiction that won the Costa award for a first novel in 2018. His second book is an even more exuberant demonstration of his storytelling skills. In 1634 the governor of Batavia in the Dutch East Indies and his entourage set sail for Amsterdam. Danger, possibly supernatural in origin, soon threatens the voyage. Murders occur; strange symbols appear on the sails; a voice in the night whispers threats and promises. Responsibility for throwing light on the darkness falls to the governor’s wife and to Arent Hayes, bodyguard to Samuel Pipps, the brilliant investigator whom the governor has imprisoned

title: Idris Elba’s Luther ‘isn’t black enough to be real’, says BBC diversity chief
text:
The character of John Luther only became black when Idris Elba was given the lead role in the series, which also stars Ruth Wilson as the research scientist Alice Morgan. Luther ran for five series on BBC One

As one of the first prime time television dramas starring a black actor in the title role, Luther broke new ground for on-screen representation.

Idris Elba’s depiction of the obsessive detective John Luther earned him a clutch of best actor awards including a Golden Globe, as well as recognition from the NAACP, America’s foremost civil rights organisation.

Sponsored

Miranda Wayland cited the popular crime drama as an example of a series that is only superficially diverse, as the corporation seeks for more convincing and rounded portrayals of minority groups.

title: Sophie’s tears for ‘amazing’ Queen reflect the national mood after death of Prince Philip
text:
The Earl and Countess of Wessex leave with the window open so Sophie could speak to an onlooker

For a moment the national mourning was paused, replaced by a glimpse of the profoundly personal sadness of family loss. As the Earl and Countess of Wessex departed Windsor Castle yesterday, the windows of their car were lowered, and the Queen’s favourite daughter-in-law offered a few words of comfort to those close enough to hear.

Responding to a question from an onlooker, Sophie shifted in her seat as Prince Edward steered their car and replied through the open window: “The Queen has been amazing.” It wasn’t much; it didn’t need to be. Sophie’s glistening eyes told their own story of the heartbreak behind palace walls.

title: Dostoevsky in Love by Alex Christofi, review — an intimate look at the writer
text:
Connoisseurs of the misery memoir must feel frustrated that Fyodor Dostoevsky never wrote an autobiography. For no writer ever endured a life more wretched than his.

Myopic and epileptic, a martyr to haemorrhoids and bladder infections, he spent his career facing financial ruin, gambling away his possessions, being swindled by sharky publishers. Born in 1821 into the lower ranks of hereditary nobility, he spent time in prison and faced a firing squad. His love life was marred by illness and infidelity; death stalked his young family. But he died at 59 a national hero, invited to dine with Tsar Alexander II’s children and hailed by crowds as a saint and prophet.

Sponsored

Along the way, he also upended the rules of literature. His key novels, Crime
summary:
Connoisseurs of the misery memoir must feel frustrated that Fyodor Dostoevsky never wrote an autobiography.
For no writer ever endured a life more wretched than his.
Myopic and epileptic, a martyr to haemorrhoids and bladder infections, he spent his career facing financial ruin, gambling away his possessions, being swindled by sharky publishers.
Born in 1821 into the lower ranks of hereditary nobility, he spent time in prison and faced a firing squad.
His love life was marred by illness and infidelity; death stalked his young family.

title: Marina Wheeler on life after Boris Johnson and her new‑found freedom
text:
Ask Marina Wheeler her most vivid childhood memories and she will recount a supper where she, her sister and parents took turns to say what they were good at. When it was the turn of her mother, Dip, her father, Charles, prompted her: “You are good at cleaning the lavatory.” A frustrated stay-at-home wife, Dip did not appreciate the joke. Instead she stood over him and insisted he take it back or she would pour ketchup on him. He carried on laughing so she did the deed. “It really was something seeing his shock and all this red gloop over his white hair,” Wheeler says. “I didn’t know I had it in me,” her mother told her afterwards.

Her father was Charles Wheeler, then

title: The Times Film Club — In a Lonely Place
text:
What did you think of In a Lonely Place? Join Kevin Maher for a live chat about the film on Monday, September 28, from noon to 1.30pm. If you would like to submit your thoughts in advance, please post them in the comment section below

In a Lonely Place (Nicholas Ray, 1950)

Making most other film noirs seem like feelgood rom-coms, this is a brutish character study in which Humphrey Bogart plays the screenwriter from hell, Dixon Steele. An acknowledged abuser with a hair-trigger temper, Dixon, we learn, has broken a previous girlfriend’s nose and, we see, will beat anyone to a pulp if they dare to cross him (watch out for the luckless college football player who confronts him on the road).

title: Can your relationship survive the second wave?
text:
In normal years the divorce calendar has two spikes on it; one after the summer holidays, followed by a much larger one post-Christmas.

You can almost look at divorce like a virus, and this year it is spreading atypically, at present rising rampant across the western world in a bumpy upward curve. The first wave started to climb shortly after the peak of coronavirus, with a brief abatement during the lightening of the skies, load and rules during the summer. Now cases are building at unusually high rates again. Are you becoming hyper-aware of someone else’s toenails, whether attached to their host or not? Has your relationship got enough immunity to survive the winter Covid-strain?

Sponsored

Or, as Eric Spiegelman, a podcast executive, wrote on social
summary:
In normal years the divorce calendar has two spikes on it; one after the summer holidays, followed by a much larger one post-Christmas.
You can almost look at divorce like a virus, and this year it is spreading atypically, at present rising rampant across the western world in a bumpy upward curve.
The first wave started to climb shortly after the peak of coronavirus, with a brief abatement during the lightening of the skies, load and rules during the summer.
Are you becoming hyper-aware of someone else’s toenails, whether attached to their host or not?
Has your relationship got enough immunity to survive the winter Covid-strain?

title: Best children’s books of the year 2020
text:
This was a good year to be a bookish kid. Shirley Hughes has a new Dogger story out, JK Rowling published her first children’s book since Harry Potter, funny doctor Adam Kay wrote a gruesome guide to the human body, and much more . . .

This is the reading equivalent of wallowing in a hot bath. It’s the aftermath of the First World War, and children Ben and Lottie and their tutor, Clara, find themselves on an emotional journey. Ben must find his brother Sam — wounded in France — or he will be sent to an orphanage. Lotti, an orphan herself, must find her French grandmother to avoid being sent to boarding school by her cruel uncle. Clara is searching for her fiancé,
summary:

title: Turks are turning back the clock on women’s rights
text:
I am absolutely fuming. Having spent the past two weeks in a bubble of rage and disbelief following Sarah Everard’s death and the subsequent conversation about women’s safety in Britain, I’ve been tipped over the edge by the Fatherland. Two days ago, Turkey left the Istanbul Convention.

Signed in 2011, the Istanbul Convention is a human rights treaty between 45 countries and the EU that aims to prevent violence against women (including domestic violence), protect victims and ensure perpetrators are duly punished. Turkey was the first to ratify it and I was so proud; it proved that the country wasn’t backward and the treaty’s title meant Turkey would forever be equated with a major advancement in women’s rights. Now all of this has been undone.
summary:
Having spent the past two weeks in a bubble of rage and disbelief following Sarah Everard’s death and the subsequent conversation about women’s safety in Britain, I’ve been tipped over the edge by the Fatherland.
Two days ago, Turkey left the Istanbul Convention.
Signed in 2011, the Istanbul Convention is a human rights treaty between 45 countries and the EU that aims to prevent violence against women (including domestic violence), protect victims and ensure perpetrators are duly punished.
Turkey was the first to ratify it and I was so proud; it proved that the country wasn’t backward and the treaty’s title meant Turkey would forever be equated with a major advancement in women’s rights.
Now all of this has been undone.

title: Calls for statue to celebrate forgotten suffragette Mary Clarke
text:
She was the sister of Emmeline Pankhurst and the first woman to die for the suffragette cause. Yet Mary Clarke has been all but forgotten.

Pankhurst’s loyal younger sister escaped an abusive marriage to become an organiser in the fight for votes for women, winning praise for her “pluck” and courage.

Sponsored

Every afternoon, between 3pm and 5pm, she would give speeches on the Brighton seafront before crowds of hundreds, dealing calmly with hecklers who hurled rotten apples and facing down mobs who threatened to “throw her off a cliff”.

She braved police beatings in the infamous clashes that became known as Black Friday, and went on hunger strike in prison, where she was kept in solitary confinement.

title: Sylvain Sylvain obituary
text:
When Sylvain Sylvain first told his parents he wanted to become a rock star, his mother slapped him around the face and told him: “You’re going to learn how to cut shirts.”

His parents were Jewish refugees from Nasser’s Egypt turned New York tailors, and from an early age he helped out in the family business. As a boy he turned the crank for his mother’s hand-driven Singer sewing machine and she taught him to sew buttons on the garments she made. In his teens he progressed to cutting shirts as his mother had ordered, yet his passion for rock’n’roll would not abate and so he invented the New York Dolls as a way of uniting his love for music with his training in the

title: Douglas Matthews obituary
text:
Regular commuters on the Lewes to London Victoria train might have noticed a fellow traveller with papers and cards balanced on his knee and wondered how one man’s journey could be consumed by so much paperwork. Yet as Douglas Matthews, librarian at the London Library, was keen to point out: “Indexing was only ever a parallel profession.”

Matthews was the indexer of choice for many authors, determining who or what appears under which subheading at the back of their books. Claire Tomalin acknowledged him in her 2011 biography of Charles Dickens, while a Financial Times reviewer of Jeremy Lewis’s Graham Greene biography, Shades of Greene, observed that “rarely has an index been more useful”, describing Matthews as “our greatest living indexer”.

Sponsored

Indexing is not
