title: Luster by Raven Leilani, review — a caustic, candid and convincing debut
text:
Raven Leilani’s debut novel has already been praised by a list of authors that includes Zadie Smith, Mary Gaitskill and Diana Evans. It’s easy to see why. Edie, the 23-year-old black narrator, is memorable and candid — and someone, it quickly becomes clear, who is lost. She doesn’t care about her low-grade job in publishing and sleeps with men “who lose interest in [her] when [she] talk[s]”. The only thing she wants to do is paint, but she hasn’t been able to do so since her father died. Then she starts seeing Eric, a white, middle-aged library archivist living in the suburbs with his adopted black daughter, Akila, and his wife, Rebecca, who has tentatively agreed to an open marriage. title: Honour: ITV’s true-life drama about an honour killing
text:
On January 24, 2006 three men tortured, raped and then strangled to death a 20-year-old woman in the sitting room of her parents’ home in southwest London. It was just as her father and uncle had intended. It was also what Banaz Mahmod had herself predicted when in December she had visited a police station to report that her family were plotting to kill her.

Thirteen years later, on the afternoon of October 1, 2019, one of the nation’s favourite actresses, Keeley Hawes, is dressed in a navy blue trouser suit and striding down a bleak corridor in the old BT building in Watford. She enters what on ITV’s Honour, a dramatisation of the investigation, will pass for a police incident room in Lewisham,

title: From Bridgerton to The Serpent — these are the TV shows set to influence your wardrobe
text:
How will you be dressing in 2021? As street style has all but disappeared and celebrity events are cancelled, the answer is literally right in front of you: your television. You may already have been inspired by the Seventies flicks and swirly fabrics of the BBC One thriller The Serpent, or the bodiced Regency romance of Netflix’s Bridgerton; you might even experience a surprising fluoro moment when you dip into Russell T Davies’s vibrant new Eighties drama, It’s a Sin, at the end of the month. Perhaps later this spring you will find yourself googling pieces inspired by the chic interwar stylings of the BBC/Amazon Prime adaptation of Nancy Mitford’s The Pursuit of Love, or the upcoming Netflix spectacular Inventing Anna

title: Lord Lester of Herne Hill, human rights lawyer who quit Lords in sex scandal, dies at 84
text:
Lord Lester was an influential human rights lawyer before resigning from the House of Lords after being accused of sexual harassment

Lord Lester of Herne Hill, the lawyer who played a crucial role in enacting race and sex discrimination laws in the UK, as well as pressing for human rights legislation, has died aged 84.

In 2018 he resigned from the House of Lords amid allegations that he had sexually harassed a woman campaigning against forced marriage.

Sponsored

The QC was affiliated first with the Labour Party, then the SDP, before becoming a Liberal Democrat peer in 1993. But at the end of 2018 the Lords confirmed an earlier finding that the peer had breached the House’s code of conduct by sexually harassing a lobbyist 12 years earlier.

The peers agreed a report from the Lords privileges and conduct committee into the allegations made by Jasvinder Sanghera
summary:

In 2018 he resigned from the House of Lords amid allegations that he had sexually harassed a woman campaigning against forced marriage.

title: London Bridge terrorist Usman Khan spoke with Lee Rigby’s killer in prison
text:
Usman Khan killed two people during a rampage at Fishmongers’ Hall, next to London Bridge, in November 2019

A convicted terrorist who killed two Cambridge graduates discussed Islam with the murderer of Fusilier Lee Rigby and was still considered a highly dangerous inmate days before his release from prison.

Usman Khan had carried out a racist attack aged 13 and was radicalised by sermons given by the notorious British preacher Anjem Choudary, an inquest into the graduates’ deaths was told.

Sponsored

He stabbed to death Saskia Jones, 23, and Jack Merritt, 25, during a prisoner rehabilitation conference at Fishmongers’ Hall in the City of London in November 2019. Khan was shot dead by police on London Bridge.

Video footage shown to the hearing showed Khan, 28, the day before the attack buying the clothing he wore during his rampage, the tape used

title: The Best Catholics in the World by Derek Scally, review — John Banville on the fall of the Church in Ireland
text:
There is an acronym, of uncertain provenance, which it amuses the Irish to apply to ourselves: Mope, that is, Most Oppressed People Ever. That we can laugh at the notion of having been singled out among the nations of the earth for especially bad treatment is to our credit, although the laughter is tinged with self-mockery, even self-loathing.

Certainly we were oppressed, over many centuries, mainly by the English. There was the slaughter and despoliation in Munster after the Desmond rebellions in the latter half of the 16th century (the poet Edmund Spenser, who occupied vast estates in Co Cork, felt the best solution to the Irish “problem” was enforced mass starvation), Cromwell’s religious massacres the following century, the attempt to suppress Catholicism under the
summary:

title: Henry McKenzie Johnston obituary
text:
After the Italians changed sides in the Second World War in the autumn of 1943, Gian Gaspare Napolitano joined the Allies as a liaison officer and later wrote a book, To War with The Black Watch, a series of vignettes about the British Army fighting in Italy. Writing in the third person, Napolitano tells of an encounter with Henry McKenzie Johnston, a veteran of the campaign in Tunisia and the long, wretched battle for Monte Cassino.

The Italian wrote: “He reproached himself with having been irritated for so long by the [British] adjutant, until the night when, entering his room by mistake, he surprised him in pyjamas, kneeling on the floor, in front of his flag, in the act of praying to the Lord.
summary:

title: Statesman of Europe: A Life of Sir Edward Grey by TG Otte review — the Great War wasn’t his fault
text:
Edward Grey, Britain’s longest-serving foreign secretary and “the most conspicuous figure in the British political world”, was showing signs of wear and tear as 1914 began. A swollen ankle and torn muscles and ligaments were new experiences for this lithe, fit fiftysomething countryman, who had been in his post since 1905. But his biggest worry was his deteriorating eyesight, which meant he could no longer track the ball when playing real tennis, a sport at which he had once excelled. His doctor’s prognosis was poor, so he scheduled an appointment for September 1914 with Dr Hermann Pagenstecher, a leading specialist, in the German city of Wiesbaden.

There were few reasons to think that the appointment would not take place. The most likely impediment would be

There were few reasons to think that the appointment would not take place.

title: ‘New employment judges are far from inexperienced’
text:
Marian Bloodworth says tribunals need to make better use of technology to speed up cases

Marian Bloodworth’s fearsome-sounding maiden name — retained after her marriage for its distinctive and memorable quality — belies the calm and conciliatory nature of the chairwoman of the Employment Lawyers Association.

She needs to be calm, otherwise her blood may boil. The solicitor took over the tiller of the 6,000-strong group last September as the pandemic worsened the backlog in employment tribunals, which were already crippled by years of underfunding.

title: The key to a happy marriage: it’s time for some ‘radical generosity’
text:
A couples’ therapist once told me that her motto was “A cup of tea gets you sex”. The 80/80 Marriage, A New Model for a Happier, Stronger Relationship, by the husband and wife Nate and Kaley Klemp, echoes this theme. Their concept is, rather than rigid insistence on fairness, you adopt an approach of “radical generosity” — with each partner trying to contribute 80 per cent to the marriage (you excuse the maths) and prioritise shared goals. Your success is my success. There’s a chapter entitled Sex-Orgasmic Altruism. The more you give, the luckier you get. So the cup of tea principle, in effect.

Coincidentally or not, the Klemps are the perkiest couple I’ve encountered in a year. They’re speaking on Zoom from

title: Sirin Phathanothai: why I was sent to China as a ‘gift’ aged eight
text:
It is a plot that would be outlandish even by the standards of a Cold War thriller, packed with clandestine meetings, superpower intrigue and remarkable personal drama. But Sirin Phathanothai lived it all after she was secretly dispatched in 1956 as an eight-year-old girl by her father, a Thai politician, to the inner sanctum of Chairman Mao’s China.

Sent with her 12-year-old brother, Warnwai, as diplomatic offerings of goodwill between Thailand and China — sworn foes at the time — Sirin grew up behind Asia’s “Bamboo Curtain” as the ward of one of the most influential statesmen of the 20th century, Zhou Enlai — Mao’s right-hand man. “I was sent to China as a tribute, a gift, an offering of trust between the two nations,”

title: Fancy sharing Sir Benjamin Slade’s stately pile?
text:
Sir Benjamin Slade was quite clear about what sort of person he wanted to live in his manor house and share his 2,000-acre Somerset estate. “Good right-wing, hunting, shooting types,” he told The Times this week, with a love of fine wine and £20,000 a month to pay their way.

So I feel a bit of an impostor as I sit in front of his roaring log fire, sipping tea and asking if he thinks I might be suitable material as a tenant of Maunsel House. We haven’t discussed money yet, but I have confirmed that I am not a Marxist — “that’s good” — and that I enjoy wine, although I usually don’t spend more than a tenner on a bottle. “I prefer
summary:
Sir Benjamin Slade was quite clear about what sort of person he wanted to live in his manor house and share his 2,000-acre Somerset estate.
“Good right-wing, hunting, shooting types,” he told The Times this week, with a love of fine wine and £20,000 a month to pay their way.
So I feel a bit of an impostor as I sit in front of his roaring log fire, sipping tea and asking if he thinks I might be suitable material as a tenant of Maunsel House.

title: Charity boss Kenneth Ferguson ‘forced out for Christianity’
text:
The chairwoman of a poverty relief charity has denied that her support for gay marriage turned her against her chief executive who is a Christian, an employment tribunal has been told.

Shonaig MacPherson, of the Robertson Trust, had been “distressed” on discovering one of its venues had been booked by the Stirling Free Church, where Kenneth Ferguson was a senior lay figure. In several emails and conversations with trustees and staff, it was alleged that Ms MacPherson had repeatedly highlighted the church’s opposition to same-sex marriage.

Sponsored

She was asked, by Mr Ferguson’s lawyer: “Is it fair that you disagree with those who believe the only right form of sexual relationships are hetrosexual?” Ms MacPherson agreed, adding the issue was a question of human rights.
summary:
The chairwoman of a poverty relief charity has denied that her support for gay marriage turned her against her chief executive who is a Christian, an employment tribunal has been told.

title: On the Rocks review — soggy, sloppy and hugely disappointing
text:
★★☆☆☆

The Oscar-winning Lost in Translation team of actor Bill Murray and writer-director Sofia Coppola reunite for another freewheeling meditation on relationships, careers and the emotional toll of affluenza. This one is set in the exclusive restaurants, private members’ clubs and gorgeous loft apartments of Lower Manhattan, where the young mother and creatively stymied novelist Laura (Rashida Jones) shares marital woes with her wisecracking and eminently charismatic father, Felix (Bill Murray, very Bill Murray). Yet whereas Lost in Translation was a structurally assured, slow-build charmer, this thematic sequel is a strange hybrid movie, part Woody Allen-inspired character study, part wacky conjugal rom-com, a film of two disparate halves that fails to fully service either one.

text:
Haya Harareet’s first Hollywood film was Ben-Hur, the 1959 classic in which she played Charlton Heston’s love interest

When William Wyler was searching for a female lead for his biblical epic Ben-Hur, his mind turned back to a beautiful young Israeli actress he had met two years earlier at the Cannes Film Festival.

He had already cast the title role but was struggling to find the right actress to play Charlton Heston’s love interest, Esther. More than 30 names were considered, including Ava Gardner and Carroll Baker. None of them seemed right, and then the director remembered the little-known Haya Harareet.

Wyler had come across her at Cannes in 1955 when Hill 24 Doesn’t Answer, in which she starred, had been nominated for the Palme d’Or. Directed by Thorold Dickinson, the film did not win but had its own place in

title: Christopher Plummer obituary
text:
Few actors had a more conflicted relationship with their most famous role than Christopher Plummer, the Oscar-winning Canadian actor. As the buttoned up widower Captain von Trapp in The Sound Of Music, Plummer was an integral part of one of the most phenomenal box-office successes of all time. The role secured Plummer’s heart-throb status and ensured that when he returned to his beloved theatre, seats immediately sold out, albeit often to punters intrigued to see what the yodelling, nun-wooing military man would do in the role of Lear.

Yet although he finally mellowed towards The Sound Of Music, for a long time Plummer chafed against the stuffy dullness of the character and the “awful and sentimental and gooey” nature of the film. He
summary:
Few actors had a more conflicted relationship with their most famous role than Christopher Plummer, the Oscar-winning Canadian actor.
As the buttoned up widower Captain von Trapp in The Sound Of Music, Plummer was an integral part of one of the most phenomenal box-office successes of all time.
The role secured Plummer’s heart-throb status and ensured that when he returned to his beloved theatre, seats immediately sold out, albeit often to punters intrigued to see what the yodelling, nun-wooing military man would do in the role of Lear.
Yet although he finally mellowed towards The Sound Of Music, for a long time Plummer chafed against the stuffy dullness of the character and the “awful and sentimental and gooey” nature of the film.

title: The Mirror and the Palette by Jennifer Higgie, review — putting female artists back into art history
text:
Art history is a subjective discipline. At any given time its thrust depends on the attitudes of whoever is holding the pen. And where Jennifer Higgie is unquestionably right in her spell as a pen holder is in complaining that western art history has been written chiefly by men, and reflects attitudes and prejudices that are overtly masculine.

As she points out, it is indeed ridiculous that the two most popular entry-level slabs of art history, Ernst Gombrich’s The Story of Art and Horst Janson’s History of Art, omit to include a single female in their artistic canons. That really is outrageous.

Sponsored

Unfortunately, Higgie’s own effort on this significant battlefront, a charged and emotional look back at the history of female self-portraiture in art,

title: Series four of The Crown takes on Princess Diana: exclusive pictures and interviews
text:
Lasers. That’s what helped Emma Corrin understand Princess Diana in the latest series of The Crown. When the cameras were rolling, she imagined that lasers were pointing at her, as if she were in a spy film or a bank heist drama. It was her way of imagining hundreds of people staring right at her. Lasers helped her with the iconic Diana head tilt. She pretended she was shying away from them.

Corrin could also draw on her own trajectory as a 24-year-old actress. Before landing her part in The Crown, she was an unknown. Suddenly “there’s a huge amount of pressure”, she says.

title: The rise and rise of the micro wedding
text:
Leanne Baily, 33, from Essex, has watched her friends struggle to raise up to £40,000 to spend on their big fat weddings — only in some cases, sadly, to get divorced soon afterwards. So when lockdown gave her the chance to enjoy a “micro wedding” to her fiancé, Alan Warren, 41, from Lancashire, she grabbed it. The couple had planned to have a ceremony with only six guests on New Year’s Eve last year. “We wanted to say goodbye to a rubbish year and start the new year on a high,” Baily recalls.

When second-wave restrictions nixed their plan, the couple rescheduled for next month at a venue with cottages near Truro, Cornwall, with the same six guests — even though they could have had

title: That’s not a meat-free sausage. It’s a grainrod
text:
There’s an amendment to a farming bill, being debated in Brussels at the moment, to do with whether vegetarian sausages and burgers should be allowed to call themselves sausages, burgers, wurst, escalope, steak, schnitzel and so on. Some people think these names belong to meat alone — I imagine a red-faced, bull-necked man from Big Meat stamping some things with a “meat” logo and crossly rejecting others — and that their use for vegetarian or vegan products is misleading. Some people think: “Don’t be so silly.” An EU farmers’ association says it’s had enough of “surreal” descriptions of non-meat products. title: Robert Burns had more than fond kisses for women
text:
I always knew that Robert Burns wrote almost countless poems, songs and letters about women — a near inexhaustible outpouring of words that fuels our enduring fascination with Scotland’s national bard. But it was only when curating a new collection of his work that I came to appreciate the complexity of his love of women as one of the defining features of his short life — he died in 1796 at 37 — and how his experiences with women formed such an essential component of his creativity.

Burns composed hundreds of poems and songs in honour of the women he admired; some held an enduring sway over his emotions, others were simply a fleeting encounter. Perhaps more than any other writer of his time —
summary:

title: Domestic violence drives rise in lockdown divorces
text:
The increase in marriage break-ups was an indication of the emotional burden weighing on many couples during lockdown, legal experts said

Divorces rose by 5 per cent in the final quarter of last year with domestic violence applications increasing by more than a fifth, official family court figures published today showed.

Legal experts said that the rising number of marriage break-ups and allegations of abuse in the home were an indication of the “emotional burden” weighing on many couples as a result of the coronavirus lockdowns.

Sponsored

Figures from the Ministry of Justice showed that 68,634 cases were started in family courts between October and December last year, an increase of 6 per cent compared with the same quarter in 2019.

The figures were higher in most categories, with domestic violence allegations up 21 per cent and divorces rising by 5 per cent.

title: The Crown’s Erin Doherty: how I became a Princess Anne superfan
text:
As it manoeuvres into the bloody battlefields of the Eighties, the fourth season of Netflix’s The Crown brings out the big guns: Thatcher and Diana. Yet this autumn’s episodes boast no more affecting or powerful scene than a quiet encounter between the Queen and her daughter, Princess Anne, in the grounds of Gatcombe Park, Anne’s Gloucestershire home. It hits the viewer resoundingly, like a nail on the head, or a bullet to it.

It is 1981. Anne is unhappy. The press, head over heels with Diana, is out to get the older woman. Having relished scaring people, she is now scared herself, alone and friendless. Her eight-year marriage to Mark Phillips persists only in name. The Queen has heard from the head of royal protection
summary:
As it manoeuvres into the bloody battlefields of the Eighties, the fourth season of Netflix’s The Crown brings out the big guns: Thatcher and Diana.
Yet this autumn’s episodes boast no more affecting or powerful scene than a quiet encounter between the Queen and her daughter, Princess Anne, in the grounds of Gatcombe Park, Anne’s Gloucestershire home.
It hits the viewer resoundingly, like a nail on the head, or a bullet to it.
Anne is unhappy.
The press, head over heels with Diana, is out to get the older woman.

title: Sathnam Sanghera on the British Empire: ‘Growing up, I was fed the idea that I was a novel social experiment’
text:
I am not a particular fan of the British seaside. I don’t need to work on my tan, I can barely swim, I grew up in the beach-free West Midlands and my heritage can be traced back in its entirety to the landlocked state of Punjab. Frankly, the kindest thing I can bring myself to say about Brighton on this bitter afternoon is that, if you close your eyes, the sea sounds a little like the M6 on a busy day – a sound that, having grown up near junction 10, I will always regard as comforting.

title: Caring’s not sharing his South Kensington view
text:
The renowned cellist and former cabinet minister who have complained about a property scheme in South Kensington have company: bouffant-haired restaurateur Richard Caring.

The perma-tanned owner of Annabel’s nightclub in Mayfair and the Ivy in Covent Garden joins the chorus of disapproval over plans by Transport for London (TfL) to build a four-storey office block and 50 homes.

Sponsored

Critics, including the former international development secretary Rory Stewart and musician Julian Lloyd Webber, claim it will ruin protected views of the Natural History Museum. Two years ago, Caring spent £40m on Park House, a cottage set in one acre of land that is a stone’s throw from the Tube station, to live there with his second wife, Patricia Mondinni.

title: Philomena Lee ‘dismayed’ at leaking of mother and baby home report
text:
Philomena Lee said it was “essential” that the Irish state and churches apologised and compensated families

Philomena Lee has criticised the leaking of the mother and baby homes report, saying it will add to the “heartache and trauma” of those affected.

Ms Lee, whose life was the subject of the film Philomena, starring Judi Dench, said she was “dismayed” that details of the report were leaked.

Sponsored

title: Domestic abuse: Police reveal violent past of partners
text:
There was a 34 per cent increase in applications to the domestic abuse disclosure scheme during lockdown

More than half the people who have used an abuse disclosure scheme were told that their partner had a violent or abusive past.

Police Scotland’s disclosure scheme for domestic abuse enables individuals to request information about a partner. Requests can also be made on their behalf by a family member, friend or neighbour.

Sponsored

The system has received 8,533 requests since it was launched in 2015. Of those, 4,536 people, or 53 per cent, were told of their partner’s violent or abusive past.

Assistant Chief Constable Judi Heaton, Police Scotland’s lead for major crime and public protection, said: “Behind the numbers are people who have either escaped becoming victims of domestic abuse or who are now aware of their partner’s abusive past.”

Ms Heaton said that

title: Prophet cartoon was shown at Batley Grammar School ‘a week before row’
text:
When Batley Grammar School sent an email to parents apologising for any offence caused after a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad was shown in a religious studies lesson, they might have hoped that would be the end of the matter.

Instead protests took place for two days outside, government ministers intervened and the teacher suspended over the incident went into hiding with fears that he might never be able to return to the area. It emerged last week that the cartoon had been shown at the West Yorkshire school in a previous year by another member of staff.

title: Hunter Biden on family tragedies and the drug addiction that nearly destroyed him
text:
As I began writing this in November 2019, I sat in the centre of a political firestorm. The president of the United States was smearing me almost daily from the South Lawn of the White House. title: A year in the life of the Sussexes: from Megxit to sharing the love in a podcast
text:
After a year of global grimness, Harry and Meghan have swept into our lives to offer comfort and solace. Their new podcast features Meghan telling us that love always wins, Harry urging us to “grab a cosy beverage” and Archie uttering his first words in public. It was this time last year that the royal family first reached for the smelling salts over Harry and Meghan. They might want to keep them to hand.

title: If Harry can’t tell his past from his elbow, he shouldn’t enter the Commonwealth shames
text:
The statesman and philanthropist Prince Harry has released footage from a Zoom call in which he explains that the Commonwealth must face up to the past, no matter how uncomfortable that might be. As I’d always imagined the Commonwealth was a sort of club that organised a fun sports day every four years for countries that needed a nice old lady to put on their banknotes, I couldn’t imagine what terrible crimes it had committed. So I did a spot of research.

And it was like looking into the history of Stow-on-the-Wold’s jam-making society. Literally nothing has happened, which is quite an achievement, since it counts as members nearly a third of the world’s population and covers 20% of the planet’s land mass.

Sponsored

It was

The statesman and philanthropist Prince Harry has released footage from a Zoom call in which he explains that the Commonwealth must face up to the past, no matter how uncomfortable that might be.
As I’d always imagined the Commonwealth was a sort of club that organised a fun sports day every four years for countries that needed a nice old lady to put on their banknotes, I couldn’t imagine what terrible crimes it had committed.
So I did a spot of research.
And it was like looking into the history of Stow-on-the-Wold’s jam-making society.
Literally nothing has happened, which is quite an achievement, since it counts as members nearly a third of the world’s population and covers 20% of the planet’s land mass.

title: Colm Tóibín: Our lost children don’t need apologies from the church, only answers
text:
The report on mother and baby homes in Ireland, published last Tuesday, is one more investigation of a dark past in Ireland. This was a time when the Catholic Church operated as a sort of shadow state. All of us who were brought up in that state took its power for granted. The church controlled the schools and owned the hospitals; it ran orphanages and industrial schools and homes for unmarried mothers. A compliant state paid the church for these services and let it run them as it pleased.

The report, at almost 3,000 pages, establishes that over nearly 80 years from 1920 almost 60,000 women and the same number of children went through the system and 9,000 children died. According to the minister
summary:
The report on mother and baby homes in Ireland, published last Tuesday, is one more investigation of a dark past in Ireland.
This was a time when the Catholic Church operated as a sort of shadow state.
The church controlled the schools and owned the hospitals; it ran orphanages and industrial schools and homes for unmarried mothers.
A compliant state paid the church for these services and let it run them as it pleased.
The report, at almost 3,000 pages, establishes that over nearly 80 years from 1920 almost 60,000 women and the same number of children went through the system and 9,000 children died.

title: The Most Rev Philip Tartaglia obituary
text:
That Philip Tartaglia should die on the feast day of St Mungo, the founder and patron saint of Glasgow, seems fitting. At his installation as the eighth Roman Catholic Archbishop of Glasgow in St Andrew’s Cathedral in September 2012, he blessed the congregation before being presented with the crozier of St Mungo, a shepherd’s crook.

Tartaglia’s appointment as archbishop and spiritual leader of the largest Catholic community in Scotland marked a joyous homecoming for this son of the city and keen supporter of Celtic football club. He was only the second Italian-Scots archbishop after Charles Eyre, who with the restoration of the Catholic hierarchy in Scotland in 1878 had been the first Catholic Archbishop of Glasgow since the Scottish Reformation of 1559-60.

Sponsored

Although at 61

title: Poland fears EU backlash over anti-gay towns
text:
Clément Beaune, the French minister for Europe who is himself gay, said he had been pressured into abandoning a visit to Krasnik, eastern Poland

A French minister has claimed he was browbeaten by the conservative government in Poland into cancelling plans to make a stand against homophobia during a trip there this week.

Clément Beaune, 39, France’s Europe minister, said he had intended to visit one of the 100 or so Polish towns that have infuriated human rights activists by declaring themselves “free of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender ideology” or by adopting “family charters” that reject same-sex marriage.

Sponsored

Beaune had wanted to draw attention to a trend that has been widely condemned in western Europe.

The declarations are legally toothless but activists have called them discriminatory in a country that ranks worst in the EU for gay rights, according to ILGA-Europe, an umbrella organisation for 600 LGBT advocacy
summary:
Clément Beaune, the French minister for Europe who is himself gay, said he had been pressured into abandoning a visit to Krasnik, eastern PolandA French minister has claimed he was browbeaten by the conservative government in Poland into cancelling plans to make a stand against homophobia during a trip there this week.
Clément Beaune, 39, France’s Europe minister, said he had intended to visit one of the 100 or so Polish towns that have infuriated human rights activists by declaring themselves “free of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender ideology” or by adopting “family charters” that reject same-sex marriage.

The declarations are legally toothless but activists have called them discriminatory in a country that ranks worst in the EU for gay rights, according to ILGA-Europe, an umbrella organisation for 600 LGBT advocacy

title: The Art of the Glimpse: 100 Irish Short Stories selected by Sinéad Gleeson, review
text:
Sinéad Gleeson’s exertions in the service of Irish literature are Stakhanovite: editing four Irish short-story collections in a decade is a singular achievement, unlikely to be surpassed. For this, countless Irish writers owe her a profound debt of gratitude.

Still, it’s hard to see this massive new anthology as a natural progression from the groundbreaking project pursued in her earlier anthologies, The Long Gaze Back and The Glass Shore. It is Gleeson’s evangelical fervour for the unsung, the neglected and the marginalised that has distinguished her work to date, which makes it feel slightly strange to see so many iconic figures included. James Joyce, Flann O’Brien, Frank O’Connor and Elizabeth Bowen hardly need a leg-up, and leaving them out of this collection would have

title: Nawal El Saadawi obituary
text:
Nawal El Saadawi was six years old when she was circumcised. She cried for her mother until she saw her standing with her aunts, watching and smiling. “Since I was a child that deep wound left in my body never healed,” she wrote long after the traumatic event.

Other episodes in her childhood outraged her too. She was furious when her grandmother declared that “a boy is worth 15 girls at least . . . girls are a blight” and angry at her parents’ favouritism towards her older brother. When told at school that she had to use her father’s family name, not her mother’s, she became upset again. Aged seven, she wrote a letter to God in which she stated: “If you are not

title: TV reviews: Bridgerton; All Creatures Great and Small; Ghosts; Worzel Gummidge: Saucy Nancy; Motherland
text:
No seamy reimaginings of Hercule Poirot, no brand-new retro ghost stories with Mark Gatiss, no Charles Dickens extravaganza: there were, for obvious reasons, noticeable absences in this year’s Christmas TV schedules. There was, however, no need to be brave, knuckle down and make the best of Mrs Brown’s Boys just yet. (Not that anyone’s missed their chance now it’s slated to appear every December 25 until 2026. Imagine a pink cardigan smothering a human face for ever.)

For sheer escapist comfort and joy there was Bridgerton, an opulent hothouse pineapple of a show based on the novel series by Julia Quinn. A Jane Austen deepfake, lab-grown Georgette Heyer, this Regency romance galloped from the stable of the Scandal and Grey’s Anatomy producer Shonda Rhimes,
summary:

title: French border closure and disruption in Kent
text:
Sir, Does not the French blockade (“Seafood rots by the roadside as gridlock predicted to last days”, News, Dec 23) demonstrate with exquisite clarity that France has lost not one iota of sovereignty by its EU membership? Desiring to protect its citizens, the French state has done what it perceives to be necessary, to the consternation of the rest of Europe. It may be an over-reaction but disdain for our country is now laid bare around the world. Our pride, our self-determination and our wealth are waning, thanks to Brexit dogma.

Dr N P Hudd

Tenterden, Kent

title: Reclaim data as well as the streets to make women safe
text:
Just days on from the Metropolitan Police confirming the appalling murder of Sarah Everard the government has already been able to announce changes in an attempt to help women feel safer. Doubling the money given to the Safer Streets Fund for more CCTV cameras and better street lighting is a tangible and swift response. Government were able to act quickly because problems with personal safety are already understood. So why do women in the UK feel unsafe now more than ever?

Women’s experience of personal safety is dramatically different to mens. And the data government collects on women’s experience of personal safety is poor. The most common form of violence women experience is sexual harassment; this isn’t the experience of men; and it isn’t measured
summary:

title: Gareth Thomas: ‘Stripping is an art. It’s a tease’
text:
At 46, Gareth Thomas still maintains an elite athlete’s body. The former rugby union full back and renowned Wales player regularly runs, cycles, and swims in the sea. He even does the occasional Ironman event, involving a 2.4-mile swim, 112-mile bike ride and 26.2-mile run. Now he is undertaking a sporting challenge unlike any other — The Full Monty on Ice, which starts next week on ITV. And it would be fair to say he’s a little nervous.

“I’m ice skating and I’m OK at it. But adding another element is really a big challenge,” he says.

title: Lady Elizabeth Shakerley obituary
text:
When Lady Elizabeth Anson, later Shakerley, was coming out as a debutante, she often missed the glittering parties she was expected to attend, hovering on the threshold with nerves before fleeing in terror.

On the occasions when she summoned the courage to enter, she recalled being “that girl standing alone in the middle of the room with a canapé, feeling awkward”. She even underwent hypnosis in an attempt to cure her timidity. “The idea of most social occasions terrified me and I have always dreaded parties because of feeling that way,” she said. “So I vowed to create parties where no one had to feel like that.”

Sponsored

Lady Elizabeth with Princess Anne, who was her bridesmaid in 1972, at Ascot in 2013 MAX MUMBY/INDIGO/GETTY IMAGES

As therapy for her social bashfulness it was perhaps extreme, but in 1960, aged 19, she launched Party

title: Prince Philip: the Greek who bore gifts of total support to the Crown
text:
The Duke of Edinburgh’s role in life, as he saw it, was to be a facilitator, a banger-together of heads and, above all, a husband

Prince Philip was a man of many talents. One was for making widely quoted off-the-cuff remarks — hilarious or deeply inappropriate depending on your point of view. Another was for self-deprecation.

He once described himself as “a discredited Balkan prince of no particular merit or distinction”. That might have held true in the years immediately after his birth, on his parents’ kitchen table on the island of Corfu in 1921, but his subsequent life proved dramatically otherwise.

title: Jewish women need more protection from racist abuse
text:
Today is International Women’s Day. Choose to Challenge is the theme and it has resonated strongly with me. Like those of us who come from immigrant backgrounds with strong women at the forefront, the matriarchs in my family chose to challenge the prejudices they faced as working class, immigrant, Jewish women long before they realised their equal future in the world, or indeed feminism became a movement.

I have discovered that Jewish women have long held a special place in the heart of Jew haters and misogynists. In recent years I chose to challenge. Sticking my head above the social media parapets to speak out, I have experienced this very specific type of targeted hate I would imagine my great grannie Annie faced when arriving
summary:

I have discovered that Jewish women have long held a special place in the heart of Jew haters and misogynists.
In recent years I chose to challenge.

title: Religious orthodoxy is rooted in fear of women
text:
Whose taboos count highest? Have you a right to impose your notions of sacredness on the public sphere? We in the West may think ourselves children of the Enlightenment, our democratic post-Christian liberalism prettily laced with cultural sensitivity, but small events confound us. Take the case of Melanie Wolfson, who is suing Easyjet for discrimination.

At Ben Gurion airport in Tel Aviv she paid extra for an aisle seat but was moved by cabin crew because two ultra-Orthodox male passengers objected to sitting next to a woman. She says she was “insulted and humiliated . . . it was the first time in my adult life I was discriminated against for being a woman”. She was told that ultra-Orthodox men often make this demand and

title: A prince is born, Diana upstages Charles and the marriage falters
text:
Prince William was born on June 21, 1982. In the South Atlantic, Britain had just been to war in the Falklands. In England, the Archbishop of Canterbury said that the prince and princess “deserve their happiness and we rejoice with them”. The bookies’ odds-on favourite name was George. Charles favoured Arthur; Diana wanted William.

The couple were by now arguing constantly, often about Charles’s continued friendship with Camilla Parker Bowles. She and her husband, Andrew, were regular visitors to royal residences including Highgrove. James Gilbey, a friend of Diana since she was 17, told the journalist Andrew Morton that “the whole prospect of Camilla drives her spare. I mean, what the hell is that woman doing in her house?” During one row Charles told Diana

title: Robert Webb: ‘The doctors literally switched me off. A lung and heart machine was breathing for me’
text:
Robert Webb does laps of Queen’s Park three times a week, running the perimeter outside, not inside any more, because he can’t stand the other “arsehole” runners, “who think because they go faster, they have right of way”. And he can’t stand the dog-walkers – “I hate dog-walkers” – or, in fact, people in general; especially the ungrateful bastards who didn’t notice him skidding about in the mud trying to give them space, which is what forced him onto the pavement. As he jogs, in an old pair of gas-blue trainers, tracksuit bottoms (shorts if the temperature is in double digits, “never” leggings), he mutters a little mantra in time with his footfall and breathing: “You’re a c***. You’re a c***. You’re a c***.” Occasionally

A 12-year-old Kenyan girl was married off by her father to two men in the space of a month.

The prospect of receiving cows as a dowry had prompted him to find his daughter husbands, the authorities who rescued the girl said.

title: Prince Philip obituary
text:

News reached them of the King’s sudden death, aged 56. The duke’s wife was 25 and he was 30. Born to privilege but not to duty, he would now and for the years to follow embrace duty. title: White men’s control of the news agenda must end, says BBC boss
text:
Jonathan Munro, head of newsgathering, said too many top editorial positions had been held by Caucasian men

The views of white men must not be allowed to dominate decisions about the BBC’s news coverage, according to a senior executive.

Jonathan Munro, head of newsgathering, said that the corporation’s diversity drive was necessary because too many senior editorial positions had been held by Caucasian males.

Sponsored

Mr Munro also admitted that the national broadcaster and other news organisations were blindsided by the failings that led to the Grenfell Tower fire in 2017 because so few journalists had grown up on housing estates.

Tim Davie, the new BBC director-general, has made diversity one of his priorities, promising to transform the corporation into a “50/20/12 organisation” — with a workforce that is 50 per cent female, at least 20 per cent black, Asian and minority

text:

The political stars had never been so aligned in Nicola Sturgeon’s favour. Even in the midst of a pandemic, support for the Scottish National Party (SNP) and Scottish independence has never been higher.

Scotland’s first minister has won plaudits for her communication skills during the Covid-19 emergency, allowing her to draw a contrast between her performance and that of Boris Johnson. title: Bring Back Our Girls by Joe Parkinson and Drew Hinshaw, review — hearing from the Chibok schoolgirls
text:
For two weeks it was the biggest story on earth: 276 Nigerian schoolgirls abducted from their dormitory in the middle of the night in April 2014 by a little-known but extremely deadly Islamist sect called Boko Haram. What had drawn the media was not the mass kidnapping, which initially was barely reported, but a catchy hashtag, #BringBackOurGirls, which was retweeted by millions across the globe, from Michelle Obama to Oprah Winfrey.

The Obama administration, the prime minister David Cameron, the French, Canadians and Israelis sent drones, spy planes and satellites to scour the Sambisa forest where the girls had been taken. Dozens of intelligence agents, hostage negotiators, psychosocial therapists and rescue teams set up office in the Abuja Hilton.

All to no avail. Seven years

title: Eddie Van Halen obituary
text:
At the height of his reign as the fastest guitar-slinger in the west, Eddie Van Halen guested on Michael Jackson’s Beat It, playing a typically razzle-dazzle solo and rearranging the song. The single went to No 1 and Thriller, on which the song featured, became the biggest-selling album of all time, but Van Halen waived his fee and told Jackson to regard it as a favour.

Van Halen could afford to be so generous because the band that carried his name was at the time the most successful heavy-rock act in the world. A month after Jackson’s song had gone to No 1, Van Halen and his group were paid $1 million for a show in San Bernardino, California, the largest sum ever

title: The West can’t ignore Macron’s call to action
text:
Another day, another outrage on the streets of a European city. Five years on from the Bataclan attacks in Paris, Vienna this week joined a victims’ club that includes Brussels, Nice, Berlin, London and Manchester. The response has been the same in each of these cities: bafflement that jihadist cells still exist, followed by a tweak in policing and counterterrorism tactics.

The political imperative, though, is to move on as soon as decently possible. Any deeper self-examination could polarise society and spread xenophobia, runs this tired and defeatist logic.

Sponsored

And so the attacks will continue, as inevitable as bad weather. Europe is a soft target for any killer who wants to drum up maximum publicity for the lowest possible cost. That’s why we should be

Five years on from the Bataclan attacks in Paris, Vienna this week joined a victims’ club that includes Brussels, Nice, Berlin, London and Manchester.
The response has been the same in each of these cities: bafflement that jihadist cells still exist, followed by a tweak in policing and counterterrorism tactics.
Any deeper self-examination could polarise society and spread xenophobia, runs this tired and defeatist logic.
SponsoredAnd so the attacks will continue, as inevitable as bad weather.
Europe is a soft target for any killer who wants to drum up maximum publicity for the lowest possible cost.

title: Noëlla Coursaris Musunka: the model, her Malaika foundation and her mission to educate girls
text:
Noëlla Coursaris Musunka’s life reads like a fairytale. Born in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), her father died suddenly when she was five and her mother, left destitute, was forced to give her up. She was sent on her own to Belgium, then Switzerland, and spent a deeply unhappy childhood living with cruel, indifferent relatives. However, Musunka worked hard, excelled at school and moved to London to study business management, where she fell into modelling via an Agent Provocateur competition. Hey presto: a jet-setting life of catwalks and shoots, her long limbs and enormous eyes making the cut on the pages of Vogue, Elle and Vanity Fair. So far, so Cinderella.

title: Dame Barbara Windsor obituary: EastEnders actress dies, aged 83
text:
Barbara Windsor and Sid James, with whom she had an affair, in the 1973 film Carry On Girls

For Barbara Windsor, Babs as she was known, acting in the Carry On films involved its own crazed discipline. None had more than a six-week shooting schedule and the director, Gerald Thomas, rarely allowed more than two takes. “Nobody analysed what they were doing,” Windsor recalled. “We had to be there early, know the script backwards, cause no aggravations and endure all kinds of awful weather in order to finish on time.”

Typical was the shooting of Windsor’s famous bra scene in Carry On Camping (1969), a film set in midsummer but shot during a cold February and March. The scene required Windsor to lose her bikini top during a keep-fit class, the strap, unable to withstand the physical pressures, snapping with a spectacular twang.
summary:

The scene required Windsor to lose her bikini top during a keep-fit class, the strap, unable to withstand the physical pressures, snapping with a spectacular twang.

title: Bitter trial shone light on sexism in the City
text:
Amanda Staveley’s case against Barclays led to her abilities being disparaged by the bank and revealed that she was the subject of lewd comments

Amanda Staveley’s High Court battle has cast a spotlight on pay packets for bankers and sexism in the City. It is also a reminder that just over a decade ago Barclays, one of Britain’s biggest banks, avoided a taxpayer bailout only through a £7.3 billion rescue financed mainly by Middle Eastern investors.

In an eagerly awaited ruling yesterday, Mr Justice David Waksman reached a mixed verdict. Staveley has been denied the £1.5 billion that she initially claimed she was due from the bank for her part in the emergency financing deal.

title: Best political and current affairs books of the year 2020
text:
We live in interesting times. Here are the year’s best books to understand what’s happening and how we got here: from the rise and fall of Corbyn and turbulence in the Middle East, to the life of Barack Obama and shenanigans inside David Cameron’s government.

The most gossipy and mischievous diarist since Alan Clark begins her account in 2010 when her husband, Hugo, is appointed minister of state in the Northern Ireland office, and is so excited that he insists on being called “minister” at home. Hardly anybody comes out of this well, certainly not poor Hugo. Apparently, there

title: Muslim leaders can’t dodge the questions
text:
It is, after all, called Woman’s Hour and given that organised religion is historically no friend of womankind, Zara Mohammed, new leader of the Muslim Council of Britain (MCB), might expect tough questions. A female head of a Roman Catholic umbrella group would brace herself for a grilling on papal edicts about abortion, contraception or a ban on women priests. And doubtless 200 prominent women would not write an open letter attacking the BBC.

Yet according to Labour MPs Diane Abbott and Naz Shah, and the Tory peer Baroness Warsi among others, the presenter Emma Barnett was “strikingly hostile” in asking Mohammed about the number of female imams in Britain. It was, to be fair, a snippy exchange: Barnett refused to accept the MCB leader

title: Unmarried women no longer have to flee UAE if pregnant
text:
Unmarried women who become pregnant in the United Arab Emirates will no longer have to flee the country for an abortion or marry in the latest move by the Gulf state towards secularism.

Previously, unmarried women who became pregnant faced deportation or jail, with expatriates commonly flying abroad for a shotgun wedding, or opting for a termination in their home country.

Sponsored

Many low-paid workers who could not afford to leave, including maids who have been raped by their bosses, have been forced to give birth secretly and bring up their children hidden from authorities.

Children born to unmarried parents cannot obtain a birth certificate, and are not eligible for healthcare or education.

title: Nimco Ali on Boris, Carrie and her campaign to end violence against women
text:
For Nimco Ali, the personal has always been political. She is a black, Muslim, 38-year-old survivor of female genital mutilation who has become one of the world’s most effective campaigners against the barbaric practice of cutting girls. Describing herself as the “chief fanny defender”, she has been awarded an OBE by the Queen for her work. She arrived in Britain at the age of four as a refugee from Somalia, grew up supporting Labour, once stood as a candidate for the Women’s Equality Party, and at the last election voted Green. Now she has become one of Boris Johnson’s most trusted allies and his fiancée Carrie Symonds’ closest friend. She is godmother to the prime minister’s son Wilfred and, before the lockdown, played ping-pong regularly

Fresh from exposing his behind to the world in Bridgerton, the British actor Regé-Jean Page has been cast in Netflix’s answer to the James Bond films.

title: Germany’s new divisions: 30 years on from reunification, what’s next?
text:
In the heart of Berlin stand two imposing buildings not far from the River Spree. One is the Reichstag, all monumental stone and classic pillars, the historic home of the German parliament. A short stroll away is the Federal Chancellery, a postmodernist triumph of glass and concrete that houses government offices. The old and the new. The Chancellery, completed in 2001, reflects the Germany reunited in 1990 after being split in two following the Second World War. The cabinet room where Chancellor Angela Merkel holds court has two large windows, one facing the former communist East Germany and the other looking towards the west.

The landscaping tells a story of a modern, unified Germany, one a long way from the troubled history of the Reichstag
summary:

The landscaping tells a story of a modern, unified Germany, one a long way from the troubled history of the Reichstag

Sir David Barclay was the elder, by a few minutes, of twin brothers who quietly, some said secretively, created one of Britain’s largest business empires.

In 2020, the Sunday Times Rich List estimated their wealth at £7 billion. At one time they owned, to mention just a few of their better known assets, the Daily Telegraph, the Ritz Hotel, the mail order company Littlewoods and Ellerman, the shipping group.

Scotland’s first woman bishop is at the centre of a “bullying” row that is threatening to cause a schism with the Episcopal Church.

The Rt Reverend Anne Dyer, 63, was consecrated as the Anglican bishop of Aberdeen and Orkney in 2018. An investigation has been started after she dismissed the musical director at her cathedral and suspended a high-profile priest.

title: Making a drama out of Germany’s move to allow assisted dying
text:
The German writer Ferdinand von Schirach was 15 years old when his father died. Two weeks later, on the family’s country estate in Baden-Württemberg, he waited until his mother was in bed, went to the house’s bar and systematically drank a bottle and a half of whisky in little sips.

He then stumbled into the cellar, took a shotgun from the gun cabinet and went outside to the elm tree his father had planted on the day he was born, with an African gold coin buried beneath its roots for good luck.

Sponsored

With his back resting against the smooth trunk, Von Schirach looked up at the mansion in the light of dawn and put the barrel of the gun to the roof of his mouth.
summary:
The German writer Ferdinand von Schirach was 15 years old when his father died.
Two weeks later, on the family’s country estate in Baden-Württemberg, he waited until his mother was in bed, went to the house’s bar and systematically drank a bottle and a half of whisky in little sips.
He then stumbled into the cellar, took a shotgun from the gun cabinet and went outside to the elm tree his father had planted on the day he was born, with an African gold coin buried beneath its roots for good luck.
SponsoredWith his back resting against the smooth trunk, Von Schirach looked up at the mansion in the light of dawn and put the barrel of the gun to the roof of his mouth.

title: What’s on TV: Thursday
text:
CRITICS’ CHOICE

Being Frank — The Frank Gardner Story (BBC Two, 9pm)

There’s an abdominal gurgling that so overwhelms the first interview in this impressive documentary that the BBC’s security correspondent needs a moment to deflate himself through a hole in his side. In live broadcasts he is forced to cover it with a loud cough. It is a result of Gardner being shot and partially paralysed by al-Qaeda gunmen in a 2004 attack that killed cameraman Simon Cumbers. This film sees him take stock, pay tribute to his former wife and introduce his new love. “The big lie,” he says, ostensibly of lying injured 16 years ago, “is that you pass out with great pain.” Helen Stewart

Eat Well For Less? (BBC One, 8pm)
summary:
CRITICS’ CHOICEBeing Frank — The Frank Gardner Story (BBC Two, 9pm)There’s an abdominal gurgling that so overwhelms the first interview in this impressive documentary that the BBC’s security correspondent needs a moment to deflate himself through a hole in his side.
In live broadcasts he is forced to cover it with a loud cough.
It is a result of Gardner being shot and partially paralysed by al-Qaeda gunmen in a 2004 attack that killed cameraman Simon Cumbers.
This film sees him take stock, pay tribute to his former wife and introduce his new love.
“The big lie,” he says, ostensibly of lying injured 16 years ago, “is that you pass out with great pain.” Helen StewartEat Well For Less?

title: Can Nicola Sturgeon ‘set the record straight’ in Salmond affair?
text:
As Nicola Sturgeon prepares to appear before the Scottish parliament’s inquiry into her government’s botched handling of harassment claims against Alex Salmond, her spokesman says she is “relishing the opportunity” it finally presents for answers to the questions asked of her.

If that’s the case, she isn’t the only one. Over the past year, a blizzard of questions that go to the heart of the first minister’s leadership have been put to her administration’s communications team and to the Scottish National Party, but batted away on the basis that she would tackle it all in her testimony. Within the next week or two, less than three months before she asks voters to place their trust in her again to lead the country in the Holyrood
summary:
As Nicola Sturgeon prepares to appear before the Scottish parliament’s inquiry into her government’s botched handling of harassment claims against Alex Salmond, her spokesman says she is “relishing the opportunity” it finally presents for answers to the questions asked of her.
If that’s the case, she isn’t the only one.
Over the past year, a blizzard of questions that go to the heart of the first minister’s leadership have been put to her administration’s communications team and to the Scottish National Party, but batted away on the basis that she would tackle it all in her testimony.

title: What the critics are watching and listening to, from The Nutcracker to My Generation
text:
The Nutcracker

Covid may have forced Birmingham Royal Ballet to cancel its Nutcracker seasons in Birmingham and London, but instead the company is streaming Peter Wright and David Bintley’s handsome production from the stage of the Birmingham Rep. It has been shortened to 90 minutes, but the magical moments remain: the Snowflakes, the battle with King Rat and the Kingdom of Sweets dances from around the world. Tchaikovsky’s magnificent score will be performed live by the Royal Ballet Sinfonia, conducted by Paul Murphy. The pay-per-view live stream is available on demand until midnight on Christmas Eve. brb.org.uk

Debra Craine

Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom

Black Panther star Chadwick Boseman delivers the performance of his tragically curtailed career as the wildcard trumpeter Levee, one of four session

title: Muslims accept France’s secular values
text:
The “charter of republican values” is central to President Macron’s campaign against terrorism

French Muslim leaders have approved a charter rejecting radicalism and accepting equality between the sexes in a success for President Macron’s plan to promote an “enlightened Islam”.

The rejection of fundamentalist doctrines and acceptance of secular values is contained in a text drafted over the past six weeks by the French Council of Muslim Worship (CFCM), which represents the faith in relations with the state.

Sponsored

The “charter of republican values” is central to Mr Macron’s campaign against a culture of what he describes as separatism and foreign interference hostile to French society. A new system to license imams will require all preachers to sign the charter.

The president put pressure on the council in November to accelerate its work. During the previous month Samuel Paty,

The rejection of fundamentalist doctrines and acceptance of secular values is contained in a text drafted over the past six weeks by the French Council of Muslim Worship (CFCM), which represents the faith in relations with the state.

title: The monarchy in 2030: Charles III needs the king of all rebrands
text:
Prince Harry made an important point when he said, in his interview with Oprah Winfrey last week, that he, Prince William and their father feel trapped. I was once crass enough, in a conversation almost 30 years ago, to suggest to the heir to the throne that there comes to all of us, amid troubles, a time to stop feeling sorry for ourselves and get on with life. Prince Charles banged his fist angrily on the table and said: “Nobody but me can possibly understand how bloody it is to be Prince of Wales!”

title: Don Piccard obituary
text:
Don Piccard at White Bear Lake, Minnesota, where he held the first US balloon race

It was not the kind of electric atmosphere that Don Piccard and Ed Yost had expected when they floated into France at the climax of their history-making balloon trip across the English Channel.

As they drifted towards the coast near Calais, travelling at about 30mph and fearing a capricious gale would blow them over the North Sea, they initiated a rushed and steep descent through clouds. Tall sticks dotting the bleak farmland suddenly loomed large. “What are those poles?” Yost asked. “Those are power lines! Hit the burner!”

Sponsored

The unflappable Piccard took a closer look. “There are no wires yet,” he replied. “They’re brand-new poles.” Their craft, the Channel Champ, duly flopped down in a muddy field in the commune of Gravelines, making the American

title: On record: pop, rock and jazz — October 25
text:
ALBUM OF THE WEEK

BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN

Letter to You

Columbia

All successful songwriters end up competing with their younger selves. Bruce Springsteen, reunited on record with the E Street Band for the first time since 2014, gives a sly nod to this truth by including freshly minted recordings of three songs from the early 1970s (one of them being the notorious and semi-mythical If I Was the Priest). Their inclusion is apt, for Letter to You is a headily nostalgic affair; sonically, it takes you back to the glory days of Born to Run, Darkness on the Edge of Town and The River. There is something profoundly moving about the sound of Bittan, Tallent, Weinberg et al leaning right into the music;

Sponsored

title: Amy Coney Barrett: Catholic rightwinger ‘is Trump’s choice for Supreme Court’
text:
Amy Coney Barrett, if confirmed, will join Mr Trump’s two other appointments to swing the nine-member court 6-3 to the right

A Catholic mother-of-seven is tipped to be President Trump’s choice to replace Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the liberal Supreme Court judge who yesterday became the first woman and the first Jewish person to lie in state in the US Capitol.

Amy Coney Barrett, 48, has been pushed hard by the Christian right after Mr Trump decided to speed ahead with the appointment before the election. He is due to name his candidate this evening.

Sponsored

Mrs Barrett’s children include one who has Down’s syndrome, contributing to conservatives’ belief that she will support restrictive rulings on abortion in cases pushed by anti-abortion campaigners. They aim ultimately to overturn Roe v Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that guaranteed women’s right to choose an abortion.

If she

title: With Alexei Navalny in jail, opposition hopes are growing that his wife, Yulia, will take over as leader
text:
Alexei Navalny made a heart gesture to his wife, Yulia, as he was sentenced

Alexei Navalny smiled wryly towards his wife, Yulia Navalnaya, and traced a heart shape on the glass wall of his courtroom cage last week as a judge in Moscow sent him to prison until at least the autumn of 2023.

The couple had not been alone together since the opposition leader was arrested on January 17 after returning to Moscow from Berlin, where he spent nearly five months recovering from nerve agent poisoning that he said was ordered by President Vladimir Putin.

Sponsored

Yulia, a 44-year-old economist, had been a constant presence at his side during his long and difficult convalescence.

Navalny with his wife and children during his recovery in Berlin

Last month, like tens of thousands of other Russians, she took to the streets on two consecutive weekends to demand her husband’s release. She

title: We mustn’t surrender the UK’s reputation for fighting violence against women
text:
Today, on the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, we must demand that the government step up and commit to creating a safer world where women and girls, no matter where they reside, are able to live a life free of violence.

Though it may feel that a vaccine is in sight, Covid-19 continues to spread around the world infecting more than 50 million people causing 1.3 million deaths.

Sponsored

In the UK and around the world, Covid-19 lockdown measures have unleashed a surge in gender-based violence (GBV) at exactly the same time that the services on which survivors rely on have been cut or forced to close. This has left women and girls trapped in, or forced to return to dangerous households
summary:
Today, on the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, we must demand that the government step up and commit to creating a safer world where women and girls, no matter where they reside, are able to live a life free of violence.
Though it may feel that a vaccine is in sight, Covid-19 continues to spread around the world infecting more than 50 million people causing 1.3 million deaths.

title: Scottish teachers braced for a rise in victims of abuse
text:
Scottish Women’s Aid and Education Scotland have developed new resources to help women and children who experience domestic abuse in lockdown

Teachers have been prepared for a rise in children coming forward to say they have been abused after being away from Scottish schools for five months.

Scottish Women’s Aid has worked with government agency Education Scotland on new resources to equip teachers to support children who disclose domestic abuse they have experienced during lockdown.

Sponsored

The charity said the lockdown “has undoubtedly given abusers more tools to control, isolate and harm women and children”. It points out that Scotland’s domestic abuse and forced marriage helpline, staffed by specially trained workers managed by Scottish Women’s Aid, received 95% more calls between April and June than the same time last year.

A spokeswoman for the charity said: “As lockdown eases slightly — and women, children and young people

title: Marilyn Stowe: Dinner-table chats convinced my son to take up family law
text:
Marilyn Stowe, who recently sold her chain of family law practices to retire, with her son Ben

Marilyn Stowe opened her first office in a converted cobblers in Leeds. An attack by three masked men in 2003 led to a move that kicked off the firm’s growth into the biggest family law practice in the country, with a chain of ten offices, which she sold in 2017 to private equity investors for a figure “substantially in excess of £10 million”.

Dubbed the “barracuda” for her reputation as one of the most formidable divorce lawyers in the UK, Stowe explains the nickname came from a client’s husband, which she took as a “backhanded compliment”.

title: Boris Johnson by Tom Bower, review — he just wants to be loved
text:
Tom Bower’s biography of Boris Johnson opens with exactly the kind of scene you expect. It is August 2019 and our hero has been prime minister for less than a month. To celebrate the birthday of his father, Stanley, he throws a party at Chequers. But the mood is dreadful. Boris’s four children with his estranged wife, Marina Wheeler, are no longer speaking to him and refuse to come. “He’s a shit,” one of the Johnson clan remarks of the new prime minister. “He’s utterly selfish. He’s destroyed the family.” And this is just the first page.

Who is Boris Johnson, really? This book’s subtitle calls him The Gambler, the kind of swashbuckling nickname he might choose for himself. Yet over 500 dense pages
summary:
Tom Bower’s biography of Boris Johnson opens with exactly the kind of scene you expect.
It is August 2019 and our hero has been prime minister for less than a month.
“He’s a shit,” one of the Johnson clan remarks of the new prime minister.
“He’s utterly selfish.
Who is Boris Johnson, really?

title: The Tommy Tiernan Show deserves to be talked up
text:
As with everything else, the pandemic has created problems for television. The filming of drama series was postponed, and chat shows suffered from a lack of in-studio audiences and guests. But a year on, TV production has found a rhythm and, with other avenues of entertainment shut off and everyone at home, it’s the ideal time to be making brilliant television.

The Tommy Tiernan Show, in which the comedian has no idea whom he’s interviewing until they sit opposite him, has been a cut above since it started as a radio experiment in 2015. Now in its fifth TV season, the series has captured the zeitgeist of the pandemic. Where The Late Late Show is forced to settle for Zoom interviews in order to

title: Marvin Hagler obituary
text:
When Marvin Hagler came to London in September 1980, fresh from his honeymoon in Hawaii, to challenge Alan Minter for the Briton’s undisputed world middleweight title, British boxing fans had no real reason to fear any danger to the man from Crawley.

Hagler, with his shaven head and Mephistophelean whiskers, had no great reputation. He had failed in his first attempt at the world title in November 1979 when his fight against Vito Antuofermo at Caesars Palace, Las Vegas, was declared a draw after 15 rounds, though Hagler always insisted he was “robbed”. Minter, by contrast, had beaten Antuofermo on points to take the world crown in March 1980 and had stopped the Italian in the eighth round on his first defence in June that
summary:

title: Rise and fall of Sir Philip Green, the man who lost his Midas touch
text:
Sir Philip Green’s yacht, Lionheart. His empire failed to change with the times or weather the pandemic

Back in 2006 Sir Philip Green was riding high. His family had banked a £1.2 billion dividend from his Arcadia fashion empire and he had elbowed his way into the establishment.

A month before being knighted in the Queen’s Birthday Honours Sir Philip had summoned Tony Blair, then prime minister, to the grand opening of his Fashion Retail Academy project, which the tycoon had also persuaded to be backed by old adversary Stuart Rose with student masterclasses run by Next’s Simon Wolfson.

Sponsored

title: I married a conman. I lost £150,000 — and my dignity
text:
This year is the year I filed for divorce. It all started as the effects of lockdown really bit. But maybe it didn’t. Maybe the signs were there 13 years ago when I met my Chris at a dinner party. He was funny, handsome, erudite. He asked me a lot of questions about myself.

He was interested in my emotional interior world and I was hooked. I remained hooked, despite extremely bad behaviour, over the next decade. In many ways — and I feel ashamed to say this — I still am hooked. This is how it works when you meet a professional charmer. It’s just that you don’t know it at the time.

Sponsored

I am now, however, waiting for my decree absolute. Part of
summary:

title: What’s on TV and radio tonight: Wednesday, December 16
text:
For full TV listings for the week, see thetimes.co.uk/tvplanner

Viewing guide, by Joe Clay

Sponsored

The Vanishing of Suzy Lamplugh

Channel 5, 9pm

It is one of Britain’s most infamous unsolved murders. Suzy Lamplugh, a 25-year-old estate agent, was last seen on July 28, 1986, setting off to meet a client at a property in Fulham, west London. In her office diary she recorded details of a lunchtime appointment with a “Mr Kipper” at a property in Shorrolds Road and the police investigation has centred on identifying the man. Her body has never been found. In 1994 she was officially declared dead, presumed murdered. It was as if she had vanished into thin air and in the 34 years since her disappearance the police have followed

title: Baroness Williams of Crosby obituary
text:
As a politician Shirley Williams always seemed as ready to listen as talk, and this despite her possession of a huskily mellifluous voice. She also gave the impression that fussing about her appearance did not feature high on her list of priorities. In the sexist Seventies, her diminutive form would pointedly surface in newspaper photographs — hair tousled, head tilted, ear cocked, with the whole of her attention evidently fixed on someone else.

In 1981, when she abandoned the Labour Party to join the so-called Gang of Four in founding the Social Democratic Party — signing what would become known as “the Limehouse declaration” at David Owen’s east London house — it had to be pointed out that she couldn’t face the waiting press wearing

title: Justine McCarthy: Mary Robinson must lead on search for missing Princess Latifa
text:
For those of us who celebrated Mary Robinson’s election as Ireland’s first woman president in 1990 the vapour trails of euphoria lingered long after she had left Aras an Uachtarain seven years later. She was a feminist who did not just talk the talk; she had walked the walk to Leinster House and the Four Courts as a senator and a senior counsel, chipping away at the patriarchal edifice to carve out improvements in women’s lives. title: What would Men’s Hour look like? I’ve got a few ideas
text:
With the departure of Jane Garvey and Jenni Murray from BBC Radio 4’s Woman’s Hour, and despite the appointment of the excellent Emma Barnett to the main presenting chair, many have questioned whether the show still has a purpose, or even ever had one. title: The Lost Cafe Schindler by Meriel Schindler, review — a tragic wartime family story
text:
When her father died in 2017 Meriel Schindler felt both angry and numb. Kurt Schindler had been a mountebank, who once admitted that he liked “living on the edge”. He only once held down a job, instead making an income by importing reams of products — from jam to vitamin C supplements — only to fail to pay his suppliers. Even when he was sent to jail — served in Brixton, Wandsworth, Maidstone and finally Ford open prison — he was still dreaming up hare-brained schemes, and after he was freed he transplanted his family from London to his native Austria, where Meriel and her sister again grew accustomed to hiding from bailiffs. Kurt blamed his chaotic ways on being forced to watch his father

title: Abducted, kidnapped, escaped: the ugly tale of Dubai’s princesses
text:
As a child Marcus Essabri used to play with his cousin, Princess Shamsa, in the grounds of the palace where they lived with Shamsa’s mother, Houria, a wife of Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, the man who would later become the immensely wealthy and omnipotent ruler of Dubai. The children would ride horses, take photos of each other in the royal family’s Rolls-Royces and join excursions into the desert, Essabri has recalled in recent interviews. Shamsa was naughty, adventurous and somewhat spoilt, always pushing the boundaries, he says. title: State of Happiness review — oil rigs and fish: it’s Mad Men, Norwegian-style
text:
State of Happiness

BBC Four

★★★★☆

Van der Valk

ITV

★★★☆☆

Sponsored

My list for a good time emphatically would not contain any of the following: oil rigs, fish factories, no pubs and a Norwegian winter. State of Happiness majored heavily in all of these, and sometimes it was all quite, well, heavy. However, it is also set in 1969, which meant that we got the antidote of Mad Men-type fashion, period hairstyles, lovely old cars and drinking in work meetings (those were the days) as we prepare to see Stavanger amid the oil boom of the 1970s.

The producers have apparently denied that this is “Norway’s Mad Men”. Fine, but I was sure I could detect shades of depressed, neurotic, super-smoker Betty Draper

title: Rush Limbaugh obituary
text:
When the arch-Conservative shock-jock Rush Limbaugh announced on air that he had been diagnosed with stage four lung cancer and might not have long to live, Americans were quick to rally round. Even his legion of enemies were impressed by his composure.

President Trump knew at once how to turn the news to his advantage. The next day, on February 4, 2020, during his State of the Union address, he awarded Limbaugh the Medal of Freedom, which was placed around his neck by the first lady, Melania Trump, in full view of senators, members of Congress and the assembled justices of the US Supreme Court. For the right-wing commentator, more used to the bludgeon than the épée, it was a singular moment in which he

title: Our favourite books we read again in 2020
text:
Hard-boiled classic crime, the spying game in Berlin, a comic satire on the newspaper trade, an epic family saga set in Cairo . . . all literary life is to be found in this selection of old favourites.

Peter Brookes, Times cartoonist

James Salter’s The Hunters is an ace novel, in both subject and quality. Aces were pilots with five kills, but as well as describing the aerial battles of the Korean War (in which Salter fought with distinction), the book examines deep conflicts between rival US pilots and within individuals suffering self-doubt. title: The Weirdest People in the World by Joseph Henrich review — why the weird rule the world
text:
Hymn of the West: Joseph Henrich argues that western individualism was turbo-charged by the spread of Protestantism

For obvious reasons, sweeping theories of western civilisational dominance are not the trendy publishing proposition they once were. But here, unfashionably late on in the decline of the West’s cultural self-confidence, is a good one.

Sponsored

In The Weirdest People in the World Joseph Henrich, a Harvard anthropologist, attributes the prosperity, technological superiority and cultural ascendancy of western nations to the psychological strangeness of their populations. Happily for the progressive modern reader, he does not betray suspicious signs of being excited by the West’s historical success — not something that could be said for all his predecessors in the genre.

Henrich’s thesis begins with the idea that if you are Weird (Western, Educated, Industrialised, Democratic) then you are also weird (adj, very strange; bizarre). Psychologically, westerners

But here, unfashionably late on in the decline of the West’s cultural self-confidence, is a good one.

title: Wedding trends 2021: the cool bride guide — and the new bridal brands to know
text:
With smaller ceremonies the new norm, bridalwear has had to adapt — the demand for more affordable, understated looks and non-traditional designs has increased. At Net-a-porter there has been a rise in the popularity of alternative pieces that can be worn post-altar too, such as co-ordinates, slip dresses and suits, and it has more mini and mid-length dresses available versus traditional floor-length gowns. It’s a similar story at Matchesfashion, as sales of bridal jackets, trousers and tops are up 35 per cent, 65 per cent and 40 per cent respectively on last year.
