title: Stanley Kubrick by David Mikics review — there was method behind the cruelty
text:
David Mikics’s scholarly portrait of Stanley Kubrick features a funny and illuminating story from the actor Vincent D’Onofrio. On the set of Kubrick’s Vietnam flick Full Metal Jacket D’Onofrio remembers 300 extras waiting while the perfectionist director fiddled with a camera on top of a crane. An extra loses patience and mutters: “Get off the crane.” An assistant says: “You’ll never get a chance like this; you’re working with Stanley Kubrick, so watch it. No talking.” Another long wait. Still Kubrick doesn’t come down. “Get off the f***ing crane,” another extra yells. This time the director comes down. “Who f***ing talked?” he asks. A voice comes from the back: “I am Spartacus!” Then another: “I am Spartacus!” Kubrick guffawed along with the horde of extras.

Sponsored
summary:
David Mikics’s scholarly portrait of Stanley Kubrick features a funny and illuminating story from the actor Vincent D’Onofrio.
An extra loses patience and mutters: “Get off the crane.” An assistant says: “You’ll never get a chance like this; you’re working with Stanley Kubrick, so watch it.
“Get off the f***ing crane,” another extra yells.
This time the director comes down.
A voice comes from the back: “I am Spartacus!” Then another: “I am Spartacus!” Kubrick guffawed along with the horde of extras.

title: Hawa Abdi obituary
text:
On New Year’s Day 1993, President George HW Bush travelled to the outskirts of Mogadishu, the Somali capital, where he was taken on a tour of Hawa Abdi Hope Village. His guide was “Mama Hawa” herself, a doctor who had turned her family’s farm and the surrounding land into a haven for those fleeing famine, civil war and poverty.

What had begun ten years earlier as a one-room clinic to help women in childbirth had grown into a 400-bed facility with a hospital, school and camp for displaced people; the compound was a makeshift city, one that for a time was home to 90,000 Somalis living in huts made from sticks and plastic sheets. Under Mama Hawa they received medical care, food and education. She
summary:
On New Year’s Day 1993, President George HW Bush travelled to the outskirts of Mogadishu, the Somali capital, where he was taken on a tour of Hawa Abdi Hope Village.
His guide was “Mama Hawa” herself, a doctor who had turned her family’s farm and the surrounding land into a haven for those fleeing famine, civil war and poverty.
What had begun ten years earlier as a one-room clinic to help women in childbirth had grown into a 400-bed facility with a hospital, school and camp for displaced people; the compound was a makeshift city, one that for a time was home to 90,000 Somalis living in huts made from sticks and plastic sheets.
Under Mama Hawa they received medical care, food and education.

title: Inna Modja: my fight against female genital mutilation
text:
Inna Modja appears a daunting example of womanhood. Born in Mali and now based in Paris, she’s a regular cover girl for the likes of French Elle and Vogue Africa and walked the catwalks for dozens of designers at Paris Fashion Week. In France and Francophone Africa, she’s also a huge music star who’s recorded three award-winning albums, with her 2011 single French Cancan (Monsieur Sainte Nitouche) becoming a perennial summer anthem.

Yet for years Modja, 36, felt unworthy of the attention. “I had impostor syndrome,” she says. Her insecurities stemmed back to when she was four years old and – with her mother – visiting Bamako in her native Mali from Ghana where her diplomat father worked.

title: Tom Hayes interview: ‘I challenge anyone not to be scared in prison’
text:
Tom Hayes the Former UBS trader poses for photographs following his release from prison after serving more than five years over the Libor scandal

Tom Hayes suffered from anxiety dreams in the nights leading up to his release from prison last Friday after serving five and a half years for manipulating Libor.

There is one he remembers vividly, when he dreamt that he was stuck halfway through his cell window. “My torso was out of the window and my legs were still in the room,” he said. “I couldn’t move.”

Sponsored

It is perhaps an appropriate metaphor for the limbo that Hayes, 41, feels he has unjustly endured for the past eight years. Arrested in December 2012, he spent two and a half years on bail before becoming the first person to be convicted by a jury for rigging Libor.

title: The UK must act now to save Uighur lives from ethnic cleansing
text:
In September 2000, I left my beloved homeland and my entire family, including my five-year-old son, behind and came to the UK; my son joined me two years later. After witnessing first-hand the violent suppression of peaceful demonstrations against my people in 1997, I felt compelled to leave.

For the past 20 years, I have been unable to return to my home because I have been speaking out against the human rights violations imposed on my people by the Chinese government. My last contact with my brother was in January 2017. He said: “Please leave us in God’s hands, we leave you in God’s hands too”.

Sponsored

title: Meghan’s experience is painful yet relatable
text:
This week I’ve been reminded that I once spent an excruciating Christmas Day with a boyfriend’s family. Not because they were awful, as partners’ families can sometimes be; they were friendly and kind. But because we were all artificially thrown together for the day at that most stressful of times — Christmas. I had never celebrated Christmas so I hovered pointlessly or got in the way. His family didn’t really know me or I them; we didn’t have anything in common.

I ate food I had never really eaten, we made toe-curling small talk and then we exchanged presents that no one particularly wanted. The day was like an awkward first date. I felt like I was intruding on their family, but at least I
summary:
This week I’ve been reminded that I once spent an excruciating Christmas Day with a boyfriend’s family.
Not because they were awful, as partners’ families can sometimes be; they were friendly and kind.
But because we were all artificially thrown together for the day at that most stressful of times — Christmas.
His family didn’t really know me or I them; we didn’t have anything in common.
I ate food I had never really eaten, we made toe-curling small talk and then we exchanged presents that no one particularly wanted.

title: Why I never want to get married
text:
Question: of all the things we can no longer do, of all the social interactions we no longer have, the gatherings we no longer attend, the opportunities we no longer enjoy, how much do we miss weddings? Really? Those big shebangs that once punctuated our summers, monopolising them, should we find ourselves languishing in the late-twenties to mid-thirties age group, when the weddings come thick and fast, constant and competitive: an average three per summer, which, with attendant hen and stag dos, ceremonial dress fittings and bridal showers, leave very little time, money and energy for anything else. Do we miss them more, or less, than: music festivals, casual brunches, unanticipated boozy nights in the pub, air kissing, real hugging, restaurants and galleries and

title: Signs of anxiety, stress and depression in men
text:
If you cannot find any time to be with your children or partner, it is understandable that you may feel lonely

Midlife is the time for a reality check for most men. Your mortality comes into focus. You realise that some of your dreams may be over. Even if men succeed in their fantasy of, say, making money and attaining power, they may realise that they’re still not happy. The question underneath all of this that very few men ask themselves is: who am I really? Who do I want to be?

Last year in particular we were forced to hold up a mirror to our lives. But even without a pandemic, if a man gets to 40 or 50 and realises that he hates his job, leaves it, or loses it, this can lead to a mental crisis. So much of male identity and status
summary:
If you cannot find any time to be with your children or partner, it is understandable that you may feel lonelyMidlife is the time for a reality check for most men.
You realise that some of your dreams may be over.
Even if men succeed in their fantasy of, say, making money and attaining power, they may realise that they’re still not happy.
The question underneath all of this that very few men ask themselves is: who am I really?
Last year in particular we were forced to hold up a mirror to our lives.

title: What the critics are watching and listening to, from Promising Young Woman to Iggy Pop
text:
Promising Young Woman

This is a film, in no uncertain terms, about misogyny. It’s the story of a rape, and a suicide, and a life upturned. But it’s also a movie that crackles and fizzes with style and wit and blackly humorous subtext. It’s written and directed by Emerald Fennell, aka Camilla Parker Bowles in The Crown, making her feature debut with a gobsmacking display of authorial nous. Fennell fills each scene with characters and situations that seem dramatically real, then symbolic, then real again. Carey Mulligan is perfectly cast as Cassandra, a brittle coffee shop barista dealing with the death of her best friend, the victim of a university rape and subsequent downward spiral. But Cassandra is also an avenger and a symbolic

title: PM faces down rebels as Starmer picks new fight
text:
1. Greedy PM faces down lockdown rebels

Two lines stand out in reports of Boris Johnson’s speech to 155 Conservative MPs at a virtual meeting of the 1922 Committee last night. And neither had anything to do with Covid, the subject of his press conference an hour earlier, nor tomorrow’s vote on extending lockdown regulations until September.

The first was an attack on the BBC. The prime minister told MPs: “There is a degree of instinctive metropolitan bias in the BBC newsroom ... Let’s hope they learn from what their viewers and listeners want.”

title: Psychotherapist Philippa Perry on lockdown, love and her marriage to Grayson
text:
I was supposed to meet Philippa Perry at her house in Islington, but by a stroke of luck I got ill, so we had to reschedule for a date when she’d be at her cottage on the South Downs. By the time I reach her door at the end of a winding country track dotted with sheep and cattle grids, nestled in rolling hills, the relocation feels so serendipitous I half wonder if my subconscious might have engineered the illness just to bring me to this idyll.

It’s a ridiculous thought of course, but in the company of a celebrated psychotherapist you can’t help but start thinking about how the mind works. While I’m taking off my coat Perry is already talking about countertransference. The
summary:
I was supposed to meet Philippa Perry at her house in Islington, but by a stroke of luck I got ill, so we had to reschedule for a date when she’d be at her cottage on the South Downs.
By the time I reach her door at the end of a winding country track dotted with sheep and cattle grids, nestled in rolling hills, the relocation feels so serendipitous I half wonder if my subconscious might have engineered the illness just to bring me to this idyll.
It’s a ridiculous thought of course, but in the company of a celebrated psychotherapist you can’t help but start thinking about how the mind works.
While I’m taking off my coat Perry is already talking about countertransference.

title: Martin Bashir, Diana’s interviewer, was elusive, contradictory and a target of hostility
text:
Martin Bashir became a star in his own right after landing high-profile interviews

If there was a single moment that encapsulated the unsettling mixture of awe, mistrust, envy and hostility that has long shaded the stellar television career of Martin Bashir, it came during an after-dinner speech to an audience of journalists in Chicago in 2008.

Bashir was at the height of his renown, arguably the most famous interviewer in the world after his mesmerising encounters with Diana, Princess of Wales and with Michael Jackson — the sometime King of Pop. Lured to America by a seven-figure pay cheque and a high-profile role with ABC News, Bashir was a guest of honour at the annual convention of the Asian American Journalists Association.

As an interviewer, he was widely he was widely hailed for his discreet and sensitive handling

text:
Alan and Judi Heath hold hands for the first time since he moved into a care home in May last year

When they were forced apart by the Covid crisis after 57 years of marriage, the simple act of holding her husband Alan’s hand was one of the things Judi Heath missed the most. But today, when they were reunited at his care home, she was able to clasp it once again.

title: “I risked our lives to flee”: escaping domestic violence in lockdown
text:
It’s close to midday and a young mother is freewheeling a bicycle down a slope on the communal lawn of a women’s refuge with a carefree expression on her face. Nearby her three-year-old stands barefoot in the warm June sunshine, looking somewhat bemused at his mum’s new-found playfulness. He begs for a ride and a smile spreads across his face.

For years Gemma, 23, and her son were subjected to horrific abuse and control at the hands of her husband. Only now can she savour the simple pleasure of playing with her child without fear. They are among a small number of women and children who have found sanctuary at this refuge for victims of domestic abuse in the north of England. Nestled on a
summary:

title: China Room by Sunjeev Sahota review — this novel deserves to win prizes
text:
We expect certain things from a multigenerational family saga set in India. Colour, food, demotic speech, a little bit of magic. We expect a fat book with a pretty, bright jacket thanks to those heady days when Arundhati Roy, Vikram Seth et al led western readers safely through a post-colonial literary landscape. In fact, it was Salman Rushdie’s Midnight’s Children that compelled Sunjeev Sahota to become a writer; it was the first novel he read, when he was 18.

Sahota is now one of Britain’s most fêted young novelists. His second novel, The Year of the Runaways, was shortlisted for the Booker prize in 2015 and he was one of the “40 under 40” chosen by the Royal Society of Literature to bring their

title: How true is The Great, the lavish new drama about Catherine of Russia?
text:
Mobs of pedants are chasing makers of historical dramas, calling for series such as The Crown to carry warnings that they may be on the imaginative side of the facts. Well, Tony McNamara, the creator of The Great, a sardonic new series based on the life of Catherine the Great, has got the right idea. Each episode of his show, coming to Channel 4 this week, is preceded with the legend: “An occasionally true story.”

This suggests two things. That The Great is based on history, but not wedded to it. And that it’s going to be a hoot. McNamara, an affable, iconoclastic Australian, co-wrote the Oscar-nominated screenplay of The Favourite, which also played fast, loose and hilariously with history. Swap the English
summary:
Mobs of pedants are chasing makers of historical dramas, calling for series such as The Crown to carry warnings that they may be on the imaginative side of the facts.
Well, Tony McNamara, the creator of The Great, a sardonic new series based on the life of Catherine the Great, has got the right idea.
Each episode of his show, coming to Channel 4 this week, is preceded with the legend: “An occasionally true story.”This suggests two things.
That The Great is based on history, but not wedded to it.
McNamara, an affable, iconoclastic Australian, co-wrote the Oscar-nominated screenplay of The Favourite, which also played fast, loose and hilariously with history.

Food distribution and Packaging

€341m (£300m) ▲€43m

One of Northern Ireland’s biggest businesses, W&R Barnett has worldwide interests including molasses, animal feed, grain, oils, commodity trading, laboratory testing, storage and packing. It is chaired by Barnett, 76, the fourth generation to run the family conglomerate, founded in Belfast in 1896 as a grain merchant.

title: Hardline Hindus force interfaith Indian TV ad off air
text:
Hindu nationalists have forced the withdrawal of a TV advert showing an interfaith couple celebrating the upcoming birth of their child, the latest intensification of the culture war in India.

The commercial was intended as a celebration of tolerance and diversity but instead provoked a furious reaction for showing a Hindu woman arriving at a baby shower thrown by her Muslim in-laws. As the two families and faiths join in celebration of the unborn child the narrator asks, “What can’t we achieve, if we are united?”

title: How accurate is The Dig? What’s true and false in Netflix’s Sutton Hoo film
text:
The Sutton Hoo excavation, which forms the central focus of the new Netflix film The Dig, produced one of this country’s most important archaeological finds. Dubbed “Britain’s Tutankhamun”, the uncovering of a 1,300-year-old ship entombed beneath a huge mound in Suffolk was breathtaking. As sensational golden treasures emerged, spectral visions of vanished royal lives — probably the Anglo-Saxon king Raedwald — were irresistible. The film is based on a novel by John Preston in which more attention is paid to excavating the characters of those doing the digging, than to the archaeology. But how much does The Dig — directed by Simon Stone — reflect the reality of Sutton Hoo?

Could you see the ship as clearly as it appeared on screen?

The first
summary:
The Sutton Hoo excavation, which forms the central focus of the new Netflix film The Dig, produced one of this country’s most important archaeological finds.
Dubbed “Britain’s Tutankhamun”, the uncovering of a 1,300-year-old ship entombed beneath a huge mound in Suffolk was breathtaking.
As sensational golden treasures emerged, spectral visions of vanished royal lives — probably the Anglo-Saxon king Raedwald — were irresistible.
But how much does The Dig — directed by Simon Stone — reflect the reality of Sutton Hoo?
Could you see the ship as clearly as it appeared on screen?

title: Up close and personal with Prince William: an intimate portrait of the future king
text:
Next month Prince William will celebrate his tenth wedding anniversary — the day he became a duke and embarked on the most formative decade of his life. Back then, the tentative 28-year-old newlywed was not ready to devote himself entirely to royal duties. A decade on, he is in a very different position.

The job of being the heir to the heir to the throne, of finding a balance between life and duty, is difficult at the best of times. These are not the best of times. In their bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey this month the Duke and Duchess of Sussex accused the royal family and the institution around it of racism and callous disregard for a suicidal newcomer, among many other damning charges.
summary:
Next month Prince William will celebrate his tenth wedding anniversary — the day he became a duke and embarked on the most formative decade of his life.
Back then, the tentative 28-year-old newlywed was not ready to devote himself entirely to royal duties.
A decade on, he is in a very different position.
The job of being the heir to the heir to the throne, of finding a balance between life and duty, is difficult at the best of times.
These are not the best of times.

title: Luster by Raven Leilani review — when there are three in a marriage
text:
The first novel by the New York writer Raven Leilani is a darkly entertaining story of things forced together until they uncomfortably fit.

First, there is a romantic clash between the protagonist, Edie, her lover, Eric, and his wife, Rebecca. They have an open marriage, but one that works on the condition of discretion, which Edie quickly destroys. Then there is a generational clash of an unhappy 23-year-old with the equally dissatisfied middle-aged couple on whom she soon becomes dependent. And finally there are clashes of life experience: between Edie, a black woman, parentless too soon and living in a cockroach-infested flat; this wealthy suburban white couple; and Akila, their adopted black daughter, whose hair is falling out because her parents don’t know how to

title: Rod Liddle: Troops pour over a border and we appease their leader. Stop me if you’ve heard this one before
text:
I have become very bored with this virus and come to the conclusion that thermonuclear war might be a more agreeable way to finish us all off. The cleansing light of a thousand suns, and then: adios. No need for hand sanitiser, hoarded lavatory paper or a bloody QR code app thing on our mobile phones so we can get into the pub.

Luckily, as a well-connected journalist, I have a hotline to the various gods of Armageddon and they are already working their magic, as you will notice if you cast your eyes in the direction of southeastern Ukraine. Are Luhansk and Donetsk the Sarajevo and Poland of the Third World War?

Probably not, according to the many doveish experts I have read recently,

title: Mary Astell: pioneering feminist’s library unearthed at Cambridge University
text:
Catherine Sutherland, deputy librarian at Magdalene College, with the collection that she discovered

Almost 50 books and pamphlets that belonged to the writer and philosopher often regarded as “the first English feminist” have been found in the library of a Cambridge University college.

Copious annotations in the 47 works in English, French and Latin reveal how Mary Astell, who lived from 1666 to 1731, engaged with politics, religion and complex natural philosophy, such as the ideas of René Descartes.

Sponsored

Astell was a proponent of women’s education who railed against the “unjust” monopolising of learning by men. The works were identified by Catherine Sutherland, deputy librarian at Magdalene College, based on handwriting comparisons and other clues.

Mary Astell urged the education of women ALAMY

title: MPs debating harassment claims against them is ‘slap in face’ for victims
text:
Jacob Rees-Mogg has introduced restrictions which would prevent MPs from referring to details of harassment cases but staff affected say this does not address their concerns

Victims of sexual harassment and assault have said plans to allow MPs to debate complaints against members are “retraumatising” and “a slap in the face”.

MPs will be asked to approve proposals today which will permit them to discuss serious allegations against members of the House on the floor of the Commons, despite a long-running campaign for a fully independent process. Supporters say the plan upholds an important constitutional principle that MPs should have the final word on matters that may result in the expulsion of a member.

Sponsored

Jasvinder Sanghera, a campaigner against forced marriage, had a complaint of sexual harassment upheld against Lord Lester of Herne Hill, a former Liberal Democrat peer, by the Lords conduct watchdog in 2018. He denied the allegations.

text:
Immigrants should adopt French values, rely on work rather than welfare payments and stop listening to left-wingers who say they are victims of racism, according to a newly published book.

It contains the sort of ideas that President Macron is seeking to promote in his fight against what he defines as Islamist separatism.

title: Chris Froome’s rocky marriage with Sir Dave Brailsford destined to end unhappily
text:
There are two ways for the Sir Dave Brailsford/Chris Froome relationship to end well. Brailsford can decide winning isn’t the only thing or Froome can accept it’s OK to be a first lieutenant on a team going into the Tour de France. Neither is going to happen. So, to this relationship, there will be no happy ending.

The best thing that could happen is that they go their separate ways.

Sponsored

It’s complicated though. Froome, 35, is contracted to ride with Team Ineos until the end of the season and Brailsford has said that he can’t leave unless the team agree. With an ageing champion, it’s ever thus. Ineos have three leaders going into this summer’s Tour, scheduled to begin in Nice on August 29. If

Brailsford can decide winning isn’t the only thing or Froome can accept it’s OK to be a first lieutenant on a team going into the Tour de France.

title: Our pick of the latest paperbacks, February 13, 2021
text:
American Dirt by Jeanine Cummins

This bestselling novel about the migrant crisis caused controversy in the US with critics complaining about “cultural appropriation” — how dare Jeanine Cummins, a white woman, write about Latin Americans from their perspective. The scandal definitely told us more about the weirdness of Twitter than the quality of the actual novel, a literary thriller that follows Lydia and her son, Luca, who are forced to flee to the US after the rest of their family are murdered by a drug cartel. Leaving behind their middle-class life in Acapulco, they have to navigate all the perils of illegally crossing the border. title: Airline crews trained to spot forced marriage
text:
Distressed young people and one-way travellers with lots of luggage are seen as warning signs

Airline staff will be trained to spot signs of forced marriage amid fears of a surge in cases of women being taken abroad as travel restrictions ease.

Charities have said that calls from young people whose parents are intent on marrying them off against their will have more than doubled.

Sponsored

Freedom, a forced marriage charity, is helping to train ground and cabin staff to spot signs of someone being taken abroad, most often to Pakistan, for a forced marriage. An overly distressed young person, someone travelling one way with lots of luggage and families wearing wedding jewellery are all indicators, according to experts.

A gay Saudi Arabian woman claimed asylum in Ireland because of the marriage equality referendum and the fact that Leo Varadkar was taoiseach.

Alamri Amjaad, 22, arrived via Turkey in late February. She has applied for asylum because she claims that her life is at risk in her country due to her sexuality.

Speaking to The Times through an interpreter, she said she wanted to come to Ireland because the situation for women in Saudi Arabia was “very bad”. She added: “Simply, I am gay and I left Islam, I don’t believe in it anymore. It is against my rights as a gay person and a human.”

Ms Amjaad said she was going to be forced to marry a man if she stayed in Saudi

title: Oxford Nanopore: the DNA detectives on the trail of £3.9bn blockbuster float
text:
On a Friday afternoon in March, Matthew Loose made an alarming discovery. The professor of developmental and computational biology at Nottingham university analyses samples from Covid-19 patients in the area to track the spread of strains. Using a DNA sequencer, Loose found that a patient at a nearby hospital had tested positive for the vaccine-resistant South African variant of the coronavirus. More worryingly, this person had not travelled overseas — meaning they had picked it up locally.

“It was the first time we’d seen this strain,” said Loose, 44, who informed the hospital’s head of infection control. “What we have done well in the UK is set up surveillance — we can identify and monitor what’s happening.”

Sponsored

Loose is one of a network of DNA

title: Klara Kasparova obituary
text:
One Sunday morning in the spring of 1968 at their home in Baku on the Caspian Sea, Klara Kasparova and her husband were grappling over the breakfast table with a chess problem printed in a Soviet newspaper.

When the solution proved elusive, their five-year-old son, Garry, intervened to point out that all they needed to do was to promote a pawn to a knight and the problem was solved. Kasparova was surprised for she was unaware that her son even knew how to play.

Sponsored

Within a month he was repeatedly beating his mother and father, who were both accomplished chess players. By the age of 12 he was the Soviet junior chess champion.

Kasparova and her son

title: John Edrich obituary
text:
A brave and combative left-handed opening batsman who played 77 Tests for England, John Edrich made up in application and temperament what he lacked in style. He was an undemonstrative figure who did not seek attention and his achievements tended to be undervalued. Yet his Test record of 5,138 runs at 43.54 stands comparison with that of most of his contemporaries. Seven of his 12 Test hundreds were made against Australia, against whom he averaged nearly 49. More naturally gifted players, such as Ted Dexter, Tom Graveney and Colin Cowdrey had averages down in the thirties.

Edrich also joined the small band of batsmen to make 100 centuries, only the third left-hander after Philip Mead and Frank Woolley to do so. He achieved the feat
summary:
A brave and combative left-handed opening batsman who played 77 Tests for England, John Edrich made up in application and temperament what he lacked in style.
He was an undemonstrative figure who did not seek attention and his achievements tended to be undervalued.

More naturally gifted players, such as Ted Dexter, Tom Graveney and Colin Cowdrey had averages down in the thirties.
Edrich also joined the small band of batsmen to make 100 centuries, only the third left-hander after Philip Mead and Frank Woolley to do so.

title: Who is Carrie Symonds? The rise and rise of Boris Johnson’s fiancée
text:
Carrie Symonds’ Instagram feed is a millennial dream – all giant negronis, baby elephants and refurbished pink velvet chairs. “Apples” (her username) is shown beaming at dinner with friends, campaigning to save the whale and looking ravishing in a bikini on an Italian beach. There are many selfies of the 32-year-old blonde with Dilyn the Downing Street dog. On January 31, the day Britain left the EU, the Jack Russell is pictured dressed in a Union Jack coat.

In February, Symonds posted a photograph of herself with Boris Johnson. She is staring straight at the camera, flawless skin, stylish straw trilby, neat gold hoop earrings. He is kissing her on the cheek, his eyes closed in apparent devotion. Alongside the image is the emoji-studded announcement,
summary:

“Apples” (her username) is shown beaming at dinner with friends, campaigning to save the whale and looking ravishing in a bikini on an Italian beach.

She is staring straight at the camera, flawless skin, stylish straw trilby, neat gold hoop earrings.

title: Here’s a blockbuster idea: a lie‑filled show about a TV boss’s family. I bet the Queen would watch
text:
I am three-quarters of the way through the latest series of The Crown, which is being shown on Netflix, and so far I’ve seen the funeral of Lord Mountbatten, overlaid with the soundtrack from an IRA statement on British oppression in Ireland. I’ve watched Princess Diana vomiting noisily and often. And I’ve heard Michael Fagan, the man who broke into Buckingham Palace, explaining to the Queen how so many lives were being ruined by Mrs Thatcher’s policies.

Meanwhile, the Queen Mother has not yet uttered a single pleasant or kind word, Prince Andrew has told his mother about what his latest girlfriend did with an aeroplane joystick, Prince Charles has been perpetually wet and useless and Mrs Thatcher has explained she doesn’t like women,

title: Couples, beware watching Us: it might give you itchy feet
text:
Anna Maxted

Quite recently I sat dazed in a hospital bed, holding a tiny child, marvelling, I have a son. Now he’s off to university. Life passes in a blur. “We’ve only got 20 good summers left,” says my best friend spitefully, “and this one’s been a write-off.” Is it too late for a thrilling second act? Even if we withered husks were up for adventure and reinvention, we’re stuck at home thanks to the pandemic. As my 15-year-old said when he heard of a fiftysomething’s divorce, “But what’s the point, now?”

This may be why David Nicholls’s book Us — adapted by the BBC as a four-part drama — depicts both a fantasy and nightmare. Albie, the only child of Connie and Douglas Petersen,

title: Oliver Stone: ‘You talk about fake news. I feel that way about MI5 and MI6’
text:
‘It’s a strange place, England,” Oliver Stone informs me at the start of our Zoom call. “You’ve managed to make it worse than it was,” he says, speaking from his home in Los Angeles. “You’ve turned it into World War Two with your attitudes over there. The English love punishment, it’s part of their make-up.”

You sure know how to break the ice, Mr Stone. It’s a slightly galling accusation, given that he has hitched his wagon to Russia, hardly a paragon of enlightenment. The New York-born writer-director has never shied from ruffling feathers, though. Stone has taken on the American establishment to thrilling effect in his movies, from Platoon to Born on the Fourth of July, JFK to W, Salvador to Snowden
summary:
‘It’s a strange place, England,” Oliver Stone informs me at the start of our Zoom call.
“You’ve managed to make it worse than it was,” he says, speaking from his home in Los Angeles.
“You’ve turned it into World War Two with your attitudes over there.
The English love punishment, it’s part of their make-up.”You sure know how to break the ice, Mr Stone.
The New York-born writer-director has never shied from ruffling feathers, though.

title: My escape from a Chinese internment camp
text:
After two or three days at the internment camp, Sayragul Sauytbay heard the screams for the first time. She had been sent to work as a teacher in one of the centres where China “re-educates” Uighurs and other ethnic groups in the northwest province of Xinjiang. Already she had seen that the “living dead” inmates, shaven-headed with black eyes and mutilated fingers, were chained together in packed, stinking cells.

The sounds of distress resonated through the halls of the “concrete coffin” in which they were housed. “I’d never heard anything like it in all my life. Screams like that aren’t something you forget. The second you hear them, you know what kind of agony that person is experiencing,” she wrote later. “They sounded like the
summary:
After two or three days at the internment camp, Sayragul Sauytbay heard the screams for the first time.
She had been sent to work as a teacher in one of the centres where China “re-educates” Uighurs and other ethnic groups in the northwest province of Xinjiang.
Already she had seen that the “living dead” inmates, shaven-headed with black eyes and mutilated fingers, were chained together in packed, stinking cells.
The sounds of distress resonated through the halls of the “concrete coffin” in which they were housed.
The second you hear them, you know what kind of agony that person is experiencing,” she wrote later.

title: Keeley Hawes on life with Matthew Macfadyen, acting in a pandemic and loneliness
text:
Sadly this bleak midwinter it does not fall to Keeley Hawes to take our minds off the Grim Reaper — but then how was British television’s favourite actress to know that a pandemic would bring universal resonance to the three separate dramas she was about to star in? Although Finding Alice, It’s a Sin and To Olivia are hugely different in tone from one another, they are all much possessed by death. Each time, however, Hawes attacks this meatiest of subjects with something like relish. At one point, as we discuss the most distressing of the productions, Russell T Davies’s Eighties Aids serial, she describes working on It’s a Sin as “an absolute joy”. Watch and you will understand what she means.

Death is
summary:

title: British girl stuck in Syrian camp was trafficked at 12 then raped
text:
Syria’s Roj camp, pictured, and Al Hol camp are thought to house nine British men, 16 women and 34 children

A British girl who was trafficked to Syria at the age of 12 and then raped and impregnated by an Islamic State fighter is among 50 women and children stranded in refugee camps.

A report from the campaign group Reprieve reveals that two thirds of British women detained in northeast Syria were coerced and trafficked to the region before being sexually exploited.

Sponsored

The group says that many were under 18 when they travelled to Isis territory and have suffered years of exploitation, including forced marriage, rape and domestic servitude.

Some have since had their own children, who are denied basics such as education and consular assistance. Reprieve argues that the government is “systematically failing trafficking victims” by not bringing them home.

The Conservative MP Andrew

title: How it feels to... be a stepmother to twins
text:
‘One should always go into a marriage with one’s eyes stark staring open.” That is a line from my novel, Darling, the tale of a black British stepmother and her toxic relationship with her white English stepdaughter. It may be unforgivable for an author to quote herself off the bat, but what do I care? I too am a stepmother, after all, and unforgivable by definition. Vows have been broken for me even to exist. Unlike the blended family of my novel, our own family’s time together, though often challenging, has been more joyful than homicidal.

I knew that Peter, my separated boss at the marketing company he ran, was a single father to two five-year-old twins, Emma and Charlie, before we went on

title: Single in 2020: the year when dating stopped
text:
The end of another year, and time to strike resolved resolutions off the list and write new ones. So what have you achieved? One of my resolutions has been the same for a few years: find a nice man. I’m a few weeks off 33, single and in the middle of the marriage-and-babies years. Or at least my friends are. In truth all that I’m in the middle of at the moment is a family-sized panettone.

In 2020 “single” took on a new meaning. If you lived alone you isolated alone. That’s 15 million or so people in the UK for whom the first national lockdown meant solitary confinement for 23 hours a day (and a solitary walk for the other one). No real life

title: Czech Republic will be first former eastern bloc country to legalise gay marriage
text:
Legalising gay marriage would show that the Czech Republic belongs firmly in the West, supporters say

The Czech Republic is set to become the first country in the former eastern bloc to legalise gay marriage after MPs passed a new equality law.

The bill, which enjoys widespread public support, according to polls, has been in front of parliament for three years but opponents had delayed a vote until its proponents finally forced a special session today to pass the legislation.

Sponsored

The result will be closely watched in Hungary and Poland whose leaders often extol “traditional values” and where constitutional stipulations define marriage as a union between a man and a woman. Budapest and Warsaw are key “conservative” forces in the culture wars raging across Europe and have implemented several anti-LGBT policies.

title: To ignore the plight of the Uighurs is to forget the lessons of the Holocaust
text:
After 75 years the two tonnes of human hair piled up to the ceiling in Auschwitz is disintegrating. Only the tightly bound children’s plaits retain their shape. The Nazis, who were big on euphemisms, called this “human recycling” and used the hair to make military socks and blankets.

News of the seizure of 13 tonnes of Uighur hair, on a US-bound ship from China and destined to be sold as wigs, brought back memories of those ghostly display cases.

Sponsored

The plight of the Muslim Uighurs touches the rawest of Jewish nerves. We’ve been here before. A full head of human hair weighs about an ounce. There are 35,274 ounces in a tonne, so that hair was shorn from half a million heads.

Its owners
summary:
After 75 years the two tonnes of human hair piled up to the ceiling in Auschwitz is disintegrating.
The Nazis, who were big on euphemisms, called this “human recycling” and used the hair to make military socks and blankets.

A full head of human hair weighs about an ounce.
There are 35,274 ounces in a tonne, so that hair was shorn from half a million heads.

text:
The long-running British soap opera Emmerdale has landed itself in hot water because a forthcoming episode features a couple deciding to abort a child diagnosed with Down’s syndrome. This has outraged families who have children with this condition, and for good reason.

title: There’s no better expression of British values than welcoming Hongkongers
text:
It’s often said that you can measure the progress of a society by how women are treated. I think a similar test applies to China. You can measure how authoritarian China has become by the treatment of minorities in that country. And without a doubt China is more authoritarian now than it has been for generations.

Over the past few years the Chinese government has crushed the freedoms that once made Hong Kong famous. The right to protest, the right to speak freely, the right to even a small amount of democracy — these no longer exist.

title: Unmarried women no longer have to flee UAE if pregnant
text:
Unmarried women who become pregnant in the United Arab Emirates will no longer have to flee the country for an abortion or marry in the latest move by the Gulf state towards secularism.

Previously, unmarried women who became pregnant faced deportation or jail, with expatriates commonly flying abroad for a shotgun wedding, or opting for a termination in their home country.

Sponsored

Many low-paid workers who could not afford to leave, including maids who have been raped by their bosses, have been forced to give birth secretly and bring up their children hidden from authorities.

Children born to unmarried parents cannot obtain a birth certificate, and are not eligible for healthcare or education.

title: Andra Day on playing Billie Holiday: I drank, I smoked, I lost three stone
text:
She takes the stage with stately poise — jaw set, killer frock, a gardenia in her hair. Under a single spotlight she sings Strange Fruit, the chilling portrait of a lynching that became one of the first protest songs and made its singer a target for the American government. You won’t see many better performances than Andra Day’s in The United States vs Billie Holiday. Her portrayal of Holiday in the film captures the woman’s full complexity; by turns imperious and vulnerable, glamorous and wretched, warm and cold. As more and more nations have expressed their concern about the growing evidence of concentration camps and even genocide in the Chinese province of Xinjiang, there has been silence from the one entity that has the whole of suffering humanity at the core of its mission. I refer to the Holy See.

Pope Francis — who was open in his criticism of Donald Trump’s Mexican “border wall” — has nothing to say about this publicly. title: Ministers are right to take control of abortion in Northern Ireland
text:
It is shameful that in 2021 women and girls in Northern Ireland are still being denied the same rights to abortion as women and girls across the rest of the United Kingdom. Quality healthcare is a basic human right.

I respect that this is a matter of conscience for many. I have defended the right of those in parliament who passionately disagree with me to not be shouted down. However, the law changed in Northern Ireland a year ago and it is unfathomable that we would stand by and allow it to be ignored. Women and girls in Northern Ireland must not be treated as second-class citizens.

title: What the critics are watching and listening to, from Promising Young Woman to Iggy Pop
text:
Promising Young Woman

This is a film, in no uncertain terms, about misogyny. It’s the story of a rape, and a suicide, and a life upturned. But it’s also a movie that crackles and fizzes with style and wit and blackly humorous subtext. It’s written and directed by Emerald Fennell, aka Camilla Parker Bowles in The Crown, making her feature debut with a gobsmacking display of authorial nous. Fennell fills each scene with characters and situations that seem dramatically real, then symbolic, then real again. Carey Mulligan is perfectly cast as Cassandra, a brittle coffee shop barista dealing with the death of her best friend, the victim of a university rape and subsequent downward spiral. But Cassandra is also an avenger and a symbolic

title: Freeze Chinese oppressors’ dirty money and assets in UK
text:
Disney’s new Mulan film brings into focus again the Chinese government’s brutal repression of the Uighur population in Xinjiang. The end credits of the new film give thanks to different government entities from the province despite detailed reports of more than one million people being kept in so-called re-education camps there.

Included in those thanked is the public security bureau in the city of Turpan, which experts have suggested is the body primarily tasked with running the internment camps. This is no small thing. Reports from the camps are horrific, detailing physical abuse, squalid conditions, and forced denouncement of religion. Forced sterilisations and abortions have also been reported, with human rights groups likening the situation to genocide.

Sponsored

Calls to boycott the film were already being
summary:
Disney’s new Mulan film brings into focus again the Chinese government’s brutal repression of the Uighur population in Xinjiang.
The end credits of the new film give thanks to different government entities from the province despite detailed reports of more than one million people being kept in so-called re-education camps there.
Included in those thanked is the public security bureau in the city of Turpan, which experts have suggested is the body primarily tasked with running the internment camps.
Reports from the camps are horrific, detailing physical abuse, squalid conditions, and forced denouncement of religion.
Forced sterilisations and abortions have also been reported, with human rights groups likening the situation to genocide.

title: Court in South Korea tells Japan to pay compensation to wartime sex slaves
text:
Portraits of late former South Korean “comfort women” on display near the Japanese embassy in Seoul

A court in South Korea has ordered Japan to pay compensation to a group of former wartime sex slaves in a ruling that will worsen tensions between the neighbours.

The Japanese government reacted angrily to the order by the Seoul central district court to pay 100 million won (£67,000) to 12 “comfort women”, a handful of the hundreds of thousands who were forced into brothels for the Imperial Japanese Army. The court granted an order that makes it possible to seize Japanese government assets to cover the compensation award.

Sponsored

Japan refused to acknowledge the case, claiming that the courts of one country cannot claim jurisdiction over the government of another. It took no part in the proceedings.

“State immunity cannot be applied to crimes

title: Alba candidate Margaret Lynch angers global LGBT group
text:
Margaret Lynch, an Alba candidate for Central Scotland, said that proponents of “queer theory” want to lower the age of consent

An international gay rights group has condemned “dangerous and irresponsible” claims by Alex Salmond’s Alba Party that it is campaigning to lower the age of consent to ten years old.

Margaret Lynch, an Alba candidate for Central Scotland, claimed proponents of “queer theory” want to lower the age of consent. Alba said her remarks were “based on fact”.

Sponsored

The row stems from a misrepresentation of the term “adolescent” adopted by the International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association (ILGA), a global alliance of more than 1,300 groups which includes Stonewall Scotland and LGBT Youth Scotland.

ILGA signed a women’s rights declaration that seeks the global repeal of “laws limiting legal capacity of adolescents, people with disabilities or other groups to provide consent to sex”.
summary:
Margaret Lynch, an Alba candidate for Central Scotland, said that proponents of “queer theory” want to lower the age of consentAn international gay rights group has condemned “dangerous and irresponsible” claims by Alex Salmond’s Alba Party that it is campaigning to lower the age of consent to ten years old.

Alba said her remarks were “based on fact”.

ILGA signed a women’s rights declaration that seeks the global repeal of “laws limiting legal capacity of adolescents, people with disabilities or other groups to provide consent to sex”.

title: Poland implements near-total ban on abortions
text:
Demonstrators took part in a pro-choice protest in the centre of Warsaw yesterday

Protests broke out across Poland as the government brought into immediate effect a controversial law that effectively outlaws abortion.

The official publication of a court ruling late yesterday tightens already strict laws in Poland, which will now permit the procedure only in cases of rape, incest and when the mother’s life is at risk.

Sponsored

In its October verdict, the country’s top constitutional court deemed terminations in cases of foetal defects, which accounted for nearly 98 per cent of Poland’s just over 1,000 legal terminations in 2019, to be unconstitutional.

Protests break out across Poland after abortion ban

Last night thousands of protesters gathered in the capital chanting “this is war” and “my body, my choice” as they marched from the Constitutional Tribunal in central Warsaw towards the headquarters of the ruling Law and

text:
The dramatic stop and search carried out on black British athlete Bianca Williams and her partner Ricardo dos Santos at the weekend has brought home, once again, the need for reform. Now don’t get me wrong, I’m not in favour of scrapping the police – there’s no way I could deal with an unemployed husband getting bored at home, for starters – and I believe stop and search tactics are needed, yet the manner in which this particular act is carried out must change. Why? Because black people are still being targeted unfairly.

Legal action at The Hague yesterday coincided with a white paper protest — free of banned slogans — by Legco councillors in Hong Kong over the new security law

Exiled members of China’s Uighur minority have submitted hundreds of pages of evidence to the International Criminal Court alleging genocide and crimes against humanity — the first attempt to use international law to hold President Xi accountable for atrocities in Xinjiang province.

They are seeking an investigation into the alleged involvement of more than 30 senior Communist Party officials in the repression of Muslim minorities in western China. The complaint speaks of “widespread and systemic” crimes that “have taken placed on a mass scale”.

title: MPs must back the genocide amendment to oppose the oppression of the Uighurs
text:
In the 1948 Genocide Convention, genocide is defined as five prohibited acts committed with the intention of destroying a group of people “in whole or in part”. As well as the more obvious acts of killing and causing serious harm, the list includes preventing births, forcibly removing children and “deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part”.

These acts must be carried out with the intention to destroy. This is what distinguishes genocide from other international crimes. But few genocidal regimes leave a paper trail detailing their genocidal intentions, and so intent can be inferred from actions.

Sponsored

Is what is happening to the Uighur people in China a genocide? Let us look at
summary:
In the 1948 Genocide Convention, genocide is defined as five prohibited acts committed with the intention of destroying a group of people “in whole or in part”.
These acts must be carried out with the intention to destroy.
This is what distinguishes genocide from other international crimes.
But few genocidal regimes leave a paper trail detailing their genocidal intentions, and so intent can be inferred from actions.

title: David Quinn: Be a man — stand up to Beijing on human rights
text:
Part of Disney’s new live-action remake of Mulan was shot in China, where the story is set. Some filming was done in the Kumtag desert in Xinjiang. That northwestern province is, of course, the home of China’s Uighur Muslims, which the Beijing government has subjected to mass internment, forced abortion and sterilisation, and a campaign of relentless ideological indoctrination — all of which amounts to cultural genocide.

In the end credits of Mulan, Disney thanks the public security bureau in the Xinjiang city of Turpan and the “publicity department of CPC Xinjiang Uyghur autonomy region committee”. According to Chinese expert Adrian Zenz, Turpan’s public security bureau runs China’s internment camps while the “publicity department” produces state propaganda in the area.

Sponsored

What Disney has done

title: China condemned by Mike Pompeo after report of mass sterilisation of Uighurs
text:
China has been accused of displaying an “utter disregard for the sanctity of life” after a German researcher claimed Beijing had used mass sterilisation and forced abortions to suppress birth rates in its restive Uighur minority by as much as 80 per cent.

The report, based on leaked Chinese communist party (CCP) documents, suggested that up to 34 per cent of married Uighur women of reproductive age had been targeted with a campaign of sterilisation surgery and contraceptive implants.

Sponsored

The authorities in the province of Xinjian aimed to sterilise at least 80 per cent of women who were capable of having children in four southern districts, according to Adrian Zenz, senior fellow in China studies at the Victims of Communism foundation in Washington.

title: China is guilty of genocide against Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang, says US report
text:
Canada, Britain and the EU joined the US last week in imposing new sanctions on four Chinese officials involved in the Xinjiang abuses

China is committing genocide and crimes against humanity against Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang, the US State Department declared in its annual human rights report to Congress, raising the stakes in the superpowers’ fraught relationship.

Anthony Blinken, the secretary of state, verbally endorsed his predecessor, Mike Pompeo’s judgment that China was guilty of genocide during his confirmation hearing but the report is the first time the charge has been formally laid before Congress.

Sponsored

The State Department is required to submit the report annually to Congress for the government to take countries’ human rights into consideration when formulating trade and foreign policy.

The 2019 report under the Trump administration accused the Chinese government of a campaign of mass detention of Uighurs and other Muslim minorities in camps
summary:

title: Man found guilty of sexual assault on asylum seeker
text:
The jury at the Central Criminal Court in Dublin convicted the man of sexual assault but was deadlocked on further charges of rape

A 54-year-old man has been convicted of sexually assaulting a woman who had come to Ireland seeking asylum.

The man, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had pleaded not guilty to three counts of rape, one of sexual assault and one of attempted rape of the woman at his Dublin home over the weekend of December 1-3, 2017.

Sponsored

The jury told Mr Justice Alex Owens, after eight and half hours of deliberation at the Central Criminal Court in Dublin, that they could reach a majority verdict on one count but they were deadlocked in relation to the other four.

Mr Justice Owens remanded the man in custody and revoked his bail before he adjourned sentencing to July 12.

title: Kids Company undermined by false claims of sexual abuse, says judge
text:
Camilla Batmanghelidjh, Alan Yentob and six former trustees of Kids Company were vindicated after a ten-week hearing at the High Court

The charity Kids Company would have succeeded but for unfounded claims of sexual assault, a judge said as trustees including Alan Yentob and Camilla Batmanghelidjh received the all clear to run companies.

Yentob, Batmanghelidjh and six former trustees faced a ten-week hearing at the High Court after the official receiver argued that they should be banned from being company directors. The case detailed claims of politically driven briefings designed to bring about the downfall of the charity by figures such as Dominic Cummings, and “planted” stories alleging sexual assault.

title: Almost 50 sexual offences revealed by St Andrews
text:
An open letter to St Andrews demanding changes to its misconduct policies garnered 500 signatures

The University of St Andrews has defended its record on student safety after 47 reports of sexual assaults and harassment in the past four years.

Officials at the alma mater of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge released the figures after they were criticised by a student group.

They show that 14 reports of sexual misconduct have been recorded in the academic year to 2021, with 11 listed for each of the previous three years.

The university took “disciplinary or precautionary action” in all but one case in the 2018-19 and three cases in the current year.

title: Fewer than one in six women sexually assaulted report it to police
text:
Victims cited embarrassment and a belief that the police could not help as reasons for not formally reporting their experience

Fewer than one in six women sexually assaulted by rape or penetration reported it to the police, new figures have revealed.

Four in ten of them were too embarrassed to formally report the offence, while 38 per cent did not think the police could help and a third feared that the experience would be humiliating.

The annual crime survey by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) found that 1.6 million adults had experienced sexual assault by rape or penetration, including attempts, since the age of 16.

The survey of adults in England and Wales suggests that one in 40 women aged between 16 and 24 are raped or assaulted by penetration, including attempts, every year.

Eighteen cases of sexual violence are reported at universities every week, but overall just one in twenty leads to the accused being expelled, according to data released under information laws.

title: SNP chief whip Patrick Grady steps down amid sexual harassment allegations
text:

title: Rape and sexual assault has an effect on all of society
text:
In the wake of 14,000 testimonies of sexual abuse and harassment published on the website Everyone’s Invited, Ofsted has been ordered to undertake an “immediate review” into safeguarding policies and practices in state and independent schools and colleges. The focus on the education system is well intentioned, but it ignores the much wider problem of sexual violence against young people.

Data from the 2020 Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) shows that nearly one in fourwomen and girls were sexually assaulted since the age of 16, ranging from indecent exposure to rape. A third of all female victims were under 15 years old. Boys aged 10 to 14 account for 29.5 per cent of all victims in recorded sexual offences. In two thirds of
summary:
In the wake of 14,000 testimonies of sexual abuse and harassment published on the website Everyone’s Invited, Ofsted has been ordered to undertake an “immediate review” into safeguarding policies and practices in state and independent schools and colleges.
The focus on the education system is well intentioned, but it ignores the much wider problem of sexual violence against young people.
Data from the 2020 Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) shows that nearly one in fourwomen and girls were sexually assaulted since the age of 16, ranging from indecent exposure to rape.
A third of all female victims were under 15 years old.
Boys aged 10 to 14 account for 29.5 per cent of all victims in recorded sexual offences.

title: Australian prime minister Scott Morrison accused of cover-up after sexual assault claims
text:
Brittany Higgins, who says she was raped at Parliament House, with prime minister Scott Morrison

The Australian prime minister was accused of leading a “don’t ask, don’t tell” culture or being part of a cover-up after four women claimed to have been sexually assaulted by the same ministerial staff member.

The scandal has engulfed the government of Scott Morrison since Brittany Higgins, a former ministerial press officer, alleged last week that she had been raped in parliament at the age of 24 in 2019. Morrison has denied any knowledge of the assault until being told last week.

Sponsored

Since the initial claim, three other women have come forward to report being sexually assaulted by the same ministerial adviser. Police will begin interviewing the alleged victims this week.

The multiple claims and impending investigation provoked opposition claims that Morrison had failed
summary:

title: Millionaire hedge fund boss Crispin Odey cleared of indecent assault
text:
Crispin Odey arriving at court in Westminster yesterday. The judge said his accuser’s evidence was not credible

The multimillionaire hedge fund boss Crispin Odey has been cleared after a junior banker accused him of indecently assaulting her at his home.

The complainant in the case, who met Odey through work, told the court that the financier had put his hand down her shirt and reached up her skirt during a meeting more than 20 years ago.

Then in her mid-twenties, the complainant agreed to a drink with Odey, now 62, in 1998 in the hope that it would “further her career”, the court was told.

Instead, she said, Odey had launched himself at her like “an octopus”.

title: Turkish chef who kissed waitress is cleared of sexual assault
text:
A Turkish chef who kissed a teenage waitress has been cleared of sexual assault after he claimed it would be considered acceptable behaviour in his native country.

Neset Gunbat, 48, was accused of hugging and kissing a female colleague at a restaurant in Macclesfield, Cheshire, where he worked as the head chef. He appeared at Stockport magistrates’ court on two charges of sexual assault after the alleged victim, a university student, reported him to the police.

Sponsored

The waitress told the hearing that Gunbat, known as “Nesh”, had “at first seemed like a nice colleague”. But she said that one night after finishing work in 2019 Gunbat had approached her car window and asked to kiss her.

summary:
A Turkish chef who kissed a teenage waitress has been cleared of sexual assault after he claimed it would be considered acceptable behaviour in his native country.
Neset Gunbat, 48, was accused of hugging and kissing a female colleague at a restaurant in Macclesfield, Cheshire, where he worked as the head chef.
He appeared at Stockport magistrates’ court on two charges of sexual assault after the alleged victim, a university student, reported him to the police.

title: Everyone’s Invited: Universities under pressure as website sexual abuse claims mount
text:
Durham University was among some universities that were named dozens of times on Everyone’s Invited

The website that exposed the scale of sexual harassment and abuse in schools is turning the spotlight on universities.

Everyone’s Invited is today releasing the names of more than 100 universities where students have submitted anonymous testimonies of abuse.

Sponsored

After receiving more than 1,000 accounts in a single week — a fifth of all testimonies posted to the site — the website took the step of naming universities. It had previously stopped naming schools because of concerns about privacy and balance. The site’s organisers said: “We are encouraged that university students have found the confidence to come forward and share their testimonies.

“Many people find that the act of sharing their story helps them in many ways. For some it gives them a sense of

title: Former English National Ballet dancer Yat-Sen Chang ‘used massages as excuse to assault students’
text:
A leading ballet dancer sexually assaulted teenage students under the pretence of sports massages, a court has been told.

Yat-Sen Chang, 51, used his position as a principal dancer for the English National Ballet to abuse four teenage girls, a jury at Isleworth crown court heard yesterday. The celebrated Cuban dancer had a dark side and demonstrated a “pattern” of offending, with increasingly invasive massages, the prosecution said.

Sponsored

The court was told the girls, aged between 16 and 18, were in awe of Chang, who “used his position to commit sexual offences against young students in his care” and believed his fame would protect him. title: Report boys to the police for sexual abuse, top schools told
text:
Latymer Upper School was among those named in anonymous accounts of sexual abuse on an Instagram site set up for the reporting of allegations

The leader of England’s top public schools says she is willing to refer boys to the police after more than 3,000 allegations, ranging from sexual harassment to rape, were posted on Instagram.

Eton, St Paul’s, Harrow, Hampton and Latymer Upper are named in the anonymous accounts of sexual abuse, some from girls as young as 11, posted on @everyonesinvited.

Sponsored

A small number of state schools and universities are also named on the site, set up by Soma Sara, 22, a former boarder at Wycombe Abbey.

The claims include more than 50 of rape, 35 allegedly linked to schools.

One contributor describes being choked until she passed out. Others detail Instagram pages where nude photographs are shared and rated. Many describe being pressured into giving oral
summary:

title: Schools ‘cover-up’ sexual abuse by pupils
text:
One of the country’s most senior police officers has said he believes that schools have covered up sexual offences to protect their reputations as a task force took charge of the surge in abuse complaints.

Chief Constable Simon Bailey told The Times that the outpouring of allegations was the education sector’s “MeToo” moment and that he feared a “culture of misogyny and sexual harassment” had not been challenged in some schools.

Sponsored

Bailey is the lead officer for Operation Hydrant, the national task force for child sexual abuse investigations in institutions. It will assess allegations of abuse in schools before they are given to individual forces to investigate, with a national hotline for abuse reports to be set up within 72 hours.

His comments come after
summary:

title: Brexit has left domestic abuse victims in limbo
text:
Brexit has so far generated headlines about hauliers forced to fill in more customs forms and travellers caught in longer queues at passport control, but it has also created problems for victims of domestic violence.

The issue is that Westminster and Brussels failed to make the Victims’ Rights Directive part of the withdrawal agreement.

Sponsored

The directive came into force in 2015 and allowed protection measures such as non-molestation or restraining orders that are made in one EU member state to be enforced elsewhere in the bloc.

It provided protection for those individuals who had experienced domestic abuse and meant that, having gone through the ordeal of securing an order in one jurisdiction, they would not have to repeat the process.

title: Amber Heard’s domestic violence ‘dossier’ is a hoax, says Johnny Depp
text:
Johnny Depp has rejected claims that he was a serial abuser whose drinking and drug use fuelled attacks on Amber Heard, insisting that her allegations of domestic violence were a premeditated “hoax” and an “insurance policy”.

The Pirates of the Caribbean star told the High Court yesterday that Heard, an actress, began making a “dossier” of false allegations before their wedding in 2015. Depp, 57, is suing Dan Wootton, The Sun’s executive editor, and its publisher in the High Court over a 2018 article that described the actor as a “wife beater”. He denies a series of attacks on Heard, 34.

Sponsored

text:
Julia James was found dead on a remote path near Aylesham, Kent, at about 4pm on Tuesday

The family of Julia James have paid tribute to the “fiercely loyal” community support officer who police say died from a massive head injury.

Her family said in a statement issued through Kent police: “There are no words to adequately describe the void left in our lives by the death of our mum. She was so much to so many people: a wife, mother, daughter, nanny, sister and a friend.

title: The Times Diary: Dame Maggie steals a scene
text:
The name’s Crawley, Violet Crawley. Licence to purse one’s lips and say something acidic. Yes, the Dowager is Back. Dame Maggie Smith will be in the second Downton Abbey movie, on which filming has just started, but Gareth Neame, the producer, is tight-lipped on whether she makes it past the first scene. “You never know,” he says when I ask if she will play a ghost who tuts when people use the wrong cutlery.

title: Brenda Power: Blaming male cruelty on women makes me snap
text:
Eight years ago, Cork farmer Martin McCarthy brutally murdered his little daughter in order to spite her mother and then, rather than face the consequences, drowned himself too. And yet there were some people in Ballydehob who took McCarthy’s side, according to his widow, and blamed her for his wicked deed.

The only reason we can name the drowned child, Clarissa, is because McCarthy was too much of a coward to stand trial for her murder and so, as no charges were brought, no crime was recorded and the prohibition on naming child crime victims doesn’t apply. This technical absurdity is matched by the obtuse absurdity of those locals’ sympathy for the killer, and disdain for his bullied and ultimately devastated wife. They don’t believe
summary:

title: Joe Biden moves to tackle America’s gun ‘epidemic’
text:
President Biden waded into one of the most contentious issues in American politics yesterday by announcing new measures to stem gun violence.

Speaking in the White House Rose Garden to an audience that included those who had lost loved ones in mass shootings in recent years, Biden, 78, denounced members of Congress for offering plenty of thoughts and prayers but little in the way of concrete action to stop the deaths of hundreds of people. “Gun violence in this country is an epidemic,” he said to applause. “And it’s an international embarrassment.”

Sponsored

He thanked those who had the courage to campaign on the issue and “to turn pain into purpose and demand that we take the action that gives meaning to the word ‘enough’”. He
summary:
President Biden waded into one of the most contentious issues in American politics yesterday by announcing new measures to stem gun violence.
Speaking in the White House Rose Garden to an audience that included those who had lost loved ones in mass shootings in recent years, Biden, 78, denounced members of Congress for offering plenty of thoughts and prayers but little in the way of concrete action to stop the deaths of hundreds of people.
“Gun violence in this country is an epidemic,” he said to applause.
“And it’s an international embarrassment.”SponsoredHe thanked those who had the courage to campaign on the issue and “to turn pain into purpose and demand that we take the action that gives meaning to the word ‘enough’”.

title: Donald Trump says Biden is appeasing domestic terrorists
text:
President Trump raised the stakes in his law-and-order election battle with Joe Biden by accusing his Democratic rival of “appeasing domestic terrorists” and praising US marshals who killed a left-wing activist suspected of shooting dead a right-wing protester.

Four officers fired on Michael Reinoehl, 48, as he tried to flee arrest for killing Aaron Danielson, 39, a supporter of Mr Trump and a member of the Patriot Prayer group. Portland,Oregon, where Mr Danielson was killed, was braced for further unrest this weekend as it prepared to mark 100 consecutive days since protests erupted after the death of George Floyd.

title: Cartel claim puts Mastercard in line for fine from regulator
text:
Mastercard has accepted some of the claims levelled against it relating to claims of operating a cartel in the pre-paid cards market

Mastercard is among five card payment companies facing a total fine of more than £30 million for operating a cartel.

Regulators said in a provisional report that the American multinational — along with allpay, Prepaid Financial Services and Sulion, of Britain, and APS, which is based in Luxembourg — had broken competition law by agreeing not to compete or poach each other’s clients.

Sponsored

The report from the Payment Systems Regulator relates to pre-paid cards used by local authorities to distribute welfare payments. They are aimed at some of the most vulnerable in society, including homeless people and victims of domestic violence.

Mastercard, allpay and PFS have acknowledged some breaches. Responding to the allegations, Mastercard blamed two former employees for any unlawful behaviour on its part.
summary:
Mastercard has accepted some of the claims levelled against it relating to claims of operating a cartel in the pre-paid cards marketMastercard is among five card payment companies facing a total fine of more than £30 million for operating a cartel.
SponsoredThe report from the Payment Systems Regulator relates to pre-paid cards used by local authorities to distribute welfare payments.
They are aimed at some of the most vulnerable in society, including homeless people and victims of domestic violence.
Mastercard, allpay and PFS have acknowledged some breaches.
Responding to the allegations, Mastercard blamed two former employees for any unlawful behaviour on its part.

title: Government is failing vulnerable victims of domestic abuse
text:
One of the strange things about this viral pandemic is that we are reacting and responding to something we cannot see, yet it is pervasive and destructive. Furthermore, our desire to restrict its spread through periods of lockdown has inadvertently led to the rise in other unseen and destructive things. Behind closed doors it is not only isolation which has increased, so too has the scourge of domestic abuse, which has been referred to as a shadow pandemic.

This week the Domestic Abuse Bill reaches Report Stage in the House of Lords and for the first time will provide a statutory definition of domestic abuse which includes emotional, controlling, coercive and economic abuse as well as physical violence. It has been repeatedly pointed out that

title: Tories ‘dismissing violence against women by not suspending rape suspect MP’
text:
The biggest unions representing staff at Westminster have joined women’s charities and the TUC in calling for the MP to be suspended pending a full investigation

The Conservative Party has been accused by women’s charities and trade unions of “minimising violence against women and girls” by refusing to suspend an MP arrested on suspicion of rape.

The MP, a former minister, was arrested on Saturday after a former parliamentary aide accused him of assault and sexual offences. However, the Conservatives have made clear they will take no action against him while the allegations are investigated.

title: Coronavirus in Ireland: Airbnb offers temporary rooms for victims of domestic violence
text:
Airbnb will work with Safe Ireland to offer places to stay when specialist accommodation cannot be found

Airbnb will provide free temporary housing for victims of domestic violence if specialist emergency accommodation is not available.

The company said it will source hotels for women and cover all costs in partnership with Women’s Aid and Safe Ireland.

Sponsored

Capacity in specialist accommodation for victims of domestic violence is down by about 25 per cent because of the need to ensure safe social distancing and to allow for isolation units if needed.

The Women’s Aid National Helpline responded to 39 per cent more calls during the crisis compared with the same period in 2019.

Safe Ireland, the national policy and services hub for 39 domestic abuse member services, will co-ordinate the initiative with its frontline services and support from the Women’s Aid national freephone helpline.
summary:
Airbnb will work with Safe Ireland to offer places to stay when specialist accommodation cannot be foundAirbnb will provide free temporary housing for victims of domestic violence if specialist emergency accommodation is not available.
The company said it will source hotels for women and cover all costs in partnership with Women’s Aid and Safe Ireland.
SponsoredCapacity in specialist accommodation for victims of domestic violence is down by about 25 per cent because of the need to ensure safe social distancing and to allow for isolation units if needed.
The Women’s Aid National Helpline responded to 39 per cent more calls during the crisis compared with the same period in 2019.
Safe Ireland, the national policy and services hub for 39 domestic abuse member services, will co-ordinate the initiative with its frontline services and support from the Women’s Aid national freephone helpline.

title: Victims of domestic abuse told to take civil action as courts clog up
text:
Victim Support said in its report that police had been slow to respond to some domestic violence incidents

Victims of domestic abuse and harassment have been encouraged by the police to take civil action rather than a criminal prosecution because the system is overwhelmed, it has been claimed in a report.

Victim Support’s assessment of the pandemic’s impact stated that police responses to crime were slower than before, and that some victims had tried to kill themselves because of court delays.

Sponsored

In its report, due to be released today, it says: “Staff have also found that police have been encouraging [Victim Support] service users to go down the civil route, for example applying for a non-molestation order rather than criminal justice process or prosecution.”

Victim Support is an independent charity that provides specialist services to help people affected by crime. Its report, Crime

title: Twitter bans Trump permanently for glorifying violence
text:
Mr Trump has used Twitter to announce policy, sack colleagues and stoke domestic tensions

President Trump has been banned permanently from Twitter, severing forever his favourite way of communicating with his supporters.

The social network explained a move it had resisted for years by saying that Mr Trump’s recent tweets, in which he called his supporters “great American patriots” and declared he would not attend Joe Biden’s inauguration, posed a “risk of further incitement of violence”.

title: Gender-based violence is a global pandemic
text:
The UN estimates that in the 12 months before the pandemic 242 million women and girls were subjected to sexual or physical violence. While this is a shocking figure, experts predict that it will be significantly increased by the Covid-19 crisis.

In the UK the lockdown has confined many women to a home they share with their abuser, resulting in dramatic increases in domestic violence. Overseas, predators in conflict zones have taken advantage of the distracted international community to commit monstrous crimes of sexual violence.
