title: Gun crimes and violence soar as gangs settle scores after lockdown
text:
Police forces had tried to take advantage of lockdown to arrest known gang members

Violence on the streets has surged to levels not seen since before Covid-19 alongside sharp rises in gun crime as gangs settle scores and enforce debts.

Firearms were discharged in London at nearly twice the rate last month as the same period last year and Scotland Yard recorded its third highest month for violent crimes in a decade.

title: Domestic abuse victims and rough sleepers to benefit from £76m boost for ‘most vulnerable’
text:
Robert Jenrick, the communities secretary, announced the £76m package “to support the most vulnerable in society” Russell Hart/Alamy

The communities secretary today announced £76m of funding to support “the most vulnerable in society”, including survivors of domestic and sexual abuse, vulnerable children, rough sleepers and victims of modern slavery.

Giving the daily Downing Street press briefing, Robert Jenrick said people in danger should not stay at home during the lockdown and pledged to give domestic abuse victims priority for social housing.

Reports of domestic abuse sent to police by Crimestoppers have surged by nearly 50%, while the charity Hestia has seen a 47% rise in victims using its free domestic abuse support app Bright Sky.

Jenrick said: “I can announce a package of over £76m in new funding to support the most vulnerable in society during the pandemic.

“This funding will help charities…

title: Large rise in domestic abuse over three years
text:
The number of incidents reported to gardaí this year has risen sharply, but the number of individual victims has stayed about the same

The number of people who reported that they suffered domestic violence shot up by 57 per cent between 2016 and 2019.

Department of Justice figures showed that 7,489 individuals contacted gardaí last year, up from 4,755 in 2016. The latest figures showed that the number of reported victims of domestic violence this year had stayed at a similar level to 2019, with 7,258 people contacting gardaí up to November 23.

Sponsored

Separately, however, the force has reported that the number of individual incidents of domestic violence reported has increased by 18 per cent so far in 2020. This has widely been attributed to the lockdowns and other pandemic restrictions.

title: “I risked our lives to flee”: escaping domestic violence in lockdown
text:
It’s close to midday and a young mother is freewheeling a bicycle down a slope on the communal lawn of a women’s refuge with a carefree expression on her face. Nearby her three-year-old stands barefoot in the warm June sunshine, looking somewhat bemused at his mum’s new-found playfulness. He begs for a ride and a smile spreads across his face.

For years Gemma, 23, and her son were subjected to horrific abuse and control at the hands of her husband. Only now can she savour the simple pleasure of playing with her child without fear. They are among a small number of women and children who have found sanctuary at this refuge for victims of domestic abuse in the north of England. Nestled on a
summary:

Nearby her three-year-old stands barefoot in the warm June sunshine, looking somewhat bemused at his mum’s new-found playfulness.

title: Caitlin Moran: how I’ve learnt to deal with online abuse
text:
It’s funny, the skills and knowledges you acquire as you get older and the world changes. For instance, if “abuse on social media” were, say, an area of the Lake District, I would be as a wise, local shepherd, who knows every nook and cranny, and can predict the next week’s weather – simply by looking up at the sky.

“Ahhh,” I would say, leaning on my crook. “I see Labour MP Jess Phillips has tweeted about domestic violence and women’s refuges. There will be a heavy shower of people called ‘@prouddad57757575’ replying, ‘But what about MALE victims of domestic violence, Jess, you misandrist feminazi?’ before nightfall.”

title: Ex-garda chief Karl Heller to help male victims of domestic abuse group Men's Aid
text:
A former senior garda who led investigations into child and domestic abuse has joined Men’s Aid, an organisation that provides support services to male victims of domestic violence and coercive control, writes John Mooney.

Karl Heller, a former chief superintendent who once commanded the force’s community relations branch, has been recruited to work as a “court accompaniment” who will provide support services to abuse victims.

Sponsored

The role involves attending in camera hearings at the family courts where victims apply for protection and barring orders against wives, partners and girlfriends who engage in violent and threatening behaviour.

Heller’s work will include supporting men who have been denied access to their children or subjected to violence and psychological abuse. “Domestic violence doesn’t discriminate by sex,” he said.
summary:

Heller’s work will include supporting men who have been denied access to their children or subjected to violence and psychological abuse.
“Domestic violence doesn’t discriminate by sex,” he said.

title: Coronavirus in Scotland: Domestic violence soars as families endure lockdown
text:

Reports of domestic violence have soared during lockdown with women and children being trapped indoors with their abusers, it has emerged.

The volume of calls to the national domestic abuse helpline and similar services have risen by 50 per cent in recent weeks.

text:
Three children sought help for the first time every day for six months

More than 4,000 women and children contacted a domestic violence service for the first time during the first six months of the pandemic.

The 3,450 women and 589 equates to 19 women and three children every day.

title: Rooms review — a colourful portrait of urban living
text:
★★★★☆

Do we really know what goes on behind the closed doors of our neighbours? The city that the Norwegian choreographer Jo Stroemgren conjures up in his hour-long dance film for Rambert is quite the place. All human life seems to be here. title: PFS hit with €1m fine for role in ‘payments cartel’
text:
Prepaid Financial Services (PFS), the payments company founded by entrepreneurs Noel and Valerie Moran, has been fined up to €1 million after allegations that it participated in a cartel in Britain with rival providers.

A provisional report published last week by the UK’s Payment Systems Regulator alleged that PFS, together with Mastercard, Allpay, Sulion and APS, broke competition law by agreeing not to poach each other’s customers or compete for contracts to provide pre-paid cards to local authorities in Britain.

Sponsored

These cards are used to distribute welfare payments to homeless people, victims of domestic violence, asylum seekers and “other vulnerable members of society”, the regulator said.

text:

Irish supermarket chains have no immediate plans to follow Lidl in providing free sanitary products to women and girls, it has emerged.

title: Turkey summons Italian ambassador after Mario Draghi called Erdogan ‘dictator’
text:
Turkey has summoned Italy’s ambassador after his country’s prime minister called President Erdogan a “dictator”.

Mario Draghi’s comments were made while he was expressing support for Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, who was not given a chair during a meeting this week with Erdogan and Charles Michel, the European Council president. Instead she was sidelined on a sofa.

Sponsored

Draghi said during a press conference in Rome that he “felt sorry for the humiliation” inflicted on von der Leyen. Michel was given a seat alongside Erdogan at the meeting in Ankara.

Mevlut Cavusoglu, Turkey’s foreign minister, posted a tweet that condemned “the unacceptable populist rhetoric of the appointed Italian Prime Minister Draghi and his ugly and unrelenting statements about our elected president”.

Matt Moulding, 49, who is the son of a road resurfacer and was expelled from school for bunking off to visit his brother in prison, is giving back some of the wealth he acquired as an online retail entrepreneur.

Moulding made his fortune with The Hut Group, which began in 2004 as a retailer of CDs

Divorces rose by 5 per cent in the final quarter of last year with domestic violence applications increasing by more than a fifth, official family court figures published today showed.

Legal experts said that the rising number of marriage break-ups and allegations of abuse in the home were an indication of the “emotional burden” weighing on many couples as a result of the coronavirus lockdowns.

The figures were higher in most categories, with domestic violence allegations up 21 per cent and divorces rising by 5 per cent.

title: Starmer ‘to axe shadow chancellor’ Anneliese Dodds after Labour poll slump
text:
Sir Keir Starmer is preparing to replace his shadow chancellor, Anneliese Dodds, in a shake-up of his frontbench team.

Starmer, who will mark his first anniversary as Labour leader next Sunday, is due to demote several underperforming shadow ministers after the local elections in an attempt to get on the front foot and challenge Boris Johnson.

title: Court orders to stop domestic abuse soared in lockdown
text:
Domestic violence in the country’s first lockdown led to a record number of people using the courts to protect themselves from abusers, new figures show.

More than 8,800 applications for domestic violence remedy orders were made in England and Wales between April and June 2020, the highest number ever recorded by the Ministry of Justice in a quarter. The figure was 24% higher than the same quarter last year.

The sharp rise has been attributed to the “pressure cooker” effect of lockdown, trapping victims at home. A Women’s Aid survey found that more than 60% of those living with an abuser reported that their predicament got worse during the pandemic.

title: Teachers given help to spot signs of domestic abuse
text:
Professionals who work with children were asked to look out for anger and stress-related illnesses

Local authorities are sending domestic violence resource packs to schools to help teachers to recognise signs of abuse at home, due to an increase in incidents of abuse during the pandemic.

There was a sharp rise in the number of people seeking support from domestic violence during the first six months of the Covid-19 pandemic.

Sponsored

Between March and August of 2020, 3,450 women and 589 children contacted a domestic violence service for the first time. It is a crime that often goes under-reported, so the true prevalence is likely to be higher.

The information packs have been distributed to schools and other professionals such as GPs and community volunteers in Roscommon, Dublin City North and Fingal. They contain information on different types of domestic abuse

title: Domestic abuse charities need a lifeline from the chancellor this week
text:
Every day can be terrifying when you are living with a perpetrator of domestic abuse. Home is supposed to be a place of safety, but for too many this is not the case. Often the only lifeline victims have to keep them safe are frontline workers in small, local domestic abuse charities.

But frontline services are facing a cliff-edge in funding, with no guarantees that these services will have the money to keep going beyond March 2021. That’s why, ahead of the spending review on Wednesday, we are calling on Rishi Sunak, the chancellor, and Boris Johnson, the prime minister, to ensure that there is longer-term sustainable funding to make sure these frontline domestic abuse services have a sustainable future.

Sponsored

These key workers provide so
summary:
Every day can be terrifying when you are living with a perpetrator of domestic abuse.
Home is supposed to be a place of safety, but for too many this is not the case.
Often the only lifeline victims have to keep them safe are frontline workers in small, local domestic abuse charities.
But frontline services are facing a cliff-edge in funding, with no guarantees that these services will have the money to keep going beyond March 2021.
That’s why, ahead of the spending review on Wednesday, we are calling on Rishi Sunak, the chancellor, and Boris Johnson, the prime minister, to ensure that there is longer-term sustainable funding to make sure these frontline domestic abuse services have a sustainable future.

title: Police search for stranger after PCSO Julia James found murdered in Kent woodland
text:
Julia James often walked her dog in the woods where her body was found

A police community support officer found murdered near woodland in Kent may have been the victim of a random attacker, detectives believe.

They are investigating whether Julia James, 53, who had worked for the police for nearly 15 years and had been commended for bravery, was set upon by a stranger.

Sponsored

She was found on a path at the edge of a field in Akholt Wood, Snowdown, near Dover, about 4pm on Tuesday. Her Jack Russell terrier was beside her body.

Officers from Kent’s serious crime directorate are investigating the attack on James, who is thought to have worked in the domestic violence unit. Officers are examining whether the attacker was in the area the previous day.

title: Rates of domestic abusers completing anti-violence courses drops during pandemic
text:
One organisation that offering workshops for men to address the violence they wreak on their partners reported a 90 per cent drop in completion rates

The number of men who have completed domestic violence mitigation programmes has dropped sharply despite a rise in incidents during the pandemic, figures from the Department of Justice show.

The garda force recently reported that incidents of domestic violence have increased by 18 per cent so far in 2020. This has widely been attributed to the lockdowns and other coronavirus restrictions.

Sponsored

The latest figures show that two of the three programmes supported by the Department of Justice have reported a significant fall in completions.

In response to a parliamentary question from Mark Ward, a Sinn Féin TD, Helen McEntee, the justice minister, said “very few men have completed the programme due to the disruption in providing the group programme this year.”

title: David Thompson: Free police from handling some domestic cases, suggests chief
text:
David Thompson, the chief constable of West Midlands police, said few domestic abuse referrals end up in the criminal justice system

Police should be freed from handling some domestic abuse and harassment complaints so they can focus on fighting crime and responding to emergencies, one of the country’s most senior police officers has suggested.

David Thompson, chief constable of West Midlands police, said forces were increasingly responsible for “policing relationships”, safeguarding and protection but it was “debatable whether or not that’s actually something best discharged by the police in all cases”.

Sponsored

His remarks drew anger from Refuge, a leading support charity, which said that domestic abuse was a “serious life-threatening crime and all police should respond to it as such”.

However, Mr Thompson, who runs the second largest force in England and Wales, said that a very high proportion of domestic abuse referrals were unlikely
summary:

text:
Paul Parks, who served in the SAS, was banned from the clergy for two years

A former soldier who became a vicar has been defrocked for abusing his wife, whom he called “Jezebel”, for 14 years.

The Rev Paul Parks, 60, formerly rector of St Helen’s Ore and St Barnabas in Hastings, was arrested in 2017 after his wife revealed the abuse, which included beating her and threatening to stab her with a letter opener.

title: Measures needed to cut persistent sexual violence
text:
Tougher measures to tackle gender-based violence are needed in Scotland, campaigners and politicians have said after figures highlighted blackspots for sexual offences.

A breakdown of crimes, including rape and assault, last year shows that the highest number, 203, were recorded in the Anderston/City/Yorkhill area of Glasgow, followed by Edinburgh’s Liberton/Gilmerton ward, with 102. Govan, in Nicola Sturgeon’s Glasgow Southside constituency, had 100, as did Buckhaven, Methil and Wemyss villages in Fife.

Sponsored

A total of 13,240 incidents were reported last year, an average of more than 1,000 a month. When the number of sexual offences is adjusted to account for population, the highest rate was recorded in the police division of Fife, with 32.3 crimes for every 10,000 people. title: Worry over trans reform widespread, survey shows
text:
60% of respondents to a Panelbase poll for the Sunday Times said trans women should not be allowed to compete in women’s sporting events

Proposals for gender reforms in Scotland are causing widespread concern amid calls for more open public debate on the issue.

A Panelbase poll for The Sunday Times found that 54 per cent of those surveyed were opposed to trans women using female changing rooms in venues such as swimming pools and sports centres, when “don’t knows” were excluded. On the question of trans women having access to lavatories in cinemas, theatres and pubs, 54 per cent expressed support. Sixty per cent said that trans women should not be allowed to compete in women’s sporting events, while 27 per cent thought they should. title: Is gun violence in the United States increasing?
text:
Is gun violence in the United States increasing?

American gun violence is broadly categorised in two ways: mass shootings, which are usually defined as where four or more people are killed at the same time, and smaller incidents. Despite several high-profile shootings last month — especially those in Atlanta and Boulder — the numbers killed in such events decreased markedly during the pandemic. Between March 2020 and the start of this year, there were no such public mass shootings, although 2018 and 2019 were especially bad.

The murder rate has increased, however. A report published at the end of last year by a group of criminal justice academics found that the total number rose sharply in 2020, up 30 per cent on 2019’s figures and
summary:

title: Russia struggles to awaken from its domestic abuse nightmare
text:
Vera Pekhteleva was beaten to death by her ex-boyfriend

There is a saying in Russia: “If he beats you, it means he loves you.” The trouble is that, if he beats you, you may well end up dead because the police refuse to save you.

That is what happened to Vera Pekhteleva, 23, an economics student, after she broke up with her boyfriend.

title: Drug feuds and domestic abuse reach 10-year peak
text:
Police said that there had been a series of stabbings linked to drugs gangs after the market was disrupted by Covid-19

Violent crime has hit its highest level in a decade with a surge in drug feuds, domestic violence and hate crime attacks, analysis by The Times shows.

Police said drug rivalries had become increasingly vicious as gangs fought to retain their turf after the first phase of the pandemic.

title: Misogyny and violence won’t die with the Yorkshire Ripper
text:
The death on Friday of Peter Sutcliffe, the so-called Yorkshire Ripper, will not be mourned, although the deaths of his 13 known murder victims — there were probably more — should be. His death has brought some painful reminders and an element of closure to their relatives.

Yet in burying Sutcliffe, have we also buried the incompetence and misogyny that let his killing spree last so long? John Robins, chief constable of West Yorkshire police, has offered a “heartfelt apology” for mistakes in the investigation and for the “language, tone and terminology” of the senior officers in charge of it.

Sponsored

He was right to do so. As Julie Bindel — who fears she came close to being a victim — describes in News Review today

title: Sewell review is an overdue step in the right direction on race
text:
Thomas Sowell said: “When you want to help people, you tell them the truth. When you want to help yourself, you tell them what they want to hear.” It’s a fitting mantra to underpin the kind of race debate that has recently been raging.

The report by the Commission on Race and Ethnic Disparities is out today. Evidence-based, it tells truths that some don’t want to hear. Truths like racism still exists in the UK, but disparities don’t always arise because of it. Truths like geography and socioeconomic factors are far more likely to drive unequal outcomes. An anti-domestic abuse charity has received almost 50 per cent more calls since the coronavirus pandemic began, compared with the same period last year.

title: Domestic abuse victims in Ireland to receive rent supplement without means testing
text:
Emergency calls for help relating to domestic violence have increased by 25 per cent this year, according to garda statistics

Victims of domestic violence will be able to access the state’s rent supplement payment without a means test, the government has said.

Under changes announced by the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection, victims of domestic violence can get immediate access to rent supplement for a three-month period to ensure that they are not prevented from leaving their home because of financial concerns.

Sponsored

The department said that the usual rent supplement means test would not apply to this period. After that a further three-month extension may be provided, subject to the usual rent supplement means assessment. title: Met police officer accused of rape by two colleagues was not suspended
text:
Both women were awarded substantial sums last year after the compensation authority concluded that police evidence indicated that they had suffered serious sexual and physical abuse

A serving officer with the Metropolitan Police accused of rape by two female colleagues has continued working since the allegations surfaced four years ago.

The officer, who has not been charged, was restricted in his interactions with the public but the force has not prevented him from working with female colleagues.

Sponsored

The two co-workers accused him of sexual and physical abuse but the case was not taken up by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), according to the Bureau of Investigative Journalism.

However, the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA), which compensates the victims of violent crimes, awarded both women substantial sums last year after concluding that police evidence indicated that each had been the victim of serious sexual and physical abuse.

The government-run CICA assesses cases
summary:

The officer, who has not been charged, was restricted in his interactions with the public but the force has not prevented him from working with female colleagues.

title: Johnny Depp fails to overturn ‘wife beater’ verdict in libel trial
text:
Johnny Depp arrives at the Royal Courts of Justice last July for his libel case

Johnny Depp has failed to win permission to appeal against a ruling that he is a “wife beater” after judges today dismissed his claim that a retrial was necessary because of the “devastating” impact on his career.

The Pirates of the Caribbean star had claimed that the evidence of his former wife Amber Heard was unsafe because she had told a “manipulative lie”about donating her £5 million divorce settlement to charity.

Sponsored

Lord Justice Underhill, sitting with Lord Justice Dingemans, rejected his claim that there was a compelling case for a retrial because the outcome had been “devastating for Mr Depp” and had “wider repercussions for alleged victims of domestic violence or those accused of it”.

Depp, 57, sued The Sun for libel over an article

title: Private detective joins search for Briton Sarm Heslop
text:
A private investigator has been called in to hunt for clues to the whereabouts of a British tourist missing in the US Virgin Islands.

Friends or family of Sarm Heslop’s American boyfriend, Ryan Bane, have hired the detective as frustration mounts over the handling of the case by US Virgin Islands police, who have asked the FBI to “support” but not lead the inquiry.

Sponsored

“I am confidently saying I know Ryan is innocent but we need to get real authorities involved,” Flora Pickard, a friend of Bane, said yesterday. Bane, 44, called police early on March 8 to report Heslop, 41, missing from his luxury catamaran, Siren Song, on which they had lived together for several months. It was moored around 150ft from shore
summary:
A private investigator has been called in to hunt for clues to the whereabouts of a British tourist missing in the US Virgin Islands.

title: Student rape victim wrote essay to understand attack
text:
William Muir was found guilty of three rapes involving the student and a 28-year-old woman at the High Court in Edinburgh

A student wrote a personal thesis on the definition of consent to work out whether she had been raped by a boyfriend, a court has been told.

When she completed her PhD research the 30-year-old woman concluded that the verbal and physical abuse to which William Muir subjected her meant that she had not willingly consented to sex with him.

Sponsored

She told a court that she had been “playing a character” in an attempt to defuse an angry row with Muir and that character would have been OK in having sex with him. However, she said that looking back on the experience she realised that she had not freely consented to intercourse.

The jury took five and a half hours to find Muir, 32, guilty

title: Admissibility of similar fact evidence to show propensity to domestic abuse
text:
Court of Appeal

Published October 6, 2020

R v P Children (Children: Similar Fact Evidence)

Before Lord Justice David Richards, Lord Justice Hickinbottom and Lord Justice Peter Jackson

[2020] EWCA Civ 1088

Judgment August 18, 2020

The approach to the admissibility of similar fact evidence in family proceedings was the same as the approach in civil proceedings.

Sponsored

Where similar fact evidence was admitted and it comprised an alleged pattern of domestic abuse, the court had to be satisfied to the civil standard that the facts relating to the alleged occasions of abuse had been proven so as to form a sufficient basis to sustain a finding of propensity to domestic abuse.

title: Glasgow Women’s Aid plans nursery classes on toxic behaviour
text:
Primary school pupils will be taught about consent and coercive control, and lessons may be extended to under-fives

Nursery children may be taught about healthy relationships to help them to recognise abuse under charity plans.

Glasgow Women’s Aid said that it hoped to include under-fives in a new project for teenage girls that highlights “red flags” for abuse. Such behaviour can be easier to spot in celebrity stories than real life, the charity said.

Ruth McMillan, an outreach worker, said: “There is a culture of young people not recognising issues are abuse and that’s what we want to address.

title: Coronavirus in Ireland: 25% increase in domestic abuse during lockdown
text:
Drew Harris, the garda commissioner, said gardaí had placed focus on crimes against the vulnerable during the restrictions

Almost 5,600 incidents of domestic abuse have been recorded by gardaí in the past two months in a surge of cases linked to Covid-19 restrictions on people’s movement.

New figures provided by An Garda Síochána show gardaí have dealt with 5,592 cases of individuals who have been the subject of domestic abuse since Operation Faoiseamh, the Garda’s dedicated domestic violence operation during lockdown, was launched on April 1.

Sponsored

The figures represents a 25 per cent increase in the number of domestic abuse incidents recorded by gardaí over the same period in 2019.

Drew Harris, the garda commissioner, said gardaí had placed significant focus on crimes against the vulnerable during the restrictions introduced to combat the spread of the Covid-19 virus, particularly on victims

title: Sexual abuse survivors want Dario Gradi to be stripped of MBE
text:
An independent review concluded that Gradi “should have done more” to investigate rumours circulating about Bennell

A support group representing the survivors of sexual abuse in football has written to the Cabinet Office demanding that Dario Gradi have his MBE taken away.

This week an independent review led by Clive Sheldon, QC, concluded that the former Crewe Alexandra manager “should have done more” to investigate rumours circulating about Barry Bennell, the now convicted paedophile who raped and abused young boys under the care of the club’s academy.

Sponsored

The FA confirmed for the first time that Gradi has been suspended indefinitely from football since 2016, with such bans in place when “a particular individual could potentially pose a risk of harm to children”. It is understood that Gradi’s ban concerns his apparent failure to recognise key safeguarding boundaries.

Gradi told The Times
summary:

title: Too many questions left unanswered for abuse victims let down by football
text:
Four men are on a Zoom call, each with stories so harrowing that it took decades before they could find the words. For Colin Harris, it still pains him to recall hearing his mum ask, ‘What’s happened to our little boy?’ almost 50 years ago. He never could tell her what had transformed him from a promising Chelsea apprentice into a man who talks now of a “long shadow over your life, a very dark shadow”.

Gary Cliffe talks of decades of medication for depression and anxiety, and how sexual abuse at the hands of Barry Bennell when he was a youth player at Manchester City is one reason that he has not brought children into the world.

Sponsored

Also on the call are two more

title: Highgate School’s female pupils walk out in protest at abuse culture
text:
A dossier of testimonies from students past and present has been sent to the governors of Highgate School

Female pupils are planning a walkout today at one of Britain’s most prestigious private schools after it was accused of upholding a rape culture.

A dossier of testimonies from students past and present of abuse and harassment has been sent to the governors of Highgate School in north London. Pupils told The Times that the accounts were upsetting but not surprising.

One said that a boy had pressured girls in Year 8 to send him nude photos and that female pupils were planning to walk out of lessons today and stand outside the head’s office to convey the strength of feeling to the school.

The Times has spoken to a former Highgate pupil who said that boys chanted the name of another boy in support

title: Crewe Alexandra board members urged to resign by MP over handling of sexual abuse scandal
text:
The Sheldon report found the Crewe hierarchy should have done more when rumours first circulated about Bennell

Board members of Crewe Alexandra have been urged to stand down by their local MP over their much-criticised handling of the child sexual abuse scandal at the club.

Last week the independent report published by Clive Sheldon, QC, said that the Crewe hierarchy should have done more when rumours first circulated about Barry Bennell. A youth team coach at Crewe in the 1980s and 1990s, Bennell is serving 34 years in prison for raping and sexually abusing young boys.

Sponsored

Now Dr Kieran Mullan, the member of parliament for Crewe and Nantwich, says that John Bowler, the Crewe chairman, and other members of the board who were there in the Nineties “should consider their positions”.

Bowler and his colleagues have come in for heavy criticism since
summary:

title: Our weak tech laws have made children easy prey for abuse
text:
In 2008 I was commissioned by the government to investigate the harms, some shocking, that children face online. I made more than 30 recommendations, all accepted but many still not realised. Over a decade later the online risks to children have grown immeasurably but we are still waiting for tech firms to take responsibility.

That could all change in the coming months. In December the government revealed proposals for a new Online Safety Bill, which will enforce a duty of care on companies to protect children.

Sponsored

As a clinical psychologist, I see the devastating impact abuse has on children who, via online platforms, are groomed, exploited, abused and left broken. We would not give free rein to child abusers in any other part of society
summary:
In 2008 I was commissioned by the government to investigate the harms, some shocking, that children face online.
Over a decade later the online risks to children have grown immeasurably but we are still waiting for tech firms to take responsibility.
In December the government revealed proposals for a new Online Safety Bill, which will enforce a duty of care on companies to protect children.
SponsoredAs a clinical psychologist, I see the devastating impact abuse has on children who, via online platforms, are groomed, exploited, abused and left broken.
We would not give free rein to child abusers in any other part of society

text:
Pupils stage a protest against rape culture at Highgate School in London. Rachel de Souza said the government must be careful not to kick the problem of sexual abuse in schools into the long grass

The government has announced a review into sexual abuse in schools after thousands of girls shared testimonies of their experiences.

The NSPCC will set up a dedicated helpline to provide support to victims and Ofsted has been asked to examine school safeguarding policies immediately.

The dedicated phone line will go live tomorrow to provide both children and adults, who have experienced sexual abuse in schools, with the appropriate support and advice.

title: ‘A player called my abuser a paedophile — yet I defended him’
text:
Shortly after 9.30am on January 7, 2019, a car drove into a tree near the village of Bottisham in Cambridgeshire. It was a red Mazda 3, and had left the A1303, without skid marks or signs of any other vehicle being involved, on a straight stretch of quiet country road.

It travelled along a grass verge for almost 50 metres before smashing against the tree. Passers-by, paramedics and an air ambulance crew tried to save the driver, but in vain. He was a 75-year-old man, dressed in a pinstripe suit and tie, who that morning had said goodbye to his wife, Pauline, and left their home in Cambridge, ostensibly for Peterborough.

Sponsored

The A1303 near Bottisham, however, was in the opposite direction and 45 miles away
summary:

It travelled along a grass verge for almost 50 metres before smashing against the tree.

title: Eighteen cases of sexual abuse a week at universities
text:
A third of students say they have “learnt more about sex from pornography than from formal education”, according to a report for the Higher Education Policy Institute

Eighteen cases of sexual violence are reported at universities every week, but overall just one in twenty leads to the accused being expelled, according to data released under information laws.

At least 2,800 reports of sexual assault, rape and harassment have been made in the past three years, including more than 1,026 claims last year despite attendance being reduced by Covid restrictions.

Universities have expelled or suspended at least 156 students for sexual violence since 2018, including ten each from Nottingham and Warwick universities.

title: Dulwich College turns boys into sexual abusers, former pupil claims
text:
Billie Errington says Dulwich boys ‘trolled’ a Facebook page she set up when at school

Dulwich College is today accused of being a “breeding ground for sexual predators” in an open letter organised by a former schoolboy that contains more than 100 anonymous accounts of assault, harassment and sharing intimate photos online.

The letter, written by Samuel Schulenburg, 19, a former pupil at the south London private school, said “experiences of assault, revenge pornography and slut shaming were exacerbated by ... young men who ... laughed at stories of sexual violence”.

Sponsored

His letter includes about 100 anonymous testimonies written by girls who went to neighbouring schools, such as James Allen’s Girls’ School (Jags). One claims there was “an established rape culture” at the school.

In a statement issued yesterday, Dr Joe Spence, master at Dulwich, said the school “condemned unreservedly”

title: Ofsted will visit schools named on sex abuse claims website
text:
Ofsted will send inspectors into schools named on the Everyone’s Invited website as it emerged that the regulator failed to mention sexual abuse in any reports on secondary schools in the year before lockdown.

The watchdog said yesterday that it would visit a sample of schools and colleges at which cases had been highlighted. It declined to say how many or how they would be chosen. Inspectors will talk to head teachers and pupils and look at how systems of support and response are working. They will also “discuss the wider issues raised by the evidence” they find.

Sponsored

Gavin Williamson, the education secretary, said last week that an immediate review of sexual abuse in schools would be led by Ofsted and a helpline for victims
summary:
Ofsted will send inspectors into schools named on the Everyone’s Invited website as it emerged that the regulator failed to mention sexual abuse in any reports on secondary schools in the year before lockdown.
The watchdog said yesterday that it would visit a sample of schools and colleges at which cases had been highlighted.
Inspectors will talk to head teachers and pupils and look at how systems of support and response are working.
They will also “discuss the wider issues raised by the evidence” they find.
SponsoredGavin Williamson, the education secretary, said last week that an immediate review of sexual abuse in schools would be led by Ofsted and a helpline for victims

title: Australian leader Scott Morrison denounces sexual harassment in parliament
text:
Australia’s prime minister fought back tears while lamenting the “crap” that women were forced to put up with and expressing disgust at the lewd behaviour of some male employees in parliament.

Scott Morrison’s emotional press conference came hours after a government adviser was sacked over Australia’s mounting scandal of sexism and sexual abuse in Canberra.

Video footage showed the man performing a solo sex act on a female MP’s desk; other government staff also recorded their sex acts within parliament. The footage was routinely shared among a group of male government staff.

“We must get our house in order,’’ Morrison said as he raised the possibility of his party setting quotas to boost the number of female MPs. “Women have been putting up with this
summary:
Australia’s prime minister fought back tears while lamenting the “crap” that women were forced to put up with and expressing disgust at the lewd behaviour of some male employees in parliament.

The footage was routinely shared among a group of male government staff.

title: Rape and sexual assault has an effect on all of society
text:
In the wake of 14,000 testimonies of sexual abuse and harassment published on the website Everyone’s Invited, Ofsted has been ordered to undertake an “immediate review” into safeguarding policies and practices in state and independent schools and colleges. The focus on the education system is well intentioned, but it ignores the much wider problem of sexual violence against young people.

Data from the 2020 Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) shows that nearly one in fourwomen and girls were sexually assaulted since the age of 16, ranging from indecent exposure to rape. A third of all female victims were under 15 years old. Boys aged 10 to 14 account for 29.5 per cent of all victims in recorded sexual offences. In two thirds of
summary:
In the wake of 14,000 testimonies of sexual abuse and harassment published on the website Everyone’s Invited, Ofsted has been ordered to undertake an “immediate review” into safeguarding policies and practices in state and independent schools and colleges.
The focus on the education system is well intentioned, but it ignores the much wider problem of sexual violence against young people.
Data from the 2020 Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) shows that nearly one in fourwomen and girls were sexually assaulted since the age of 16, ranging from indecent exposure to rape.
A third of all female victims were under 15 years old.
Boys aged 10 to 14 account for 29.5 per cent of all victims in recorded sexual offences.

title: Students accuse ‘groping’ teachers in school sex abuse scandal
text:
Dandy Doherty said a staff member at Westminster School gave her a pink teddy bear with the words “baby girl” sewn into it

The scandal over sexual abuse in schools in which more than 13,700 former pupils have come forward with allegations has extended to involve teachers.

Staff are accused of groping female pupils, making sexual comments towards them and masturbating during classes in 20 claims made at schools across London and in Bedfordshire on the Everyone’s Invited website.

Sponsored

Dandy Doherty, a former pupil of Westminster School, a private boys’ school with a mixed sixth form, said she felt “humiliated” after dealing with months of harassment from a staff member while she was in Year 12. title: Male survivors of sexual abuse deserve better
text:
While developing a report on child sexual abuse and exploitation, I have been fortunate to benefit from the advice of a group of survivors who can speak to failings in our system with an expertise we all wish they did not have. Brave and brilliant men and women from all walks of life pulling together to try to drive up standards for the children of today. I have developed nearly 100 policy recommendations to improve our response to these awful crimes with their support and guidance.

We have discussed at length the public conversation on sexual violence that has taken place over the last few weeks: the outpourings of testimony from women and girls on violence and abuse they have endured, the desperate statistics on
summary:

title: Everyone’s Invited: Universities under pressure as website sexual abuse claims mount
text:
Durham University was among some universities that were named dozens of times on Everyone’s Invited

The website that exposed the scale of sexual harassment and abuse in schools is turning the spotlight on universities.

Everyone’s Invited is today releasing the names of more than 100 universities where students have submitted anonymous testimonies of abuse.

Sponsored

After receiving more than 1,000 accounts in a single week — a fifth of all testimonies posted to the site — the website took the step of naming universities. It had previously stopped naming schools because of concerns about privacy and balance. The site’s organisers said: “We are encouraged that university students have found the confidence to come forward and share their testimonies.

“Many people find that the act of sharing their story helps them in many ways. For some it gives them a sense of

Everyone’s Invited is today releasing the names of more than 100 universities where students have submitted anonymous testimonies of abuse.

title: Sexual abuse rises in Thailand during pandemic
text:
A street in Bangkok, Thailand. Police say that cases of child abuse increased by as much as 40 per cent last year

Cases of online sexual abuse of children in Thailand have risen dramatically as the pandemic leaves more and more potential victims at home unsupervised, bored and spending large amounts of time on their phones.

Police and child protection organisations say that cases of abuse, including the extracting of pornographic images from children, increased last year by as much as 40 per cent.

Sponsored

“The lockdown allows minors, usually aged between ten and 18, and who have a mobile phone, to be easily abused online,” said Boom Mosby of the Hug Project, which fights sexual abuse and human trafficking.

Perpetrators contact young people via social media sites under the guise of friendship and inveigle them into sending indecent photographs. They then use these to blackmail them into
summary:
A street in Bangkok, Thailand.
Police say that cases of child abuse increased by as much as 40 per cent last yearCases of online sexual abuse of children in Thailand have risen dramatically as the pandemic leaves more and more potential victims at home unsupervised, bored and spending large amounts of time on their phones.
Police and child protection organisations say that cases of abuse, including the extracting of pornographic images from children, increased last year by as much as 40 per cent.
Sponsored“The lockdown allows minors, usually aged between ten and 18, and who have a mobile phone, to be easily abused online,” said Boom Mosby of the Hug Project, which fights sexual abuse and human trafficking.
Perpetrators contact young people via social media sites under the guise of friendship and inveigle them into sending indecent photographs.

title: Calls for state inspection of private schools after abuse scandals
text:
Pupils protest this week at Highgate School in north London, which was the subject of a dossier containing 220 testimonies of peer-on-peer sexual harassment and rape

Private school inspections should be overhauled after a series of sexual abuse and harassment scandals, the chairman of the education select committee has said.

Robert Halfon made the comments in response to allegations of abuse across the private school sector. Highgate School, which was the subject of a dossier featuring 220 testimonies of peer-on-peer sexual harassment and rape, has appointed Dame Anne Rafferty, a former Court of Appeal judge, to lead an independent review. Meanwhile, Dulwich College was said to have threatened pupils with disciplinary action if they joined a planned protest yesterday after some students were reported to police over allegations of sexual harassment.

Sponsored

title: Crewe’s bid to shut down sex abuse apology from manager David Artell
text:
Crewe Alexandra yesterday appeared to take steps to suppress the reporting of an apology made by their manager David Artell to the victims of child sexual abuse at their club. A Crewe official told The Times that the club had intervened yesterday because their directors were “uncomfortable with the ‘sorry’ thing”.

A report published this week said Crewe could have done more to prevent sexual abuse carried out in the 1990s by their former coach Barry Bennell, who is serving a 30-year prison sentence for his crimes. In response, the club issued a carefully worded statement that did not apologise directly to survivors, instead saying sorry “if there were in fact any warning signs that ought to have led the club to do more”.

Sponsored

The
summary:
Crewe Alexandra yesterday appeared to take steps to suppress the reporting of an apology made by their manager David Artell to the victims of child sexual abuse at their club.
A Crewe official told The Times that the club had intervened yesterday because their directors were “uncomfortable with the ‘sorry’ thing”.
A report published this week said Crewe could have done more to prevent sexual abuse carried out in the 1990s by their former coach Barry Bennell, who is serving a 30-year prison sentence for his crimes.
In response, the club issued a carefully worded statement that did not apologise directly to survivors, instead saying sorry “if there were in fact any warning signs that ought to have led the club to do more”.

title: Political scientist Olivier Duhamel admits he sexually abused stepson Antoine Kouchner
text:
Olivier Duhamel, 70, acknowledged the truth of allegations in a book by his stepdaughter

A senior academic and powerbroker at the centre of a paedophile scandal that rocked the French establishment has admitted that he abused his stepson.

Olivier Duhamel, 70, acknowledged “with difficulty” the truth of allegations in a book by Camille Kouchner, his stepdaughter, that he had sexually abused her twin brother, Antoine, when he was a teenager, police said.

Sponsored

In January Kouchner’s book La familia grande caused a storm over the sexual mores of the powerful political and media class that emerged after the 1968 Paris student revolt. Thousands of people posted accounts on social media of their experiences of abuse.

Duhamel, a political scientist, did not address the claims but complained of “personal attacks” against him and resigned all his posts, including chairmanship
summary:
Olivier Duhamel, 70, acknowledged the truth of allegations in a book by his stepdaughterA senior academic and powerbroker at the centre of a paedophile scandal that rocked the French establishment has admitted that he abused his stepson.

title: Unfettered smartphone porn is fuelling abuse, say head teachers
text:
Former Haberdashers’ Girls pupils Sophie Max, left, and Philippa Lawford, say their time there was marred by sexual harassment and misogyny from boys at the next-door school

Children’s “unfettered access” to pornography on their phones and the film Fifty Shades of Grey are partly to blame for the crisis of sexual abuse at private schools, head teachers warn today.

Rose Hardy, headmistress of Haberdashers’ Aske’s School for Girls in Hertfordshire, and Gus Lock, headmaster of the neighbouring Haberdashers’ Aske’s Boys’ School, said children were able to watch porn “often depicting aggressive, violent and degrading acts against women [which] have played their part in the burgeoning crisis”.

Sponsored

The heads, who run two of the most academic private schools in Britain, said in a joint statement: “The schools are committed to the culture change required to play their part in tackling societal sexism, and are ready to have some uncomfortable conversations.

title: New law will finally give sports abuse victims protection
text:
English football was rocked by a child sexual abuse scandal five years ago when Barry Bennell, a former coach at Manchester City and Crewe Alexandra, was jailed for a total of 34 years at Liverpool and Chester crown courts for 50 counts of child sex abuse between 1979 and 1991.

The outcry resulted in the Sheldon review into sexual abuse of children in football, which this month published its report.

Sponsored

One of the report’s criticisms centred on a failure properly to respond to the repeated complaints about behaviour. Sheldon also said the FA was culpable of “institutional failure” in delaying the introduction of safeguards after 1995.

title: Schools ‘cover-up’ sexual abuse by pupils
text:
One of the country’s most senior police officers has said he believes that schools have covered up sexual offences to protect their reputations as a task force took charge of the surge in abuse complaints.

Chief Constable Simon Bailey told The Times that the outpouring of allegations was the education sector’s “MeToo” moment and that he feared a “culture of misogyny and sexual harassment” had not been challenged in some schools.

Sponsored

Bailey is the lead officer for Operation Hydrant, the national task force for child sexual abuse investigations in institutions. It will assess allegations of abuse in schools before they are given to individual forces to investigate, with a national hotline for abuse reports to be set up within 72 hours.

His comments come after
summary:

title: The Times view on allegations of sexual abuse at leading independent schools: Educating Equality
text:
The allegations of sexual abuse in schools have been likened to a “MeToo” moment in education GETTY IMAGES

Recalling his experience of Charterhouse, the poet Robert Graves wrote: “The opposite sex is despised and hated, treated as something obscene.” There is disturbing evidence that this still describes attitudes within independent schools in the 21st century. It is vital that schools are transparent and allow a full external investigation into allegations of sexual harassment of girls.

title: Ban on naming woman who killed child will remain, Court of Appeal rules
text:
The Court of Appeal ruled that the statute was “unequivocal” and if change was required that is a matter for the Oireachtas

The Court of Appeal has rejected an application by several media outlets to be allowed to name a woman who smothered her three-year-old child to death with a pillow.

The woman was acquitted of murdering her child by reason of insanity in October last year. Before her trial began two High Court judges ordered that the deceased child should not be identified and, as a consequence, the woman could not be named as to do so would identify the dead child.

title: Rebeccah Blum death: Gallery shuns art by murder suspect Saul Fletcher
text:
Rebeccah Blum was close to Saul Fletcher, an artist and friend of Brad Pitt

A piece of art by a British photographer who allegedly murdered a woman before killing himself has been removed from a Venice exhibition out of respect for the victim.

Investigators believe that Saul Fletcher, 52, killed Rebeccah Blum, the American curator who was his partner, in Berlin last July.

Sponsored

The Pinault Collection in Venice has taken down a large work that Fletcher created. The decision reflects a growing consensus that artists be held accountable for their crimes. The gallery said that the work was removed “out of respect for the memory of Rebeccah Blum” and “out of solidarity with the women victims of violence”.

Fletcher, who was born in Barton-upon-Humber, Lincolnshire, gained a reputation as a photographer in London then Berlin.

title: Murderer of backpacker Karen Aim in New Zealand may be freed
text:
Karen Aim was alive when she was found but died of brain injuries shortly afterwards

A man who murdered a Scottish backpacker and became the youngest person in the history of New Zealand to receive a life sentence may be granted parole this week.

Jahche Broughton was 14 when he beat Karen Aim, from Orkney, to death with a baseball bat in the North Island resort of Taupo as she was walking home after an evening out with friends. Ms Aim, 26, who had been on a working holiday, was alive when she was found but died of brain injuries shortly afterwards.

title: Midsomer Murders returns, as whimsical and wicked as ever
text:
Here’s a mystery for you. Which British TV show that isn’t a soap has been running for 24 years? And has been officially declared the UK’s biggest detective export? The answer is Midsomer Murders, the ITV crime drama in which bizarre killings — and oddball killers — lurk beneath the surface of the quaint and picturesque villages of this fictional English county.

The world loves Midsomer Murders. It sells in more than 200 territories (international sales go by territories, not countries): it’s big in Germany — Angela Merkel is a fan; Anglophiles in America lap it up; and they go crazy for it in Denmark, where apparently it’s more popular than The Killing ever was. summary:

title: Star female gamer, 19, ‘murdered by rival’
text:
Ingrid Oliveira Bueno da Silva, 19, is thought to have gone to the home of Guilherme Alves Costa, right, to play in a competition

A talented Brazilian female player in the male-dominated world of professional video gaming has been murdered by a fellow competitor.

The body of Ingrid Oliveira Bueno da Silva, 19, was found at the São Paulo home of Guilherme Alves Costa, 18. The two had played for rival teams in the game Call of Duty: Mobile. She is understood to have gone to Alves Costa’s house on Monday expecting to take part in a joint competition after making contact online last month.

Alves Costa was allegedly armed with a knife and repeatedly stabbed Ingrid. He uploaded gruesome images of the killing to social media, and fellow Brazilian gamers raised the alarm.

title: Sentence ‘too lenient’ for teenager who slashed woman’s throat on date
text:
The offender lured his victim to an isolated area in Dún Laoghaire where he tried to kill her

The Court of Appeal has found that the 11-year sentence for a teenager who attempted to murder a woman he met on a dating app was too lenient.

The court said that the element of planning and premeditation meant that “even as attempted murders go” the offence had to be seen as being at the high end of the spectrum.

Sponsored

The Director of Public Prosecutions had appealed, arguing that a review of the sentence imposed on the teenage boy after a five-year period was too early.

The now 17-year-old, who cannot be named because he is a minor, has been in custody since December 2017, when he lured Stephanie Ng to an isolated area at Sea Front, Queen’s Road, Dún Laoghaire.

title: PC Timothy Brehmer charged with woman’s murder
text:
Timothy Brehmer with his wife, left. He has been charged with the murder of Claire Parry, right, who died on Sunday morning after suffering a brain injury

A serving police officer has been charged with murdering a woman said to have been his lover of ten years in a village pub car park.

PC Timothy Brehmer, 41, is accused of strangling Claire Parry, an NHS nurse practitioner, outside the Horns Inn in West Parley, Dorset, on Saturday.

Sponsored

Mrs Parry, also 41, was found unconscious at the scene. She died on Sunday morning. A post-mortem examination showed she died from a brain injury caused by compression of the neck.

Mr Brehmer, who lives with his wife Martha, a detective, and their nine-year-old son in the New Forest, is said to have suffered self-inflicted injuries. He was also taken to hospital before being released and charged with the murder of Mrs Parry.

summary:
Timothy Brehmer with his wife, left.
PC Timothy Brehmer, 41, is accused of strangling Claire Parry, an NHS nurse practitioner, outside the Horns Inn in West Parley, Dorset, on Saturday.
A post-mortem examination showed she died from a brain injury caused by compression of the neck.

title: Italian female farmer who disappeared five years ago ‘was murdered and fed to pigs by mafia’
text:
Maria Chindamo vanished from her farm in southern Italy in 2016. Her car, found abandoned with the engine running, contained traces of her blood but her body has not been found

An Italian woman who disappeared five years ago was murdered and fed to pigs by an alleged drug trafficker with mafia ties, an informer has claimed.

Maria Chindamo, 43, a mother of three, vanished from her farm in Calabria in southern Italy in 2016 after refusing offers to buy her land made by her neighbour, Salvatore Ascone.

Sponsored

Her car, which was found abandoned with the engine running, contained traces of her blood and tufts of her hair but her body was never discovered.

Mr Ascone, who is standing trial accused of being a trafficker for the Calabrian ’NDrangheta mafia, was arrested in connection with her murder in 2019 but released for lack of evidence.

title: Why gardai think JoJo Dullard was murdered
text:
JoJo Dullard went missing in 1995 while hitchhiking home from Dublin to Callan in Co Kilkenny

Des McTiernan’s appeal to the public for information on the 1995 disappearance of JoJo Dullard was unexpectedly blunt. The 21-year-old Kilkenny woman, said the detective superintendent, had met her death through violent means and was no longer alive.

“We are satisfied that JoJo came to harm and we are classifying this investigation as a murder,” said McTiernan last Monday. It was the first time in almost 25 years that Dullard’s family had heard a senior garda say those words. Until now, the case had been classified as a missing persons inquiry.

title: Police arrest man after pregnant Jewish woman assaulted
text:
The victim, who is said to be 27-weeks pregnant, was taken to hospital for treatment for minor injuries following the assault last Thursday evening

A man has been arrested on suspicion of grievous bodily harm after a pregnant woman was assaulted in Stamford Hill, north London.

The man, aged in his late 50s, was arrested at a residential address in Haringey and is now in custody at an east London police station, the Metropolitan Police said.

Sponsored

Police were called shortly after 7pm last Thursday to an assault that had happened about 30 minutes earlier on Manor Road.

The victim, a 20-year-old woman who is said to be 27-weeks pregnant, told officers she had been approached from behind by the suspect, who put a pillow case over her head before assaulting her. She was taken to hospital for treatment for minor injuries following the assault last Thursday evening, the Metropolitan

title: Friend raped and murdered young woman after birthday celebration
text:
Wesley Streete attacked Keeley Bunker, who had trusted him to get her home

A man has been convicted of raping and murdering his childhood friend who had trusted him to walk her home.

Wesley Streete, 20, attacked and killed Keeley Bunker after she told a worried friend: “I’ve got Wes. Wes will walk me back, it’ll be fine.” She had been out celebrating her 20th birthday at a gig in Birmingham on September 19 last year before returning by taxi to Tamworth, Staffordshire.

Sponsored

Ms Bunker turned down the offer of staying at a friend’s house because she wanted her own bed and believed that Streete would get her home safely. However, he raped and murdered her before leaving her body in a stream in a park. She was found by her uncle on the day she was meant
summary:

Wesley Streete, 20, attacked and killed Keeley Bunker after she told a worried friend: “I’ve got Wes.
Wes will walk me back, it’ll be fine.” She had been out celebrating her 20th birthday at a gig in Birmingham on September 19 last year before returning by taxi to Tamworth, Staffordshire.

title: The best new thrillers for February 2021 — kidnap, murder, revenge and cold cases
text:
Following the traumatic events of the novel that first introduced her, The Fragility of Bodies, the Argentine investigative journalist Veronica Rosenthal takes off upcountry for a holiday. She falls in with two European girls and finds herself seduced by one of them. But at a party to which she brings the pair, they disappear and are later found murdered.

Sponsored

A black magic ritual is blamed. However, Veronica begins to uncover previous killings of local women dating back decades that have gone unpunished, as all the while she is dogged by an assassin bent on revenge. With its social concerns, The Foreign Girls is very much a literary novel rather than simply a thriller. It largely overcomes the difficulties of being translated from another language
summary:
Following the traumatic events of the novel that first introduced her, The Fragility of Bodies, the Argentine investigative journalist Veronica Rosenthal takes off upcountry for a holiday.
She falls in with two European girls and finds herself seduced by one of them.
But at a party to which she brings the pair, they disappear and are later found murdered.
However, Veronica begins to uncover previous killings of local women dating back decades that have gone unpunished, as all the while she is dogged by an assassin bent on revenge.
With its social concerns, The Foreign Girls is very much a literary novel rather than simply a thriller.

title: Father apologises to woman his teenage son tried kill
text:
The Court of Appeal was told the teenager had been suffering from “dark thoughts”

The father of a teenage boy who tried to murder a woman he met on a dating app has apologised to the victim for the “terrible actions” of his son.

The Court of Appeal also heard yesterday that the man regretted his son not being hospitalised or being given the correct medication at an earlier stage. The father said he wished he had not allowed his son to have such a high dose of antidepressants, which he felt may have induced the manic episode during which he attacked the victim.

Sponsored

The teenager will find out today whether his sentence will be increased following an “undue leniency” appeal by prosecutors.

The boy, now 17, who cannot be named, was originally sentenced by Mr Justice Michael White
summary:

title: Peter Sutcliffe murdered 13 women: I was nearly one of them
text:
The women murdered by Peter Sutcliffe were left to right, top row: Jean Jordan, Vera Millward, Helen Rytka, Yvonne Pearson and Emily Jackson. Second row with Sutcliffe in the middle: Josephine Whitaker, Irene Richardson and Marguerite Walls. Third row: Barbara Leach, Patricia Atkinson, Jayne McDonald, Wilma McCann and Jacqueline Hill

The Yorkshire winter of 1980 was a harsh one. Women could be seen rushing home at the end of the day, wrapped in warm coats and trying to get back before it turned dark. Some clutched bunches of keys as protection, many avoided shortcuts down narrow lanes or through parks and almost everyone stuck to busy roads.

A serial killer was on the loose and had already murdered 11 women by the time I moved to Leeds from Darlington in November 1979, aged 17. Four of the women had been killed in Leeds and my mum was worried sick. It turns out that she had good reason to be.

title: This month’s best crime novels — ghastly revelations in a hurricane and murder in the Blitz
text:
The 20th thriller featuring the forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan begins with a hurricane — which beaches a container holding two corpses showing signs of execution — and ends with a whirlwind of hectic action and ghastly revelations in the Carolinas and Canada. Tempe, you see, also works in Montreal where her longtime squeeze, the ex-cop Andrew Ryan, lives: “Am I the most talented and beguiling man you’ve ever laid eyes on?” The humour — also shared in Bones, the TV series based on the character — is vital to offset the litany of horrors that Tempe uncovers as she investigates death masks, vaccines and a bacterial pathogen (Capnocytophaga canimorsus) found in the saliva of healthy cats and dogs: “Online images of mottled

Sponsored

title: Woman tasered and arrested after two men die at house
text:
Police were called to a disturbance at the house at about 4.30am yesterday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of murder after two men died at a house in east London.

The 28-year-old suspect was tasered by the police who had been called to a disturbance at the semi-detached house in Ilford at 4.30am yesterday.

Sponsored

Inamul Hussain, 32, a neighbour, said he called the police after hearing a woman screaming at the house.

“I saw them taser her, she had blood on her. I heard police say, ‘Put the knife down,’” he said. “She was screaming something about her husband but it was quite broken, I think they’re Polish. Several men and several women live there, they are always partying and drinking.”

title: Trans murderer Sophie Eastwood ‘would be out of jail already if she was a man’
text:
Sophie Eastwood has been living as a woman behind bars for more than three years

A murderer is to take legal action against the Scottish prison service after claiming that she has been discriminated against because she is transgender.

Sophie Eastwood, 35, who is serving a life sentence for killing a fellow inmate, began her prison sentence as a man but has been living as a woman behind bars for more than three years and is in a wing at Polmont prison for female offenders. She believes that had she continued to live as a man, she would have been freed already and is now instructing a lawyer to fight her case to accelerate her release.

title: Newham murder accused ‘kept woman’s body in freezer for three years’
text:
Mihrican Mustafa was allegedly murdered, along with Henriett Szucs, by Zahid Younis

One of two vulnerable women whose battered bodies were found stuffed in a freezer is believed to have been there for three years, a court heard yesterday.

Henriett Szucs disappeared after moving in with her alleged killer at the house in Newham, east London, where her body was found.

Sponsored

Zahid Younis, 36, is accused of murdering her in August 2016 before killing Mihrican Mustafa in May 2018.

Both women, who struggled with drug addiction and spells of homelessness, would have been in their thirties.

Police officers searching for the defendant discovered the corpses in the small, locked chest freezer at his house last April, Southwark crown court was told this afternoon. He denies two charges of murder.

title: Libby Squire murder: butcher with history of sex crimes found guilty
text:
Libby Squire was attacked by Pawel Relowicz in Hull in February 2019

A married butcher who used his family car to stalk the streets for young women after dark has been convicted of raping and murdering a student on a night out.

Pawel Relowicz, 26, left his wife and two young sons sleeping at home and scoured Hull until he saw Libby Squire, 21, vulnerable and alone after a night drinking with friends in February 2019.

Sponsored

Relowicz, a voyeuristic and depraved sex offender obsessed with pornography, picked up Squire and raped her in a playing field before dumping her, dead or dying in the Humber, Sheffield crown court was told.

title: Murder trial hears of 13 injuries on wife’s body
text:
A woman allegedly drowned by her husband so that he could claim millions in life insurance suffered 13 injuries to her head and body, a court heard.

Donald McPherson, 47, is accused of murdering his wife Paula Leeson in the swimming pool of a holiday cottage in a remote part of western Denmark.

Sponsored

McPherson denies targeting his wife, 47, in what prosecutors consider to be a “sinister pre-planned killing” to claim £3.5 million in life insurance after forging her will and taking out seven insurance policies on her life.

He told Danish police that he woke up to find his wife fully clothed, face down in the pool and that he struggled to pull her out.

title: Pat Quirke’s obsession with woman was key to murder trial, court told
text:
Pat Quirke’s lawyers say his trial was made unfair by garda comments about his private life

Evidence of Pat Quirke’s bad behaviour towards Mary Lowry was necessary to set the context for the murder of Bobby Ryan, state lawyers have said.

Lawyers acting for Quirke in the appeal against his murder conviction have said that his trial was rendered unfair by evidence showing him taking underwear off Ms Lowry’s washing line and suggestions from gardaí that he had “cash on demand and sex on demand”. Bernard Condon, SC, for Quirke, has complained that the prosecution relied on “tittle tattle” and overemphasized the importance of Ms Lowry’s claims that Quirke was “controlling”.

Sponsored

Yesterday Michael Bowman, SC, for the state, said that Quirke was entangled both financially and intimately with Ms Lowry in what she saw as a “seedy” relationship compromised by “deceit

title: Strangled woman’s ‘trusting nature led to her murder’
text:
Mary McLaughlin was found dead at her home in Glasgow in 1984

The “friendly and trusting” nature of a woman strangled in her own flat ultimately brought about her death, a court has been told.

Mary McLaughlin, 58, a mother of 11, was found dead at her home in Partick in Glasgow’s west end in October 1984 after enjoying a night out at bars playing dominoes, the High Court in Glasgow has heard.

Graham McGill, 59, denies murdering her and fastening a belt from her dressing gown around her throat with intent to rape on September 26 or 27 of that year.

title: Woman who staged murder victim’s suicide sent back to prison
text:
The Central Criminal Court was told that Janice Brady was suspected of repeated shoplifting and had moved without telling her probation officer

A woman serving a suspended sentence for staging a murder victim’s suicide has been sent back to jail having been charged with more than 30 new offences.

Janice Brady, 30, moved into a B&B in Dublin without informing her probation officer in March and was warned that she would be sent back to jail if she did not keep in contact with the probation service. A warrant was issued for her arrest this month when she broke the terms of her probation again and the Central Criminal Court was told that she had been charged with 32 more offences, mostly shoplifting in Dublin.

title: Daughters of Night by Laura Shepherd-Robinson audiobook review – murder, vengeance and justice abound
text:
Forget Georgette Heyer’s arch wit and Julia Quinn’s randy Bridgerton. Here’s an altogether murkier take on Regency shenanigans. Daughters of Night begins at a cracking pace with the murder of a high-class doxy in the Vauxhall Pleasure Gardens and never lets up.

Recall Harry Corsham and thief-taker Peregrine Child from Laura Shepherd-Robinson’s excellent Blood & Sugar? Now it is Harry’s wife, Lady Caroline Corsham who employs Child in her quest for justice for a woman she had good reason to like and trust.

Sponsored

The powers that be and the rest of the beau monde do their utmost to discourage them, but Caro persists in a perilous exploration of the darkest corners of London high life to discover the fates of Lucy Loveless,

Here’s an altogether murkier take on Regency shenanigans.

title: Policeman appears in court charged with kidnap and murder of Sarah Everard
text:
Sarah Everard vanished on March 3 as she walked home from a friend’s house in south London

A police officer will stand trial at the Old Bailey over the kidnap and murder of Sarah Everard.

Wayne Couzens, 48, a diplomatic protection officer with the Metropolitan Police, appeared in the dock at Westminster magistrates’ court in central London for the first time today after being charged with the abduction and killing of the 33-year-old marketing executive on the night of March 3.

Sponsored

Everard was walking home from a friend’s flat in Clapham, south London, when she disappeared, triggering one of the biggest manhunts of recent times.

Police confirm body found in Kent woodland identified as Sarah Everard

Her body was discovered in a builder’s bag in woodland near Ashford in Kent last Wednesday. She is believed to have been identified through her dental records.

title: Suspect arrested over rape and murder of British safari lodge owner Christine Robinson
text:
Christine Robinson and her husband, Daniel. Andrew Ndlovu, right, is suspected of murdering her

The prime suspect in the rape and murder of a British woman in South Africa was arrested yesterday after six years of detective work by her niece.

Christine Robinson, 59, a retired teacher, was allegedly attacked by a gardener at the 125 acre Rra-Ditau safari lodge she ran alone after the death of her husband.

Sponsored

Mrs Robinson, from Liverpool, had put up a struggle against her attacker, who raped her then tried to strangle her before stabbing her to death in her bedroom in July 2014.

The prime suspect Andrew Ndlovu, then 24, had vanished and was thought to have returned to his native Zimbabwe and then come back to South Africa.

title: Film reviews: Promising Young Woman; The Reckoning
text:
Promising Young Woman

Sky and Now

Emerald Fennell, 15, 113min

★★★

The Reckoning

Amazon et al

Neil Marshall, 15, 100min

★

Sponsored

Quentin Tarantino has a great riff on what he calls “uptight” action movies — revenge movies that don’t quite have the stomach for revenge, like the fight on the boat at the end of Patriot Games, in which Sean Bean helpfully falls on an anchor to save Harrison Ford the job of killing him. “The minute you kill your bad guy by having him fall on something, you should go to movie jail,” Tarantino said. “You’ve broken the law of good cinema.”

The writer-director Emerald Fennell’s rape-revenge movie Promising Young Woman offers a slightly different variant: instead of outsourcing the act of revenge

title: Murder victim’s father loses faith in police inquiry
text:
The father of a woman who was murdered along with her sister has lost faith in police investigating the case amid claims that officers posed for selfies next to their bodies.

Bibaa Henry, 46, and her half-sister Nicole Smallman, 27, were stabbed to death this month as they celebrated Bibaa’s birthday.

Sponsored

Two police officers sent to guard the crime scene in Wembley, northwest London, allegedly took photos of themselves next to the women’s bodies and shared them on a WhatsApp group that included members of the public. The officers have been arrested.

Bibaa’s father Herman Henry, a former boxer, said he was “sickened” by the allegations and had lost faith in the ability of the Metropolitan police to find the killer. Asked whether he felt
summary:
The father of a woman who was murdered along with her sister has lost faith in police investigating the case amid claims that officers posed for selfies next to their bodies.
Bibaa Henry, 46, and her half-sister Nicole Smallman, 27, were stabbed to death this month as they celebrated Bibaa’s birthday.
SponsoredTwo police officers sent to guard the crime scene in Wembley, northwest London, allegedly took photos of themselves next to the women’s bodies and shared them on a WhatsApp group that included members of the public.
The officers have been arrested.
Bibaa’s father Herman Henry, a former boxer, said he was “sickened” by the allegations and had lost faith in the ability of the Metropolitan police to find the killer.

title: Iranian woman hanged after dying of heart attack
text:
Zahra Ismaili, left, was convicted of killing her husband, who was an official of the Iranian intelligence ministry

A woman who died of a heart attack just as she was about to be executed for murder in Iran was hanged anyway as a concession to her alleged victim’s mother, her lawyer has claimed.

The woman, named as Zahra Ismaili, had been convicted of killing her husband, although Omid Moradi, her lawyer, said that he was abusive and she had acted to defend herself and her daughter.

Sponsored

Moradi posted online a description of his client’s death, saying she was waiting in line behind 16 men and was forced to watch as they were hanged.

Before her turn came she collapsed with an apparent heart attack and appeared to be dead. However, according to Moradi, she was hanged anyway so that her husband’s mother could

Mary McLaughlin, 58, was found dead at her home in Partick in Glasgow’s west end in October 1984 after spending a night out at bars playing dominoes, the High Court in Glasgow has been told.
SponsoredGraham McGill, 59, denies murdering her and tightly fastening a belt from her dressing gown around her throat with intent to rape on September 26 or 27.
DNA samples on her dress, the dressing gown cord, a cigarette end, and a black bra found near her flat are all attributable to McGill, the court was told.

title: Woman arrested on suspicion of murdering ten-year-old boy in Acton
text:
The boy’s body was found shortly after the woman walked into a police station

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of murdering a ten-year-old boy after handing herself over to police in the early hours of yesterday.

Olga Freeman, who is in her 40s, walked into a police station at 2.30am on Sunday to speak to officers, who a short time later found the body of the boy at a home in Acton, west London. She will appear at Uxbridge magistrates’ court today.

Sponsored

Officers in protective forensic suits, gloves and masks were seen entering the property in a street made up of large semi-detached houses and flats.

Scotland Yard said the woman was known to the boy but could not confirm the relationship between the two. Officers believe they know his identity but are awaiting formal identification. His
summary:
